that an academic proletariat was being nurtured here. The effect of the discussions that ensued and the countermeasures that were taken was that universities and THs largely remained institutions for the training of elites
(Table 51).
It was difficult enough for students with a lower-class background to withstand the psychological, financial, and academic pressures of the high school
system up to the Abiturzeugnis, the exit certificate. They would encounter
further obstacles if they decided to go to college. The costs alone would weigh
heavily upon them, as state aid was difficult to come by. In 1887/88 the number of scholarship recipients had been 20 percent. By 1911, this figure had
declined to around 10 percent. In short, the tertiary sector offered opportunities at most for some upwardly mobile students from the lower middle class,
and virtually none for working-class children. Among the fathers of Bonn
University students between 1865 and 1914, some 19.2 percent were higher
civil servants, and 8.3 percent were professionals (Table 53). A further 24.4
percent originated from the propertied middle class. On the other hand, 48.7
percent were sons of white-collar employees, artisans, farmers, and lowranking officials. A mere 0.2 percent had lower-class backgrounds. In 1905,
some 54.2 percent of the students in Baden had fathers from the lower middle class. In Prussia this figure was as high as 60 percent in 1911/12. Such
percentages should not be underestimated when it comes to assessing rates
of mobility in Wilhelmine Germany. This was not a completely stagnant society. But it is equally important to note the very small share of lower-class
students. Barriers existed here that proved insurmountable for all but a few.
We shall turn in a moment to other formal and informal obstacles (such as
social and political prejudices and the practice of giving retired noncommis47

Society

sioned officers preferential treatment in the lower civil service) that faced upwardly mobile people, especially from the lower classes. First, however, we
will investigate patterns of upward and downward mobility at the bottom of
the social scale, now that a better idea has been gained of movement higher
on the scale. In this respect we are relatively well informed about a few industrial towns. Thus, David Crew has followed the changes in occupational
mobility among workers and employees in Bochum between 1880 and 1890
(Table 43).13 His statistics showed that, of those holding unskilled and semiskilled jobs in 1880, some 87.1 percent still worked in the same category ten
years later. A mere 6.9 percent had been able to climb to the position of
skilled laborer or craftsman. Although immobility among skilled men was
lower during the same period (78.8 percent), it would be a mistake to assume
that they did better; for of the remaining 21.4 percent some 11.3 percent had
been forced to move down the social scale. By the turn of the century the picture had improved somewhat for both unskilled/semiskilled and for skilled
men. Among the former some 21 percent had achieved skilled positions;
among the latter, 23.6 percent had become white-collar workers. But these
figures must be juxtaposed with a share of 15.5 percent among skilled workers who had moved down to lower positions.
Studies considering the national picture have arrived at somewhat lower
figures than Crew’s. For reasons that will be discussed later, mobility among
working-class women was even more stagnant, and their dispiriting experience must be included when we come to consider the basic character of German society. As far as social mobility was concerned, this society was
relatively immobile at the top and bottom of the scale. There was a good deal
of upward mobility within the broad spectrum of the middle class. Even if intergenerational mobility is taken into account, workers mostly succeeded in
achieving no more than small steps upward within the larger bracket of the
working class.14 What remained possible for them was horizontal mobility,
moving into other occupations in the hope of improving their material situation in times when labor was scarce and companies were competing for hardworking personnel. Most unskilled laborers, and the many women among
them, did not even have this opportunity. In the end, only a very special kind
of upward mobility existed at the bottom of the pyramid, if one includes Germany’s rural areas in the equation. In the context of the huge migrations to
the cities, it has already been mentioned that many land laborers from the
east, as well as short-distance migrants, left their jobs in agriculture because
they saw better prospects in industry. For many, perhaps after a difficult initial period, the move brought benefits, and in this sense the migratory phenomenon may also be discussed under the rubric of social mobility. It was a
mobility that occurred within the lower class, but not much beyond it. We
shall examine in a moment what the virtual vertical immobility meant for the
48

Social Stratification and Inequalities

“exterior life situation and the inner existential predicament” of the industrial
working class, male and female.15
C. Marriage Patterns
The continuing importance of the link between town and country, which
commuters and short-distance migrants in particular never severed, is also
reflected in what has been called connubial mobility. Like occupational mobility, marriage patterns provide a deep insight into the degrees of openness
of a particular society, especially at the upper and the lower end of the social
pyramid. The hour of truth has arrived whenever a daughter of “good” family background wants to marry the upstart. Unfortunately, we are much less
well informed about questions of connubial mobility than we are about occupational mobility.
Reliable figures exist on the number of married people as a percentage of
the total population. In 1871 some 51 percent of all Germans over the age of
15 were married. By 1910 this figure had risen to 54 percent, an increase that
has occasionally been taken as a manifestation of improved life chances,
given that never getting married or having no family was another characteristic of the lower strata of society that changed slowly.
There are a few statistics relating to marriage patterns among the lower
strata in the regions of Bielefeld in Westphalia and Esslingen in Württemberg. The figures for the latter, a small industrial town in the southwest, indicate relative openness. Two-thirds of the local textile and metal workers
there married daughters of craftsmen and, to a smaller degree, of peasants.
In many cases occupational upward mobility went hand in hand with connubial mobility. In the textile town of Bielefeld, on the other hand, no more
than 4 percent of the unskilled laborers and 9 percent of the skilled men succeeded in marrying into artisanal families. Somewhat higher was the share of
unskilled and skilled workers who found a peasant daughter from the region,
usually without inheritance rights. These figures must be compared with
those 48 percent of the unskilled laborers and 27 percent of the skilled men
who married into land laborers’ families. Similarly high (48 percent) was the
share of skilled workers in Bielefeld who married working-class women.
Among the unskilled, the figure was 35 percent. As far as the latter group is
concerned, this share nearly doubled by 1910, while it rose to 59 percent
among the skilled men. In the meantime marriages with daughters of land
laborers declined to 18 percent among unskilled laborers and to 11 percent
among the skilled ones. Around the turn of the century, some 80 percent of
the industrial workers in Chemnitz in Saxony married their female counterparts, and another 7 percent married local domestic servants. All these figures
seem to indicate that, even taking account of the many variations in these patterns, industrial workers increasingly married among themselves.
49

Society

Whereas statistics on connubial mobility for the lower middle class and
middle class remain rudimentary, there are interesting data on very wealthy
businessmen. Keeping the assets together was an important consideration
among larger family enterprises and among private bankers, leading to marriage circles that were often closed in social and denominational terms. Thus,
over 50 percent of entrepreneurs’ wives were daughters of other businessmen, and another third came from very wealthy entrepreneurial families.
Around 10 percent hailed from the upper middle-class groups of higher civil
servants and professionals. Marriage links with noble families were rare.
Although there are signs that mobility through marriage was more frequent than it was in the lower classes, horizontal patterns predominated. Even
if the desire to marry upward was strong, parental pressure and the well-worn
argument that the prospective husband would not “fit into the family” led to
the cancellation of many wedding plans. Conversely, fewer barriers apparently existed against a daughter-in-law who did not quite come from the
“right” social background. The danger of “mismatches,” whether on the male
or the female side, was of course often avoided because parents saw to it that
the social life of eligible children took place in the “proper” circles. In other
words, the opportunities to meet the “wrong” prospective bride or bridegroom were quite limited.
Restrictions were even greater at the top of the social pyramid that, in
monarchical Germany, was occupied by the nobility and the courts of the
federal states. Here being of equal birth was actually a “juridical category”
and not just a social requirement, and as such had an “extraordinary influence upon the objective social position and the social self-image,” especially
of the ruling houses and the high nobility.16 To be sure, their family laws
were quite varied and in most cases open to marriage links with the lesser nobility. Exceptions were even possible in the case of marriages with women of
bourgeois background, and such exceptions included elevation to the nobility. The lesser nobility was not so strict in regard to equal birth as a sine qua
non. In these circles connubial mobility was more likely to encounter social,
rather than legal, obstacles. The ancient nobility felt superior to the new nobility or, even more so, to members of the upper bourgeoisie who had been
ennobled.
On the other hand, this hauteur was not so powerful as to prevent “social
linkages or even the blending of aristocratic groups with parts of the upper
bourgeoisie.”17 Thus it happened from time to time that close family alliances
were forged among the upper strata that gave the nobility access to bourgeois
wealth and, in turn, provided the upper bourgeoisie with the prestige of having become part of the “first estate.” Still, the important point to remember is
that such marriage links remained the exception. Marriage “into non-noble
circles was generally regarded with displeasure, unless they were represented
50

Social Stratification and Inequalities

by non-noble or recently ennobled higher civil service families and, depending on the status of the bride, it could mean the end of an officer’s career.”18
If it was a marriage for the money of a non-noble heiress, such a match was
“excused after the raising of many eyebrows.” No such excuses were accepted if an officer wanted to marry into a Jewish family. Ultimately, then,
only “a relatively small stratum of the upper bourgeoisie” fostered relations
with “parts of the nobility.”
D. Life Expectancy and Health
In terms of population growth in the Kaiserreich, it has already been noted
that mortality rates declined noticeably after the turn of the century. The birth
rate also declined, but not as dramatically as the mortality rate, and thus the
population continued to grow. So far only averages have been mentioned. We
must now ask about the health of different social groups and about inequalities in the face of illness and death. Infant mortality (i.e., deaths within the
first twelve months of life) provided particularly telling illustrations showing
that the averages veiled considerable inequalities (Table 61). Various fluctuations notwithstanding, until the turn of the century the infant mortality rate
was over 30 percent among the often illegitimate babies of domestic servants. It was 22 to 24 percent among unskilled workers, and 14 to 17 percent
among the self-employed, white-collar employees, and civil servants. Disregarding a brief hiccup in 1911, infant mortality declined tangibly and across
the board after 1900. Yet chances of survival within the first twelve months
for a baby born to a civil service family remained three times higher than for
a child of a domestic servant and twice as high as for the infants of unskilled
laborers. The rates were also lower for skilled workers so that a dividing line
arose that, for once, put the latter into a category closer to the middle class.
Due to these developments, average mortality rates came down between
1876 and 1913 by 7.7 percent for men and 6.2 percent for women. If these
averages are broken down by age and region, it becomes clear that Prussian
city-dwellers from the ages of 10 to 15, as well as those from 20 to 25, remained below the average (Table 60). However, for Prussian city-dwellers
over the age of 30, the rate declined more slowly than the average for the
whole of that state. This has led Reinhard Spree to assume that the latter groups
had begun to suffer from a higher incidence of illness, weaker immune systems, and more generally from getting worn out by long hours of hard work,
all of which reduced their life expectancy.19 Since many of them were prone
to fall ill with particular diseases and in some cases even to die from them, it
appears that it was not just the life chances of infants that depended on the
stratum to which an individual belonged. Men and women over 30 who
worked in the industrial centers of Prussia were similarly subject to this rule.
The spread of tuberculosis (TB) is the most striking example on this score.
51

Society

According to rough estimates, 600,000 to 1 million Germans suffered from
TB of the lungs before World War I. In many cases the illness was fatal. Reich
statistics show that in 1887 some 44 percent of all deaths were due to nine
types of diseases, among which the share of TB was 14 percent. Another 11 percent died of acute infections of the respiratory tract, followed by deaths due
to diseases to the digestive tract (9 percent). Until 1904 the share of these
three diseases even rose by another 3 percent to 37 percent. In 1913 the share
of TB and other fatal diseases of the respiratory tract still stood at 33 percent.
More importantly, that these were diseases of the industrial lower classes is
demonstrated by the fact that the death rate was higher in the cities than in
rural areas and that white-collar employees, civil servants, and the self-employed were less affected by them than unskilled workers. Successes in the
treatment of TB, which were achieved before 1914, did little to change the
ratios. By 1913 the number of patients, it is true, had risen to 50,000, and the
sums spent on their treatment had reached 16 to 18 million marks. But those
who participated in these programs comprised at most a mere 8 percent of all
those who should have been treated, and the most needy were presumably
among the other 92 percent.
Furthermore it would be a mistake to deduce that, once TB could be
treated, the decline in the overall mortality rate was the result of more knowledgeable doctors and improved medical provisions. Although, disregarding
wide regional discrepancies (Tables 69–70), the share of physicians per
100,000 population increased from 35 in 1885 to 51 in 1913, and although
the number of hospital beds grew by 250 percent, it is widely accepted today
that the decline in mortality was more decisively influenced by nonmedical
factors. Among them were changes in nutritional standards, the quantity and
quality of the daily diet (especially with respect to drinking water and fresh
milk), better personal hygiene, and housing conditions. These areas also witnessed tangible improvements over time, as will be seen below. However,
their effectiveness, too, was related to the system of social stratification, and,
as in the case of health, illness, and death, they must be included in our account in order to gain a better understanding of prevalent patterns of social
inequality in the German Empire.
E. Nutrition
As has been shown on the basis of statistics for the eastern provinces of Prussia, there exists a fairly close connection between life expectancy, health, and
proper nutrition.20 Thanks to the general rise in real incomes and living standards in Imperial Germany, many more families could afford higher quality
food and drink. But again, and given the large income differentials, there existed major differences in this respect. The improvement of the transport system had—as we have seen—resulted in a wider availability of fresh fruit and
52

Social Stratification and Inequalities

vegetables, also in the urban centers. But such produce was expensive, as was
meat and many imported foods (Kolonialwaren). Only the more prosperous
and wealthy strata could actually afford these goods on a regular basis. To be
sure, if the per capita consumption of meat grew from an annual 25 kilograms
to 51 kilograms between 1870 and 1910 and that of sugar from 6 kilograms
to 18 kilograms, the lower classes, too, had a share in these increases (Table
20). And yet, the differences in food consumption between them and the middle and upper classes were very tangible. Contemporary cookbooks tell us
part of this story. Above all, the biggest per capita increases were in the consumption of potatoes and bread flour.
This means that for many working-class households the greatest nutritional improvement was that they had enough food to put on the dinner table.
The decline in the number of children also exerted a favorable influence. Civil
servants and white-collar employees had begun to limit their family sizes to
an average of three children even before 1905; by 1909, their average family
size had dropped to just over two children (Table 64). At this time the average in families whose members worked in agriculture and mining, for example, was still as high as five children. But lower-class persons who married
in 1910 would already have at least one child less. Higher real wages and
smaller families certainly helped to create a situation where, as had often
been the case before, the wife no longer had to eat the scraps after she had
just about managed to serve enough food for her husband and their children,
and enough food usually meant sufficiently large quantities. Working-class
meals were also rich in calories, and this was rarely the most nutritious diet.
At a time when the workday was still 10 to 12 hours, six days a week (Table
15), meals frequently contained animal fats, but few vitamins and minerals.
Thus up to 90 percent of the energy intake in lower-class families consisted
of potatoes, bread, pastries, and animal fats.
Walther Hoffmann’s calculations provide a rough guide to the development of food consumption in Germany.21 Up to 1874 the average intake of
calories was around 90 percent of the daily requirement. Between 1875 and
1879 the German population reached the 100-percent level. There was a renewed drop to 95 percent during the 1880s, but from the 1890s onward the
daily intake finally surpassed the daily requirement for good, at least until
World War I. Indeed, just before 1914 it was close to the 120-percent mark.
Looking at the consumption of specific food items provides another indication of the general improvement in nutritional standards. Thus it appears that
fewer potatoes and more sugar were consumed. Wheat consumption increased,
while rye consumption stagnated. Meat, though primarily reserved for the
wealthier strata, increasingly appeared on the tables of the lower classes as
well. The per capita consumption of pork quadrupled between 1850 and 1910,
constituting 60 percent of meat consumption, if sausages are included. It is
53

Society

probable that working-class families had meat once or twice per week, but it
was rarely the more expensive cuts. The consumption of cabbage and root
vegetables also saw an increase, and by 1914 some 1 million units of canned
food were produced in some thirty-two factories in the Reich. Fresh fruit remained a luxury for the lower classes, although the acreage for growing it
doubled between 1878 and 1898.
If consumption of all these items fluctuated, it was not only because of
varying harvest levels and prices, but also because of developments in income and the labor markets. As we have seen, periods of increased unemployment and short-time work continued after the “Great Depression,” and
they usually hit the lower classes hardest. As late as 1907, some 80 percent
of the private consumption of a working-class household was taken up by the
necessities (food, clothing, rent, and heating). The remaining 20 percent was
divided between purchases of household goods (6.1 percent), personal hygiene
(2.8 percent), education and entertainment (5.9 percent), and miscellaneous
expenditures (2.0 percent). The percentages that J.S. Roberts has calculated
largely tally with these figures, but his research is additionally interesting for
its comparisons with the household budgets of civil servants and teachers
(Table 67).22 Thus, the 522 working-class families of his sample spent 80.6 percent of their annual income on food, clothing, rent, and heating, leaving 19.4
percent for the rest. By contrast, the respective averages for his 218 middleclass families were 72 percent and 28 percent. This meant that working-class
families had little room for maneuver, if struck by serious illness or unemployment. Inevitably, nutritional standards also suffered in such times of crisis. This is when belts had to be tightened, often at the expense of the health
of the family, and of the mother in particular, who would in most cases come
last.
A seemingly contradictory connection between infant mortality and breastfeeding habits demonstrates, however, how difficult it is to make a straight
connection between life expectancy and nutrition. According to the statistics,
mortality rates for infants who were not breastfed by their mothers increased
by 300 percent. At first sight, this nutritional factor might explain the abovementioned high mortality rates for lower-class children (Table 61). The complicating factor is that working-class children were apparently more frequently
breastfed than infants in the upper strata (Table 63). Their life chances were
increased by the better general care and attention they received, though not
by as much as might have been had the babies been breastfed. In other words,
upper-class infants became victims of deeply ingrained cultural traditions, so
that infant mortality rates here moved against the general trend and remained
higher because of an ignorance about the benefits of breastfeeding. Conversely, cultural traditions in this case inadvertently worked to the advantage
of lower-class infants. Once the benefits of breastfeeding had been advertised
54

Social Stratification and Inequalities

more widely, the rates for upper-class infants began to decline more steeply.
What is not included in the undoubtedly welcome discovery of the benefits
of breastfeeding is the question of its effect on the health of lower-class
mothers. It may be surmised that, if their health was often poor, this was not
just because of more frequent pregnancies and of standing back at dinnertime, but also because breastfeeding was a drain on their bodies.
F. Housing
However indicative the structure and changes in the nutritional standards of the
German population may be for gauging social inequalities, studying housing
patterns is no less instructive. Here, too, the question arises of what were the
dividing lines that may also tell us something about the basic principles along
which the German Empire was organized.
The huge population movements from the countryside to towns and cities
confronted local governments and the construction industry with unprecedented challenges.23 Two major problems were the supply of drinking water
and the building of sewage systems. A greater understanding of the causes of
epidemic diseases such as cholera and typhus increased pressures on town
planning departments to make adequate provisions. The massive outbreak of
cholera in Hamburg in 1892 had once more raised the importance of establishing a modern infrastructure. Accordingly, quite a lot was already being
done. By 1895, approximately 87 percent of all towns with more than 10,000
inhabitants had a central water supply (Table 66). For small towns (with 5,000
to 10,000 inhabitants), the figure stood at 62 percent, with communities of
2,000 to 5,000 inhabitants trailing far behind at 38 percent. The 1890s also
saw a considerable rise in the number of water works, although around 1900
only 52 percent of all towns were connected to such works. The regional differences are even more striking. Non-Prussian states made remarkable strides;
meanwhile in Prussia, the largest federal state, some 60 percent of the population continued to depend on tanks and pumps.
With regard to sewage systems, most towns did develop active construction programs before 1914. Nevertheless, barely more than 66.5 percent of
the Prussian population living in communities of over 2,000 was linked to
such a system. As with the water supply, the cities’ sewage systems were by
and large better than in the rest of the country. These shares mirrored inequalities that affected different strata—for example, lords and smallholders—in
the same way and cannot easily be disaggregated. It is another matter when
we come to examining the proliferation of flush toilets. Certainly with regards
to Berlin, about which we have the best information, it is possible to make a
strong connection between the quality of housing in different parts of the city,
the number of toilets, and mortality rates (although the latter, as has been
noted, also depended on other factors). Since a high correlation also existed
55

Society

between districts with a large number of inhabitants per heatable room and
the number of communal toilets halfway down the stairwell of an apartment
bloc, the question of residential culture also comes into play.
The size of a family’s accommodation was closely connected to its purchasing power. In agriculture no major changes occurred in this respect. The
owners of large estates continued to live in their often spacious homes, many
of which had been built or extended in better times. Those among them who
were not satisfied with their seclusion in the countryside, who enjoyed the alternative of an urban lifestyle and perhaps even had contacts at the court of
their state, would acquire a town residence if they could afford it. Peasants
lived in a wide variety of houses, ranging from the well-equipped Gutshaus
to the hovel that had no more than one small room. Many of these hovels did
not even contain the most important household goods. Wealthier peasants, on
the other hand, took pride in using the interiors of their noble neighbors’
homes or those of town residences as their model when it came to selecting
furniture and draperies. In many farm houses in Central Europe, whether
large or small, animals lived under the same roof with the humans. If the
family could afford servants, they would be put up in small rooms next to or
above the stables. Many land laborers also lived on the fringes of estates in
hovels that often had a small vegetable plot in the back.
As for urban dwelling, it has already been mentioned in connection with
the question of wealth and income that many prosperous burghers built their
often ostentatious villas in the suburbs of the large cities. Closer to the center, Mietspaläste (“rental palaces”) were built, offering prestigious accommodation for members of the upper bourgeoisie, for professors and higher
civil servants who could not, or did not want to, buy property. These apartments had salons, dining rooms, and libraries. Bedrooms and rooms for the
children and domestic servants would be at the end of a long corridor. Balconies and staircases were also lavishly laid out, pandering to the representation needs of the residents. Of course, owning one’s own home remained
an aim that an increasing number of people were able to realize for themselves. But for millions of others it remained but an unattainable dream.
From the residential “palaces” downward many types of apartments could
be found. At the bottom of the scale ranked those tiny one- or two-room spaces
into which the so-called Mietskasernen (or “rental barracks”) were divided.
These houses had narrow stairwells, dark backyards, and “light shafts.” In
1871, there existed close to 14,500 of such blocks, half of which contained 1
to 10 separate apartments; a similar number had between 11 and 50. Fortynine blocks had been built containing between 51 and 100 apartments. In
1895, about 53 percent of Munich’s working-class families lived in one-room
accommodations, with an additional kitchen or small chamber in some cases
(Table 65). But even the two-room units meant that conditions were extremely
56

Social Stratification and Inequalities

cramped. As we have seen, working-class families had on average more children than civil servants and white-collar employees. Worsening this situation, in order to pay the rents that the rising housing demand in the wake of
the great migration to the cities had pushed sky-high, between 10 and 20 percent of working-class families took in lodgers to help pay for their apartments (Table 68).
According to a survey conducted in Berlin in 1880, some 39,298 households (15.3 percent) had overnight lodgers (Schlafgänger), while another
18,318 (7.1 percent) had full-time lodgers (Einmieter). Some 8,000 households offered beds to either two male overnight lodgers or one male and one
female lodger. It is not difficult to imagine what this meant for the day-today life of a family, for marital relations, or for the upbringing of children.
Such apartments were also hotbeds for infectious diseases. Nor should the effects on the life of the lodgers be ignored. In 1893, some 25 percent of miners in the Ruhr lived as Schlafgänger, and many of them were lucky to have
to share a bed, after a long workday, with no more than one other person. And
if the rent that these lodgers paid became too small to cover the family’s
weekly expenses, the search for cheaper accommodation began. In the region
of what later became the city of Wuppertal there were even fixed days for
moving. Although family possessions tended to grow with the advent of the
mass production of cheap households goods, in most cases all belongings
could be put on a cart for the move to another part of town. Again it was the
working wives, the children, the chronically sick, and the elderly who suffered most from these realities of daily life.
For economic and social, but also political, reasons, some employers started
to build company housing. Krupp was one of the pioneers of this idea; he knew
how to keep “his” workers loyal and to impose a puritanical lifestyle with the
help of strict rules. Other firms copied his model. By 1914 the Ruhr mining
companies had a total of some 82,000 company-owned apartments on their
books whose rents were often one-third of the going market rate, and sometimes even less. Finally, there emerged yet another type of lower-class accommodation, the workers’ colony—housing estates built on the fringes of the
Ruhr cities or in the rural spaces between them. These colonies multiplied
quickly, especially in the northern parts of the Ruhr district, housing in some
cases over 50 percent of the workforce of a particular mine. Compared with
the overcrowded “rental barracks” of the big cities, the colonies had many
obvious benefits, the strict rules imposed by the owners notwithstanding. The
housing units were smaller, the individual apartments a bit more spacious.
The backyard was large enough for the growing of some vegetables. There
was often a sports field at the center of the housing complex.
At the same time, as has been convincingly argued elsewhere,24 these settlements promoted the opposite of what the mine owners had envisaged. They
57

Society

created a strong sense of a common fate among the inhabitants. There emerged
a cultural infrastructure and a milieu that was propitious for the formation of
a working class. This does not imply that the feelings of solidarity forged by
the conditions in the cities’ “rental barracks” were any less significant in forming a cohesive group of individuals who had discovered how much they had in
common with their neighbors, not just in terms of their exterior conditions in
life but also in terms of their inner existential predicament. Certainly, the city
was not a melting pot of all the different social groups that settled in them.
If one surveys the material that has been presented so far, one is certainly
struck by the variety of social life and lifestyles that could be found in Imperial Germany. Here we have millions of men, women, and children who were
differentiated not only by their divergent backgrounds, talents, occupations,
socioeconomic situations, cultural tastes, and opportunities for development,
but also by divergent hopes and expectations. And yet these inequalities are
marked in crucial respects by common features. Structures of inequality existed inside and outside the workplace. We have noted them by looking at occupational and connubial mobility. It also made a difference in respect to
health and life expectancy whether a child was born into a lower-class or a
civil servant’s family. The same held true of nutrition and housing. At the
same time, there were uniformities that sharpened the dividing lines. In most
cases certain social groups found themselves thrown together with those who,
in a cumulative way, experienced similar life conditions. However, before we
address the question of whether these structures reflected an industrial class
society and whether the class character of German society before 1914 became its most basic criterion to which all other inequalities became secondary, it is necessary first to turn to other areas of social inequality.

6. Women and Men
For a long time research into patterns of social inequality during the Imperial period focused on the broad spectrum of social strata. More recently, the
discussion has been broadened and considerably enriched by intensive research into the history of gender and the family. The history of classes was
primarily concerned with reconstructing the situation of nondescript millions
at the lower end of the social scale. Women’s history, by contrast, is interested
in the situation of no less than half the population, and increasingly also in
the interaction between the two sexes in all spheres of life. Some of the handicaps from which women suffered have already been mentioned in our examination of inequalities in the workplace and in income.25 If women were more
poorly paid than men, what was their situation in an increasingly industrial
society in which place of work and residence had become separated more
sharply than had been the case in agrarian societies?
58

Women and Men

The overall employment rate for women hovered around the 30 percent
mark between 1882 and 1907. Put in absolute terms, in 1882 there were 7.79
million working women out of a total of 23 million. By 1907 this figure had
risen to 9.74 million out of 31.26 million. The employment structure underwent similar changes during this period (Tables 29–31). In 1882 “helping
family members,” most of whom were female, amounted to 40.7 percent.
Some 15.5 percent of agricultural laborers were women. By 1907 these shares
had declined to 35.2 and 14.5 percent respectively, following a general trend
toward work in industry. The share of domestic servants also declined. Meanwhile the rates for women working in industry rose from 17.9 percent in
1882 to 18.3 percent in 1907. It must be added that the statistics for “helping
family members,” most of whom worked in small-scale agriculture, crafts,
and domestic industry, are rather incomplete. This type of female labor was
particularly widespread in southern and southwestern Germany.
In industry, the share of women in textiles and clothing was especially
high, even though it declined toward 1914. The home-based textile industries
met with a similar fate. Food producers, including breweries and sugar manufacturers, were the third-largest industrial employer in 1907; in this sector,
women made up 24.7 percent of the labor force—a quadrupling since 1882.
The share of women was lowest in the metal industries and in machine tools.
In 1907 a mere 3.3 percent and 2.0 percent respectively of all women laborers worked in these areas. In relation to the male workforce the shares in
these industries were 6.3 percent and 4.8 percent respectively. Only in cities
such as Duisburg and Dortmund in the Ruhr area were these percentages a
little higher. Regional differences in female industrial labor can also be discerned. In the Saxon textile town of Plauen, nearly half the workforce was
female. In cities such as Barmen, Krefeld, and Elberfeld it was at least a quarter and more. But there is also a slow shift away from textiles toward electrical engineering, a new and thriving branch whose rationalization policies
resulted in a growing demand for unskilled and semiskilled women.
A marked rise also occurred in the tertiary sector (Table 29). The expansion of consumption increased the demand for shop assistants. While many
smaller shops could rarely afford more than one employee, the emergence of
the department store created jobs in much larger numbers. As has been mentioned, the rise of white-collar employees was accompanied by a growth in
“white-blouse” occupations. In the proliferating public services women would
find employment as secretaries and receptionists. In 1882 no more than 7.7
percent of all working women were involved in the tertiary sector. By 1907
the share had increased to 14.6 percent.
Reference must finally be made to a relatively small group of women who,
unlike most of the female laborers discussed so far, as a rule did not come
from lower-class backgrounds. Before 1914 there were very few female doc59

Society

tors, lawyers, or academics in Germany, since the required professional training for a long time had remained closed to them. But a beginning was made
when opportunities to attend high school and to obtain the Abitur were expanded. At the time of the founding of the Kaiserreich, most girls whose parents wanted to give them better educations beyond the primary level went to
private schools. In 1872 there were also some 165 high schools for girls that
were supported by the state or local government and in which instruction was
mostly in German, French, mathematics, needlework, and religion. The range
of subjects offered was based on the assumption that the task was to equip
these girls, most of whom were of bourgeois or upper-class background, to
become better future mothers, not to train them for professional careers.
Consequently, most girls left these schools without a certificate that institutions of advanced learning required. Only a few institutes were specifically
geared to preparing their pupils for the Abitur, the state-supervised final examination. Individual teachers, such as Helene Lange, made a stronger academic orientation of the curriculum their concern. In this way a growing
number of women succeeded, after 1890, in passing the necessary examinations. After this breakthrough, the universities had a much harder time upholding their traditional refusal to admit women. However, from the start their
policies were marked by contradictions and a lack of uniformity that made
the exclusion of women appear ever more absurd.
First there was the tug-of-war over the admission of women as auditors.
Saxony and Bavaria had granted this privilege even before the founding of
the German Empire. It took Prussia until the 1890s to follow suit, and even
thereafter the practice of admission varied considerably from university to
university. Admission figures showed that interest in academic study was by
now considerable (Table 54). In 1896/97 some 223 female auditors were registered in Prussia; nine years later the figure had increased to 1,669. All the
while, some southern states had continued to handle admission in a more liberal fashion and began to experiment with the idea of allowing women to enroll as full-time students. This in turn exerted pressure on Prussia to abandon
its restrictive practices. When the last barriers finally came down in 1909, the
share of female students rose quickly. Just before World War I, some 7.44 percent of the Prussian student body was female. The Reich total was 4.8 percent. A mere 7.1 percent of the female students were Catholic, whereas the
share of Jewish women was more than twice that figure.
These developments were accompanied, almost inevitably, by the question of whether women could take university examinations and to which disciplines they should be admitted. This in turn unleashed a debate on whether
they were actually capable of scholarly inquiry. Not a few scientists, lawyers,
and medical professors openly expressed their doubts about this. Paul Möbius
even went so far as to publish a pamphlet in 1900, focused on the alleged
60

Women and Men

“physiological debility of women.” But for others, too, the most primitive arguments were good enough to be fielded against the entry of female high
school graduates who wanted to attend universities. It made little difference
that a few foreigners had successfully passed their examinations as early as
the 1870s at places like Göttingen and Leipzig.
Nor did it help that women had long been admitted to foreign universities,
above all in Switzerland, where they had obtained higher qualifications in the
sciences as well as in the humanities. Some had even received their doctorates. Around 1900, there were twenty female physicians who had passed
their qualifying examinations in Switzerland and had subsequently opened
practices in Germany. The types of emotional hurdles women had to overcome is demonstrated by the case of the famous physicist Max Planck, who—
in this respect rather more liberal than many of his colleagues—had allowed
women to attend his lectures as early as 1897. Nevertheless, he continued to
hold the view, widespread at the time among men and women, that being a
mother and housewife was the natural role of women and that this alleged
law of Nature could not be ignored without serious detriment to individual
and society.
The expansion of the school system, however, opened the door early on
for unmarried women with pedagogical inclinations who wanted to become
teachers. This career could be taken without the Abitur certificate by studying at one of the pedagogical institutes. Even many men, who were otherwise
hostile to female professionals, found it plausible that girls were best instructed by women. Thus, it happened that as early as 1875 Prussia had some
3,896 female primary school teachers. Their number more than doubled to
8,380 by 1891 (Table 44). Twenty years later, there were over 24,000 women
teaching alongside 91,600 male colleagues. Similarly the growth of girls’
high schools required more female teachers. Some 9,100 of them worked in
these schools around the turn of the century. Meanwhile the question of pay,
which was higher for men than for women at all levels, generated much controversy. Similarly, the requirement for female teachers that marriage carried
with it a statutory end to their teaching careers was bound to cause bitterness.
There was also the problem of equal promotion rights that were time and
again denied to women. Conflicts also broke out over access to further training and qualifying examinations that would allow women to rise on the
career ladder in tandem with their male colleagues. Men were at the forefront of the opposition to an incipient, female-dominated preschool movement. The critics insisted that six was the appropriate age for starting a formal
education.
Meanwhile fresh opportunities arose for women, usually of lower middleclass background, who decided to go into the nursing profession. Here, too,
special training was required, and work was no doubt more interesting than
61

Society

factory manufacturing. Before World War I, the female share in the health industry was around 55 percent. In the arts, a few actresses and artists made it
to the top. Although they were statistically insignificant, they nevertheless
acted as role models. Even if the most prominent among them earned high
honoraria, there was no question that their male colleagues would receive
more, and this was equally true of women in the legal and medical professions. Even if they, too, were left behind when it came to promotions, these
women nevertheless achieved a higher level of job satisfaction than female
laborers, secretaries, and shop assistants.
Whatever the many handicaps under which working women labored in
comparison with their male colleagues, when it came to the factory shop
floor, where thousands of them found employment, they were all in the same
boat. Here men were just as much without a vocation or a perspective on their
future as their female counterparts. But in order fully to appreciate the special difficulties encountered by women, we must present yet another set of
statistics, relating to their marital status. In 1907 agriculture still employed
the highest share of married women at 54 percent. Their share in industry
rose from 31.1 percent in 1895 to 32.9 percent in 1907. Some 44.7 percent of
domestic servants were married, closely followed by women in the tertiary
sector (44 percent). For the year 1875, we also have a breakdown by agegroup for Prussia. According to this table, some 25.1 percent of women aged
16 to 18 were laborers, of whom 0.6 percent were married (Table 33). Among
those aged 18 to 25 years, a group representing 43 percent of the total, no
less than 88.6 percent were unmarried. Only among women above the age
of 25 was the percentage of those who were married again considerable at
56 percent. This means that the majority of female factory workers in various branches of industry were young and unmarried (Table 32). Workers in
home industries present a different picture; most were married or widowed.
These industries had the lowest pay rates and the fewest promotion prospects.
Whatever other handicaps these women workers may have faced, homeindustrial work offered certain logistical advantages, especially for women
with small children. All in all, they constituted a badly exploited group whose
work was moreover subject to sharp seasonal vacillations.
Still, in terms of pay and prestige, the unmarried female servant working
in agriculture was probably at the bottom of the pile. The only escape from
these conditions was to move to the city, where positions as domestic servants to the well-to-do were available. In terms of city work, being a maid
was pretty much the pits. The working day was long and included Sundays.
Chambers were often no more than cubby holes. Since room and board were
free, domestics received rarely more than a small “pocket money.” They also
had to contend with supervision by the “mistress of the house,” which was
frequently very strict. On the positive side, these women had left the worse
62

Women and Men

conditions in agriculture behind them. They immediately had a roof over
their heads and usually enough to eat. Employers were not invariably exploitative. Maids could expect to be given unwanted clothes from the mistress,
who might also be generous in other ways. Finally, these women also gained
an insight into the organization of the household that would be useful later
on when they decided to get married.
Even before the decline in the number of domestic positions, many women
who arrived in the cities as commuters or long-distance migrants would go
straight into the factories. Some would return to their parents at night, if they
lived nearby; others would look for a bed as lodgers with working-class families. There were also shelters for young female workers. However difficult
life might have been, at least the pay was better than it was for maids. The
women who did not commute did not have to hand over part of their earnings
to their parents. They thus had money to spend, while the slow reduction of
work hours gave them more leisure time. In the 1880s the workday for female textile workers was still twelve to thirteen hours (Table 15).
After the turn of the century, the eleven-hour workday became more typical in the textile industry. In other branches it even came down to ten hours,
and in 1910 a law was promulgated that prescribed the sixty-hour week for all
industries. Nightshift work was banned, and laws protecting pregnant women
from dismissal were enacted. If the factory was some distance away from the
worker’s abode, all these improvements could still mean an exhausting daily
routine. But at least Sunday was completely free, and when Saturday work
hours were reduced to eight, the evening of that day was similarly available
for leisure pursuits. Beyond this, few of these working-class women succeeded in moving up into the group of white-collar employees. Income improvements could perhaps be achieved by moving to jobs in other companies
that paid higher wages and offered better benefits.
And many unmarried female factory workers did try to enjoy their Sundays. They went to dancehalls or beer gardens with their friends and colleagues, where they would meet single men, many of whom had also migrated
from the rural parts of the country. Social contact might lead to sexual relations, causing bourgeois social critics to utter dark warnings about an alleged
decline in morals. But any attempt to understand the sexual behavior of young
working-class men and women would go wrong if we were to apply the yardsticks of these critics. Civil servants, white-collar employees, craftsmen,
wealthy businessmen, and the nobility expected their daughters to preserve
their virginity until marriage. To become pregnant with an illegitimate child
was deemed a violation of family honor. Of course, different standards applied to “young gentlemen.” Ever so discreetly, they would be encouraged to
sow their oats during their bachelor years. The codes were again different for
female laborers, maids, and—at least in some regions—agricultural servants.
63

Society

Certainly they were less restricted than women from the middle and upper
classes. If, having met at some dance, a young couple warmed to each other,
the relationship would not stop short of sexual intercourse. It also happened,
especially in economically harder times, that female factory workers or domestic servants would slip into occasional prostitution. In 1873, the number
of prostitutes under police supervision in Berlin was 2,224. The share of female workers among them was 16 percent, while domestic servants and shop
assistants made up another 42 percent. By 1890, the figure had risen to 4,039,
and contemporary estimates of the actual levels were many times higher.
Around 1909, the number of prostitutes in Berlin was thought to be 40,000,
contributing to a high percentage of illegitimate births.
According to some estimates, the latter figure climbed as high as 350,000
in 1914. However, the share of illegitimate births in relation to the total number of births varied considerably from city to city. In Munich it was as high as
31.6 percent, in Dresden 20.5 percent, in Berlin 12.3 percent, and in Cologne
a mere 9.8 percent. Pastor Paul Göhre, who in the 1890s signed up as a factory worker and later wrote a report on his experiences, came to believe that
it was difficult to find a young factory woman over the age of seventeen in
Chemnitz who was not sexually active.
It would be mistaken to deduce from these percentages that members of
the lower classes were devoid of morals. Even when illegitimate children
were born in larger numbers, they often were the result of stable relationships
that knew genuine love, emotional relief, and mutual support. If such relationships did not last, this was due to many circumstances, but not, as a rule, to
an unwanted pregnancy. For just as in rural society, there existed unwritten
codes of honor, according to which a young worker would not just “dump”
his pregnant girlfriend. That is how sailors might behave in port cities, or soldiers in garrison towns, or “gentlemen” students in university towns, or the
fictive Baron Botho von Reinäcker in Theodor Fontane’s novel Irrungen und
Wirrungen. For most workers, it was “a matter of course” to get married now
or at least to establish a joint household, if marriage was not yet possible for
economic or other reasons. If necessary, colleagues or the family would exert a bit of moral pressure. Such social mechanisms were even stronger in
cases where a journeyman had started a liaison with the master’s daughter.
However, we are best informed about the workings of these mechanisms
in certain rural areas. As the above-mentioned figures on illegitimacy in individual cities of the Reich indicated, there were some surprising differences.
This applied even more so to larger regions. The fact that some parts of Catholic Bavaria ranked high, and the Catholic Rhineland low, points to the perhaps surprising fact that confessional factors were not decisive, if we discount
the low illegitimacy rate among German Jews. Rates were also low in Protestant Frisia and around Brunswick near Hanover, but were sharply up in Prot64

Women and Men

estant Saxony further east. To some extent these differences may be explained “with divergent intra-Church currents and the varying effectiveness
in the imposition of High Church norms.”26 Most demographers are inclined
today to see marriage age and work organization as the decisive factors.
In most of northern Europe the marriage age for women declined from
26–27 years to 24–25 years during the nineteenth century. At the same time
the start of a woman’s fertility cycle moved back to 14–15 years from an earlier 18–20 years. Unlike in the Balkans and in the Mediterranean, with their
patrilinear family systems and patriarchal structures, there was no tradition
of “child marriages” in Central Europe. Consequently, women had ten years
between reaching sexual maturity and their average marriage age to gather
sexual experiences. They lived “dangerously” in this period. At an age when
the chance of conception was high, they and their often no more “sexually
enlightened” or experienced boyfriends experimented, if at all, with contraceptives and techniques that were very unreliable.27 Wherever, following the
abolition of the marriage consent, sanctions against sexual intercourse
among unmarried people were mild, but outside pressures to honor the promise of marriage or not to “dump” a woman were high, we also find high illegitimacy rates. This was true, above all, of those rural parts of Germany in
which inheritance laws had prevented a splintering of peasant lands. These
larger farmsteads were unable to operate on a family basis and were hence
dependent on servants. This pattern, together with an increased sexual freedom among young people, offered greater opportunities for sexual contact.
If, in these circumstances, birth control was practiced carelessly or not at all,
a high pregnancy rate was the almost inevitable result.
Existing statistics, of course, refer only to actual births. The number of infanticides in the Kaiserreich was low, if court records provide any guide. The
large unknown is the number of abortions, about which we have no more than
crude estimates, running into hundreds of thousands. Contemporary interviews
with female factory workers showed that many had several intended and unintended terminations. In Berlin circa 1900, about 25 percent of pregnancies
ended in abortion. There are no comparable figures for the rural areas. What
presumably prevented a high incidence of abortions in the villages, where
everyone knew everything about everybody else, were, apart from a fear of
criminal prosecution, the existing instruments of social pressure. Here local
traditions and the economic dependence of the female servants had a powerful influence. It was difficult for a father to abandon the mother of his child,
and in many cases marriage took place just before or after the baby’s birth, or
the couple established a common law household. If this solution proved impossible, alimony payments were due. But even in such cases, the children did
not have to grow up in foster families without their biological mother. They
would simply be raised on the farm together with the other children.
65

Society

Employers in the cities, by contrast, very rarely offered a domestic servant
the opportunity to stay on with her illegitimate child. For financial reasons,
bourgeois households preferred maids that had just arrived from the country.
But if these maids brought with them the sexual norms of the village and suddenly became pregnant, the “mistress of the house” would not even wait with
giving notice until the child was born. Consequently, unqualified doctors and
backstreet abortionists in the cities were busier than their rural counterparts.
Considering that an unwanted pregnancy always meant emotional and material hardship, even if the father stood by his lover, it was no doubt fortunate
that high illegitimacy rates were an ephemeral urban phenomenon. The lower
classes, too, began to limit pregnancies by practicing more effective birth
control. Urbanization, the lowering of the marriage age by an average of two
years, and a higher marriage rate finally contributed to reducing the problem
further.
Meanwhile the situation of an unmarried mother and her children did not
necessarily improve if the father of her child stayed with her. As has been
mentioned,28 infant mortality rates remained high during the first year, not
least because of the poor living conditions into which these children were
born. These conditions also contributed to the relatively low life expectancy
of women, even though it was slightly higher than that of men (Tables 58,
60). What remained was the increased danger to working-class women
throughout pregnancy or during birth. There was also the progressive undermining of their health due to inadequate nutrition and sheer overwork. Affliction with tuberculosis, the “disease of the poor,” provides a good indicator of
this. Not only was the rate of infection higher for females over the age of five
than it was for males, but it also experienced no more than a very small
decline between 1875/79 and 1914 among those between the ages of twenty
and forty.
Nor were chances particularly great that children would grow up with
both parents. This was not due to high divorce rates, but rather because, although the average marriage age of women declined, working-class men
continued to marry late, and because they died earlier than the male average
if they came from the industrial working class. One factor accounting for the
late marriage age was that many men had to perform military service but
could be drafted only from the age of twenty. Military pay in 1913 was 23
pfennigs per day, making it difficult to save for a future family. Not surprisingly, therefore, at the end of 1910 no more than 8 percent of 20 to 25 year
olds were married. The figure then rose to 50 percent for 25 to 30 year olds.
A good four-fifths of all industrial workers finally got married by the age of
50, and there was merely a modest increase in this figure between 1882 and
1907 from 83 percent to 86 percent. Meanwhile, the average life expectancy
was still under 50 years.
66

Women and Men

Since most women would ultimately get married, the question arises as to
why the nuclear family came to be the most common form of living among
the lower classes, even though it was exposed to so many emotional and material hardships. Among agricultural and industrial laborers, marriage in most
cases became the destination not because the couple was longing to have
children or because the wife expected to devote herself exclusively to her
family. To begin with, many children either existed before marriage or arrived shortly after the modest wedding. Above all, around 30 percent of all
married women had to work in order to make ends meet. This figure does not
include those who had a small and often irregular job to boost the weekly
budget. With the decline in the number of domestic service jobs, such jobs
included working as cleaning women for well-to-do middle-class families or
in one of the proliferating offices and stores.
There were obvious advantages to not having to work the full ten- to
twelve-hour workdays that factory labor still involved. A few hours in the morning or late at night made it easier to find supervision for the children. Unless
the economy as a whole did poorly, the wage was in many cases enough to
secure a slightly higher living standard. Logistical considerations of this kind
also explain why the share of married women in the domestic industries was
particularly high. It was clearly easier to look after small children if the
workplace was in the home. If one of the children fell ill, factory women stood
to lose a full day’s pay and perhaps even their job. Moreover, domestic workers could put their children to work at an early age—finishing garments,
making cigars, or wrapping sweets and chocolates. The preparation of meals,
washing, and other domestic chores were also more manageable. If there was
an elder daughter, she would look after the smaller children or do the cooking.
The 30 percent of married women who had a full-time job with unequal
pay had no relief from carrying the triple burden of monotonous and often
unhealthy factory work, the bearing and raising of children, and keeping
household for four to five people on a meager budget. The fact that the patriarchal family structures and attitudes survived in many working-class marriages, just as they obtained elsewhere in society, only made matters more
difficult for women. There may have been more equality of the sexes when
it came to major economic decisions than in bourgeois families, but rarely
did the husband bear his share in running the household. Time and again
would his wife sacrifice her needs to those of the family. Kitchen aids were
too expensive to be affordable for the lower classes. If her indispensability
provided her with some influence within the existing family hierarchy, the
time that she had to herself was strictly limited. We will never know how
many of these women harbored the modest and secret hope that one day their
husbands’ income would be high enough for them to be able to give up their
menial jobs. This is when “life” might at last begin.
67

Society

Similarly, it seems that many lower-class husbands, too, dreamed of the
day when they would be able to relieve their wives of the burden of working
outside the home. Reaching this goal would have been proof that workingclass marriage had ceased to be no more than an emergency arrangement offering emotional and material shelter against illness, job loss, and political
discrimination by the employer and the police, especially when the family’s
ideological commitment was to the left. That many working-class women
strove to devote themselves to the family and did not take jobs outside the
home—as was the ideal and in most cases the reality for many bourgeois and
upper-class married women—should not mislead us, however, into thinking
that working-class women were being absorbed into the bourgeois universe.
Workers and the middle class lived in different worlds in Imperial Germany,
and indeed increasingly so; this was also true of working-class women and
their bourgeois counterparts.
When we consider the middle classes, gender role divisions were even
more asymmetrical and polarized. This applied to the families of shopkeepers
and artisans, where the wife might lend a hand with the accounts or behind
the counter. Divisions were also sharp among civil servants and white-collar
workers, whose wives by and large stayed at home minding the “private sphere.”
If nothing else, the existence of this sphere differentiated them from workingclass women. Though often stifled by prudishness and sexual repression, it
was also larger simply because accommodation was more spacious. The rituals of bathing may be a good example after the bourgeoisie had discovered
the seaside for their summer vacations. These rituals stood in curious contrast
to the nudist movement that emerged before 1914 in connection with many
middle-class individuals’ search for new ways of life and relationships between men and women. While the working-class family with its larger number of children and lodgers remained “half-open,” the overall effect of the
different economic and sociocultural conditions in the middle classes was
that there existed more spaces to which husband and wife could withdraw
and be undisturbed.
The husband acted as the sole breadwinner, while his wife kept the house
for him and was in charge of the private sphere, economically and legally dependent on him. To some extent, the size of her household budget determined
her ability to spend her day as a successful homemaker who understood the
needs of her husband. In her Practical Cookbook for the Bourgeois Kitchen,
published in 1913, Mary Hahn described this idyll as follows: “The path to a
husband’s heart goes through the stomach.… Love alone is insufficient, to
guarantee the happy continuation of a marriage. A soup that is too salty, a
roast that is burnt, often constitute the minor causes of a failed marriage.…
The husband is coming home from his office or workplace at lunchtime and
wants to refortify himself at the family table.… One should also constantly
68

Demographic Structure and Development

vary the dishes; this makes the meal interesting. The grateful husband will
smile and be thrilled to see what new [dishes] the inventive house-wife is putting [on the table].… The social question will be solved quickly as soon as
all wives cook well and know how to provide a comfortable home so that the
husband likes it better there than in the pub.”29
What Hahn, of course, overlooked was that this kind of care required economic resources that not even all middle-class families had. It also depended
on how far she actually wanted to be a “perfect housewife” who lent “domestic glamour” to the spacious home; how frequently she went out to buy fashionable clothes or to see her women friends in one of the many coffeehouses;
how far she moved beyond the home, for example, by being active in charitable work; and how far she was willing to be the devoted lover of her husband. Clearly, she had more space than a working-class wife in a tenement
apartment. But historical research will probably never be able to reconstruct
what went on behind those larger four walls of the “rental palaces” and in the
bedrooms of the well-fed bourgeois couple. All that can be said is that it was
a different, though not necessarily happier, world from the one of those who
faced the “social question” in their hard daily lives.
Among the lower middle classes—those whose incomes often barely kept
up with inflation—it was virtually unthinkable to have a domestic servant.
Here housewives did their own shopping, laundry, and housecleaning. Children
below school age had to be supervised and kept occupied full-time; school
children came home around lunchtime, not, as in other countries, in the midafternoon. If there was a small back garden, some time would be spent growing vegetables, thus relieving the budget. Part of the fruit season might be
spent making preserves for the winter. The advent of the sewing machine made
it easier to save on clothing expenditures. If all these activities were taken seriously, not much time was left in the day for social life. A longer chat with
a neighbor at the local shop or on the street fulfilled an important social function. And on Sunday, after church, one might meet with friends in the afternoon over coffee and cake or in the evening for a glass of beer at the local pub.
The social obligations of middle-class husbands, especially if they belonged
to the local oligarchy of notables, could make for a busy life. To be sure, many
of the evening affairs were for men only. But for the wives there were also
theaters, concerts, and balls to attend, and receptions and private dinner parties to prepare. The often strict demands of etiquette required considerable
organizational talents to avoid embarrassments. What was at stake here was
the ability of the husband to demonstrate his status. On such occasions, some
of his public status and prestige would also reflect upon his wife, just as she
would benefit from any of his professional achievements by being addressed
as “Frau Doktor” or “Frau Direktor” when out shopping. Still, it was a world
set apart from the virile ambiente of men, as they went after their public busi69

Society

ness, gathered in clubs and smoke rooms, and occasionally even challenged
each other to a duel.
Social commitments multiplied for women whose husbands moved in
court circles, in the diplomatic service, or in the armed forces. The diaries of
Baroness Spitzemberg provide a good insight into the changing, but often
very stiff, lifestyle and sociability of the more urbanized and cosmopolitan
nobility, where on some days one reception, dinner party, or concert would
be chasing another, and where a single new evening dress might cost as much
as the annual wage of a factory worker.30 However, these women could also
retreat into their own homes and private suites. They could sit alone in the
garden. They had most of the comforts of modern life—a bath tub, central
heating, gas. The family budget of the upper bourgeoisie and the still wealthy
nobility was also large enough to accommodate a vacation that a wife and
children would spend, accompanied by the nanny, at the seaside, in the mountains, or in one of the famous spa towns. Waiting outside might be a horsedrawn carriage or, after the turn of the century, perhaps even an automobile.
In short, many women lived busy, but often also emotionally empty lives,
especially where the genuine love of the early marriage years had been replaced by routine and indifference. Since divorce was viewed as a serious
violation of social norms and hence rarely entertained, happiness often proved
elusive. Migraine headaches became one of the symptoms and symbols of a
neglected female psyche. And in many cases it was also a weapon of refusal
used by many “well-situated” women who were disenfranchised politically
and economically. Where it was so difficult to realize one’s individuality in
constructive terms, migraine became the often subconscious negative selfexpression of a physically and psychically deprived wife and mother.
Compared with women of the urban upper classes, the wives of landed estate owners had more sedate lives that could become one of isolation during the
long winter months. At the same time, there were quite a few organizational matters to manage. The servants had to be supervised. Church and parish welfare
had to be supported. The wives were required for consultations with the children’s private teachers. Hunting parties had to be entertained. In the evening,
there might be time to read a book or, during the summer, to sit in the garden.
But just as in the case of working-class women in comparison with their bourgeois counterparts, the relationship between actual work and tending the private
sphere defined the difference in the lives between the ladies of the manor and the
peasant wife. On wealthier farmsteads, the woman was still an administrator of
the family sphere. Lower down the income scale, she, too, would bear the triple
burden of hard farm labor, looking after the children, and keeping the household.
What was common to the situation of all women was that they had to operate within a patriarchal society and family structure that did not move with
the rapidly changing economy around it. To be sure, many partners had deeper
70

Issues of Generation and Socialization

emotional and sexual ties than the average marriage. But they, too, ran up
against the legal, political, and social obstacles that existed to secure male
dominance. Sometimes marriages would break up over the strains that the
unequal relationship imposed. In 1895, some 8,300 marriages were legally dissolved. Six years later, the number had actually declined to 7,892. By 1913
some 152 out of every 100,000 marriages ended in divorce, with considerable variations between Catholics and Protestants, and between city dwellers
and rural folks. The big city perhaps made coping with divorce easier. But
considering that divorce law severely disadvantaged women, available figures probably represent no more than the tip of the iceberg and do not tell us
much about relations between the sexes. The number of unhappy marriages
was most likely considerably higher.
This section’s focus on gender relations in the workplace and within the
family will be expanded in Part IV to a discussion of women’s position in the
political sphere. Suffice it to say at this point that many of the above-mentioned
inequalities were cemented in law and political power positions. Some legal
changes, such as the ratification of the Association Law of 1908, which allowed women to participate for the first time in political organizations, at first
glance seemed to improve the situation of women. The gains turned out to be
more ambivalent. Above all, there were also very tangible and immediate setbacks. A good example can be seen in the property and inheritance clauses
of the Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch, BGB) promulgated after years
of debate in 1900.

7. Issues of Generation and Socialization
A. The Young and the Aged
As a result of rapid population growth, the percentage of children and young
people was particularly high during this period. In 1913, the share of youngsters under the age of 15 in terms of the total population was 34.4 percent. At
the other end of the spectrum, the increase in life expectancy had led to a
slightly larger number of elderly people (Table 55); but as long as average
life expectancy remained at 47.7 years for men and 50.7 years for women, it
is not surprising that in 1910 no more than 5 percent of the population was
over 65. At the same time, the young and the aged were among the most defenseless groups of the population and the ones who suffered the most from
existing inequalities.
With infant mortality as high as it was, for the newly born it was first of
all a question of surviving the danger zone of the first twelve months (Tables
59–62). This in turn depended in large measure on the social group into
which the child happened to be born. It is true that chances of survival for an
71

Society

infant born to an upper-class family were lower by international standards,
and infant mortality rates fluctuated. Still, the fact remains that the survival
rates of working-class children or of illegitimate babies were depressingly
low. Thus, the social background of the parents, legitimacy, and housing, as
well as nutritional standards, remained important factors. For example, infants who were not breastfed died most frequently of diarrhea and vomiting
caused by unpasteurized milk that had gone sour during the hot summer days
for lack of a cool space or refrigeration in the overcrowded apartment blocks
of the big cities. And more generally it tended to make a difference between
the life or death of a child whether or not the mother had basic medical or
nutritional knowledge. Finally, there was the question of whether the family
could afford calling a pediatrician when children fell ill.
It is now also common knowledge of child psychology that the early years
of childhood can be decisive for a person’s later psychic, intellectual, and
even physical development. Nor can there be any doubt that emotional warmth
and close human contact are no less important than proper nutrition. In the
late nineteenth century, many people had at least a rudimentary appreciation
of these aspects of childrearing, promoted by doctors and social reformers.
They also knew about the important role of parents in the transmission of
cultural capital. Yet this knowledge rarely (or, at best, incompletely) reached
the lower classes. The educated and well-to-do middle classes were most
likely to pick up the proliferating information on child development. It was
rarely put into practice among the upper classes, where wet-nurses and nannies were more common, and where the mother’s social commitments kept
her away from the children and the patriarchal fathers remained remote. The
detrimental effects of an aristocratic upbringing have been studied most closely
with respect to the development of Crown Prince Wilhelm, who was to become emperor in 1888.31 His may be an extreme case, but, whatever the material comforts, it was not always easy to grow up in a noble family with its
time-honored traditions and strict conventions. That the use of wet-nurses
was less common in bourgeois families, even if the mother did not breastfeed, is related to middle-class perceptions of family life and the fear that
wet-nursing might interfere with the bonding between mother and child.
Although preconditions for a happy childhood were least favorable in
working-class families, this does not mean that love and warm relationships
could not develop between parents and children in this milieu. However,
material hardship and the difficulty of articulating feelings toward family
members, spouses, or children put up considerable obstacles. The father, who
spent ten to twelve arduous hours in the factory, would not be present during
the day. When he returned to the overcrowded apartment of no more than a
kitchen and a bedroom, often after a detour to the local pub, he would be
tired and irritable. He did not have to be particularly brutal or authoritarian
72

Issues of Generation and Socialization

to grab a coat hanger or leather belt to give his boisterous children an intemperate trashing. Even without this, his tone and language would frequently be
coarse. There would be no long discussions; authority was not to be questioned, and any argument was liable quickly to degenerate into a shouting
match. If the father had an alcohol problem, all members of the family would
fall victim to his violent outbursts. However, it must be stressed that research
on the extent of battering and child abuse in all strata in this period is still
very much at the beginning. Some have argued that the increased consumption of bottled beer, which might have eliminated the need for an after-work
trip to the pub, points to more frequent socializing within the family circle.
While her husband was at work, his wife would be fully occupied with the
household and, in many cases, with improving the family income through a
part-time job. If she was lucky, there might be a nearby grandmother to take
