over as a babysitter. Elder daughters also helped watch the other children.
Even if the mother had to work full-time, crèches or babysitters might be too
expensive and difficult to come by. In 1914, there existed in Germany around
1,400 kindergartens with no more than 85,000 places. Consequently, in many
cases the children were just left to themselves. A neighbor might agree to
keep an eye on them, as they were playing in the backyards and stairwells of
the apartment buildings. In Berlin alone there were an estimated 20,000 of
these unattended children in 1912.
By comparison, children of middle-class families must be considered fortunate. Whether it was their mother or nanny, someone would be around them
all day. There would be toys and children’s books; they would be encouraged
to play imaginatively. Stories would be read to them at bedtime. There was
no need to give them—as frequently happened in working-class families—
tranquilizers like beer or a lump of sugar dipped in brandy so that there would
at last be peace and quiet in the small apartment at the end of a long day. However poor and monotonous the food that lower-class children were served may
have been, it had to be eaten. Their bourgeois counterparts were offered greater
variety and more choice all around. One could think of other aspects of a
child’s life to provide further illustrations for how much of a head start was
given by having the “right” family background and by having parents who
were well-to-do and pedagogically enlightened.
The beginning of school was the next major step in a child’s development,
and one that many working-class parents looked forward to as a relief. Whatever the benefits and drawbacks of primary schooling for their education and
socialization,32 children were now also old enough to contribute to the family income. However, this was no longer the kind of child labor involving long
hours in the mines or factories with which we are familiar from industrialization’s earlier periods. In Prussia the minimum age had been fixed at twelve
as early as 1853. The Gewerbeordnung of 1869 had outlawed the employment
73

Society

of children in jobs that were dangerous to their health. Further legislation in
1891 raised the minimum age to thirteen and imposed a general ban on child
labor in the factories. The maximum number of hours for fourteen to sixteen
year olds was fixed at ten, and this also applied to apprentices and agricultural servants, most of whom were taken under contract at age fourteen.
The changes in the law led to a drastic decline in the number of children
working in industry, whose number had doubled to 27,500 during the 1880s.
By the mid-1890s this figure slipped to fewer than 5,000, but rose once more
to 10,900 in 1906. Yet, however progressive labor legislation may have been
in Wilhelmine Germany, abuses continued to occur, especially in the treatment of apprentices and agricultural servants. In 1904, the Berlin Insurance
Association reported a high incidence of workplace-related illness among apprentices. According to the annual report of the factory inspectorate at Minden in Lower Saxony for 1905, many employers tried to flout regulations by
obliging their apprentices to stay on after their ten-hour workday to clean the
machinery. Moreover, behind the vague term of “supplementary work” lurked
another and even bigger problem: hundreds of thousands of children under
fourteen years of age held “small” jobs. Around the turn of the century, some
540,000 school-age children were registered as having part-time occupations.
This figure represented well under 10 percent of primary school students.
But the actual number must have been much higher. This is reflected in a survey by the Prussian government, according to which 40 percent of all school
children worked for at least three hours, six to seven days a week. Many of
them delivered newspapers or fresh rolls at daybreak. Or they stayed up late
at night setting up pins in bowling alleys or washing dishes and glasses in
restaurants and pubs. However, the largest number of these part-time child laborers worked in domestic industries.
The Child Protection Law that came into force in 1904 tried to regulate
the permissible hours of work and to outlaw the employment of children in
particularly dangerous jobs. However, this law’s shortcoming was that it protected children from other families more effectively than the biological children of a family. The position of the latter was governed by Paragraph 1617
of the Civil Code of 1900, in which parents’ rights had been given precedence over children’s interests. Nor was it easy to police families who employed their own children. In fact it was not the parents who complained
about the extent of this type of child labor, but primary school teachers. Legal sanctions notwithstanding, every day teachers faced children who had
clearly slept too little, either because they had gotten up hours before the start
of school to run errands or because they had not gone to bed much before
midnight. To be sure, these children had not been sent out to work part-time
because this furthered their education or apprenticeship; rather they took on
these jobs to contribute to the family budget.
74

Issues of Generation and Socialization

In agriculture, child labor was so deeply rooted that the government, faced
with the sharp opposition of agrarian pressure groups, was forced to exclude
rural children from the law’s sanctions altogether. It just was not possible politically to introduce in the agricultural sector a clause similar to the one that
industry had so grudgingly accepted. Opposition was particularly vocal in East
Elbia, where day-laborers in some cases even had a contractual obligation to
the local lord to send their school-age children into the fields. In Prussia
alone the number of children working in agriculture was estimated to be just
under 1.8 million in 1904. Thanks to the Prussian bureaucracy’s penchant for
meticulous record keeping, we possess some interesting statistics relating to
the children who worked outside their own families. Of the approximately
1.8 million children, some 445,000 were under ten; 717,000 were over twelve,
with the rest distributed in-between. How many of the children were employed
in agriculture from within the family is not known. We do have some official
statistics, though, concerning the total number of hours worked. Thus, around
446,000 children were temporarily employed for over six hours per day. Demand was particularly high during harvesttime, and at those periods the total
count came to at least 1.5 million for children from other families.
The sons and daughters of the middle and upper classes were, exceptions
always granted, never exposed to the health-damaging conditions that children
from the lower strata experienced. It was on the whole economically possible
for parents to grant them slightly bigger wishes for toys and entertainment,
especially at Christmas and on birthdays. Helping their children with school
assignments was not beyond these parents’ ability and education, and, if necessary, private tutors might be asked to help with homework. However, few
of these children, except for those from very sheltered homes, would have remained totally ignorant of the poverty in which some of their fellow public
school pupils lived. True, the concentration of certain social groups in specific
parts of town promoted separation in different primary schools. But at least
in the more mixed neighborhoods, it was difficult not to notice the differences
between the well-to-do and the poor. Rarely did this lead to closer social contact or even friendships, though. In short, in this period the young experienced
very different childhoods, depending on whether one’s parents were factory
workers or belonged to the middle classes, whether they were small peasants
and land laborers or estate owners. In many ways the situation of children
with a bourgeois background came closest to the prevailing notions of the
ideal family espoused by family politicians and child psychologists, who wrote
about the psychic and intellectual needs of young people. As regards the children of the rural or industrial proletariat, one is often left to wonder how
many of them experienced a childhood, as we would recognize it today, at all.
Boys from this latter milieu initially fared no better than girls. But with
rising age, differentiations set in. Thus, daughters would be asked to help in
75

Society

the kitchen and with the supervision of younger siblings. Later on, when they
had their first jobs, girls were more likely than boys to have to surrender a
larger share of their earnings to the family budget. Teenage men also began
to insist more loudly on their economic independence. Reports exist from the
region around Esslingen in southwestern Germany about “young insolent
lads, who gave improper expression of their sense of freedom on Sundays at
the local ale-house.”33 Other parents were said to be glad if they got hold of
the weekly wage “without deductions and were able to determine the amount
of their sons’ and daughters’ pocket money.” Siblings were also treated differently when it came to further education or training. Here sisters often had
to defer to the needs of their brothers—a treatment that daughters of middleclass parents might also find themselves subjected to, especially if high
school fees exceeded the financial means of the family.
Among the lower classes, however, not even the boys had many opportunities to remain in school beyond the primary level. Therefore, most tried to
find apprenticeships, while many of the girls would sign up as servants. Still,
working-class youths lived by and large a somewhat happier life than they
had had in their early childhood. With respect to their developing adolescent
sexuality, it may even be said that they were less inhibited in expressing it
than their bourgeois counterparts, especially middle-class girls. The latter were
often more restricted by the religious norms of their parents. On the whole,
however, our knowledge of sexuality among middle-class teenagers is limited and generally confined to what can be gleaned from memoirs or contemporary advice on puberty and sanctions against such “sins” as masturbation.
In the memoirs of educated women we may find references to the start of
menstruation or to the long years of waiting and celibacy at a time when the
average marriage age for women was twenty-four to twenty-five. For many of
these women, these were the years of further education or of preparation for
eventual marriage.
The quite high illegitimacy rates reflect,34 at least in part, a lack of an elementary sex education. On this point, most parents tended to be mute and too
embarrassed to talk to their children. In lower-class families, where life revolved around the kitchen and one or two bedrooms, children could not avoid
becoming witnesses to their parents’ sexuality. Or they would by chance observe an elder sister, a lodger, or, on the farm, servants or land laborers engaging in sex. The idea that children were brought by the stork was most likely
to persist longest among boys and girls from middle- and upper-class backgrounds who had fewer opportunities to come across adults in sexual situations. However, sooner or later even they would pick up the basic information
from their older friends or in the school grounds. While parents and teachers
would warn against the dangers of venereal disease, advice on unwanted pregnancies would be most easily available outside the family. Also largely ex76

Issues of Generation and Socialization

cluded from public discourse were questions of homosexuality. After the turn
of the century, adolescents organized in the Youth Movement started to raise
these topics as serious issues. Meanwhile the older debate on the advantages
and disadvantages of separating the sexes in schools also continued.
In rural areas, the sexual behavior of young people was furthermore regulated by traditions that varied from region to region. In the south, Fensterln
(climbing through the window into a woman’s bedroom) was practiced as a
courting ritual, ending, not always but frequently, in sexual intercourse. If an
unwanted pregnancy resulted, the couple would enter into marriage, which in
many cases had been previously agreed upon. In this respect, Schwärmen
(swarming) was safer, a practice by which young men would roam through
the village and visit the young women in their bedrooms in groups. The
so-called Spinnstuben (spinning sessions) were similarly policed by the adolescents themselves but, at a time of increasing sexual freedom, would occasionally get out of hand. This may partly explain the survival of Katzenmusik
(cats’ music), which was aimed at publicly humiliating and condemning
members of the village community who were suspected of having violated
local sexual norms. Many of these practices were, of course, impossible to
uphold in the anonymity of large industrial cities. And yet it might happen
even there that workers would perform “cats’ music” for a colleague who had
reneged on a marriage promise. In some parts of Upper Bavaria around the
towns of Miesbach and Bad Tölz, the custom of well-organized Haberfeldtreiben (charivaris) continued that were directed against “fallen maidens”
and young couples who had diverged from local norms for sexual behavior.
However, what also came to the surface in such practices in the years before
1914 were conflicts between young people and the irritated local police authorities who were often called to the scene.
Conflicts between parents and their teenage children also arose, not least
because the low life expectancy frequently produced early widowhood and
remarriages, with the resulting problems associated with step-parenthood.
Conflicts across three generations, on the other hand, were rare, because not
many children ever got to know both their grandparents. If the grandparents
lived to see their grandchildren as adults, the relationship was often one of
respect and mutual support. Only after the turn of the century, with rising life
expectancy, did the hitherto positive image of the elderly undergo some change.
Now help from the younger family became vital for many of the aged. The
benefits of the old-age insurance schemes were still very meager for the insured and more so for their widows (Tables 75, 77).35 In 1907, no more than
17 percent of all men over the age of seventy actually received a pension.
Among the retired self-employed and rentiers it was at least 32 percent.
The middle classes also had a higher capacity to put some of their money
into savings. All this meant that many elderly people had to carry on work77

Society

ing for as long as they could manage, preferably in occupations that did not
require much physical exertion. This was also the age when men and women
would begin to suffer from many smaller ailments, if not from more serious
illnesses, for which medication was either unavailable or too expensive for a
low-income person. Some had to think twice about whether they could afford
a visit to a doctor. If one had been permanently disabled by a work-related
accident, the insurance system that had been established under Bismarck
might pay a small pension. Apart from the wealthy, who did not have to worry
about getting the best treatment or a spa cure after an illness, civil servants,
whether still active or retired, probably enjoyed the most generous benefits.
Their medical care as well as their retirement pensions had been taken over
entirely by the state.
Furthermore, there was the problem of loneliness, from which many elderly people suffered. Chances were high for those who lived beyond the age
of fifty that they would lose their spouses early. In the villages, custom and
tradition made it relatively easy to keep the aged integrated into the community and provided for. The cities’ rental barracks made this much more difficult, though not impossible. Many a widow became an ersatz granny to a
young family next door. At a time when the offerings in affordable leisure
activities for the elderly were few and boredom could be debilitating, these
relationships were welcome, also because they gave a sense of purpose to a
widow’s life. Since economic factors were so crucial in a retired person’s
lifestyle, the middle and upper classes generally found themselves in appreciably better situations. Independent peasants had greater security because
they remained owners until the farmstead was either handed over to the eldest son or divided up among the children. But even thereafter the aged parents would continue to live on the farm and, if possible, lend a helping hand.
Meanwhile retirees of the urban bourgeoisie had plenty of time to meet
with their friends in clubs, restaurants, or at the Stammtisch, a table in the local pub for the regular notables. For well-to-do widows an afternoon out
among friends with coffee and cream cake in one of the cafés in town would
be a welcome distraction. Elderly noblemen could count on the continued
respect of the younger members of their families, and among the high aristocracy the most senior person of the clan had, as the “head of the house,”
far-reaching powers with respect to the management of family property and
marriage policy.
B. Generations and Generational Conflicts
Many of the elderly found the rapid pace of change in society and economy
in the German Empire worrisome. If the young impatiently pushed toward
new frontiers, the elderly wanted to preserve “what had proven its worth.”
Since the work of Karl Mannheim, generational research has started from the
78

Issues of Generation and Socialization

assumption that it is historical experiences and socialization into a certain era
that binds members of several cohorts together as a generation.36 Since later
generations will have undergone a social and ideological experience different from that of their elders, conflicts are likely to arise. To some extent, the
history of Imperial Germany may be illuminated with the help of this model.
Certainly, there was something like a Gründergeneration that had supported
the founding of the Bismarckian empire and the historic compromises forged
during the 1860s and 1870s. Faced with the period of retarded growth in the
1880s, this generation continued to be convinced that the main task was to
consolidate what had been achieved in 1871. However, it must be added that
this consensus was not shared by all large social groups. Industrial workers
of this generation, especially if they were Social Democrats and experienced
constant police harassment, would hardly have agreed that consolidation was
the most important objective of the age.
Beyond this significant intra-generational conflict, a younger generation
was growing up in the 1880s that was keen to move to new shores in domestic and foreign policy as well as in cultural taste.37 Wilhelm II, who ascended
to the throne in 1888 at the age of twenty-nine, has generally been regarded
as the embodiment of a different sensibility and Weltanschauung than that of
the Gründergeneration. Both tendencies can be traced most clearly through
the broad spectrum of the middle classes, while our knowledge of generational conflict within the industrial working class remains rudimentary.
This does not mean that tensions did not emerge between working-class
parents and children—fathers and sons, mothers and daughters. But their
concerns were different. Faced with innumerable discriminations to which
industrial workers were exposed socially, economically, and politically,
young workers, it appears, began to rebel against what was to them the excessive caution and conservatism of their fathers and of the Social Democratic leadership in particular. Spurred on by much bitterness and youthful
fervor, exacerbated by the promulgation of the antisocialist laws of 1878,
some of them were even prepared to accept further persecution for their acerbic criticism of conditions under the Hohenzollern monarchy. Many of the
older generation, who had a longer experience facing police brutality and
who moreover had to think of the wellbeing of their families, thought this
radicalism dangerous and self-destructive. They also had high hopes, which
soon turned out to be illusory, that the young emperor as the representative
of the Wilhelmine generation would be a Kaiser of reform and of the workers of Germany. Indeed, Wilhelm II, in his desire to set himself apart from
the Bismarckian generation, had at first presented himself as the man of a
fresh start. Young workers had always been more skeptical of the Kaiser’s determination to initiate fundamental change, and they turned out to be correct
in their doubts.
79

Society

After the turn of the century yet another generation began to raise its voice
against the spirit of the Wilhelmine age, albeit with different arguments from
those advanced by working-class activists. However, the members of this
generation did not reach positions of power before the outbreak of World War
I to a degree that would have enabled them to influence events in tangible
ways. Instead they became the “Generation of 1914”38, whose world of ideas—
hardened and partly transformed on the battlefields on the Western front, as
will be seen in Part V—helped shape the Weimar Republic’s ideological climate and political culture. Still, their critique of the status quo began before
1914 and—as far as the middle-class adolescents among them were concerned—found a rallying point in the Youth Movement. These were the young
rebels who felt alienated from the self-satisfied materialism, the cold profitoriented rationality, and the plush lifestyle of the Wilhelmine generation.
Thus, segments of Germany’s middle-class youth set out in search of alternatives that tended to emphasize the romantic and irrational, that discovered
nature and longed for human warmth in what they saw as an age of heartless
technology. Some found themselves on the flight from reality.39 But much of
this activity remained confined to weekends during which they went on hiking trips and, in the evening by the fireside, talked about Eros and eternity or,
accompanied by the guitar, sang songs from the Zupfgeigenhansl collection.
Many of them also found themselves fleeing from an age of the “masses” and
of democracy. They displayed a strong elitism and were receptive to charismatic leadership. With respect to this elitism and their social backgrounds,
members of the bourgeois Youth Movement were distinctly different from
the “proletarian Generation of 1914” that became organized in Young Socialist associations. Even if both movements encouraged reformist ideas, with
the growing polarization of German society in the years before 1914, the dialogue between them also became more difficult. It was only in the trenches
of World War I that the members of this generation stood next to each other
again and jointly faced the carnage of total war around them.
C. Agents of Socialization: Family, School, Churches, Apprenticeship,
Military Service, High School, University
As in other European societies, family and school, religion and occupational
training, universal military service and the educational system played important roles as agents of socialization, partly mediating and partly exacerbating
generational tensions. Historians have pleaded, however, that we not apply
the concept of socialization too widely and that we differentiate between
socialization’s divergent levels and phases.40 If the family is the first institution for the transmission of general societal norms, the younger generation is
introduced to the sphere of politics only later during the school years. The
assembly of all these and other influences into a more coherent Weltanschau80

Issues of Generation and Socialization

ung is then assumed to occur during a final third phase. Above all, while it
cannot be stressed too strongly that in the Kaiserreich social origins made a
considerable difference in people’s lives, it must also be emphasized that the
various agents of socialization had contradictory impacts on the young. On
the one hand, they promoted the integration of the next generation into the
existing society; on the other hand, we are dealing with institutions against
which the young rebelled. Indeed, in many cases it was an explicit or tacit
critique of their experiences with these institutions that incited their resolve
to do things differently once they had reached adulthood.
For most children, the family was the organization that helped them adapt
to their immediate environment and to the existing order in the widest sense
of the word. Children of the rural or urban lower classes, who had to contribute to the family income, were moreover slowly conditioned to the routine of the workday and the regularity of economic processes. The family
milieu also left its traces in the way the young learned to interact with others, to eat, to drink, to sleep, to spend their leisure time. Solidly bourgeois
parents instilled in their children values and conventions of social intercourse
that were in many ways markedly different from those of working-class parents. As a rule, they also equipped their offspring with a better capacity to get
ahead in life, to articulate themselves, to seize opportunities, and to master a
crisis. To be sure, too much sheltering might have left middle-class children
ill-prepared to weather setbacks. Nor would it be right to draw too idyllic a
picture of the bourgeois family as an agent of socialization, with its fundamentally patriarchal structure and marriages that frequently existed only on
paper.
Yet, however effective the mechanisms of integration may have been,
family life and the assertion of parental authority also offered many points of
friction that reinforced a youthful tendency to rebel as a way of finding one’s
identity. Frequently, and particularly in those “fatherless” families in which
the breadwinner was present only in the evening, children were liable to feel
alienated. In rural areas and the cities’ industrial quarters this alienation would
find its clearest expression in the fact that many children would leave the
home soon after finishing their basic compulsory education or because they
had been turfed out by an irate father. If, for whatever reason, they stayed at
home, they would at most put in a fleeting appearance at dinnertime. They
would spend their free time in loosely organized groups or gangs. Even in
those days, adults would complain loudly about the loutish Halbstarke. The
boys among them would be open to the influence of a charismatic ersatz father, whom they would find in those gangs or in one of the religious or secular youth groups that mushroomed especially during the Wilhelmine period.
Girls, insofar as they did not join a coeducational or single-sex youth group,
would “hang out” among themselves or with one of the male gangs. Occa81

Society

sionally it might also happen that the youngsters who were looking for role
models would become fascinated by one of their teachers.
Most schools, however, tended to project a different model in which the
teacher appeared as the stern drillmaster. School was not merely the place
where basic rote learning was systematically instilled by repetition, with the
effect—inter alia and in this case no doubt positive—that illiteracy rates were
reduced to practically zero (Table 49). Still, next to the family, school served
as a major agent of socialization. The dramatist Gerhard Hauptmann has
given a vivid description of the military style of his primary school, with its
rigid discipline. Even Wilhelm II complained bitterly in his memoirs about
how, in his youth, the uninspiring approach taken by his private tutor Georg
Hinzpeter in dissecting the classical texts of antiquity had killed off whatever
interest he may have had in them. And Wilhelm did not have to sit in overcrowded classes.
Indeed, to some extent, the stress on discipline was a function of very unfavorable staff-student ratios and of many one-class primary schools. Almost
twenty years after the founding of the Empire, over half of Prussia’s 4.5 million pupils attended village schools in which all age-groups were instructed
in a single room (Table 50). Meanwhile class-sizes in cities were in many
cases over 100 students. As late as 1911, in the new industrial cities of the
Ruhr and in Upper Silesia, there were on average 50 to 60 students for every
1 teacher. Only in towns with strong middle-class populations, such as Wiesbaden or Berlin-Wilmersdorf, did class-sizes drop meanwhile to 43 and 37
pupils respectively.
Apart from purveying a knowledge of the Three R’s, the state had traditionally used schools as institutions of ideological indoctrination. The educational policies adopted after 1871 continued this practice. It reached a new
level of intensity after Wilhelm II ascended to the throne. In May 1889, he
issued a cabinet order that warned of the dangers to society and political stability posed by Social Democratic ideas and demanded that efforts be redoubled
to instill conservative-monarchical values in the young. Shortly thereafter,
discussions began on a new curriculum that was unveiled two years later.
German was to be given greater emphasis vis-à-vis other languages. The revamping of history and religious studies, it was hoped, would lend support to
the traditions of the Hohenzollern monarchy. The success of these educational policies may have been greater at the beginning than in later years. This
raises the question of whether primary education remained no more than a
“school for the production of subjects” (“Schule der Untertanen”).41
The indications are that school had a more ambiguous effect on pupils because not all their teachers were monarchist drill sergeants. First there arose
a growing teachers’ rebellion against political interference from the top. As
Marjorie Lamberti has shown, teachers developed their own professional ethos
82

Issues of Generation and Socialization

and standards and insisted on applying them.42 Many of them, confronted daily
with the poverty and poor preparation of their pupils, also turned toward a reformist Left liberalism. They questioned the wisdom of offering crude patriotic indoctrination to pupils and tried to gain the trust not only of their students
but also of their working-class parents. Meanwhile the struggle was well underway to provide opportunities for advanced education to middle-class girls. The
female teachers who, through their work, were committed to this idea also
acted as role models for their charges. Their lives contradicted prevailing male
notions of femininity and the position of women in society, if we discount the
relatively small number of liberal-minded parents who encouraged their daughters to prepare themselves for university study. Indeed, the success of indoctrination through school also depended on whether the family reinforced
ministerial policies or acted as a counterweight to them. The latter is more
likely to have been the case in households where the father (and perhaps also
the mother) were left-leaning liberals or Social Democrats than in middleclass families where the parents were loyal monarchists and church-goers.
Nor should we underestimate the contribution to children’s socialization
made by regular attendance of churches and Sunday schools. In Germany’s
Protestant regions, it was the peculiar link between church and state, the alliance of throne and altar, that fostered a conservative orientation of the young
who were searching for a religio. Although the Kulturkampf, the struggle of
the Liberals and Bismarck in the 1870s against the “ultramontane” influences
of the Catholic Church, had complicated relations between religious institutions and the secular authorities in Germany, this was more true in Prussia
than it was in, say, Bavaria. Church communities there did not see a contradiction between being a good Catholic and being a loyal supporter of the
Wittelsbach monarchy. Moreover, the local Catholic clergy remained in most
cases the representatives of a very conservative institution whose influence
on the formation of norms and values in children was considerable. Lay
Catholics, who began to organize in the 1890s in the hope of affecting reforms within the church and of promoting a new relationship between church
and state, could not seriously undermine the prevailing conservative mood in
which ritualized piety was an important element.
Nevertheless, the fact that this lay movement gained increasing support in
the years before 1914 points to a generational change. Many who had been
raised in a very strict, hierarchical Catholic milieu now pushed for a modification of what they had been taught on Sundays or in preparation for their
first communion. Although anticlericalism never became as strong as in
France, the move of many Catholic workers toward the Social Democrats
may also be taken as a sign that the church as an agent of socialization triggered contradictory responses among the younger generation. The tensions
that this induced probably affected men more than women. Certainly the lat83

Society

ter remained more firmly attached to the orthodoxies of both the major Christian denominations and also continued to attend church more regularly. The
Jewish experience also reflected these tendencies. Here the strict regime of
rules and rituals among Orthodox congregations was increasingly challenged
by the proliferation of liberal ideas, and many intellectual Jews abandoned
institutional affiliations altogether. In short, generational change and the contradictory impact of religious conservatism were clearly interrelated.
After finishing school, many young people underwent apprenticeships
through which they were socialized into the world of work. In the workshops
adolescents would not only learn the rules of precision and craftsmanship,
but also of behavior in a professional hierarchy. Still, many apprentices,
faced with the petty authoritarianism of their masters or journeymen, must
have sworn to themselves to organize things differently once they had workshops of their own. Whether this rebellious determination was eventually put
into practice was another matter. Later, in many cases, the weight of tradition
and the greater convenience of rulings from the top overrode the erstwhile
reformist zeal. There was also the problem that many handicrafts were threatened by the rise of the factory, and more generally an apprenticeship presumably never had the same importance as family and school for the socialization
of the young. Industry and commerce, it is true, jumped into the breach by
developing their own training systems. But they and the network of occupational training schools (Berufsschulen) that was established were more interested in expert knowledge than in conservative indoctrination. Nor was the
mindset of those who saw further training as an avenue for upward mobility
ever such that they were open to rebellion and radical ideas.
Finally, universal military service channeled thousands of young men year
after year, for a period of service lasting twenty-four months, into an organization built on conservative traditions. No doubt, this experience had a profound effect on many of them. In the army the importance of obedience and
punctuality were drilled into them. Men from very different regional and social backgrounds were thrown together in the confining spaces of a garrison
and forced to work out a modus vivendi. A large proportion of them came
from the country’s rural regions, once the Prussian War Ministry showed an
increasing reluctance to draft urban youth, who were suspected of harboring
Social Democratic sympathies. Meanwhile many sons of the bourgeoisie succeeded in getting deferments. Thus, the army came to be seen as the “school
of the nation,” where poorly educated young men from the provinces were
filled up with conservative notions about the Hohenzollern monarchy and national unity. “Whoever has influence over the youth, has command of the
army” was a later Social Democrat slogan; but as an insight and motto it applied conversely to the officer corps that considered itself charged with upholding the existing order in its conservative and monarchical form.43
84

Issues of Generation and Socialization

For a long time the army relied on the quasi-automatic formative influence of military service as a “duty to the Fatherland.” By the 1890s, however,
this indirect socialization came to be regarded as insufficient. For a number
of years, formal patriotic instruction was introduced in which officers gave
their recruits rather one-sided and potted versions of the course of German
history and of contemporary politics. Soon some of the students, who had experienced different realities in the slums of the big cities and who had come
into contact with Social Democratic ideas, began to ask pointed and embarrassing questions. They were questions that left the mostly upper-class officers either helpless or seduced into giving provocative answers. Slowly, even
the politically less sophisticated recruits started to think about what they
were hearing. The infamous Zabern Affair of 1913 was in fact triggered by
an indoctrination lesson that went terribly awry.44 Meanwhile, the contradictions of socialization through the military also came to the surface as more
and more details about the “maltreatment” of soldiers were made public and
became a matter of public debate. Suspecting a ubiquitous revolutionary threat,
the army reverted to well-worn methods: searches of lockers for subversive
propaganda material and bans on frequenting certain public houses in the
vicinity of the garrison.
Overall, the mechanisms of socialization discussed so far nevertheless
proved powerful enough to promote a basic identification by a majority of
the population with the existing order and its institutions. True, there was a
growing number of voters who supported a reform of the political system;
but only a few aimed to overcome the Hohenzollern monarchy through revolutionary means. This also explains why so many millions joined up, enthusiastically or pensively, when a war broke out in 1914 that had been presented
to them as a war in defense of the Fatherland.45 Nor would one wish to deny
that the army achieved considerable successes with its methods of training
and socialization if we look at its purely military achievements and its capacity to keep millions of men fighting a very costly war until the “military
strike” of 1918 ushered in the final collapse of the Kaiserreich. School and
military service certainly contributed to a nationalization of the population.
But this nationalization also involved a division into alleged patriots, on the
one hand, and “unpatriotic fellows,” on the other, and hence contributed to a
polarization of German society that will emerge in subsequent chapters.
For a small minority, high school and tertiary education finally constituted
important socialization experiences (Table 51). All three types of high school
that proliferated in Imperial Germany experienced an expansion in the number of students. The figure for Prussian Gymnasien increased from 63,200 in
1873 to over 103,000 in 1911. The figures for the second type, the Realgymnasium, almost doubled to 48,100. Finally, the Oberrealschulen grew tenfold
from 4,120 in 1882. Of course, such rises must be correlated to the popula85

Society

tion explosion in this period. In this respect inequalities diminished, but participation rates nevertheless remained very low. If in 1870 0.4 percent of the
total population went to high school, the figure for 1900 was 2.7 percent, rising to 3.2 percent by 1911. High schools remained dominated by the middle
classes, the more so since school fees were high enough to remain beyond
the reach of many lower-class families. This was also true of high schools for
girls. While the impact of the latter on their charges may have been more ambiguous, boys’ high schools remained agencies of socialization that influenced most of their students in a conservative and elitist direction, especially
where the emphasis was on the value of a “humanist” education centered on
Greek and Latin. Only the Oberrealschulen may be said to have provided
their students with an education that was more geared toward a future in an
industrial-technological society. It was also the type of high school frequently
seen by lower middle-class and middle-class parents as an avenue of upward
mobility for their sons. If their daughters made it to a girls’ high school, the
expectation was that they would come out as better educated mothers who
would be able to offer their children a more nurturing environment.
The dividing lines that the school system introduced were reinforced by
the tertiary sector. In 1891, there were just under 34,000 university students
in the Reich. By 1912, that number had risen to 71,710 (Table 52). In 1871,
some 0.5 percent of the population had an academic education. By 1900 this
share had increased to 0.9 percent, rising further to 1.3 percent in 1910. This
small minority received first of all a systematic scholarly training in a chosen
field that provided a springboard for a comparatively well-paying position in
the private or public sector later on. The exclusiveness of higher education
also strengthened in university students an elite consciousness that had first
been instilled by parents and in high schools. This was the third phase of socialization during which many students consolidated their ideological commitments, and most of them ultimately became defenders of the status quo.
Nor were the lectures of their professors free from ideology and politics.46
To be sure, higher education also bred rebels, who, if nothing more, advocated
social and political reforms. But they must be juxtaposed with the large numbers of students who, when it came to their political beliefs, adhered to an aggressive nationalism toward the outside world and to a dichotomous view of
domestic politics that divided society into large blocs of Right and Left.47
Fraternities represented an organizational focus for these nationalist tendencies, attracting a considerable, though declining, percentage of the students
(Table 86). At Marburg University over 50 percent of the students were members in 1873. In 1913, the share was a little over 45 percent. At Bonn, the
share slumped from around 56 percent in the late 1880s to 40 percent during
the final years before World War I. In Berlin, by contrast, around 75 percent
of the students never joined a fraternity throughout the same period. Yet, how86

Minorities and Majorities

ever interesting these latter figures may be, because they undermine the widespread later impression that virtually all German students were fraternity members, the ideological force of the student subculture radiated well beyond those
fraternities. By the turn of the century, even the sports fraternities (Turnerschaften) that had their roots in the liberal era of the first half of the nineteenth
century had moved away from their earlier ideals and had adjusted their styles
and outlook to the more conservative Korps and Landsmannschaften.
By 1914, many of their members propounded an integral nationalism and
supported illiberal policies at home. Meanwhile the largely conservative “old
boys” paid for the maintenance of fraternity houses and tried to be helpful
when it came to career-planning for younger fraternity “brothers.” Their
presence also saw to it that new recruits integrated themselves into the conservative consensus that permeated higher education in the German Empire.
Contemporary critics of the tertiary sector as a socialization agent never tired
of pointing to its role as a breeding ground for a profound disdain of the
“masses.” This is where social divisions were in fact deepened “from above.”
It has been said in retrospect that the German university system was relatively more open when compared with the institutions of tertiary education
in other European countries. Even if correct, this did not mean that it prevented rather than reinforced the illiberal elitism that many of its students
and professors came to advocate.

8. Minorities and Majorities
A. Basic Issues
In trying to understand the development of German society during the decades
before 1914 it is helpful to study the situation of women, young people, and
the elderly, as we have just done. But no less telling is how those individuals
and groups living as minorities in Germany were treated and how ordinary
citizens and those in positions of power and influence reacted to them. On
the one hand, this raises the question of how far the majority was prepared to
permit the integration of minorities, a process not to be confused with assimilation; or, alternatively, how far the majority tried to ostracize the minorities
in their midst. Integration, in short, implies acceptance of difference, of the
“other.”
The second question is related to the willingness of minorities to assimilate and adapt to the majority society around them. In other words, the concepts of integration and assimilation are not being used interchangeably here,
but as complementarities, as a way of looking at the relationship between
majorities and minorities from opposite angles. However, our knowledge of
certain marginal groups like homosexuals remains quite limited even today
87

Society

and therefore cannot be dealt with here in any detail. The important general
point to be made about homosexuals in the context of our discussion is that,
in principle, their interactions with the majority society also fall within the
analytical framework presented here.
What complicates the analysis is that homosexuals were ostracized by the
majority to the point of being treated as criminals. This meant that even a homosexual relationship between consenting adults could only exist in the
shadows. However, it is a sign of the larger sociocultural ferment on Wilhelmine society that a public debate on this question began in the 1890s, if not
before. In 1897, the physician and sexologist Magnus Hirschfeld founded a
“Scientific-Humanitarian Committee” that advocated the reform of Paragraph 175 of the Criminal Code, the clause that criminalized homosexuality.
The idea was taken up in January 1898 by August Bebel, the leader of the
Social Democrats, when, in a statement in the Reichstag, he supported the introduction of legislation to this effect. Not surprisingly, his proposal was
flatly rejected by the other parties. Instead the Conservatives incorporated the
issue in a campaign to uphold prevailing norms of morality—a campaign that
the North American historian John Fout has seen as a manifestation of a
larger crisis in gender relations and of masculinity.
Research on another minority—the criminal “underworld”—faces similar
problems. The group was by definition also subterranean, but it raised fundamental questions of judicial philosophy and practice. Was the application of
justice primarily based on deterrence and retribution or on rehabilitation and
the reintegration of ex-criminals into society? Again German society began
to debate these issues, all the more so since many felonies were in effect
committed by those living in abject poverty, as recent social-history research
has reminded us. Quite obviously such felonies cannot be explained by invoking biologistic theories concerning the criminal behavior of marginal groups
or notions of urban decadence that were promoted at the time. As happened
with other minorities, myths, misperceptions, and scapegoating proved difficult to change by invoking reality. Today we know that the highest rates of
property crimes and crimes involving bodily harm (including murder) were
recorded not for the big cities (with Berlin representing the sole exception)
but for the rural parts of the Prussian East.48
B. The Catholic Minority
The Catholic population of the Kaiserreich represented by far the largest minority. In 1871 over 62 percent of the population were Protestants, and 36 percent belonged to the Catholic Church (Table 38). Until 1910 a slight shift
occurred in this imbalance in favor of the Catholics. However, there were considerable regional variations. In Hamburg and Saxony the number of Catholics per 10,000 population was a mere 503 and 491 respectively. In Bavaria,
88

Minorities and Majorities

Baden, and Alsace-Lorraine, on the other hand, the Catholics were in the majority, as they were in a number of Prussian provinces (West Prussia, Posen,
Silesia, Westphalia, Rhineland, and Hohenzollern).
Our analysis of denominational developments would be badly flawed if
we were to use these latter regions to construct a majority position for Catholicism. Both within the whole of Prussia and the Reich, Protestants not
only held the numerical majority, but they also enjoyed predominance in qualitative terms of power and influence. In Prussia, Protestantism had long been
recognized as the official faith. The alliance of throne and altar turned the
Protestant Church into an instrument of the state, although it would be wrong
to assume that this gave Protestants unlimited discriminatory leverage against
minorities. Still, it is undeniable that the victory of the Prussian army and state
over Catholic Austria in 1866 was also seen as a triumph of Protestantism.
In the Catholic south, the sense of defeat was temporarily overcome by the
wave of enthusiasm that swept through these states at the time of the FrancoPrussian War. But soon thereafter Bismarck and his Liberal allies launched
the Kulturkampf in their quest to weld the new federal Germany together on
a Prussian and Protestant basis. In pursuit of this strategy, it seemed promising to portray Catholics as the “enemies of the Reich.” Instead of trying to
integrate a minority, the majority began to ostracize it to provide an additional glue for the creation of the Prusso-German constitutional order.
As a result, this struggle, whose political dimensions will be discussed
later,49 temporarily came to assume very menacing proportions for the Catholics and their church, and its traumatic memory lived on long after Bismarck
had quietly abandoned the conflict by the 1880s. After this unpropitious start,
whose aim on the part of the majority had been to exclude the Catholic minority, the denominational question remained on the agenda. At a very general
level, the difficulties that continued to face Catholics can be neatly illustrated
by comparing patterns of social mobility. In education—a channel of upward
mobility, albeit a limited one—the participation rate of Catholics in high schools
and universities was significantly lower than that of Protestants. However, the
fact that this lower participation rate applied not only to Protestant Prussia
but also to Catholic Bavaria indicates that additional factors came into the
equation that had more to do with the prevailing Catholic social milieu than
with actual discrimination by the Protestant majority.
Thus, most Catholic high school students, and even more so pupils at Catholic girls’ schools, were geared toward rather more traditional personal objectives. Of the young women registered as first-year students at Prussian
universities in 1910, only 7.1 percent were Catholic, with the Jewish share
being more than twice as high (Table 54). A noticeable gap also remained
when it came to signing up for science and economics courses. All in all, it
may be said that the professional ethos of Catholics was more “preindustrial”
89

Society

than that of the Protestant bourgeoisie. Although by 1914 this ethos had come
under the pressure of change, few Catholics seem to have been oriented toward the many currents of modernity and the opportunities they offered to
young people. The repercussions of this attitude may be gleaned from data
on the professions and on industry. As late as 1910, the share of Catholic attorneys was a mere 12 percent. Catholics were also strongly underrepresented
among entrepreneurs.
On the other hand, as regards the civil service, not only social background
and lower educational attainment proved to be handicaps, but also political
and ideological discrimination. Thus in 1907, Catholics, in terms of the total
population, were lagging behind Protestants by as much as 17 percent when
it came to positions in the higher civil service and in the professoriat. Of the
cadets who entered the navy between 1895 and 1914, only 14 percent were
Catholic. There are many indications that these discrepancies had socioeconomic and political causes. In promoting civil servants, it was quite clear that
Protestant superiors, guided by their latent anti-Catholicism, quietly discriminated against Catholics, who faced the blanket accusation that they were ideologically unreliable and not sufficiently loyal to the Reich. Their loyalties
were allegedly with the Vatican, that power beyond the Alps (hence “ultramontane”), and not focused on serving the secular German national state.
Social background remained important both subjectively and objectively.
Statistics clearly show that the majority of Catholics lived in the Reich’s rural regions and small towns, and we have already seen that opportunities for
upward mobility were few for this population, even if they were Protestants.50
In other words, denominational discrepancies in terms of upward mobility
were less stark for groups at the bottom of the social pyramid. However, the
picture is different when a comparison is made between the two denominations with regard to the middle classes. Here discrimination based on politics
and ideology was probably most blatant. But again there was a difference
that cannot be reduced to “extra-religious facts” but rather resulted from different “value notions, mentalities, [and] behavior.”51
These intangibles were, as Thomas Nipperdey has argued, partly responsible “for a measure of a stronger motivation among Protestants to be mobile
and dynamic, [to be interested] in science and [a better] education.” Catholics, by contrast, were less “individualized and professionalized, more traditionalist and less oriented toward upward mobility and success and toward
career planning.” At the same time they were “better integrated into social
groups and more affirmative toward life.” Apart from highlighting the differences in professional ethics between Catholics and Protestants, scholars have
sought to support their findings by pointing out that Catholics had larger
families and a lower suicide rate.52 They may have been well integrated into
their local Catholic milieu, though not into the larger Protestant-dominated
90

Minorities and Majorities

nation. The latter was an objective that their political leaders pursued with
varying success from the 1890s to the end of the monarchy.
The discussion so far raises two questions: how prepared were the Protestant majority and its leaders in state and society to integrate the Catholic minority? And how far was the latter capable and willing to adapt its milieu and
cultural behavior to the majority that was so eagerly promoting industrialization, urbanization, and secularization (that is, forces that the Vatican eyed
with great suspicion)? Especially with regard to secularization the Catholic
Church in Germany remained conservatively dogmatic, defensive, and authoritarian. Seen in this perspective, the Kulturkampf was more than a political
conflict. It represented a clash with the forces of modernization that labored
for the “demystification of the world” (as Max Weber put it) and whose spearhead were the Liberals. The church was very reluctant to conclude an armistice, much less peace, with these forces after the end of the Kulturkampf.
And so the suspicions between the Protestant majority and Catholic minority continued, and Wilhelm II repeatedly articulated them from his Prussian
perspective.
Catholicism proved more flexible when it came to the problem of industrialization and its consequences. Above all, there was the “workers’ question” and how it might be tackled. The majority of middle-class Protestants had
little sympathy for the workers’ desire to form associations to represent their
interests. The Vatican adopted a different position, even if took until 1891 to
enshrine it in a papal encyclical. Thenceforth Catholics were called upon to
be conscious of their social responsibility, and the welfare work undertaken
by Catholic priests among the poor and in the Reich’s industrial regions became a task sanctioned at the highest level.
However, there were two sides to the 1891 encyclical. On the one hand, it
marked the church’s step toward accepting the industrial revolution, which
seemed unstoppable; on the other, it drew a line not only against Marxist
recipes for solving the “workers’ question,” but also against Protestantism.
Here lies the other root for a growing sense that Catholicism was confined to
a “beleaguered tower” that the Center Party politician Julius Bachem wanted
it to abandon when in 1906 he made public his famous appeal to this effect.
After the turn of the century, this striving for greater openness toward the rest
of society and for integration seemed realistic, not least because Protestant
discrimination was softening, at least up to 1907. To be sure, the Kaiser and
many conservative politicians remained convinced that Catholicism and the
Center Party (its increasingly more important political arm) received their orders from the Vatican. Undeterred by this hostility, the Center Party’s leadership nevertheless sought cooperation with other political forces in the hope
of breaking through the isolation that, it must once more be added, had also
been a consequence of its self-imposed retreat into the “tower.” Nothing sup91

Society

ported the Bachem line more than the impressive growth of Catholic lay associations, whose membership increased to the point where they could no
longer simply be ignored or ostracized.
If the Protestant majority showed a willingness to integrate the Catholic
minority, it was, of course, also because it was so sizeable and, in the age of
universal suffrage, potentially influential. Conversely, Catholics felt the pressure to adapt to the majority. In the final analysis, this pressure was generated by constant change in society and the economy, which eroded traditional
hierarchies and milieus. Clericalism was losing ground; the lay movement was
gaining it. A rift began to run through Catholicism. The hierarchy’s warnings
about the dangers of modern life went unheeded. Illegitimacy rates edged up
in some Catholic regions.53 There was a decline in the attendance of services,
even if Catholic priests on the whole had more success in upholding church
discipline than their Protestant counterparts. The share of female church-goers
was considerably higher than that of male Catholics. Between 1900 and 1912,
the share of young male church-goers is estimated to have declined from 90
to 60 percent. In Munich attendance at Easter communion dropped to around
50 percent during the late 1880s. Few, however, officially declared that they
had left the church. Similarly, for many Catholics it was a matter of course
that their children would be baptized and receive first communion at the appropriate time. Over 90 percent of Catholics did not wish to hold a wedding
or funeral without the assistance of a priest.
Taking a bird’s eye view, it appears that the old tensions between the Protestant majority and the Catholic minority did diminish over time. In realms
where one denomination far outnumbered the other, competition was less
fierce than in mixed areas. Catholics began to catch up with Protestants as regards their position in social and economic life. The bitter struggle of the
1870s slowly faded from memory, and a new generation came of age. Ideologically speaking, “Godless” Marxism appeared to be the greater danger in
the last years before the war. State and church moved more closely together
as they rallied the German Empire against internal and external enemies.
These developments, which point to a better integration of Catholicism
into the mainstream, must not mislead us into thinking, however, that the distinct cultural characteristics of the Catholic minority also began to disappear.
There was some adaptation to the political and social currents of the time.
Like other groups, Catholics tried, from the 1890s onward, to create a mass
base for themselves. This was the hour of the “People’s Association for Catholic Germany,” which, when founded in 1890, made the struggle against
Social Democrats one of its primary objectives. The main target shifted away
from the Liberals toward the working-class movement.
In the long run, therefore, Catholicism in Imperial Germany became more
modern and less insular. Yet there was never any question as to whether it
92

Minorities and Majorities

should allow itself to be absorbed into the Protestant majority culture. The Catholic minority culture may have become more similar to that of Protestantism,
and yet it had no wish to be assimilated by it. A clearly identifiable Catholic
milieu continued to exist in which tradition and innovation combined into a
distinctive cultural mix, and not even this mix was uniform. In more remote
rural areas, tradition remained the stronger element. There the position of the
austere and vigilant parish priest lost little of its prestige, and many pious
parishioners adhered to a dogmatic piety that acted as a screen against the encroachments of modernity. In cities and industrial centers—especially in the
diaspora or in regions where the numerical balance between Catholics and
Protestants was fairly even—the priest would appear in a more modern guise.
He knew that only if he responded to the changing circumstances and attitudes of his flock would he succeed in preserving his customary position at
the head of local associational and community life. In these regions church
loyalty and piety had a different texture from the Catholicism that lived on in
rural Upper Bavaria or the isolated Eifel region southwest of Cologne.
A glance at intermarriage rates provides a telling insight into the changing
balance between assimilation and self-assertion among German Catholics.
As a result of deep-rooted historical tensions, exacerbated by the Kulturkampf, the rate had traditionally been low, hovering around 8 percent at the
turn of the century. But although the Vatican continued to oppose such marriages as vigorously as before, by 1910 the rate had gone up to 12 percent.
C. The Jewish Minority
The relationship between Imperial Germany’s Jewish minority and the Christian majority can also be fruitfully analyzed in terms of the questions of integration and assimilation. The emancipation of the Jews had reached its
final conclusion in the 1860s. Their days of being seen as social, economic,
and political pariahs were officially over. Baden and Württemberg had passed
the legislation that gave Jews complete equality before the law in 1861–1864.
The same policy was adopted by the North German Confederation in 1869
and then taken over by the newly founded Reich. Even before 1871, Jews had
made good use of the opportunities that this equality had given them. By this
time, some 512,153 of them lived in the Hohenzollern monarchy; by 1910,
the figure had risen to 615,021. The latter figure subsumed some 79,000 foreign Jews, 13 percent of the German total, who had moved to Germany, mainly
from the east. Some 416,000 of all Jews lived in Prussia. Bavaria was home
to 55,000, followed by Baden (25,896), Hesse (24,063), Hamburg (19,472),
Saxony (17,585), and Württemberg (11,982). A little over 30,000 Jews lived
in Alsace-Lorraine.
In light of a rising anti-Semitism, which will be addressed later,54 it is also
significant that the Jewish share in terms of the total population actually
93

Society

declined from 1.25 percent in 1871 to 0.95 percent before World War I. In
large measure, this development is due to the fact that the excess in births
over deaths among the Jewish minority declined more rapidly than among
the rest of the population. On average Jews married later and practiced more
effective birth control. What prevented an even steeper decline was a lower
mortality rate among Jews, especially for infants. Another factor was that
Jews immigrating from the east tended to have larger families. In the face of
these statistics, there were even some pessimists in the Jewish community who
predicted the eventual disappearance of this minority, also because the rate
of mixed marriages with Christians kept increasing. In the last years before
the war, around 13 percent of all Jewish women had taken Christian husbands.
Conversely, between 1911 and 1915 the share of Jewish men who married
Christian women reached as high as 22 percent. In some cities and regions at
this time the share was as high as 62.6 percent (Saxony) and 73 percent (Hamburg). Finally, those approximately 15,000 Jews who converted to Christianity between 1871 and 1909 must be included in these statistics.
Looking at the residential patterns of the German-Jewish minority opens
a window to an analysis of the occupational structure. Before Germany was
seized by the great wave of industrialization and urbanization in the second
half of the nineteenth century, most Jews lived in the rural regions or small
towns of Central Europe. They made a living as traders and moneylenders,
while the legal restrictions still in force at the time prevented them from acquiring landed property. Thus, even after 1871, Jews were strongly represented
among the cattle and hops dealers of Bavaria. In Baden and Hesse, they excelled in the grain trade, and among the wine growers of western Germany
they acted as “buyers.” Many Jews also sold haberdasheries, kitchen utensils,
and foodstuffs to the local peasantry. Finally, they emerged as moneylenders,
particularly in those areas where the peasants tried to conceal their indebtedness and hence were reluctant to go to the bank or other financial institutions.
In the towns, peddlers who went from door to door had been a familiar sight
for many years. However, by 1895 the share of Jews in this trade had declined
to 8.7 percent. This change did not merely hint at shifts in the occupational
structure overall, but also at a considerable occupational mobility among the
Jewish minority (Table 24). Those who, as peddlers, had once pushed a rickety cart from house to house would soon be wholesalers or sales representatives covering entire regions. The move to the big city became imperative. In
1871 not even 20 percent of the Jewish population lived in cities; by 1910 the
share had grown to 53.8 percent; in Prussia it reached almost 60 percent
(Table 39). In 1871, some 36,015 Jews lived in Berlin; by 1910 their number
had risen to over 90,000. During the same period the Jewish minority of
Cologne quadrupled from 3,100, and increased two-and-a-half-fold from
10,000 in Frankfurt. Breslau and Hamburg also witnessed sizeable increases.
94

Minorities and Majorities

Overall, the change happened more slowly in the south than in Prussia. As
late as 1910, around 30 percent of the Jews of Bavaria and Württemberg still
lived in communities with fewer than 5,000 inhabitants. In Prussia the share
was much lower; by 1910 it had fallen to 28 percent in towns of over 20,000
inhabitants.
In line with these changes, the share of Jews in industry and crafts rose
from 19.3 percent to 21.9 percent between 1895 and 1907, amounting to
0.5 percent of all Germans employed by this sector. Many Jews continued to
work in trade and commerce. But in comparison to the total numbers employed in this sector, the share of Jews likewise declined, from 10.5 percent to
8.0 percent. The most striking findings concerning the occupational mobility
of German Jews emerge only if we look at their share among the self-employed.
In crafts and industry, this share was 43 percent, a figure considerably higher
than that of self-employed individuals in the total working population. In
1907, some 54 percent of Jews worked in commerce, compared to the 29 percent that constituted the share of the self-employed among all people working in this sector. Jews became pioneers in the development of department
stores and the mail-order business. They were also strongly represented in private banking, even if the rise of the joint-stock banks led to an overall decline
of the Jewish share among the directors of privately owned institutions by
6 percent to 37 percent between 1882 and 1895. At the same time many Jews
advanced to the management and supervisory boards of large banks and industrial trusts, though officially they were employees of these companies.
Social historians have tried to refine these statistics. By evaluating Prussian data on millionaires that Rudolf Martin, a former civil servant with the
Reich Office of the Interior, published before 1914 in twenty-one volumes,
Werner Mosse succeeded in identifying twenty-nine families whose total wealth
was over 50 million marks each.55 No fewer than nine of these families (31
percent) were Jewish or of Jewish descent. Among the 25 wealthiest individuals, the Jewish share was 44 percent; among the top 800, it was still as high
as 23.7 percent. Beyond these percentages at the very top of the income scale,
Jews in Imperial Germany generally had a higher income than the population
average. Reports from the Inland Revenue Service of Breslau show that 15
percent of Jewish taxpayers in the cities fell into the highest tax categories;
the figure for Hamburg even reached 27 percent.
The Inland Revenue Service reports are warped in two ways, though. First,
large-scale landowners rarely appeared in the upper ranks because wealth
locked up in landed property was not assessed, even though land prices had
risen. Moreover, most landowners were less honest than wealthy Jews, and
the rural tax officials, who were responsible for checking their returns, often
did not pursue even the most blatant dishonesties. Their reasons were political
and ideological at a time when the Junker were “ailing” economically, and in
95

Society

the eyes of the conservative bureaucracy any means to prop them up seemed
justified.56 Second, when assessing tax liabilities, an adequate yardstick can
be gained only if we compare Jewish middle-class taxpayers with their nonJewish counterparts rather than with the total population. At present, some
material for more specific comparisons is only available for Breslau and
Berlin.
What can be said, however, is that German Jews, their minority position
notwithstanding, fully participated in the expansion of the country’s industrial economy and made a contribution to it that was well above the average.
Their occupational mobility was remarkable. Their rise into the well-to-do
bourgeoisie opened up better educational opportunities, as many Jewish parents found that the cost of providing their children with a high school and
college education was no longer beyond their means. Education and immersion in the religious texts had long held a special importance, particularly
for Jewish men. Jewish mothers also played a major role in transmitting the
values of learning and education. Consequently, there existed few psychological or cultural barriers against going to high school or university.
As early as 1863 the share of Jewish pupils at Prussian high schools was
16 percent. As the Abitur certificate was an entry-ticket to the tertiary sector,
the percentage of Jewish men at first also saw a rapid rise at German universities. In 1886/87 around 9.6 percent of the students at Prussia’s universities
were Jewish; the figure was still 8 percent in 1911, although total numbers
had increased markedly and the percentage of Jews in the population had declined. After women had finally been admitted to Prussian tertiary institutions in 1909, the share of Jewish women was over 17 percent a mere two
years later.
Those German Jews who did not enter their fathers’ firms after graduation
or otherwise sought a career in industry and commerce would go into the
professions. In 1907, some 14.7 percent of all private attorneys and notaries
were Jewish. The figure for physicians was 6 percent, and another 8.1 percent of Jews registered in the occupational census of 1907 gave their profession as “private scholar, writer, and journalist.” As in industry and commerce,
many of them achieved positions of influence in these professions, above all
in the press. This gave them a high visibility, especially in the large liberal
newspapers for which they worked.
Since the civil service officially adhered to the principle of qualification
and merit, one would have expected to find a correspondingly large share of
Jews in the bureaucracy and armed forces. Since the 1860s, the law had established equality in the competition for these careers. However, time and again
Jewish applicants found themselves turned down through various tricks and
under all sorts of flimsy pretexts. The barriers were particularly insurmountable in the armed forces. Only the Bavarian army officer corps was prepared
96

Minorities and Majorities

to make a few exceptions. The allegedly liberal navy, like the Prussian army,
did not have a single Jewish officer, though it did have a few converts. A few
also succeeded in climbing to the top of the ladder in the civil service. Entering the transport, library, and public health services proved somewhat easier.
To obtain a promotion often proved no less arduous. In 1907, some 4.3
percent of all judges were Jewish, 906 of them in all. Since the number of
qualified attorneys of Jewish background was much higher, however, many
of them were pushed into private practice, even if they preferred the judiciary. Scholars, many of them highly qualified, had similar experiences. They
would be kept waiting for a tenured professorship for years. In 1909 some
2 percent of all full professors were Jews, with a noticeable concentration in
the sciences. During the German Empire no Jew was ever given a full professorship in German literature or in classics. Among the associate professors
(Extraordinarien), the share was 7 percent, and again an important statistical
point should not be overlooked: this percentage does not reflect the share of
Jews in the total population, but rather in the pool of qualified candidates.
Jewish school teachers also found professional life a struggle. They were virtually excluded from Christian church schools. Public schools, too, were
under a mandate to offer an education guided by Christian principles that
Jewish teachers were presumably unable to provide. Fortunately, this mandate was handled more flexibly at the high-school level. Following a decree
by the Prussian minister for cultural affairs, Jews could be admitted as teachers from 1872 onward, and the first of them served in Breslau with its large
Jewish community. Finally, there were also a few Jewish schools, and here
there was even a chance to rise to the headmastership.
The material presented so far demonstrates that, their rise in the economy
and the educational system notwithstanding, Jews were subjected to an array
of discriminations that in turn reinforced their concentrated appearance in
other professions. Finally, they experienced many handicaps when it came to
honors and decorations, and membership in various clubs and associations
was also denied to them.
D. Anti-Semitism
The reasons for these realities cannot be found among the Jews themselves.
Rather their difficulties indicate that this minority group faced many obstacles
to integration into the majority society that originated in a widespread antiSemitism. Innumerable studies have been undertaken on this topic.57 They
are all concerned with divergent types of anti-Semitism, often specific to a
particular non-Jewish group. They also deal with the organization and proliferation of anti-Jewish prejudice in the decades before 1914.
There existed a strong social anti-Semitism that was largely confined to
the upper classes as well as the rural and court nobility. Its adherents simply
97

Society

considered Jews inferior socially and hence totally unsuited to be invited to
court. Aristocrats would try to obtain useful advice from Jews in business
matters, but even then they would display the inimitable condescension with
which they would approach other people of unequal birth. The treatment of
Gerson Bleichröder is a good case in point. As Bismarck’s private banker, he
had used his considerable skills to increase the Reich chancellor’s wealth; but
this did not prevent Bismarck’s son Herbert from cracking ugly anti-Semitic
jokes the moment Bleichröder had left his father’s house after one of his visits. Although there were some Old Prussian conservatives who were unhappy
about these prejudices and about how they were used in Conservative agitation as a means of rallying support among the peasantry, a vicious type of
anti-Semitism also flourished in the entourage of the crown prince and later
Kaiser Wilhelm II that was merely different by degree from the anti-Semitism
that existed in Germany after 1918.
Segments of the lower middle classes and the peasantry adhered to a religious anti-Semitism. Promoted by the churches (or at least not opposed by
them), this prejudice had deep roots in Christianity’s history and in the early
persecutions of the Jews all over Europe. Particularly powerful was the lie
that the Jews were the “murderers of Christ.” Long before the nineteenth century, such arguments had repeatedly been accompanied by an economic antiSemitism that blamed the Jews for harvest failures and other disasters. Now,
in an age of rapid socioeconomic change, peasants, artisans, and shopkeepers time and again found themselves left behind or even faced with economic
ruin, whose larger structural causes they could not understand.58 In these circumstances it was certainly simpler and more comforting to find a scapegoat
for these ills and one’s own failures. The Jews were a small and easily identifiable group to be thrust into this unhappy role. The prejudice did not disappear in better times in those regions where Jews appeared as traders and
moneylenders, though it also proved attractive to others who had little contact with the Jewish minority. Worse, political agitators knew how to play on
this type of anti-Semitism.
During the final decade of the nineteenth century, a racist-biological variant of anti-Semitism began to spread whose emergence was connected with
the more or less simultaneous rise of an intolerant integral nationalism and a
missionary imperialism. Its advocates divided the world into “superior” and
“inferior” nations and “races.” These currents of thought were reinforced by
the spread of Social Darwinist ideas. Here history was viewed as a “struggle
for survival” in a power-political jungle in which the nations and “races” that
were better equipped biologically for dominating the weaker ones would win
out. The pseudoscientific foundations of this worldview were particularly
persuasive to the gullible. If all these tendencies are added up, it is not difficult to see why many non-Jews, threatened by socioeconomic decline, ideo98

Minorities and Majorities

logically confused, and predisposed to the above-mentioned religious and
economic anti-Semitism, would be open to the simple lie that the Jews were
