not only an inferior but a particularly menacing “race” that tried to undermine the biological fiber of the Germans in order to dominate them.
After this, practically no limits existed to the invention of the most harebrained conspiracy theories. Long before 1914, such theories were being debated in various splinter associations and propagated in obscure journals and
pamphlets. After 1918, the National Socialists added scarcely a new thought
to this jumble of anti-Semitic prejudices. Ultimately, the explanation for the
strength and prevalence of such feelings must be sought in the social pathology of the anti-Semites themselves. The Jews played their role only insofar
as their high-profile minority position made them an ideal scapegoat. Thus,
many Germans who subscribed to one type of anti-Semitism, or to all of
them, not only came to reject an integration of the Jews; on the contrary, they
hoped to remove them from all spheres of life.
The growth of a racist nationalism and its political organizations will be
discussed in a later chapter.59 The task here is to examine the evolving situation from the Jewish perspective. If the development of a vicious scapegoat
mechanism points to the limited capacity of the majority of Germans to integrate its minorities, and its Jews in particular, there is, in line with the analytical framework put forward in this section’s introduction, also the question
of Jewish assimilation and its limits. The case of the German Jews seems to
provide an even better illustration of this issue than that of the Catholics. The
emancipation of the Jews of Central Europe had been predicated on the assumption that they represented a religious community and not a “nation.”
Most Jews agreed with this, and accordingly, once a German nation-state had
been created in 1871, they saw themselves as “Germans of Jewish denomination” (Deutsche israelitischer Konfession).
Under the impact of a growing anti-Semitism and in particular of its racist
variant, Germany’s Jews began to widen this self-definition. However much
they rejected the biological arguments of their enemies, many of them came
to realize that their religion was but one important element of their sociocultural persona. What also molded them into a group was their long history,
much of which had been marked by persecution, their cultural institutions,
and their perceptions of the environments in which they lived. All these elements taken together in fact made them an ethnic group, rather than merely
a religious community within German society at large.
This consciousness was strengthened by the fact that many German Jews
were captivated by the general process of secularization that began to permeate society. They became estranged from their religion, especially in its very
strict orthodox varieties. However, this did not prevent them from identifying
with their Jewishness in a broader sense and from seeing themselves as a cul99

Society

tural minority. Because of these developments, which offered the Jews both
self-confidence and a sense of belonging, very few of them were prepared to
assimilate into the majority to such a degree that their ethnic identity disappeared completely. This is most clearly reflected in the low numbers of Jews
who converted to Christianity, a line many Jews were unprepared to step
across. At the same time, the majority environment contained many cultural
elements toward which they felt a strong affinity. Indeed, many of these elements could be reconciled quite easily with the Judaic system of values and
with their own traditions.
As pressure on this minority mounted from anti-Semites and other groups,
and Jewish children experienced open prejudice from their classmates in
school playgrounds, factions arose within the Jewish community that rejected
an adaptation that stopped distinctly short of absorption. The supporters of
these tendencies worked for a separation and, in the case of the Zionists, even
for the founding of a Jewish national state.60 However, the latter always remained a small minority within the German-Jewish community. More significantly, foreign observers were frequently struck by how “German” even these
more radical elements were in their attitudes and behavior. Theodor Herzl,
one of the fathers of modern Zionism, provides a telling case in point for how
this “German-Jewish ethnicity” amounted to a hyphenated identity that was
in fact a synthesis of partial adaptation and reinterpretation of what it meant to
be a Jew in Central Europe in the late nineteenth century. In 1895 it did not
strike Herzl as incongruous when he received the astonished Chief Rabbi of
Vienna at his home under the Christmas tree. For him this was evidently not
a paradox but a perfectly reconcilable synthesis of Central European culture.
Consequently, German Jews also had no problems with the ideals and attitudes of the educated bourgeoisie, the Bildungsbürgertum. Nor did liberal
Jews agonize over reforming their own services and integrating Christian traditions into them. Old Hebrew songs were accompanied by organ music,
while the texts were recited in German. Under the impact of secularization,
the position of Jewish women in the family and community also began to
change, and the rigid patriarchism that characterized orthodoxy softened. On
the one hand, the role of the mother remained important; on the other, the
share of working Jewish women rose by 47.8 percent to almost 49,000 between 1895 and 1907. This figure represented 18 percent of all Jewish women
and hence a smaller percentage than the 30 percent of all German women
who held jobs in the Kaiserreich. But it must also be remembered that most
Jews had by this time risen into the middle class. Those 18 percent should
therefore be compared with the share of non-Jewish bourgeois women, and
in the absence of precise statistics it may be surmised here that the Jewish
share was at least the same, if not higher. The high share of Jewish female
students at universities points in the same direction.
100

Minorities and Majorities

As these social and cultural processes unfolded, Germany’s Jews understandably felt challenged by the anti-Semites, whose numbers appeared to be
rising, indicating a disturbing sociopathological potential. They did not want
to leave uncontested the lies that were being spread. Nor were they prepared
to put up indefinitely with discrimination against them that was based on
anti-Semitic prejudice. They wanted to be integrated as full citizens but to
preserve their identity as an ethnic group that had not been totally absorbed
by the Christian majority. These aspirations finally found an organized expression in the founding of the “Central Association of German Citizens of
the Jewish Faith” (CV). The name of this organization, which rejected Zionism, says it all. In speeches and articles, its members insisted thenceforth that
they saw themselves as both—as Germans and Jews—and that they fully identified as such with the society into which they had been born. To them being
a Jew and being a German were not alternatives, but complementarities.
How seriously they took this position became evident during World War
I, in which around 100,000 Jews participated. No fewer than 2,000 of them
were promoted to the rank of officer. But this did little to lessen the discrimination against them. As we shall see in Part V, anti-Semitism and the policies of exclusion continued to rise after 1914.
E. The Polish Minority
Cultural symbiosis without the loss of one’s own identity was also a strategy
of German citizens of Polish origin, of whom large numbers moved from the
eastern provinces to the Ruhr area in the west. It was a strategy that ultimately worked no better for them than it did for German Jews. Conversely,
the attitudes of the majority and the policies of the Prussian government put
very tangible limits upon their integration. Their experience in turn led to defensive reactions that were typical of ethnic minorities. The development of
the German-Polish relationship therefore bears many similarities to that of
Germans and Jews. However, it unfolded at a different socioeconomic level.
Whereas most Jews belonged to the middle class, the Polish minority was
made up mainly of agricultural workers. Those who subsequently moved to
the west and north settled in industrial communities and lived increasingly
proletarian-industrial lives.
Moreover, the Polish minority settled in clearly identifiable concentrations
in both east and west. These circumstances, as well as the fact that Poland,
until its destruction by Russia, Prussia, and Austria in the late eighteenth century, had been a sovereign state, put the German Poles in a somewhat different setting than that of German Jews. Zionism remained a marginal force among
the latter. Geography and memories of a period of national independence
make the history of this minority under the German Empire more comparable to that of the Danes or Alsace-Lorraineans than of the Jews or Catholics.
101

Society

Above all, the Danes were not merely a culturally distinct ethnic minority,
but also a national one. And the more this minority felt ostracized, the greater
became its desire to separate. The Poles occupied an unusual position somewhere in the middle between Jews, on the one hand, and Danes, on the other,
in this spectrum of minority experiences in Imperial Germany. For a long
time they stood right at the crossroads, and whether they would take a separatistnationalist road or the path toward a German-Polish symbiosis depended on
larger domestic developments inside the country.
From what we know, the approximately 3 million land laborers and smallholders in the Prussian East did not possess a strong Polish national consciousness at the time of the founding of the Reich. This consciousness was
more highly developed among the Polish-speaking aristocracy and bourgeoisie.
Those who joined the trek to the west in the 1870s in search of better jobs
were too apolitical to have clearly articulated ideological positions. In the
first few years after 1871, only a few thousand Poles migrated to the Ruhr
region. According to Reich statistics, their numbers, including Masurians,
had risen to 34,000 by 1890. Twenty years later, this figure had grown tenfold. It is fairly certain now that the Poles who went to the Rhineland numbered from 300,000 to 350,000. To this figure must be added a string of
smaller settlements, for example, in Wilhelmsburg just south of Hamburg.
Remaining statistical uncertainties notwithstanding, it appears that there were
around 400,000 Poles outside the eastern provinces of Prussia.
Most of them went to the Ruhr area and found employment in the mines.
This occupational pattern explains to some extent why they settled in colonies.
Especially in the eastern Ruhr there emerged a number of “Polenzechen,”
mines with a high share of Poles among the workforce. Many of these Poles
were married. Once a few families had become established in the new heavyindustrial environment, they acted as magnets for friends and family who had
stayed behind. Single men were recruited by agents of the mining companies
and put into company housing. The number of overnight lodgers was large
among the Ruhr Poles. As early as 1881, a survey found that some 735 predominantly Polish households had no less than 1,377 such lodgers. A count
for the city of Essen in 1902 showed an average of three per household. The
important point is that networks were created in this way through which
long-distance migrants came to be channeled. Newcomers were given a bed
not only because the rent was needed to contribute to the family budget, but
also because there were the solidarities of the extended family and ethnicity.
Since the number of Ruhr Poles was initially small, the majority population was not yet confronted with the question of their integration. Strangers
could simply be ignored. But when they arrived in larger numbers, the question of their position within society and local politics became more acute. At
first sight, there appeared to be considerable potential for tension between
102

Minorities and Majorities

the majority and the Polish minority. Anti-Slav stereotypes and a superiority
complex had been prevalent among the native population before their arrival.
Language and culture were different. The migrants tended to come from regions in the east with very low wage levels, while Ruhr miners were among
the best paid. The Poles therefore acted as a “reserve army” that made it easier for the mining bosses to push down wage levels, creating bitterness among
the indigenous mining communities. In short, there were a number of neuralgic points over which conflicts between the newcomers and the natives might
break out.
Nevertheless, recent research has shown quite reliably that the integration
of the Polish minority into its immediate environment proceeded unevenly
yet more smoothly than earlier historians had assumed. The organization of
work in the mines no doubt helped in this respect. Here Germans and Poles
were exposed to the same dangers, and the work in gangs and teams promoted
a sense of solidarity. Finally, unlike Germany’s Jews, the German Poles did not
outpace the majority in occupational mobility. Majority and minority shared
the same very limited opportunities to move up that existed for all industrial
laborers during the Kaiserreich. At most intergenerational mobility was slightly
higher for the indigenous population at 14 percent. More worrying was the
fact that Polish miners were hardly ever promoted to supervisory positions,
which carried with them a period of study at the Mining Academy.
Similar conditions obtained in the textile factories of Wilhelmsburg, where
many Polish migrants found employment. Here native workers gained a small
advantage on the ladder to becoming skilled workers or foremen. However,
both groups rarely succeeded in rising to master positions. Better opportunities developed for Poles in the crafts sector; but like their native fellow workers they were virtually excluded from lower civil service and white-collar
jobs, except for a few Polish “railroad civil servants” who were promoted to
the position of engine driver. This meant that sources of friction due to one
group receiving preferential treatment over the other were relatively few. The
newcomers’ integration seemed to be making progress. A survey of the Dortmund Mining District Office showed that in 1893 some 40 percent of immigrant miners whose main language was Polish had married German-speaking
women. Until 1914 there was a further rise in the absolute number of these
mixed marriages, but the actual share rose only slightly between 1908 and
1912 from 2.8 percent to 3.2 percent among Polish men, and from 2 percent
to 2.2 percent among Polish women.
Promoted by the expansion of the system of company-owned mining
colonies, Polish miners tended to live closely together. This was also true in
other regions. Wilhelmsburg experienced a “tendency toward ghetto formation,” though not “in the sense of a concentration that resulted from a discrimination of the minority.”61 Thus, Polish workers were rarely disadvantaged
103

Society

when it came to accommodation. In this respect only large families had difficulties in Wilhelmsburg. The rest suffered more or less equally with the natives from the poor housing conditions. Wherever “Polish quarters” emerged
in Wilhelmsburg, they were not isolated from the rest of the town; but they
did provide stability to an emergent ethnic culture. Christoph Kleßmann’s
findings for the Ruhr have been less favorable. He found “social discrimination, … above all, as a consequence of native prejudices.”62 As in the case of
the Jews, this leads us to the second question, that of the assimilation of the
Polish minority and its openness to this process.
If nothing else, their language made former Polish land laborers from the
east who had migrated to the cities of northern and western Germany well
aware that they were culturally different from the majority around them. In
the Rhineland, Catholicism initially provided a bridge. And yet, as in the case
of the Jews, the Polish desire to adapt to their environment never went so far
as to include absorption by the native society. Name changes are a good indicator of this. It is true that, between 1910 and 1912, there was a rise in the
number of applications to change a Slavic sounding name from 382 to 764.
But apparently most of the applicants were Masurians, who, for various reasons, were less resistant to losing their cultural identity. Moreover, even this
doubling of applications remained low in comparison to the total number of
Ruhr Poles. Their preparedness to meld their cultural environment also had
clear limits when it came to eating habits or to the question of having Polish
priests to head their church communities.
Above all, it was the mushrooming of colorful associations that pointed to
a clear desire to preserve their ethnic culture. Indeed, these associations acted
as pillars of a slowly evolving Polish minority culture that became a psychically stabilizing element. In 1906, there were no fewer than 106 singing
clubs, with 5,225 members. By 1912, the total number of the mostly cultural
Polish clubs in the Ruhr was 875, with some 81,500 members. The range of
activities was astounding. There was a temperance society with 828 members; the rosary brotherhoods counted over 16,000 members; and even the
lottery associations had some 1,500 supporters. Although the new urban environment had begun to change many of the attitudes that the immigrants had
brought with them from the east, their cultural heritage was not so easily forgotten. Like the Polish language, it was upheld collectively and passed on to
the next generation. At the same time indigenous traditions and patterns of
behavior were picked up. The new blend that developed is perhaps most
strikingly reflected in the closing ceremony of the 5th Festival of the Catholic
Associations of Dortmund on 31 May 1885 that had brought Poles and Germans peacefully together. It was a matter of course that the assembled would
issue a joint salute to both the Emperor and the Pope and finish the meeting
by singing the Leo as well as the Kaiser Hymn. A year later, the Stanislaus
104

Minorities and Majorities

Association participated quite happily in the public celebrations of Sedan
Day commemorating the 1870 defeat of France.
If it had been up to the Ruhr Poles, it is perfectly plausible that they would
have continued to develop in this way and without major tensions as an ethnic minority within their industrial environment and would have seen themselves as German citizens of Polish descent. Unfortunately, the Kaiserreich
was not a country that was prepared to tolerate such a minority group with a
specific culture. The basic structure of the Hohenzollern monarchy was too
illiberal and authoritarian to accommodate this. Worse, both Germany’s elites
and larger sections of the population were becoming more intolerant in their
outlook as 1914 approached. The Germanic nationalism that made them unwilling to allow minorities the preservation of their own culture grew into an
ever more dynamic and ultimately self-destructive force. It was further deformed before 1914 by an additional racism and imperialism that pushed for
domination and submission. This nationalism, which, to be sure, was not solely
a German phenomenon, aroused resentment and ultimately a nationalist defense. Over time, this reaction developed into a centrifugal force, and in the
case of the Austro-Hungarian multinational empire, Slav counter-nationalism
became so powerful that it threatened the survival of the Habsburg monarchy. Incapable of initiating life-saving reforms, the government in Vienna began an open ethnic struggle against the different Slav minorities within their
sphere of power. On the Polish side, resistance to the repressive policies in
Vienna at first came mainly from the nobility and the middle classes, who
dreamed of the restoration of the former Polish national state.
Prussia, having annexed parts of Poland during the divisions of the eighteenth century, was bound to feel threatened by developments in the Habsburg
empire. If Polish nationalists succeeded in building up a genuine popular
movement, the eastern provinces with their large Polish-speaking populations were no longer secure. This explains why the Prussian government tried
to smother the rising Polish nationalism with ever more brutal means. Numerically, the Poles already constituted the majority in some of the provinces.
Fears arose of a “flooding” of the “German East” with Poles, partly because
of immigration from Austrian Galicia and Russia, and because the Polish birth
rate was higher than the German one and many Germans themselves began
to migrate west in search of better jobs in industry. In these circumstances, it
was not difficult to see that repressive measures would fail in the long run,
unless they were complemented by “positive” policies. This, however, meant
in the minds of the Prussian government and its supporters that the provinces
concerned should be “Germanized.”
Accordingly, Bismarck started a different kind of Kulturkampf in the east.
The first drastic measures were taken by the authorities in 1885 when they
unceremoniously expelled some 32,000 Poles whose German citizenship
105

Society

could not be immediately documented. Since even some hard-line Prussian
conservatives reacted negatively to these expulsions, a “constructive” program began a year later: with the help of a financially well-endowed Settlement
Commission, large Polish estates were bought up for distribution in smaller
parcels to German peasant settlers. Bismarck, who as Prussian prime minister was ultimately responsible for this program, apparently also hoped to foster the integration of the parties and of domestic politics with this “national”
initiative.63 However, in his conception of things this integration did not include the Polish minority; on the contrary, it aimed to ostracize the Poles.
The activities of the Settlement Commission had a somewhat paradoxical
effect. In the twenty years after 1886, it used its fund of 250 million marks
more often for the purchase of German estates than Polish ones, raising the
suspicion that heavily indebted German landowners were saved from bankruptcy under the guise of a “Germanization” program that enabled them to
sell land at vastly inflated prices. Although this was a welcome effect for the
“ailing” Junker, the program proved a disaster from the demographic point of
view. For however strenuously the government and various private associations, which barely veiled their racist intentions, tried to sell their “Germanization” policy, by 1914 a mere 22,000 German peasants had actually settled
on the bought-up land. One reason for this depressing result was that the
Poles applied the rules of the Settlement Commission to their own benefit.
Since they were German citizens, they, too, could acquire land, as long as
they paid for it. Accordingly, they founded some 85 credit cooperatives to finance the acquisition of land by Polish peasants. The advocates of “Germanization” had the tables turned upon them.
In 1904 the frustrated Prussian government made an attempt to block these
developments by an unconstitutional move that turned Poles into secondclass citizens with respect to their right to acquire land. But soon a decision
by the Prussian Administrative High Court put a judicial stop to this policy.
Unrelenting in its desire to weaken the economic position of Poles in the
east, the Reich government promulgated another law in 1908 that made the
forcible expropriation of Polish property easier for the purpose of “strengthening the Germandom in the Provinces of West Prussia and Posen.” This
fresh discrimination greatly increased tensions between Poles and Germans
when, in 1912, the new law was used against four Polish landowners.
The memorable settlement policies of Prussia were complemented by discrimination in the fields of language and education that similarly aimed at
“Germanizing” the Poles. As to educational policies, the measures that had
been introduced in the course of the Kulturkampf against Catholics also
offered a lever against the Poles, many of whom were Catholics. Thus the
Schools’ Supervision Law of 1872 had curtailed the influence of the clergy
in the classroom. Since many priests in the eastern provinces were of Polish
106

Minorities and Majorities

background, the Prussian authorities were able to hit the instruction of Polish children at the same time. In October 1873, a decree was added that made
German the sole language in schools. For the moment, Polish could continue
for several hours per week as a foreign language. Further laws followed in
1876 and 1877 that declared German as the exclusive language in the administration and in the courts. The year 1908 then saw the final phase in this
process of escalation, when a paragraph was inserted into the new Reich Association Law that banned the use of the Polish language in private clubs and
associations. In the following year, a number of public servants were dismissed because they had voted for the Polish party in a municipal election.
It is not difficult to imagine how “German citizens of Polish descent” reacted to these measures. A Polish national consciousness began to take root
among the lower classes, who were embittered by discrimination in education,
administration, and landownership. They, too, began to speak up for the preservation of their ethnic identity, sometimes underlined by the use of physical
force. The introduction of the language policies led to open clashes between
Polish parents and German teachers. In 1906/7 tens of thousands of parents
temporarily refused to send their children to school. Prussian “Germanization”
policies and the agitation of German associations, above all of the HKT movement, gave a boost to the founding of Polish counter-organizations. Faced
with discrimination of the kind described above, these organizations were no
longer content to pursue cultural objectives. They demanded a restoration of
a Polish national state. Polish nationalism became a mass movement, and differences with the Germans became more and more irreconcilable. The government proved incapable of solving the “Polish question” in the east, and
the situation there became badly polarized.
After this, it was virtually inevitable that separatism among the eastern
Poles, which German ostracism had unleashed, would spill over into the Ruhr
area. Here, too, the deterioration began when the authorities exerted pressure
on the education front. Faced with small numbers, local officials at first still
believed that the problem of ethnic minorities would solve itself. As the Landrat of the Bochum region put it, “in the long run, the Germanization of the
Polish elements in this area” will be effected “through primary schools, marriages, and the constant social intercourse with the German population.”64
But then the Polish-speaking pupils became so numerous that the authorities
lost hope that this long-term strategy would succeed. Suddenly, Polish private
schools had their accreditation refused. Public schools no longer took account
of ethnic peculiarities. Where the percentage of Polish-speaking students became too high, classes were split up. Parents who organized private lessons
for their children would find the police on their doorstep.
Other administrative obstacles were put up. Teachers and officials were
instructed that it was their special duty to promote a German national con107

Society

sciousness. In January 1899 the Mining Police issued a decree that expected
all miners to possess a sufficient knowledge of German—for reasons of
safety. Discrimination began to affect existential questions. The 1904 Settlement Law made it more difficult for Poles who wished to return to the east
to purchase land with their savings. Finally, in 1908 came the Association
Law, whose intolerant language clauses applied to the entire Reich.
The reaction of Polish minorities in the Ruhr area or in Wilhelmsburg was
predictable: they resisted these repercussions of the “Germanization” policies in the east upon their own lives. The associational life that, as we have
seen, had been predominantly cultural and oriented toward a Polish-German
symbiosis, became politicized and took on a nationalistic tone. There was a
closing of the ranks. The Catholic Church of the Rhineland and Westphalia
learned this lesson when Ruhr Poles suddenly began to demand Polish priests
and services. Unions and parties underwent a similar shift. The local Polish
newspapers that had begun to report regularly on Prussian government policies in the east distanced themselves from what was happening. Meanwhile
the German press launched attacks on the Polish minority in their midst. And
yet it would probably go too far to speak of a Polish separatism in the Ruhr
area.
What acted as a counterweight to such tendencies was the fact that many
Polish families had become rooted in their new industrial-urban environments, which were so different from the rural conditions they had originally
come from. They now identified with the Ruhr, and their main concern was
to get the majority and the authorities around them to recognize their culture
and to provide them with equal opportunities for advancement and selfexpression. However, suspicions on the part of officials and the majority population of the 400,000 Ruhr Poles had meanwhile grown so strong that they
could not visualize anything less than a minority that would allow itself to be
fully “Germanized.” It did not matter that defining this Germanness continued to be difficult; but it meant having to give up one’s ethnic identity, just
as the Jews were expected to. A majority of Germans and their spokesmen
were unwilling to allow minorities to continue along the path of cultural synthesis on which they had set out with considerable optimism in the 1870s.
F. Alsace-Lorrainean and Danish Minorities
If a comparison is to be made at all, the experience of the people of AlsaceLorraine, whose territory the Reich had annexed from France in 1871, is
more likely comparable to that of the Poles in the east than to that of the Ruhr
Poles. There were no Alsatian or Lorrainean minorities outside the Reichsland, where they in fact constituted the majority. There were also differences
between the east and Alsace-Lorraine, the most important among them being
that the gradual integration of the population into the Reich developed more
108

Minorities and Majorities

happily in the latter region until the truncated constitutional reform of 1911
and the infamous Zabern Affair two years later.65 This was all the more remarkable since the German civilian administration that had been installed in
Alsace-Lorraine in 1871 started its job in the most difficult circumstances.
The indigenous bourgeoisie was strictly anti-Prussian and culturally, economically, and linguistically oriented toward France. The peasant population
of Alsace along the Rhine Valley was predominantly German-speaking and
had many ties with Baden, just across the river to the east. The French element was dominant in most of Lorraine. Just under 80 percent of the inhabitants of the territory were Catholics; 17 percent were Protestants, a figure
that had increased slightly by 1910.
Some forty years later, around 1910, major changes had taken place. The
elites of the Reichsland no longer looked toward Paris, but toward Germany.
The bulk of the population continued to hope that further constitutional reforms would bring them the same rights and privileges enjoyed by citizens in
the Reich’s other federal states. It is tempting to explain the reorientation toward Germany in purely economic terms and to invoke the magnet effect that
the prosperous industrial German Empire exerted upon the inhabitants of
Alsace-Lorraine. No doubt, the region experienced a moderate expansion of
its indigenous industries, once trade had increasingly begun to flow across
the river Rhine. Between 1882 and 1907, the share of people employed in
agriculture declined by 8 percent to 37.4 percent. Meanwhile the share of industry rose from 36.4 percent to 38.6 percent and that of the tertiary sector
from 18.6 percent to 24 percent.
The economic reorientation toward Germany was a painful process that
was to some extent forced upon the business community by France. The high
French tariffs of 1892 hit the region’s economy hard, particularly the textile
industry that was concentrated around Mülhausen near the Swiss border. German trade policies contributed little to creating an alternative outlet. Attempts
to send more products to southern Germany encountered opposition from
vested interests there. In 1871, Bismarck had temporarily granted AlsaceLorraine special tariff protection; but when this came to an end, local industries
had to face the stiffer competition from across the Rhine. The wine-growers
of Alsace also had a hard time. For a while the local tobacco industry harbored high hopes that Bismarck would succeed in securing a monopoly position for them. When the Reichstag rejected this project in June 1882, this
branch also found itself struggling. Only the iron and steel industry of Lorraine posted a tangible rise in production. Between 1898 and 1909 it increased
its output from 374,000 tons to 1.2 million tons. Nevertheless, the overall
conclusion must be that the rest of German industry and its interest groups
did little to integrate Alsace-Lorraine, however keen the region’s businessmen were on this after the virtual loss of the French market. There were other
109

Society

factors in the early years after 1871 that might have facilitated the integration
of the Reichsland. Resistance against the annexation had been decisively weakened by the westward migration of some 300,000 people. Among them were
many who identified very strongly with France and French culture; thus, practically one-fifth of the region’s most anti-German population disappeared.
They were replaced by some 176,000 men and women who, as so-called Altdeutsche, settled primarily in Alsace and hence contributed to creating a basic
mood that was pro-German.
The case of Alsace-Lorraine also provides a good example that clearsighted policies by the administration that aimed at gradual change and reform were capable of winning the support of the indigenous population. The
measures taken with regard to school and the French language offer a case in
point. Given Berlin’s irreconcilable differences with the French “archenemy,” as well as the prevalence of a basic intolerance toward ethnic minorities,
it might have been expected that Alsace-Lorraine would also be subjected to
a dogmatic language policy geared to the region’s total “Germanization.”
German, it is true, became the bureaucracy’s official language in 1872, and a
year later the same rule applied to the school system. There were also the effects of Kulturkampf legislation on Catholic Alsace-Lorraine. But the implementation of these laws after 1874 made but slow progress, and French
explicitly remained the second language. In fact, the number of communities
in which school lessons continued to be held in French rose during the seven
years after 1875 from 385 to 435. As late as 1911, some 16 percent of primary schools had no choice but to use the French language with their firstgraders, because teachers would not have had the skills to teach their charges
in German. The newly founded University of Strasbourg did adopt the German academic system, but it had almost three times as many non-Germans
as the universities in the rest of the country.
That slow change and procrastination on the language front were seen as
the best way forward may be gauged from the way the issue was handled in
the Landesausschuss, the regional representative assembly. First, it took until
1881 before German became the official language in this quasi-parliamentary
body of notables. But even thereafter deputies who claimed to have insufficient German were allowed to read their speeches from a prepared manuscript in French. French could be used freely in committees. In comparison
with other parts of the Reich, the introduction of German as the language of
the courts was also delayed by a dozen years. When the language paragraph
in the 1908 Reich Association Law reached the statute book, the administration of the Reichsland issued a decree that generally permitted the “co-use”
of the French language in public meetings. In short, the regional bureaucracy
implemented the language stipulations quite differently from what the Poles
had to cope with. No doubt this approach was more conducive to an integra110

Minorities and Majorities

tion of the local population into the Reich than the one adopted in the eastern provinces. Apparently the German administration calculated that time was
on their side. Over one or two generations, they believed, demographic and
economic changes would take care of the problem.
Meanwhile the desire of the people of Alsace-Lorraine to adapt also developed in positive ways. Undoubtedly, they wished to preserve their regional
cultural identity; but even those who had French roots increasingly saw their
future as lying with the Kaiserreich. Thus, culturally speaking, there emerged
a mix of indigenous elements and others that came from across the Rhine.
What ultimately disrupted this trend, however, was a huge stumbling block
that increasingly appeared in the way of integration: the peculiar constitutional status of the Reichsland within the German Empire. Between 1871 and
1874, the region had de facto been under a government in which the Kaiser,
with the approval of the Federal Council, held both the executive and legislative powers. Only from 1874 did the centralism of Berlin become modified
when the above-mentioned Landesausschuss was created. From 1877 onwards, this assembly was given the right to participate in the legislative process. Thenceforth the people and leaders of Alsace-Lorraine pursued the idea
of an extension of their rights of self-government. At the end of this process,
the region would be recognized as a federal state, thus gaining equal status
with the Reich’s other federal states.
Yet, time and again the pressure for constitutional reform encountered two
obstacles. The most serious stumbling block was that the army never stopped
viewing the region as a military bastion and glacis vis-à-vis the French “archenemy” to the west. In the view of the powerful officer corps, their strategic
and security concerns demanded the continuation of Alsace-Lorraine’s special constitutional status, which guaranteed the ultimate primacy of military
interests. Second, serious problems arose over what kind of suffrage would
apply, should the region ever become an equal federal state. All other federal
states had restrictive electoral systems, and introducing a similar system to
Alsace-Lorraine became a precondition of their supporting the region’s admission as a full member of the Federal Council. The citizens of the Reichsland, by contrast, had enjoyed France’s universal suffrage before 1871 and
now expected to regain it from the Germans. This is where the other federal
states sensed danger. Introducing universal suffrage in Alsace-Lorraine would
have greatly increased the pressure to liberalize their systems, an action for
which many of their own citizens, the Social Democrats in particular, were
clamoring.
This impasse, as well as others, explains why the constitutional reform of
1911 went to the brink of the region’s recognition as a federal state, but ultimately denied it full equality. To be sure, the reform opened up the prospect
of future further changes. But the population’s disappointment with what had
111

Society

been achieved until that year was profound. Soon thereafter they were hit by
the Zabern Affair,66 which made it clear to them that, all advances notwithstanding, in the final analysis Berlin and the army determined their political
life. As in the case of other minorities, this experience was grist to the mills
of those who had always been skeptical of the chances for a synthesis between Alsace-Lorraine and the rest of Germany.
The Danish minority found itself in the Reich as a consequence of Denmark’s defeat in 1864 and the territorial gains made by Prussia at the time.
Secret negotiations in Vienna in 1879 then removed a clause in the Treaty of
Prague that would have allowed Danes to reunite with Denmark after a successful plebiscite. But even before then, Prussia had begun to “Germanize”
the Danish minority in the north by subjecting it to the same school and language policies that so thoroughly alienated the Poles. Following criticism by
Berlin of the slow progress that allegedly had been made until 1877, German
was to be used in schools in every subject with the exception of religious
studies. Repeated petitions to preserve the Danish language submitted during
the 1880s were turned down by the Prussian Ministry for Cultural Affairs.
The failure of these policies is indicated by the large number of Danes who
refused to accept German citizenship. By 1900, relations had grown so bad
that the German authorities began to deport those Danes whom they deemed
openly anti-German. Finally, the election results also demonstrate that up to
1914 the Danish minority remained alienated from the rest of the Reich’s population. The Germans were reluctant to see them integrated, and few Danes
sought anything less than the preservation of their national identity.
As we have seen, many problems arose with the country’s minorities,
whether they lived on the Reich’s periphery or right in the midst of the majority population. It is instructive to analyze these problems. They tell us much
about the basic character of official policy and about the development of German society, its level of tolerance, and its capacity and willingness to cope
with cultural difference. It cannot be said that the minorities were in principle not amenable to sociocultural assimilation. But they wanted synthesis
and resisted the idea of total “Germanization.” It would also be wrong to assume that the majority made no attempts to integrate minorities on any other
basis than illiberal domination. But the advocates of force repeatedly pushed
aside other approaches to integration. Thus a situation arose before 1914 that
many contemporaries viewed with increasing despair. On the one hand, the
“Germanizers” could conceive of only two solutions for the country’s minorities: absorption or ostracism. The ratification of the Reich Citizenship
Law of 23 July 1913 enshrined this concept when it established the racist
blood-tie principle (ius sanguinis) as the qualification for German citizenship, as opposed to the ius soli principle practiced in Western European countries, in which citizenship was acquired by anyone born on the national soil.
112

Basic Patterns of Social Inequality

The Citizenship Law provided grist for the mills of racists who viewed Jews,
Poles, and other minorities as inferior “alien bodies”; even before 1914, a
few radical voices could be heard calling for the excision of these minorities
from the nation.
This meant that, with the passage of time, the country’s minorities were
virtually pushed back into a narrow conception of their ethnicity. In these circumstances, the minority groups’ moderate spokesmen found it harder to
convince their followers that Germany was a society that tolerated the kind
of cultural synthesis and pluralism for which they strived. They had sympathizers on the German side who advocated the integration of minorities while
allowing them to preserve their cultural traditions and to practice them both
in their homes and associations. But these voices, too, found it increasingly
difficult to make themselves heard once their opponents on the Right began
to drown them out with their noisy xenophobic propaganda in the hothouse
atmosphere of polarized politics in pre-1914 Germany.

9. Basic Patterns of Social Inequality and Their Milieus
If the findings of this chapter on the development of German society between
1871 and 1914 can be summarized, it is clear that this society not only was
more colorful than earlier studies have suggested, but also that it found itself
in restless commotion. This commotion was connected with the large-scale
processes of industrialization and urbanization, of explosive demographic
change and secularization. And yet it was not complete chaos and anarchy. It
is possible to discern various lines that separated or unified those 65 million
people who lived in Germany in 1911. There were structures within which it
made a difference as to whether a person was male or female, young or elderly, Jewish or Protestant, banker or maid, Bavarian or Berliner.
The question that must now be asked is whether we can recognize within
this network a basic pattern that would allow us to arrive at more clear-cut answers regarding the character of German society in this period. This question
has often been hotly debated with reference to the argument, first put forward in
the nineteenth century, that social classes constitute the framework of capitalistindustrial societies. In the final analysis, so the argument continues, individuals
are indeed divided or bracketed together by their class affiliation.
We saw at the beginning of this book that the social situation of an individual was strongly defined by his or her position in the marketplace. It made
a big difference whether a person possessed cash savings, landed property, or
factories, or whether he/she earned a living exclusively through employment,
with the size of remuneration in turn influenced by qualifications and skills.
Max Weber has expanded the concept of social class that Karl Marx had
cast primarily in economic terms. He introduced the notion of social status,
113

Society

which led him beyond the economy into the realm of divergent lifestyles and
cultural attitudes. Beyond the question of material goods, he focused on the
“inner existential life” of men and women. German historians have taken up
these ideas and complemented the quantitative material on income, life expectancy, or social mobility with work on leisure pursuits, gender relations,
religious practice, or attitudes toward the environment. In this context doubts
have been raised that it is possible to explain the basic structure and evolution of German society before 1914 in terms of class, even if class integrates
tangible surviving elements of an earlier society made up of estates.
One of these challenges came from generational research. Its protagonists
started from the hypothesis that “the historical experiences that unite the
members of a particular age-group are more important than any social differences.”67 In other words, the real conflicts within society occur not between
classes but between generations. At the end of his careful analysis of the
“Generation of 1914,” Robert Wohl ultimately inclined more toward rejecting this position and, although some recent work on veteran’s organizations
has again emphasized the generational theme, there is no plausible reason not
to follow him.
Thus, if the generational divide is not crucial, what about gender as a category of differentiation? Is this the basic dividing line in modern European
societies? During the past thirty years, historians of women’s studies have
conducted a lively debate on this question, and some would indeed see gender as the most fundamental divide. There is little dispute today that a female
factory worker and a bourgeois woman shared certain experiences and situations within a society that was patriarchically organized. There is also
agreement that class and gender are inseparable and complementary in defining a person within a particular class and that the languages of class are gendered. The problem arises when we look at the system of social stratification
and structured inequality overall and find that a decision on which of the two
relationships has priority can no longer be evaded. At this point it would appear more decisive for the material and psychic situation of those two women
that one belonged to the working class and the other to the bourgeoisie.
As this debate unfolded, Thomas Nipperdey and others began to revive the
older notion that religious affiliation constituted a basic fissure in Imperial
German society. In this context Helmut Smith has advanced the hypothesis
that religious groups have at times influenced daily life more profoundly than
class inequalities. Wilfried Spohn went even further and postulated that “the
identities of members of the working class were constructed along lines that
were essentially based on denomination.”68 This position, too, has remained
controversial, and Nipperdey has been criticized for having given too high a
priority to religion and to the denominational factor.69 If the behavior of voters of the Catholic Center Party, which will be dealt with below, is any guide,
114

Basic Patterns of Social Inequality

it must be concluded that, certain regional “lags” notwithstanding, class, at
least in the long run, proved more important in the behavior of Catholic industrial workers than the conflict between the two major denominations.
One finds a similar outcome of a debate that stressed the significance of
regions in the structuring of German society. Research on the Ruhr area in
particular postulated that regional culture was very powerful in shaping the
structures of Imperial Germany at large. This culture was characterized by the
fact that men and women living in a region had common bonds on the level of
how they interpreted the world around them. They saw these bonds as “natural” and as a way of setting themselves apart from the inhabitants of other
regions. W. Brepohl has even gone so far as to argue that “the people of the
Ruhr area regard themselves as ‘us’, because they feel the same, judge in similar categories, and believe that, a lack of structures and a blurring of borderlines notwithstanding, there exists a spatially identifiable sense of togetherness.”
Celia Applegate’s work on regions points in a similar direction.70
There can be little doubt that space and geography play important roles in
shaping regional units. They mold human behavior and forms of expression,
including language. This was true of the Ruhr region as much as it was of
Upper Bavaria, Dithmarschen in southwestern Schleswig-Holstein, or in the
Magdeburg basin. Yet however striking regional differences—often articulated in local Heimat movements—may have been in a Germany that was, after
all, a federation of states, in the long-term class lines came more powerfully
into play. Language provides a good yardstick here. For an outsider the Baden
or Saxon dialect may have lacked class specificity. However, for the natives
of those regions it did exist. Thus, Hamburgians could instantly recognize,
also from the style of speech, from intonation and gesticulation, whether a
person had grown up in the working-class quarters of Barmbeck or in grand
bourgeois Pöseldorf. Karl Rohe has defined the culture of the Ruhr region as
“essentially a culture of the ‘little people.’”71 In this sense we are indeed dealing with a class culture of those workers who, after arriving from outside the
region, became the backbone of Ruhr industrial society.
Drawing the balance sheet from many studies on the social history of Imperial Germany leads us to the conclusion that, in spite of continuing differentiations by gender, generation, denomination, and region, its society evolved
more and more into a class society. This is not meant to imply a drastic downgrading of the significance of the other dividing lines. On the contrary, our
detailed treatment of gender in the Kaiserreich was designed to highlight its
importance for understanding the development of German society and how it
was gendered. The same point applies to the question of minorities, of generations, and of regional differentiations. Still, it was in the area of class that,
exacerbated by rapid industrialization and urbanization, the sharpest social lines
were drawn, bunching or dividing men and women, young and old. Urban115

Society

industrial society opened up opportunities for upward mobility, but rarely did
the movement, whether intergenerational or connubial, go beyond the slowly
consolidating social blocs. This is where the strongest homogenizations and
delineations occurred; this is where milieus emerged that were distinctly different from each other. These trends also weakened older statist elements that
had characterized social inequalities in preindustrial societies with their staggered levels of special rights and privileges. True, some of these traditions and
practices that stratified society survived in the provincial parts of the Kaiserreich; but after the turn of the century, if not before, they, too, were being undermined by the principles of formal equality before the law and at the ballot
box.
This is why we return at this chapter’s conclusion, after having examined
living conditions, health, housing, and many other aspects of daily life (and
in Part I also the economic realities) in conjunction with marriage patterns
and lifestyles, to the social milieus in which millions of Germans carved out
their social niches.
At the time of the German Empire’s founding, most men and women were
not employed in industry but in agriculture, and here the landless laborers,
servants, and small-holders constituted the largest bloc. The notion that these
people constituted a class has been called into question because they continued to live within an order in which their services constituted one half of a
mutual relationship that imposed certain welfare obligations on the lords
whose land they worked. Nevertheless, it can be said that with the rise of agrarian capitalism this ancient mutuality gradually became replaced by a capitalist
wage relationship. The result was that these men and women found themselves increasingly in a similar situation regarding not only the economic but
also the social and cultural conditions under which they lived vis-à-vis the
landowners and wealthier peasants who employed them.
This division is most noticeable when we acknowledge that the lords behaved as capitalist entrepreneurs freely disposing over the available labor,
while their servants continued to be contractually bound by the Gesindeordnung, the strict code that regulated their lives and remained in force until
1918. The gradual dissolution of the domestic house community is another
tangible expression of this change. Meals were no longer jointly taken, and
the servants’ food was frequently different, thus sharpening the line that had
long existed in terms of accommodation.
Day laborers, the other large group in this rural category, may have been
slightly better off in that they operated within a “free” contractual relationship and were able to return to their own cottage or tiny rented apartment in
one of the “reaper barracks” at the end of their long workday. Many of them
were able to improve their living standards by growing their own vegetables
and by keeping a battery of hens and other animals. Their wives could take
116

Basic Patterns of Social Inequality

up weaving or other domestic industries, and their children would take lunch
to the fields or mind the animals.
There may still have been some estatist elements in the relationship with
their employer; but day-laborers, too, slowly emerged from the age of deference and resigned acceptance of their fate and became increasingly aware of
the gap that yawned between “them” and “us.” Like the agricultural servants,
especially the young ones among them, they resolved the sense of alienation
not by organized resistance but by migration. The feeling of distance to the
local independent peasants may have been less strong than it was with respect to estate owners.
At the same time it would be wrong to see the lives of hundreds of thousands of men and women on the large estates and in villages as totally joyless and humdrum. In rural Germany, work and leisure in large measure
continued to be determined by the rhythm of the seasons. The day began at
four or five o’clock in the morning, and there was always work to do, even
on Sundays. Yet, however limited the horizons of rural life, there was time to
relax and socialize at the end of the day and on holidays. To be sure, this life
was still ruled by the strict hierarchies of the village or estate, except where
the next town could be reached on foot, by horse cart, or by train. Fairs and
other events permitted the younger generation to extend their network of social contacts. They saw different dress fashions, dances, and vaudeville. The
lucky ones among them might even see a silent movie in the last years before
1914. They would bring back illustrated journals and other reading matter.
Railway and road construction could push wide open the doors of the village’s secluded world. Construction workers who passed through had lifestyles
that were very different than those of the villagers, which often exacerbated
existing generational and social differences. Some villagers took the strangers as models of a more independent life; for others they were invaders without morals who did not shrink from stealing, from seducing local women,
and from spreading venereal diseases. The daily life in villages close to one
of the booming industrial regions of Saxony, the Rhineland, or in the southwest was even more profoundly affected. Fresh opportunities presented themselves to find better paying jobs with specified hours of work. Some commuted
back and forth, bringing the town with them to their villages. Their experiences influenced those who had stayed behind. And if local agrarian notables
had been complaining about their increasingly “impertinent” servants before,
they had only seen the beginning of it. Gradually tensions became politicized,
and loud accusations could be heard in the local public house against the “exploitative masters and gentlemen” and the lack of self-determination.
If the move to the city was permanent, newcomers did not take long to develop a consciousness of the situation in which workers found themselves in
the factories: ten- to twelve-hour workdays, six days a week, overcrowded
117

Society

housing conditions, and poor healthcare.72 Yet, it would be misleading simply to view life in the working-class quarters as a poverty culture in which
long hours of sleep on Sundays were the only recreation. However much factory workers lived under the threat of unemployment, inadequate nutrition,
illness, and constant moves, this group of men and women, married or unmarried, developed its own sense of solidarity and was not a “sullen mass”
of people. There was variety in the working-class suburbs, enlivened by customs and traditions that had been brought there from the former homeland.
Accordingly, not only material conditions differed substantially from
those of the local bourgeoisie, but also lifestyles. Language and dress became
hallmarks of social classes. It was a sign of social difference whether a person wore a hat, a cloth cap, or a headscarf, a frock coat, an overall, or silk
stockings; whether the preferred sport was soccer or tennis; whether on Sunday one was driven by coach or car to a gourmet restaurant or whether one
took to the streetcar to one’s allotment or to a garden café on the town’s edge
where “families were able to make their own coffee.” These are just a few examples of how clearly delineated spaces emerged outside the workplace that,
on closer inspection, were in effect attitudes of different class milieus that
created a sense of belonging to a larger societal “camp.”
All these examples cannot be understood unless the dimension of change
over time is factored in. Class milieus that were barely discernible in the 1870s
had taken more concrete shape twenty or thirty years later. Although material conditions of the industrial working class had generally improved by then,
most of its members did not move beyond the ghettoes of the “rental barracks” and workers’ colonies described earlier in this chapter. Therefore, this
was the environment in which they developed their lifestyles, patterns of social interaction, solidarities, and value systems, partly taken from the rural
culture they had left behind, partly transforming the latter.
The world of the bourgeoisie was on the whole clearly differentiated from
this universe. This world, too, underwent change, most tangibly reflected in
the rise of the white-collar employee and the civil servant, who became a
“turntable” of social mobility within the large middle class.73 The small-town
milieu in which artisans and shopkeepers had set the tone became overshadowed by the city. Wherever a provincial milieu survived, it remained largely
untouched by the larger shifts at the national level. Many craftsmen continued to have their own houses with workshops attached and to live as solid
burghers amidst heavy oak furniture and a landscape in oil on the wall over
the settee.
Much of small-town life remained tradition-bound, whether with regard to
the education of children or to social life. On the other hand, the lower middle class, whether provincial or urban, was not as restricted to its confines as
the industrial working class, from which one kept one’s distance. People did
118

Basic Patterns of Social Inequality

move up, suddenly finding themselves in a milieu that was completely
strange. The middling and upper middle class were not only more secure materially and better networked, but also had a more active cultural life. Their
social routine displayed self-confidence. Nevertheless, none of the fine and
manifold gradations within the middle class prevented them from seeing
themselves (and being seen by others) as a social bloc that delineated itself
from the urban working class, as it did, no less strictly, from the nobility.
The important point concerning this latter relationship is that it was not
just the aristocracy that shut the bourgeoisie out “from above.” The middle
class deliberately and proudly set itself apart from the upper class. Only in
some regions, such as Silesia, was there a symbiosis between the two groups
that resulted in the creation of a new plutocracy. To have a few titled guests
at a dinner party did not reflect in most cases an inferiority complex and a
desire to become “feudalized,” but tended to be a display of bourgeois pride.
Nor should business interests be ignored. The “splendid receptions” that Wilhelm and Elly von Siemens held in Berlin, or the “court” with which the
Krupps surrounded themselves at Villa Hügel in Essen, must be seen as selfrepresentations of class, buttressed, as they were, by an elaborate etiquette.
Meanwhile, although there existed in the capitals of the German Empire
an aristocratic leisure class, the main bastions of the ancient upper class continued to be situated in the remoter parts of the country. The structural crisis
of agriculture forced many of them to live more frugally. But there was also
the weight of tradition with its social “obligations” and expectations that defined the culture of large-scale estates. This was not as hectic a life as in business or industry. Going on a hunt often constituted the only “moving and
invigorating element” in an otherwise uniform daily routine.74 Upper middleclass businessmen who spent part of their newly acquired wealth to buy
stately homes and landed property did not find it easy to make inroads into
the rural aristocracy and to be accepted as social equals. Ultimately, the aristocracy remained largely among themselves.
Toward 1914 there occurred at most an ideological rapprochement, also
with the wealthier peasantry. The more the propertied strata in the countryside set themselves apart from the rest of rural society, the stronger became
their desire to stand together politically. Similarly, the bourgeoisie and the
industrial working class, economically and socially already more sharply delineated among themselves and vis-à-vis the upper class, began to form political and ideological blocs whose profile and evolution will be discussed in
a later chapter.75 Of course, we shall have to bear in mind the existence of
“grey zones” between the various class milieus that slowly took shape in the
years before 1914. Future research will reveal further differentiations of historical reality. For the moment, though, our analysis leads to the conclusion
that German society came to be structured progressively along class lines.
119

Society

Confessional, regional, and gender divisions remained important, but did not
constitute the decisive societal feature.
This conclusion, it is hoped, will become even more plausible once the
findings of this chapter are put together with the polarizing tendencies in the
political realm, to be discussed in Part IV. To be sure, along with polarization
there was also the pluralization of society. But before we deal with politics,
we must turn to the development of German culture in this period.

120

Part III: Culture

10. High Culture and Popular Culture
A. Basic Issues
The notion of culture underlying this book is a broad one, as social historians whose interest in cultural topics has been stimulated by anthropology
tend to use it nowadays. The focus is not just on individual artistic and intellectual creativity, but on customs and rituals, attitudes and experiences of entire groups, classes, and even nations. This kind of cultural history aims to
retrieve the overall milieu that influences the actions and reactions of men
and women. It includes the study of conflicts between classes, regions, ethnic
groups, and the sexes over what traditions, actions, and cultural goods shall
be acceptable and freely usable. And it raises the problem of resistance to
dominant cultural norms and practices. Culture, in other words, is never cast
into a tight and generally accepted mold, but is recognized as something that
is constantly negotiated and renegotiated between groups and individuals,
even in those cases where the discrepancies of power and influence between
the parties are considerable.
Of course, this broader framework subsumes aspects of culture that conform more closely to older themes of cultural history, which will be treated
first: the arts, music, architecture, literature, the humanities, and the sciences.
The main interest here is in the analysis of artistic and scholarly creation and
the organizational frameworks within which these activities take place. In
other words, we will deal with what is normally called “high culture,” in contrast to “popular culture.” However, no sharp line is drawn in this chapter between the two spheres, since the divisions are often blurred and overlapping.
Thus, it is well-known that nineteenth-century composers were often inspired by folk tunes. Similarly, writers found the material for their novels by
“keeping their ear close to the tales of the people.” Nor do I wish to promote
a notion of culture that is merely interested in “great works” and disdainfully
excludes the sphere of the “trivial.” Indeed, this latter sphere—even if it is regarded as “trashy”—may tell us a great deal about a society and its development in a particular age. This is true of both working-class culture and the

Culture

emergent “consumer culture” of the late nineteenth century. It also applies to
religious practices and forms of popular piety. These practices often had roots
that dated back many centuries and survived in the rural and provincial milieus
examined in Part II, in particular in the Catholic and Jewish populations.
One final general point remains to be made with respect to the thrust of this
chapter: the retrospective observer usually does not find it difficult to recognize the gradual evolution of artistic styles or of scientific theories and methods. But in tracing such developments we should not forget that time and again
it was a dominant “orthodox” school or approach that interacted with a “modern” and more radical countermovement that was slowly born in this process.
Thus, many cultural debates took the form of a dialectical conflict, and if the
year 1890 is seen by many today as an epochal divide, the roots of modernity and modernism go back much farther. What often exacerbated these conflicts was that they broke out between an older and a younger generation of
artists or scholars. And in many cases it was not so much the radicalism of
the young, but the stubbornness of the established artists and the ruthless
ways in which they used their prestige, power, and influence that made the
controversies so acrimonious.
As to the arts, this opposition, having gone through various preliminary
tussles, could be made out on a broad front by the early 1890s. This was the
turning point of the fin de siècle, of a revolution that “transformed culture in
all its branches. It utterly changed painting, sculpture, and music; the dance,
the novel, and the drama; architecture, poetry, and thought. And its ventures
into unknown territory percolated from the rarified regions of high culture to
general ways of thinking, feeling, and seeing. A very troop of masters compelled Western civilization to alter its angle of vision, and to adopt a new aesthetic sensibility, new philosophical style, a new mode of understanding
social life and human nature.”1
B. The Arts in the Bismarckian Period
If we consider the fine arts against the background of these broader developments during the first two decades after the founding of the German Empire,
what is particularly striking among its practitioners is their conservatism and
suspicion of all stylistic innovation. The aesthetic principles that painting
adhered to in this period had been firmly established for a long time. Above
all, the artist’s supposed task was to depict what was good, true, and great
in humanity. This concept of art engendered a peculiar mix of exactitude
and romanticization that can be found in most works. The political events of
the 1860s provided plenty of inspiration for the production of historical patriotic scenes. Thus, many battles of the Wars of Unification, as well as the
political and social highlights of the period, were portrayed in oil on huge
canvases.
122

High Culture and Popular Culture

Georg Bleibtreu, Carl Becker, Christian Sell, and Anton Werner were
among the best-known artists. Ferdinand Keller painted the frequently reproduced “Apotheosis of William I.” Among the painters of historical subjects
and portraits of the high and mighty were many whose names were soon forgotten. Apart from those already mentioned, Karl Friedrich Lessing, Karl
von Piloty, and Franz von Lenbach were among the successful ones. No
doubt they were all technically accomplished and even important masters
who were concerned with precision and detail. Later on they might cautiously experiment with impressionist elements; but, with the exception of
Adolf Menzel, these artists were shaped by conformism and aesthetic orthodoxy, no matter whether they worked in Prussia or Bavaria.2
This was especially true of portrait painters who enjoyed great popularity
after 1871. A growing number of bourgeois, having come into wealth, had
themselves or their families painted. Portrait sessions were no longer just a
pastime of the nobility and the heads of ruling families, even if William II
loved to sit for his pictures in all sorts of fantastic costumes that said much
about the Kaiser’s state of mind and worldview. Of course, such works were
almost invariably designed to satisfy the patron’s desire to recognize himself
on the canvas, ideally somewhat beautified. There was also a demand for historical paintings and landscapes, as museums expanded and were anxious to
fill their galleries with well-known names. The extension or new construction
of ministerial buildings, schools, assembly halls, and opera houses helped to
create a considerable market for art. Once ministers and city fathers had their
portraits put up in halls and chambers, industrialists and bankers did not want
to be left behind. There was always a special place in the lobby of the headquarters building for a bust of the firm’s founder, with the current owner in
oil looking benignly down from the wall. For those who could not afford an
original, cheap reproductions became available to be hung, in expensivelooking gold frames, above the settee in the living room or dining room: imposing Alpine landscapes or storm-whipped tall ships in the North Sea were
particularly popular.
Sculptors and architects similarly found themselves in harmony with their
bourgeois and noble patrons when it came to commissioned work. They also
moved into a new field of activity. There were first of all those innumerable
monuments that commemorated the victory of 1870 and other historical
events. The intent of patriotic edification and indoctrination was highlighted
at both the pompous opening ceremony and the annual festivities such as
Sedan Day. Until the turn of the century some 300 of these monuments were
put up in Prussia alone, excluding the war memorials that many communities
and cities erected for their fallen soldiers. Among the larger historic monuments were the Hermannsdenkmal near Bielefeld, commemorating the Battle
of the Teutoburg Forest against the Romans (built in 1875), and the Nieder123

Culture

walddenkmal near Rüdesheim on the Rhine (built in 1883). The Kyffhäuderdenkmal, erected in memory of the medieval German Emperor Frederick Barbarossa, and the Deutsches Eck at the confluence of the Rhine and Moselle
in Coblenz followed in 1897.
The last major monument erected before World War I was the Völkerschlachtdenkmal near Leipzig, a granite-clad construction, standing 91 meters
tall, built in 1913 to celebrate the defeat of Napoleon there a century earlier.
Next to Germania, Bismarck became a frequent object of veneration in stone,
whether in the shape of the old man himself, sternly gazing across Hamburg’s port in St. Pauli, or of the so-called Bismarck Towers, like those sitting atop the Deister Mountain near Hanover, or the monstrosity seen along
the road between Erfurt and Weimar in Thuringia.
In 1873, the Siegessäule, or Victory Column, was erected in Berlin. Until
the end of 1901 no fewer than thirty-two imposing statues came to line Siegesallee, which led to the column. The statues represented prominent figures in
the history of Brandenburg-Prussia, each flanked by two busts of somewhat
lesser-known men. Women were not honored in this way. All these pieces of
art tell us a great deal about the notions of art and culture of the patrons, the
artists, and the admiring passersby. They reflect a longing for stability and
solidity. The garden became the “central image of the good life,” in which architects tried to blend culture and nature.3
Beyond national monuments, it was the Heimat movement that extolled
the rootedness of its members in the local. Frequently linked to the idea of
preservation of the natural environment and in many cases also directed
against industrialization and urbanization, Heimat became an important slogan for mobilizing conservative burghers against the advance of modernity.
Residential architecture, too, aimed to show, apart from displaying pomp,
pride, and elegance, how the Reich was consolidating. The artists turned to
what was familiar—classicism or the baroque. The façades of townhouses
and apartment blocs were designed to impress. Lavish and finely chiseled
decorations were more important than simple functionality. The stairwells
were generously laid out in marble with large mirrors along the walls. The
taste of the bourgeois inhabitants for solid-oak furniture and heavy draperies
has already been mentioned. In short, the well-to-do middle class tried to represent itself not only in portraits but also in the public and private buildings
it commissioned in competition with the nobility, which had hitherto set
artistic standards.4 The conservative artistic establishment drew its strength
from this patronage.
Meanwhile, royal interest in promoting the arts did not diminish. Wilhelm
I preferred military scenes, insisting that all details of military dress be
meticulously copied, but he also kept himself informed about general developments in the field. Outside Prussia, the Bavarian kings posed as patrons
124

High Culture and Popular Culture

with a persistent preference for the traditional and its exaggerations. Ludwig
II constructed Neuschwanstein like a castle straight out of a fairytale. His
Herrenchiemsee property looked like a mini-Versailles. In 1874 the neo-Gothic
town hall was completed in Munich, the artistic and cultural center of the
south. Museums, galleries, and churches were established. Friedrich III, the
son of Wilhelm I and in 1888 Kaiser for one hundred days, had personal contact with painters like Werner, Menzel, Piloty, and Bleibtreu. He appointed
himself guardian of the Prussian museums and tried to influence their acquisition policies. The expansion of the Museumsinsel, near the Berliner Schloss
in the city’s center, was particularly dear to his heart.
Frederick’s son, William II, probably had the most pronounced views on
questions concerning the arts. He thought the statues along Siegesallee were
more beautiful than those of the Renaissance. Hermann Knackfuss, Max
Koner, and Hermann Prell were his favorite painters. He also loved the works
of the maritime painter Willy Stoewer, especially those showing the monarch
on the bridge of one of his battleships. In architecture, the Kaiser developed
a passion for the Romantic period and for the neo-baroque. Above all, in his
view, art had a pedagogical function. As he put it during the unveiling of
Siegesallee statues, art should contribute to the instilling of ideals in the laboring classes. All Germans, he added, had the task of upholding these ideals.
They would inspire the population’s lower strata and help them to liberate
themselves from the restrictions of mundane thoughts and attitudes.5 It was,
to be sure, rather a crude pedagogy designed to foster a monarchist German
identity, and we may well wonder how, and how far, his exhortations contributed to a nationalization of the “masses” and the industrial working class
in particular.
That art was to elevate the people and serve as a conservative stabilization
of society was a view that the fine arts establishment shared with Wilhelm II.
Already in Bismarck’s time, they had conquered the important institutions
through which they began to promote their ideas. Werner played a key role
here. As a young artist he had caught the eye of those in power with his large
paintings of historic scenes, like his depiction of the proclamation of the Reich
at Versailles in 1871 or of the 1878 Berlin Congress. He was an accomplished
and careful painter, albeit without much depth. His organizational talents
were all the more remarkable. In 1875, when he was only 32 years old, he became director of the powerful Berlin Academy of the Arts. He also assumed
an important role in the German Arts Association and the Association of
Berlin Artists, whose chairman he became in 1877. Founded in 1841, the Association of Berlin Artists had been granted a royal charter in 1867 and by
the late 1880s had some 600 members.
