Many of these painters possessed no more than average talent and became
Werner’s foot soldiers in his fight against stylistic innovation. Partly financed
125

Culture

by the government, the association staged annual exhibitions, and since everybody wanted to show their work, the pushing and shoving around the chairman
and selection committee were invariably great. With Werner hardly changing
his own style, he also saw to it that younger artists who were more prepared
to experiment and had begun to develop different aesthetic ideas would not
get their work exhibited. This regime remained in power for many years, supported by the cultural bureaucracy, the high aristocracy, spearheaded by the
Hohenzollerns, and the conservatism of the general public. However, around
1890, time was ripe for revolts and secessions.
Literature underwent a development similar to that of the visual arts, except that the book depended less on the support of academies and artists’ associations. Accordingly, nonconformists among the community of writers had
a better chance of achieving a breakthrough, and much earlier in their careers. Hence changes came less abruptly here than in painting. One reflection
of this is that a number of women gained recognition and popularity in an
artistic world that was otherwise dominated by men. Among them were Marie
von Ebner-Eschenbach, Clara Viebig, Gabriele Reuter, Helene Böhlau, Bertha
von Suttner, Hedwig Courts-Mahler, and Eva Marlitt. At the same time it
must be remembered that the narrative style that dominated after the German
Empire’s founding had first emerged in the middle of the nineteenth century
from a critique of the humanist bildungsroman developed by the previous
generation. As early as 1853, Theodor Fontane had argued in an essay that literature must mirror real life. But his appeal was rarely heeded in subsequent
decades. Instead books by Joseph von Scheffel or Felix Dahn’s The Struggle
for Rome were popular.
Meanwhile, real life in an age of rapid industrialization and urbanization
looked different and more depressing than what was portrayed in historical
novels and traditional, patriotically inspired short-stories. The realist novel
began with the assumption that there were clear limits to human action and
that moral ordering principles should be viewed with skepticism. This position
may have contributed to making change easier later on. At the time, however,
it tempted writers to worship the notion of power, if not of the state at least
of history, where good would win out against evil. An alternative position
that was no less conservative was to highlight the contradictions of human
existence and to end up in a noncommittal sentimentality.
Partly for this reason, novels and short stories with a regional flavor gained
great popularity—a development that can be seen in the context of a growing Heimatkunst, or regional art, movement. Theodor Storm became one of
the towering figures of regional literature in gale-torn northwestern Germany.
Hermann Sudermann took up East Prussian, and Paul Keller Silesian themes.
Hermann Löns wrote about the Lüneburg Heath south of Hamburg, while Dietrich Speckmann dealt with Rhenish motifs. Like Ludwig Thoma, Ludwig
126

High Culture and Popular Culture

Ganghofer wrote highly successful novels set against the background of the
untamed landscape of the Alps.
Gustav Freytag, Friedrich Spielhagen, and the Swiss writers Gottfried
Keller and Conrad Ferdinand Meyer are known to this day, but none of them
left the confines of the traditional novel and short-story construction. They
displayed a quietistic pleasure in collecting what had been inherited and was
small-scale. Paul Heyse, on the other hand, is largely forgotten today, although he wrote some 150 novels and received the 1910 Nobel Prize for Literature. He and his bourgeoisified classicism gained a similar position among
writers of the cultural metropolis of Munich as Werner or Adolf von Menzel
occupied among painters in Berlin. Thus, the literature of the Bismarckian
era was neither subjectively nor politically radical. It was a literature that
could be found on the coffee tables of the well-to-do middle and upper classes.
Among its readers were the young ladies of the nobility and the upper bourgeoisie, who seized upon the ever-expanding opportunities to become better
educated.6
Similarly, the plays appearing on many court and town theater stages were
intended to please and elate. Suburban stages specialized in farces, comedies,
and sentimental pieces mostly for the lower middle classes. Outside Berlin,
which became the theater metropolis of Imperial Germany, Saxe-Meiningen
under Duke Georg II developed a type of theater characterized by its “veneration for the text, the inquiry into the historical-geographic ambiance, verbal
precision, the use of prominent actors even in smaller roles, intensive rehearsals, training of supernumeraries, and careful selection of costumes and
sets.”7 This “style-shaping model stage” performed primarily the works of
Friedrich Schiller and William Shakespeare, and it is telling of the general
development of culture and society that the latter—once shown with frequent
noisy interruptions before lower-class audiences—had meanwhile been integrated into the culture of the upper classes. Of course, these groups would
sternly frown upon audience participation. The classical repertoire was concerned with beauty and the victory of good over evil. Meanwhile other theaters offered, apart from light society plays, historic dramas from antiquity
or the nineteenth century.
Neither effort nor expense was spared when it came to the supposedly
exact reconstruction of expensive historic sets and costumes. Theater thus
became an experience for the audience. But rarely did audience members
leave a performance feeling disturbed by its message. Opera was even better
at staging pompous fairytales that had little connection with real life. Only
popular theater might contain the occasional social criticism and mockingly
take on the rule of the clerics, as in Ludwig Anzengruber’s The Fourth Commandment or The Priest of Kirchfeld. Although the Gewerbeordnung, or industrial code, of 1869 had opened the way for entrepreneurial initiative in the
127

Culture

arts, for many years privately owned stages were no less conventional than
the public ones.
However, in contrast to the visual arts, there were exceptions from the start
to the basically conservative style of writing and theater of the Bismarckian
period. And the works of nonconformists became well known enough to pose
a genuine challenge to prevailing artistic canons. This challenge came less
through a change in form than in content, and next to Wilhelm Raabe and
Max Kretzer, Fontane is of course most closely associated with this shift. As
he grew older, Fontane increasingly returned to his postulate of 1853 that literature must reflect real life. In his later works, the sharper social and selfcriticism produced by this return encouraged a younger generation to abandon
the dominant themes of the day. Indeed, if Fontane’s Irrungen und Wirrungen (1888) or Frau Jenny Treibel (1892) are compared with his contemporaries’ novels, it becomes understandable why conservatives were appalled
by his subtle, indirect attacks on the upper classes and his “objective” descriptions of the lives and survival of ordinary people. Even if he never integrated the predicament of industrial workers in the cities into his genre plays,
the full range of human problems, societal fissures, and gender conflicts is
nevertheless found in them. Eduard von Keyserling was another writer who
portrayed a similar rural world coming apart at the seams.
Similarly, the young Gerhard Hauptmann turned his back on idealism. In
1889, his Before Sunrise—a play about immorality, alcoholism, and avarice—
was recommended to Otto Brahm, the director of the recently founded Freie
Bühne (Free Stage) in Berlin, by no other than Fontane. What fascinated Fontane about Hauptmann and led him to compare his work with Henrik Ibsen’s
naturalist dramas was, to be sure, anathema to what the audience expected to
see (and had until then been accustomed to seeing) on stage. Brahm could afford to put on controversial plays, including Ibsen’s Ghosts, only because
they were performed in front of the members of the association that subsidized the Freie Bühne. Government censors could not ban plays shown to
private audiences, and indeed it was for this reason that leading Berlin intellectuals like Theodor Wolff and Maximilian Harden had founded the theater.
It was as misleading as it was typical that Brahm’s opponents immediately
condemned the Freie Bühne as being a platform for the spreading of Social
Democratic ideas. Performances were disrupted by hecklers who had somehow succeeded in getting tickets. Still, Brahm certainly belonged to the artistic opposition that emerged at this time. As he put it in 1891, “the new literature
is revolutionary, the theater is conservative.… Among all factors, none clings
more pertinaciously to tradition and none is in its entire essence as hostile to
innovation as the stage.”8
Like a number of other private stage directors, Brahm worked hard to
change this. When he put on Hauptmann’s Before Sunrise in 1889, he had a
128

High Culture and Popular Culture

first scandal on his hands, surpassed four years later by the first performance
of the same dramatist’s The Weavers, which dealt with the desperate situation
of Silesian weavers prior to the 1848 revolution. No public stage was able to
show such plays at this time. In 1874 a Reich Press Law had been ratified
that required all periodicals and papers to be submitted to the local police for
scrutiny. The rule of prior notification also applied to theater performances.
If a particular issue or play was deemed to violate existing legal or moral
norms, it would be confiscated. Worse, author, publisher, and producer could
be prosecuted under criminal codes that had been sharpened by the 1878 antisocialist laws. Among the most frequent charges were lèse-majesté, obscenity,
and blasphemy. After the lapse of the antisocialist laws, there was no easing
in the application of these codes in the 1890s. Time and again authors were
hauled through the courts. The young Kaiser intervened repeatedly, first in
1890 when he ordered the Prussian minister of the interior to the palace after
he had lifted a ban on Hermann Sudermann’s Sodom’s End—a play whose
title alone made it suspect enough. But it also became clear in this period that
the advance of the new theater could not be stopped and that Imperial Germany was not an art dictatorship. A verdict by the Prussian Supreme Administrative Court in 1894 declared censorship of Hauptmann’s famous play
illegal, and soon thereafter it was performed in Berlin’s Deutsches Theater.
However, it should be added that Hauptmann never arrived at a clear-cut
definition of his naturalism. On some occasions, as in the case of Florian
Geyer, he took his material from a historic period of disruptive change. In Hanneles Himmelfahrt, by contrast, his naturalism appeared not in the shape of an
open social criticism, but of a psychologizing dream poem. For the historian,
the audience reactions are of particular interest. When Before Sunrise was performed, there were loud protests from the audience, especially against the key
figure of the socialist Loth. We have a diary entry about Hanneles Himmelfahrt by the later Reich Chancellor Clodwig von Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst,
who was not a reactionary in matters of the arts. He wrote in December 1893,
“This evening [we saw] ‘Hannele’. A monstrous, wretched piece of work,
social-democratic-realistic, at the same time full of sickly, sentimental mysticism, nerve-racking, in general abominable. Afterwards we went to Borchard’s to get ourselves back into a human frame of mind with champagne
and caviar.”9
However, as powerfully projected by Hauptmann, Halbe, Arno Holz, and
Johannes Schlaf, naturalism and the social criticism it contained of dehumanization and double standards could no longer be ignored. The shift in literature and theater had occurred. Its first rumblings could be heard earlier than
in the case of the visual arts, and thenceforth there were few barriers against
further artistic revolution; indeed, soon naturalism would be overtaken by
other and newer directions.
129

Culture

The same may be said about music—with an important qualification relating to the work of Richard Wagner. The tonal revolution that he triggered
as early as the 1870s was veiled by the backward-looking worlds that he put
on the stage in his operas. His audiences loved him as a Germano-maniac
mythmaker who perpetuated the canon of classic drama through those final
victories of good over evil. If Wagner’s music alone had been performed in
a darkened concert hall, it is doubtful that he would have found so many
bourgeois and aristocratic admirers. The schizophrenic attitude of Wilhelm II
was probably not untypical of that of many contemporaries. The Kaiser could
be heard raving about the heroic themes of Wagnerian operas; but when it
came to passing judgment on the music, he thought that it made “too much
of a noise.” This was a somewhat simple-minded response to what Wagner
had in fact dared to do, that is, to abandon, albeit not completely, the dogmas
of classic harmony. He combined this exodus with visions of a Gesamtkunstwerk, a goal to which the expressionists also aspired later, as they rebelled
against the growing specialization in the arts and in modern society in
general.
Beyond the tonal revolution of a complete chromaticism, which Wagner
initiated and to which we shall come back in a moment, musical life in the
Bismarckian period remained conservative. As with theaters and museums,
concert halls, too, formed part of the furniture of urban and court culture in
Central Europe. To be sure, music lovers did not go merely to hear the great
composers of earlier ages or to be seen in black tie and evening dress. What
also attracted them were the virtuosi on the program or their favorite conductor. Occasionally, the latter might then even succeed in “smuggling” a modern piece into a traditional program of Haydn, Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, and
Mendelssohn, as, for instance, Johannes Brahms would do when he took the
baton. Indeed, the reception of Brahms’s work is symptomatic of the obstacles encountered by more experimental composers. For however much Beethoven was his model and however audibly his work is characterized by a
dualism of a search for order and sudden bursts of romanticism, Brahms was
long denied recognition as a brilliant composer by critics and audiences.
Thus Louis Ehlert remarked on his Symphony No.1 when it was first performed in 1876 that the composer was “a far-flung, speculative mind, a mixture between a musician of the good old days, who had the sound of harmony
in him and whose cradle cover had a contra-punctual pentagram embroidered
into it, and a universally trained man of the modern age.… What differentiates his music from that of all his contemporaries is that he introduces another world into it, [a world that] gently and movingly knocks [at the door
of] our heart.”10 No doubt his disharmonies from that other world were gentle and subtle, as, for example, at the opening of his Opus 111 quintet. Only
later, the once-polite applause changed into enthusiastic cheering. Hamburg,
130

High Culture and Popular Culture

his birth place, made Brahms an honorary citizen, and he ended up as a
wealthy man whose work was used to counter Wagner enthusiasts.
Significantly, Brahms never saw himself as a radical. Connecting with
Beethoven’s oeuvre, he hoped to advance no more than a bit beyond the great
master, and even in his Symphony No. 1 shrill dissonant sequences are heard
only in the first movement. In this respect, Wagner was a very different person. During the 1848 Revolution he had been on the wanted list of the Saxon
authorities. Thirty years later, he was no longer a political revolutionary. His
work came to display a pessimistic undertone; but his gigantic ego gave him
the self-confidence to see himself as the herald of an artistic revolution. That
his bombastic operas would gain him an enormous reputation no doubt tells
us a great deal about the mentalities and dreams of his audiences. But even
his enthusiasts left the long hours of his performances somewhat exhausted
and dazed, and the revolutionary claims of the work mostly escaped them.
After this, the animated light-heartedness of an Italian opera provided a
wonderful relaxation. It was no less characteristic of the catholic tastes of the
musical world, which proved so durable, that operettas enjoyed great popularity. They depicted the rosier sides of life, and any problems raised in them
would dissolve by the last act into a superficial happy ending. For a long time
operetta lovers in Paris or Vienna may well have outdone their German counterparts; but when Franz Léhar came to Berlin, he met with a more enthusiastic reception there than the one he had found in the Austrian capital.
C. The Rise of Modernism
Although the debates on a revolutionary change and new beginning went back
to the 1880s and earlier, the shift became very clearly discernible after 1890.
In terms of cultural developments, this was both the farewell to the nineteenth century and the entry into the twentieth. Any analysis of this development, which accelerated tremendously toward 1914 and beyond, must bear
in mind that it occurred not merely in Germany but also in France, AustriaHungary, England, and Italy. For this reason, it is quite difficult, even with
the benefit of hindsight, to determine the origins of the initial impulses for
this change. Nor is it easy to discover the mainstream along which the transition proceeded. Many currents emerged that often moved in very different
directions. They might crisscross later, as artists and intellectuals tried to find
answers to what they all perceived as a cultural crisis. The debates that will
be examined below often took place in relatively small circles of artists and
intellectuals, whose ideas were usually ignored or rejected by social and political elites. Large sections of the population remained untouched by the
arguments about modernism. At most the proletarian cultural movement represents an exception insofar as it also posed the question, albeit from different ideological premises, of a “new culture” that would overcome that of the
131

Culture

bourgeois age of the nineteenth century.11 The diagnoses and solutions offered by this latter movement were correspondingly removed from those contemplated by Germany’s artists during the Wilhelmine period.
In the light of the analysis provided below,12 one further point must be mentioned here: many of the artists who participated in the march toward modernity pursued aesthetic and often highly individualistic concerns; but this did
not prevent their constant talk about a European cultural crisis from spilling
over into the political and ideological spheres. There they captivated elements of the middle class who already felt deeply unsettled by the process of
rapid industrialization and urbanization. The belief in the idea of progress
and confidence in the rationality human beings that had permeated much of
the nineteenth century were being lost. Economic and societal developments
appeared to make life more anonymous and more difficult to fathom. The
globalization of politics and economics went hand in hand with the internationalization of high culture. While foreign avant-garde artists settled in Germany, a nationalist cultural philistinism proliferated. The rise of new mass
movements on the ideological Right must therefore also be seen against the
background of the cultural shift of the 1880s and 1890s.13 This is why, next
to the evolution in economy and society, the developments in the culturalintellectual sphere examined below provide the backdrop to the treatment of
the new political movements in Part IV of this book.
If the innovations in the sphere of high culture had any common source,
it lay in the conviction of many artists and intellectuals of the time that the
certainties of the nineteenth century had been destroyed or at least had become questionable. The argument was gaining ground that bourgeois Europe
was sick and that its values were in a state of decay. Friedrich Nietzsche was
among the first to make this point, until his ideas and aphorisms were picked
up by the artistic avant-garde a generation later.14 Many intellectuals were
equally convinced that the seeds of European sickness had been sown long
before and that its visible symptoms had hitherto merely been played down.
To unmask bourgeois hypocrisy, to destroy as an illusion the idea of a world
that constantly improved itself—this was the decisive impulse behind the
cultural debates that now also started in Germany with full vigor. Modern
man—women only figured in rather peculiar ways in the mainly male world
of artists—would have the mask torn from his face; he was to be forced to
show his true physiognomy.
The powerful feelings and perceptions of reality described here could be
viewed as part of a generational phenomenon whose significance has already
been discussed.15 True, there were a number of older artists and intellectuals
among the avant-garde who had been early representatives of the “revolution” before 1890. Others had allowed themselves to be convinced that a new
beginning must be made. But on the whole, it was “the young ones,” as they
132

High Culture and Popular Culture

were called in Vienna, who joined the movement. It must remain an open
question whether these young artists and intellectuals were driven by an
oedipal complex. No doubt their rebellion was one against the “authority of
the paternal culture”;16 for in the meantime a generation of intellectuals had
come of age feeling alienated from traditional values and notions of aesthetics. They believed that they had sharply diagnosed the ills of the age and now
made their insights part of their creative wrestling with the world around
them. Earlier art had been assumed to be the expression of universal values
and order through which it seemed possible to achieve a harmonious balance
between one’s inner self and the outside world. Now artistic creativity was
seen as a violent explosion and a revolutionary acceleration toward a state of
disorder and nihilism. Value systems seemed fragmented and transitory. In
this way, the changed consciousness of intellectuals after 1890 first revolved
around emotion and imagination, the construction of the self and its dissolution, its sexuality, and its ultimate destruction.
Given these tendencies, it was quite logical that the revolt in the fine arts
defined itself as a “secession.” The term alluded to the model of the secessio
plebis by which the people of ancient Rome announced their withdrawal
from the Republic and its mismanagement by the patricians. The only question was how far this rejection should go, and this is where further controversy began. Many intellectuals and artists conceived of nothing less than the
creation of a new world in which human beings would live according to principles different from those of the nineteenth century. Others were less concerned with building an alternative world than establishing a situation of
pluralistic chaos, which they thought was the only true reflection of the human
condition. Culture was meant to mirror life in the full spectrum of its possibilities, good and bad, without cosmetic operations to show only its beauty.
The “disorderly” solution to the crisis can be traced most easily in the development of music. When discussing Wagner and Brahms above, I indicated
that the rules of tonality that had been observed since the Renaissance had
been extended step by step in the direction of dissonance. Nevertheless, composers ultimately returned to the prescribed order of consonance and harmony.
It was Claude Debussy who once stated that “music is not just harmony that
caresses the ear and has a pleasant, narcoticizing effect—something that can
easily be absorbed because so much and, one believes, so much that is different peacefully chimes together.”17 The question was how far this peaceful
kind of musical experience should be overthrown. For example, it is significant that Richard Strauss did not immediately break with the established
principles of harmony. Later he wrote with reference to his tone poem Tod
und Verklärung, composed in 1889, that the soul of the patient, who had long
been tortured by terrible pain and shaken by fever, in the hour of death left
the body “in order to find in the eternal universe in most perfect form what
133

Culture

could not be fulfilled in this world.”18 His tone poem Ein Tod, on the other
hand, made a distinct break with classical dogma. Thenceforth his operas also
began to move into dissonances that badly hurt the ears of audiences used to
Mozart or Puccini. And in his Salomé he finally broached themes on stage
that had hitherto been the taboo subjects of bourgeois morality. When he
turned, for example, to Detlev Liliencron’s poem Bruder Liederlich, his music leaves the impression of fragmentation.
It was Arnold Schönberg who finally pushed chromaticism and the disintegration of harmonies beyond Wagner to its conclusion, even if one does not
go as far as W. Mellers in his conclusion that Schönberg’s use of the full
range of the scale’s 12 semitones was “a technical and intellectual necessity.”19
Schönberg’s reluctance in the face of his own radicalism, which reflected the
uncertainty of his age, is evidenced by the fact that he took the step into
atonality only in his 1908 piano pieces and in his Quartet No. 2 of 1922. Up
to that point he preferred generating an overall mood through long modulations and the full use of the chromatic scale. In this way, the listener was
given a feeling of endless suspense of the kind that Strauss had been trying
to provide as early as 1896 in his tone poem Thus Spoke Zarathustra and, in
a different way, that Gustav Mahler had attempted to create in his Symphony
No. 5. Schönberg, too, therefore hoped to create cosmic visions that, incidentally, can also be found in his paintings. It is especially his “gazes” that gain
a central importance in this respect—those eyes that, though they may not
have seen everything, had nevertheless taken in much: the ugly and the beautiful, the good and the evil. They are eyes that give us an inkling of the unfathomable complexity and the inner chaos of the human situation; for they
speak and are mute at the same time, trying to establish a connection between
the subject and the viewer.
Other artists and intellectuals did not want to take the path into permanent
disorder. They tried to reestablish balance in a world that appeared to be
falling apart, though they hoped to do so not by repairing what was left, but
through a fundamental renovation resulting from a search of the self. Since
reality had become problematic to them, they set out on a long inner journey
during which the search of the self would not be constrained by objective
limits. It was not surprising that this search should include the sexual sphere,
which the churches and bourgeois morality had banned from public discourse. While the liberating experience of Eros may have opened up new dimensions of life emanating from the merger of woman and man, sexuality
also generated anxieties stemming from the supposedly unfathomable female
soul. If vitality and a male fear of being “swallowed up” became too difficult
to separate, an escape into narcissism and pure art remained the only way out,
the only promise for salvation beyond reality. Thus, some artists lapsed into
a world of illusions, in which they loved only their own disorderly selves.
134

High Culture and Popular Culture

Not surprisingly, this kind of journey into the unknown was unacceptable
to other intellectuals. Reality had not become blurred, fluid, and meaningless
to them. They refused to retreat from reality through introspection and to create a totally individualized and fragmented culture. Their motto was not narcissistic self-exploration that ultimately threatened to end in adaptation to a
real world that, after all, continued to exist. Instead they set out to change this
world and to create a tangible new culture. To them creativity was not l’art
pour l’art, but a judicial investigation that uncovered social injustice and condemned it in order to bring about societal change. The question was, though,
whether the great task of cultural reconstruction could be achieved through
radical revolution alone or whether it was possible to take the route of modernizing reform and to functionalize the structures and norms that had already
been built in the process of industrialization and urbanization.
Before giving concrete illustrations for the emergence of these divergent
and coexisting currents, it is important to remember that initially all protagonists of change found themselves in the same boat. Differences between
them took shape only slowly. The reason for this is that they initially shared
a common opponent who remained powerful and who was best confronted
jointly. After all, the secessio, the departure from the cultural edifice of the
artistic patriarchs of the Bismarckian age, was not just about abstract aesthetic positions; it was also about whether artists would be able to exhibit work
that had broken away from their elders’ orthodoxies. The question of power
and influence had thus been posed. None of the “young ones” was content
merely to stack up his work in the studio. These artists, too, craved recognition; they wanted their ideas to be taken seriously.20
As early as the 1880s, there had been signs of a growing dissatisfaction
with the authoritarian conservatism and the lack of imagination of the older
generation. In terms of the visual arts, the year 1892 became an important
turning point. In the spring of that year some 106 artists decided to leave the
local chapter of the Allgemeine Deutsche Kunstgenossenschaft in Munich.
Dissatisfied with Lenbach, the dominant figure in the Bavarian artistic community, and also with the funding policies of Werner in Berlin, the secessionists founded their own association, the Verein der bildenden Künstler
Münchens. The repercussions of this “Munich Secession” could soon be felt
in the Reich capital. The Munich artists had seceded partly due to their fear
of competition from Berlin and their disapproval of mass exhibitions designed to please all and sundry.
The crisis in Berlin also involved the more basic question of how far new
styles should be represented. In September 1892, the exhibitions committee
of the Association of Berlin Artists had resolved to invite the 29-year-old
Norwegian painter Edvard Munch to present his work at a special exhibition
in the rotunda of the association’s building. This was a great honor for the
135

Culture

artist. But when the show opened in November of that year, the conservatives
among the membership were scandalized by Munch’s disturbing colors and
motifs. They demanded a closing of the exhibition. Some 250 members turned
up for an extraordinary meeting of the association in mid-November, and at
the end of a heated debate a small majority favored canceling the show.
Many opponents of this decision thought of immediate secession. But little had been prepared for establishing a new organization, and they had no
money to set up an alternative. Moreover, the dissidents were split among
themselves. In the end, they followed Walter Leistikow’s advice to continue
to work inside the existing association and to try to change the attitudes of
the majority. When this proved impossible, partly because of strong animosities between Leistikow and Werner, the “Berlin Secession” was finally effected in 1897. Max Liebermann, who was now fifty-one, became the group’s
new chairman. His work enjoyed a considerable reputation, but he also had
many enemies. His themes were taken from the lives of ordinary people, and
later also included members of the upper class, whose faces fascinated him
and whom he portrayed without pathos. For this reason he was seen as an
open and conscious social critic. Yet, this was a matter of perception. Thus,
one critic professed to being absolutely horrified by the ugliness of one of
Liebermann’s paintings.21 His picture “Jesus in the Temple,” whose portrayal
of Christ offended many Catholics and Protestants alike, led to charges of
sacrilege, and Liebermann became the target for anti-Semitic attacks.
Beyond this kind of obnoxious criticism, it is not easy to classify Liebermann stylistically. It is certain that he left his peculiar type of realism behind
him for a while and, influenced by France, turned to impressionism. Some of
his later works seem to point in the direction of a completion of his naturalist phase. Perhaps it was because he painted so imaginatively that Liebermann first gained his highest recognition abroad, and only later in Germany.
His prestige enabled him to become one of the spokesmen and advocates of
modernism vis-à-vis the outside world. Among the secessionists, under whose
roof gathered a collection of artists of very different outlooks and temperaments, he acted as an integrating force. And now that these artists had left
Werner’s association behind them, they faced no limits as to their experimentation with styles and motifs.
On one side of the artistic spectrum, there were “poor people’s painters,”
as Wilhelm II called them, who advanced their social-critical concerns more
or less openly. Among them were Hans Baluschek, Arthur Kampf, and Käthe
Kollwitz, whose ideological position was close to Social Democracy. Heinrich Zille should also be mentioned in this context, although his street and
backyard scenes, taken from the milieu of Berlin working-class quarters, expressed their accusations in a more subdued form. Some of his vignettes revealed the desperate situation of the proletariat only through a reading of the
136

High Culture and Popular Culture

ironic captions. Most of them tended to confine themselves to the loving portrayal of men, women, and children, who, though living in a desolate environment, had against all odds succeeded in preserving their humanity.
At the other end of the spectrum were those who had developed what
came to be known as German Impressionism, above all Lovis Corinth, Wilhelm Trübner, and Max Slevogt. The contours in their work often disappeared completely in a soft carpet of colors. No ideological aims could be
discerned. As in the case of their French counterparts, German Impressionists did not intend to inform viewers about the subject matter. They postulated subjectivity, the primacy of what impressed itself upon the individual’s
artistic senses. Other painters concentrated on the landscapes and people of
Germany’s different regions, while a fourth group took up the ideas of the
Jugendstil, which was first developed in Vienna and extended to include the
decorative arts. Jugendstil practitioners also tried to challenge artistic orthodoxies, looking for the new in “simplified, stylized forms that were decorative and ornamental.” Above all, its adherents saw themselves as “bearers of
those utopias of happiness, youth, vitalism, and harmony that secretly” one
still hoped to achieve through art.22
Yet, there was little time for consolidating the new currents. Change came
ever more rapidly. Corinth, one of the leading members of the Berlin Secession, briefly toyed with Expressionism, to which Lyonel Feininger, Max Beckmann, and Emil Nolde had firmly committed themselves when they joined
the secession in 1905. In the summer of 1907, Ernst Barlach exhibited his
sculptures of two beggars who represented the nakedness of lonely and shivering human beings between heaven and earth. Conservatives promptly criticized the sculptures as obscene. It was probably inevitable that, just as the
artist’s role in society became the subject of heated debate, divergent styles
would also be at loggerheads inside the secession. It was not just a question
of Impressionism or Expressionism, but also of whether artists had a collective responsibility vis-à-vis society or whether, removed from politics and
ideology, they should only take their individualist creativity as their point of
orientation. Wassily Kandinski, as he put it in 1911, wanted to give voice to
his inner life through his paintings. Finally, there was the competition of older
cultural centers in Dresden, Dessau, Hamburg, Düsseldorf, and Frankfurt—
centers that, thanks to the prosperity of the local bourgeoisie, had seen a
renaissance.
The Berlin Secession in turn became threatened by further splits. Conflict
broke out openly in 1910, when the selection committee for the major annual
exhibition rejected no fewer than twenty-seven artists who had submitted their
work. Among them were Nolde, Ernst Kirchner, Karl Schmidt-Rottluff, and
Max Pechstein. Not without some justification, the latter felt that they were
now subjected to the same treatment that Werner had meted out to secession137

Culture

ists half a generation earlier. Pechstein and others thereupon founded the
“New Secession,” which organized two exhibitions a year later. A similar split
occurred at about the same time in Munich, when the local Association of
Artists rejected a picture by Kandinsky. In December 1911 the so-called Blaue
Reiter group staged a first exhibition of its own. After the arguments of
1910/11, the disintegration of the Berlin Secession could no longer be halted.
Conflicts over styles were exacerbated by personal animosities, and in the fall
of 1913 the whole enterprise finally collapsed when the majority of its members left. Further worsening the situation, the visual arts in general presented
a picture of growing fragmentation. Die Brücke, the group established in
1905 in Dresden by Kirchner and Schmidt-Rottluff, also broke apart in 1913.
It is conceivable that these centrifugal forces might have emerged much
sooner had the bastions of conservatism not remained strong, buttressed as
they were by official policy and by Wilhelm II in particular. Werner’s attacks
against modern art continued relentlessly. In this respect, he was certain to
have been of one mind with the Kaiser, whose silliness in matters of the new
styles was difficult to match. When the monarch was shown a painting of the
Grunewald by Leistikow, he remarked precociously that he had been to this
forest in Berlin’s southwestern suburbs and knew for certain that its trees did
not look like that. No doubt this was the kind of incomprehension with which
other critics also viewed the new styles. The objective of modern art seemed
lost on them. The Kaiser’s amateurism might have safely been ignored if he
had not used his position for political purposes. Art for him was supposed to
uplift people, to impart to them patriotic values. Consequently, “poor people’s painters” like Kollwitz were perceived as a real threat to society. When,
in 1896, she received a gold medal for her work, the honor was not handed
over to her. Liebermann was compelled to turn down a decoration that the
French Legion of Honor had given him in 1889. Even the German Impressionists incurred the wrath of the Kaiser—however apolitical their works
may have been.
Given this antipathy to artistic innovation, it is not difficult to imagine
how Wilhelm II reacted to Expressionism, whose aesthetic concerns ran
counter to a pedagogical definition of art that the monarch labored so hard to
promote. This had far-reaching consequences for the acquisitions policies of
the Prussian museums. It was also thanks to the Kaiser’s and Werner’s interventions that the German art show at the 1904 World Exhibition in St. Louis
was very conventional and unrepresentative of actual trends. At the same
time, the Kaiser was not powerful enough to dictate art policy. Not surprisingly, faced with growing political and societal tensions, the monarch was
deeply disturbed by talk of a cultural crisis and the need to revolutionize the
arts. Occasionally, he intervened impulsively in the decisions of the cultural
bureaucracy. But he could not stop the advance of modernism. Indeed, his
138

High Culture and Popular Culture

conflict with Hugo von Tschudi, the director of the Prussian National Gallery,
demonstrated the constraints upon the Kaiser’s power.23 Tschudi thought the
new directions in painting too important to exclude from his collections. So,
when he asked for a budgetary supplement in order to buy several paintings
of the Barbizon School and the Kaiser denied the request, the director raised
the missing 400,000 marks from private patrons. Following this impertinence, the monarch had Tschudi dismissed, but the latter went to Munich to
continue his important work in the Bavarian capital.
It may also be taken as a sign of changing power balances and of a greater
acceptance of modern art that the liberal press became more and more
scathing about the Kaiser’s interventions in the arts. While works by Liebermann, Corinth, and others continued to be banned from the National Gallery
in Berlin, the Hamburg Kunsthalle proudly acquired and showed them. The
ministerial bureaucracy, eager to portray Germany as a culturally modern
country, pleaded for greater pluralism. Hildegard von Spitzemberg, who came
from the more liberal southwest but had grown increasingly conservative
with age, went to see the summer exhibition of the Berlin Secession in June
1900. As she recorded in her diary, she did see some objectionable pieces, but
there were many others that sparked her interest and enthusiasm.24 Rejection
was often blunter in the provinces. In February 1906 Hermann Behmer railed
in the Württembergische Landeszeitung against drawings of nudes by Auguste
Rodin. One wonders what he would have said to Egon Schiele’s “Redhead
with Spread Legs” of 1910.
Others were more appreciative. One indication of this is seen in the prices
fetched by the works of Liebermann, Kandinski, Corinth, and Kollwitz on
the art market. In 1891, an oil painting by Caspar David Friedrich had sold
for a mere 38 marks at an auction. By 1906, drawings by the avant-garde cost
as much as an industrial worker would earn on average in six months. A few
years later, catalogues listed oil paintings by Liebermann or Trübner at
20,000 marks. However, it would be a mistake to deduce from Werner’s gradual marginalization that he and his supporters had abandoned the fight. They
had on their side broad sections of the educated middle classes who continued to prefer the academy’s catholic tastes to the paintings of secessionists.
What both factions had in common was that art had meanwhile become part
of a culture of consumption that was also reflected in the founding of organizations that tried to represent artists’ economic interests. Thus Die Brücke
offered subscriptions to collections of drawings. A growing number of wealthy
collectors undermined the quasi-monopoly that had been held by public galleries and widened the market. But it is probably also true that art dealers
earned more in commissions than the painters gained for their work.25
As the avant-garde rushed forward into Expressionism, another division
emerged. The Right, as a glance at their newspapers and journals shows, began
139

Culture

using the widely perceived “ugliness” of modern art as a lever for ruthlessly
politicizing intellectual and artistic debates. Toward 1914, the attacks against
what was said to be “un-German” in Wilhelmine culture were leveled in a
language against which there was hardly any protection. These attacks were
not without a dose of irony if we consider that Corinth, for example, viewed
his works as a German contribution to the relentless international competition in the arts, assuming as a matter of course that the Germans would win
it. With this view he put himself in opposition to the concept of art without
borders, advocated by men such as Julius Meier-Graefe, to whom the idea of
national schools was anathema.
This means that, when looking at the greater pluralism of cultural activity
in this period, we must not overlook the polarization of opinions that occurred at the same time. This was a seemingly paradoxical development that,
as will be seen, had its parallel in the realm of politics.26 Even if secessionists ultimately won their victory over the conservatives surrounding Werner,
the country’s elites and other groups involved in the debate over art had certainly not been won over to an unconditional liberalism and an art free of
taboos.
The shift in literature and theater that has already been examined represented a rebellion, but it also involved fragmentation. As in the visual arts,
there emerged those who categorically asserted the autonomous creativity of
the individual artist who must answer to no one and who shunned political
commitment. A leading representative of this orientation was Stefan George,
who, surrounded by his disciples, propagated the retreat into the inner self and
cast himself in the role of a poetic visionary of another world. Accordingly,
those in his circle were preoccupied with the cultic and ritualistic.27 Rainer
Maria Rilke’s aesthetic was rooted in the interpenetration of the inner and the
outer worlds. Ultimately, it appears, Rilke’s attitude towards life displayed an
optimism that the George circle had lost. But Rilke also articulated the changed
approach when he wrote in a letter of October 1907 that art must see life in
“what is horrible and seemingly repulsive” because these aspects of life were
just as valid as all others.28 Meanwhile reality remained perfectly tangible for
those engaged in social criticism. Since naturalism, having quickly attained
an influential position, continued to occupy that place, the fragmentation in
literature and theater proved irreversible in the same way as it did in the visual arts.
In a more general sense, Thomas Mann’s novel Die Buddenbrooks (1901)
may also be said to fit into this mode. In it he portrayed the slow decline of
a patrician family in the Hanseatic town of Lübeck and, more broadly, the
fragility of the bourgeois world. Mann also displayed a strong interest in the
psychology of his characters, even if he tried to distance himself through
irony. This was also true of his relationship with art and its contemporary
140

High Culture and Popular Culture

postulates. Basically of a conservative mindset, Mann in the final analysis was
an advocate of preserving the unique cultural artifacts that the bourgeoisie had
produced. He therefore remained a burgher among his oftentimes eccentric
fellow artists, which in turn made his books more accessible to an educated
readership. The antihero who perishes with and through the world remains a
marginal figure in his writings. Thus, the reader could recognize himself in
Mann, as—in this period of economic boom—he nursed his fin-de-siècle mood.
For Die Buddenbrooks does not just deal with Lübeck; it was the defining
novel of the epoch. Not surprisingly, its author found himself among the
most widely read German novelists before 1914—in contrast to his brother
Heinrich.
Typical middle-class readers had much greater difficulty identifying themselves with Heinrich Mann’s antibourgeois and politically committed critique
of society. Perhaps his characters were not as subtly constructed as those of
his brother; indeed to some extent they were grotesquely overdrawn; but sociologically his books captured basic features of Wilhelminism more accurately. His criticism was not so much of the bourgeois world per se, but rather
of its deformation (e.g., in Professor Unrat), of the emptiness of Wilhelmine
conventions that had become petrified, and of the brutality of the middle class,
especially vis-à-vis the weak and those who spoke up for them. In Der Untertan he put the following words into the mouth of his antihero, the businessman Diederich Hessling, when the latter learns of the shooting of a worker
suspected of a petty crime: “For me this event reflects something really great,
something majestic, so to speak, that some-one who cocks a snook can simply be gunned down, without a court verdict, out in the street.”29 Carl Sternheim, who put the small-town bore on the stage, tended to elicit condescending
laughter from his urban and urbane audiences. The petty bourgeois he presented was indeed despicable, but the audience never really noticed that the
mirror was also being held up to them.
Like the satire of Heinrich Mann and Sternheim, Ludwig Thoma’s sarcasm cut to the bone, especially when he dealt with basic problems of the
bourgeois marriage. In his play Moral, the character of Frau Beermann remarks to her husband that both of them had been “playing theater for many
years”—he as the “Christian head of the family” and herself as the “pious onlooker.” Yet, she added, no ideal had been “shattered.” Their marriage simply
did not have one anymore. It was difficult enough to cope with this kind of
female impertinence, which many contemporaries took as a sign of the alleged general decline of morals and of the growing demands for an emancipation of women. Even harder to stomach was the open literary discussion of
sexuality, including such topics as sex without love, erotomania, and prostitution. Just as the visual arts began to shock people with their modernist
treatment of nudity, literature was not far behind.
141

Culture

Here Frank Wedekind became one of the enfants terribles whose works
dealt with sexual murder, homosexuality, masturbation, and procuring. Wedekind’s Frühlingserwachen (1891) was relatively tame in that it put on the stage
the sexual problems of adolescents living in a world of bourgeois hypocrisy.
His Lulu took its viewers into the sphere of the nocturnal and sensual, evoking deep-seated male anxieties. For him, Lulu was the “primordial figure of
woman,” shown in this case in her most devouring and at the same time most
narcissistic embodiment.
Women appeared more often in another, less disturbing guise, which was
closer to the traditional image of them in a patriarchal society. In some writings, woman was presented as the sensitive being who enables man to discover his own sensuality. As the critic and dramatist Rudolph Lothar put it in
1885 in his study Psychologie der Litteratur, a “woman’s striving for power,
and the competition between man and woman” found expression in the fact
that “female hypersensitivity is transmitted to man in [the process of] looking, enjoying, thinking and touching.”30 Lothar’s statement, in addition to
showing an interest in psychology that was typical of his time, is significant
because he defines this alleged role of the woman as “feminism.” However,
there were limits to the discussion of sexuality in pre-1914 Germany that existed not merely because of the censor’s watchful eye. Even those artists who
counted themselves among the avant-garde adhered to a concept of gender
relations that was by no means “free.” Although interest in the self and subjectivity was great, the female psyche seemed to leave all men bewildered.
Nor was the removal of this barrier achieved through the works of Franziska Reventlow, Lou Andreas Salomé, or Ricarda Huch, who took up the
theme of the emancipated woman. Because, in the eyes of men, women were
assumed to be different, they seemed to possess a kind of frightening power,
and the postulated dissolution of a woman’s individuality in an orgiastic sexual unification was seen as bliss. In these circumstances, the stereotypes
about women that were widespread in society at large offered a stability that
the man-artist, however radical his ideas may have been in other respects, did
not dare to undermine. At most he might deal with the misery of a marriage
concluded for financial reasons; or he might raise the question of equality in
marriage. As far as gender relations were concerned, the last literary taboos
concerning sexuality and gender were dropped much later in the twentieth
century. What was later judged to be great literature was considered pornographic before 1914 and thus existed outside the realm of art. Meanwhile the
older tradition of the sentimental Heimat novel or romantic drama continued
virtually untouched by modernist and postmodernist experimentation.
In many other respects the social boundaries of the arts were fast disappearing. The more Expressionism left naturalism behind, as it had done in the
visual arts, the more shrill became its messages. Although we still possess
142

High Culture and Popular Culture

relatively little detailed knowledge of the intellectual preconditions of this
genre, there were some quite amazing eccentrics among its representatives.
As a French observer wrote in an essay entitled “Youth Searching for a German Culture of Modernism”: “The thronging in the streets, the fermenting of
ideas in literary circles” put the artists “into a state of drunkenness, the more
so since it hit them with an empty stomach.” Thus “a new messiah” presented
himself to the inebriated older bohème “at regular intervals”: “Conradi began
to swoon when he visited the bordellos; Arno Holz, standing between chimney stacks, played the prophet; in the ‘Würzburger Hof’ [a beerhall], Karl
Bleibtreu announced his royal rule over the waitresses and literature that had
been toppled.”31 Among the younger generation, the titles of their journals,
such as Sturm (1910) or Aktion (1911), published by a circle around Jakob
van Hoddis, Kurt Hiller, and Erwin Loewenson, indicated that by now more
was at stake than modest linguistic experiments. In the case of some, Franz
Pfemfert, for example, it was not just his artistic intellect but his entire mind
that seemed in a state of pathological disorder. The leaders, Hiller, Loewenson, and also Walter Hasenclever, and their disciples worshipped an activism
oriented toward the ideas of Friedrich Nietzsche and his “transvaluation of
all values.”
Hasenclever’s work, apart from exploring the theme of the rebelling son,
is permeated by a celebration of life, a cult that could be seen spreading after the turn of the century. As he put it retrospectively, his writings were designed to take him close to life. It was only in his later work, following Hiller,
that he left this narcissistic vitalism behind and turned toward an activism
that ultimately led him to promote the idea of an anti-Wilhelmian cultural
revolution. He expected a new spiritual man to be born from this upheaval,
but he lived long enough to witness an age of destruction. And when, in 1949,
he looked back upon this age, suicide seemed the only way out. Thus, destruction and self-destruction were never far apart in the thoughts and actions
of the avant-garde. However, these intellectuals not only pursued radical objectives; their language, too, was that of an experimental literature and theater whose provocations had much in common with another art form that
flourished before 1914: cabaret.
In dealing with cabaret, it is important to realize that its scope was not
limited to the political cabaret that later reached its prime in the Weimar Republic. Rooted in the Parisian Montmartre, in the carnival tradition of Central Europe, and in the fairground performances of traveling entertainers, the
art form of cabaret saw itself as an alternative to the great theater that tried
to establish a different relationship between itself and the audience. Like experimental theater, cabaret presented anything but an orderly performance
watched from numbered seats. The stage was not set apart from the audience.
Cabaret tried to create intimacy. Its lyrics were both sung and spoken. It was
143

Culture

presented in short sketches as travesties, parodies, or caricatures of the human
predicament, often without reference to the politics of the day. Thus artists
who, like Hauptmann, took the struggle for modern art very seriously might
have their leg pulled by their cabaret colleagues. The names that they gave
themselves point in the same direction. In Munich the “Eleven Executioners”
emerged as the first German cabaret in the wake of opposition to the restrictive Lex Heinze.33 They lasted for no longer than a few years before the authorities forced them to disband. Later, groups in Berlin called themselves
“Echo and Smoke,” “Colorful Plank,” “The Nasty Boys”; in Vienna a group
named itself “The Bat.”
Although political themes were occasionally taken up by all groups, it was
only “Echo and Smoke” that developed a regular series concerned with contemporary politics. In it the archconservative notions of art held by Wilhelm II
and other German princes were mocked. Art censorship was another favorite
topic, even if the bureaucracy’s presence loomed sufficiently large to engender caution. If political criticism frequently appeared in a cultural guise, this
was not just because of a fear of the police, whose methods became harsher
toward 1914; it was also because cabaret was a kind of counter-theater that
tried to provoke and fascinate, to alienate and attract at the same time.
D. Popular Culture, Workers’ Culture, and Industrial Design
Cabaret, as has been indicated, originated in bohemian pubs and cafés, on the
one hand, and in semiprofessional fairground performances on the other,
which cabaret partly rejected and partly transformed. To be sure, these forms
of popular entertainment continued and indeed expanded in the colonial age;
they began to include displays of people from non-European cultures that
promoted a Germanocentric racism. However, these displays also brought
criticism. On the Left they provided an opportunity to criticize the ethos of a
capitalist imperialism that exploited commercially other societies and human
beings. At the other end of the political spectrum were the right-wing cultural
pessimists who worried that the expressive behavior of the displayed “savages” might disturb the domestic order. Conversely, those “savages” might
gain a false impression of conditions in Germany and cause the colonial administrations difficulties on their return.
In contrast to the cabaret’s controversial offerings, publishers in the nineteenth century began to put out texts and songs handed down from earlier
decades and centuries. These publications became popular forms of entertainment among amateurs, whose recitations enlivened family reunions and
club festivities. Reclam and other publishers issued cheap softcover editions
for private occasions. Not surprisingly, this literature had a wide appeal, even
if the cultural histories of the Kaiserreich rarely included it in their discussion of artistic life.
144

High Culture and Popular Culture

This neglect is unjustified, as these were art forms rooted in peasant and
small-town culture before the advent of industry that had now gained considerable significance in the leisure pursuits of the middle classes. The same is
true of “trivial literature,” whose importance has been underestimated partly
because it was associated with the “trash and filth” that also began to be published at this time and partly because all this literature was disdainfully identified with the “masses.” To be sure, trivial literature may not have been of
great and lasting literary value. Nevertheless, in its variants of adventure novels, murder mysteries, and love stories, this literature reached millions of people and should not be ignored in a history of German society in this period.
During his lifetime, Karl May, who died in 1912, earned a large and enthusiastic following through his books. Such success was also enjoyed by science fiction authors such as Bernhard Kellermann, whose book The Tunnel
was translated into twenty-three languages. Murder mysteries with their simple linguistic but complex narrative structures would mostly be found by the
bedside of men. The love story, mostly written in accordance with a rather
conventional basic design, would appeal to bourgeois women who had time
on their hands. Trivial literature was not so much guided by artistic axioms
than by what authors and publishers thought to be the prevailing popular
taste. This was also why existing social taboos continued to be observed, particularly in romantic novels that packaged all allusions to erotic situations
very carefully. It was rare for a “trashy” novel to slide into the pornographic.
Still, these books satisfied certain sociopsychological needs and in this sense
offered more than entertainment and distraction. As the popularity of CourtsMahler or Marlitt demonstrate, this was also a genre in which female authors
could make their mark.
Religious literature remained popular in the country’s rural areas. Although the local priest or pastor continued to be an authority figure in regions
barely touched by the process of secularization, many villagers and elderly
women in particular tended to seek comfort and consolation in religion. Indeed, as more recent research has shown, secularization did not move forward in a linear fashion. Apparitions of the Virgin Mary and other “miracles”
time and again mobilized rural piety, especially among women and young
girls. These needs are also reflected in the literature sold by door-to-door
salesmen: almanacs, bibles, and catechisms were in demand. Of course,
many escaped the pressures of village life by moving to the cities and thus
became the “lost sheep” of the churches, all the more so if at their place of
work or in the ale house they came under the influence of Social Democratic ideas.
Of interest from a sociological point of view is the growth of “trivial poetry,” many of whose authors can be found in an anthology entitled NeuDeutschlands Dichterschatz, published in 1910. The percentage of female
145

Culture

poets in this collection was surprisingly high, probably reflecting a desire for
self-expression on the part of bourgeois women for whom other outlets were
not available within a patriarchally organized society. Among the examples
of Heimat and regional literature, there were many works whose authors
were quickly forgotten, while others continued to be listed in the handbooks.
Both “trivial poets” and Heimatdichter frequently took their raw material
from folklore. This also applies to music, where there existed frequently a
similarly fine line between what became “great” art and what remained “trivial.” At the same time, as Schönberg began to experiment with atonality, the
playing of evergreens by amateur orchestras and provincial brass bands continued. And the old melodies could also be heard in the coffeehouses of the
major cities.
Even in theater we find various links between “high” culture and “mass”
culture. However, unlike “trivial literature,” the old suburban stage experienced a decline that cannot be explained merely by the competition of boulevard theaters. Members of the industrial working class who labored ten to
twelve hours a day, six days a week, did not make for as amenable an audience as the townspeople of all backgrounds had been before the arrival of the
factory system. This began to change not long before 1914, when the “masses”
had gained more leisure time, and some had slightly more money in their
pockets. People did go back to the theater, although by this time the cinema
had appeared on the horizon as a medium of cheap popular entertainment. In
1910 there were 456 cinemas in twenty-nine cities; three years later, some
2,400 cinemas had opened their doors, screening a weekly silent movie,
mainly of foreign origin and of often stunning simplicity. Circa 1914 cinema
attendance was around l.5 million viewers a day. In some cities people could
choose between up to 30 theaters by this time. In Berlin that figure ran as
high as 139.32
Many of these cinemas first appeared in the working-class quarters of big
cities. Later, splendid “film palaces” were built in middle-class areas. However, this shift did not diminish the unease felt by many bourgeois about pre1914 popular culture, which they believed portrayed the sensational, the
eccentric adventure, and “women of the night.” The viewer experienced the
frivolous, the erotic, or the criminal plot in a darkened theater. Who could
know what was going on in the back rows among young men and women?
Thus, debates about “smut films” followed on the heels of earlier discussions
about “smut literature,” in which professors, theologians, journalists, and
politicians participated, while the censors continued their work in the backrooms of their ministry.33
Meanwhile the traditional theater, often subsidized by city fathers, just as
the princes took pride in supporting their court theater, attracted primarily the
well-off and educated bourgeoisie. The lower classes became involved again
146

High Culture and Popular Culture

later through the Volksbühne, or People’s Theatre, movement, which offered
discounted subscriptions and was related to the rise of the Social Democrats.
We are thus moving into an area of cultural activity whose growing importance is partly related to the above-mentioned rejection of officially sponsored arts; but it also emerged from a political critique of the products of an
increasingly commercialized “trashy art” offered to the “masses” at fairs or
in the cinema. While the impact of the working-class movement on politics
will be explored in more detail in a later chapter,35 this critique, whether articulated by the Social Democratic Party or by the unions, went beyond the
more immediate aims of these two movements. Starting from a Marxian vision of the world and of history, it aimed to reshape the cultural consciousness of its members and of the industrial working class as a whole. The task
was to create the preconditions for the establishment of a new culture that
would replace bourgeois culture once socialism had prevailed over capitalism. Social scientists and historians have in retrospect raised the question of
whether working-class culture, as it presented itself in the German empire in
advance of the emergence of socialism, represented a “subculture” or an “alternative culture”—a problem that will have to be included in our analysis.34
It is against the background of these objectives of the German workingclass movement in the realm of culture that the emergence of an extensive
network of cultural organizations after the lapse of the antisocialist laws in
1890 must be viewed. None of these objectives related to any of the “secessions” described above, but all of them identified more or less strongly with
Social Democracy. The roots of this network of associations predate 1878,
but its foundations were laid during the twelve years of persecution that followed. This was because workers’ singing clubs and gardening associations
had not been officially banned, even though they, too, found that the police
watched them ever more persistently. In these circumstances, it was only after 1890 that the Social Democratic cultural movement began to play a significant role in the cultural history of the Kaiserreich. Modernism, which
came into its own at about the same time, was not directly linked to it. The
avant-garde’s cultural radicalism notwithstanding, only a few artists openly
professed their allegiance to the Social Democrats. However, there were
common themes.
The working-class movement—very much the product of industrialization and urbanization—was highly critical of the existing socioeconomic and
political order. While accepting the idea of a modern industrial society, they
searched for new forms of organizing this type of society. In this sense there
existed an intellectual bond between Social Democrats and those elements
among the artistic avant-garde who were not driven by a phobia of industry
and urban life. Whatever the commonalities, the relationship was never free
of tension. To no small degree this was due to those members and spokesmen
147

Culture

in the working-class movement who, while favoring economic and political
reforms, remained wedded to conventional ideas about the arts and felt alienated by the aesthetic concepts of modernism. This in turn led to disputes
within Social Democracy and to contradictions that will be dealt with in a
moment. First we must look at the quantitative dimensions of the cultural
movement.
When Social Democracy once again took off after the lapse of the antisocialist laws, it initially did not have many more than the 26,000 workers who
had been members in 1875. Just before the outbreak of the Great War, this
figure had risen to a little over 1 million. The growth of the Social Democratic trade unions was even more momentous: in 1891 the membership total
had been around 278,000; by 1913 it had grown to 2.5 million. Beyond participating in politics, what were the cultural activities of the socialist movement? The first workers’ singing clubs had formed in the 1860s. Many of
these and other organizations survived official harassment under the antisocialist laws, while others that were believed by the police to be socialist
fronts were forced into liquidation.
As soon as the antisocialist laws had disappeared in 1890 and the working class was once again permitted to organize, cultural associations experienced an explosive expansion.35 In 1892, a congress was held at Berlin in
which some 319 singing associations participated. Representing over 9,000
members organized in fourteen regional associations, they founded a national
association, the Liedergemeinschaft der Arbeiter- und Sängervereinigungen
Deutschlands. By 1914, this movement had grown to some 200,000 members. Between 1907 and 1912 slightly fewer than 100,000 new members
joined. In Berlin, membership rose from 1,200 in 1890 to 7,000 in 1905, divided among some 194 local branches. From 1899, the umbrella organization
published its own series, entitled Der freie Sänger, which printed evergreens
and new compositions. Later the newspaper Arbeiter-Sänger-Zeitung was
added; in 1913, its print run reached 113,000 copies.
By contrast, workers’ associations devoted to the promotion of sports had
not existed before 1890. But thenceforth they mushroomed all over the country. The movement was spearheaded by gymnasts, whose number rose from
3,500 in 1893 to 187,000 in 1914. They published their own paper, the ArbeiterTurnzeitung, whose circulation reached approximately 119,000 copies in
1913. Their main activities were innumerable athletics trips, competitions, and
parades. With a total membership of 150,000 by 1914, the workers’ cycling
clubs also gained a very respectable size. In Leipzig in 1893, they formed a
national organization, which had no more than 10,000 members as late as 1902;
but in 1913, some 168,000 copies of the association’s paper were printed.
Workers’ rowing clubs and swimming clubs remained much smaller. The same

148

High Culture and Popular Culture

was true of workers’ chess clubs and short-hand associations, which formed
their national organizations in 1912 and 1909 respectively. Finally, by 1914
there were some 6,400 organized “Proletarian Free-Thinkers.”
There are no exact membership figures for proletarian amateur theater
groups. More is known about the above-mentioned Volksbühne movement,
which offered its subscribers reduced-price tickets for professional stages.
They operated successfully in a number of cities, with Berlin becoming the
main stronghold. There the Freie Volksbühne had been formed as early as
1890. It grew to become an organization with some 17,500 members in 1910
and was prosperous enough to establish its own stage four years later. The
Neue Freie Volksbühne that had seceded from the Berlin organization in
1892 even reached a membership level of 48,000 by 1910.36
Finally, we must deal with the workers’ educational movement, which for
financial and obvious ideological reasons was probably closest to the SPD
and trade unions. After many years of fragmentation, this movement finally
established in 1906 a Central Educational Committee that oversaw the expansion and coordination of lectures and seminars. It employed an impressively
large number of “migrant lecturers” who, traveling all over the country,
offered either one-time evening lectures or seminar series. According to the
Central Educational Committee’s annual report, no fewer than 323 talks and
44 courses were given in 1907/8 in which close to 5,000 men and women
participated. In 1912/13 there were 941 talks and 206 courses with 29,836
participants. During that year, the committee spent some 51,674 marks in support of these courses. The remaining expenses (about 80 percent of the total)
were covered by fees varying from around twenty pfennigs for a one-time
lecture to one mark per seminar course. Including other cultural events, such
as poetry readings, concerts, and lieder evenings, the 244 local workers’ educational associations spent over 680,000 marks in 1911. During the following year, the total reached 732,000 marks.
Meanwhile the Workers’ Educational School, founded in Berlin in 1891,
offered short courses on more strictly ideological and political topics. The
same held for the Social Democratic Party School, which was established in
1906. The latter, from which some 240 students had graduated by 1914, was
charged with the training of party cadres. Those attending Trade Union Schools,
which were also created in 1906, received a more pragmatic education than
their counterparts at the Party School. Finally, a number of party and trade
union libraries opened their doors to ordinary members at the local level. Up
to 1914, there were some 1,100 such institutes in 748 cities and workingclass neighborhoods. Their total holdings reached 834,000 volumes. From
1896 to 1910, Berlin’s Trade Union Library increased its holdings from 11,500
to 50,000 volumes, which could be borrowed at thirty-three local branches.

149

Culture

The library of the Wood Workers’ Union spent some 5,000 marks on books
per annum. Some eighty-seven of the larger workers’ libraries had their own
reading rooms.
As far as the membership structure of the workers’ cultural movement is
concerned, there appears to be general agreement that its active elements
came from the younger generation. Thus, in 1909 over half of the members
of the proletarian singing clubs in the district of Leipzig were between the
ages of twenty-six and thirty-five. Similarly, during the first decade of the
twentieth century, between 66 and 69 percent of the students at the Workers’
Educational School were between twenty and thirty years of age. The share
of passive members was particularly high in some singing clubs, many of
whose members were presumably elderly people. Women participated
in growing numbers. In 1910 some 277 of the 2,818 workers’ choirs were
female, and another 8 percent were mixed. The remaining 82 percent continued the tradition of purely male choirs, however, occasionally organizing an
“evening with ladies.” Women’s sections were added to the gymnastics associations. Here, too, tradition and patriarchalism remained powerful hurdles
when it came to the question of whether or not women should be allowed to
wear athletic shorts. Meanwhile, the share of women at the Berlin Workers’
Educational School vacillated between 10.9 and 12.1 percent around the turn
of the century. It dropped to 5.6 percent in 1905/6 before rising again to 7.6
percent in 1909/10.
In light of the statistical material presented so far, there can be little doubt
that the two decades following the lapse of the antisocialist laws saw the
emergence of a colorful and sizeable cultural movement that attracted above
all Social Democratic industrial workers. Differences of opinion have arisen,
however, as to how this movement should be seen within the larger cultural
development of the Kaiserreich. Guenther Roth has argued that the milieu
that defined the cultural life of the working-class neighborhoods in the cities
was a “subculture,” while Vernon L. Lidtke went beyond this view, speaking
of an “alternative culture.”37 The latter believes that a clear divide existed between the politico-economic and cultural institutions of the country and
those created by the Social Democrats. The proletarian model of society, he
added, rejected existing notions of culture and developed a “credible alternative” to them. According to Lidtke, this alternative extended beyond political
and economic systems; it existed in all spheres of life, including family,
leisure, religion, and education. Socialists and nonsocialists alike were aware
that the working-class movement was forging “a world of its own” and lived
in a “peculiar socio-cultural milieu.”38
This divergence was not only subjectively perceived as a threat by the rest
of society, but in fact it presented one objectively. These realities, Lidtke continues, were independent of the much debated question of whether or not the
150

High Culture and Popular Culture

Social Democrats themselves really wanted to overthrow the existing order
by revolutionary means. In this sense their alternative vision was radical and
could not easily be integrated into the majority society and culture on the basis of the status quo.
What, in Lidtke’s view, lends strong support to his line of argument is that,
first of all, the persecution of the Social Democratic movement, including its
cultural organizations, did not stop after 1890. The Reich Association Law of
1908, it is true, gave greater precision to a number of principles and thus constrained the possibilities for hostile government action against workers; it
also standardized a large variety of laws that existed in the federal states. And
yet, as Lidtke points out, harassment continued. Time and again difficulties
arose after 1908 concerning the membership of young people in Social Democratic sports and cultural organizations. Nor did the police ever abandon
their restrictive practices when it came to granting licenses for rallies and
demonstrations. Surveillance did not stop. Social Democratic associations
were treated somewhat more generously in some localities; but just as in the
case of the artistic avant-garde, the higher levels of government tended to
step up their attempts to muzzle the cultural and political activities of the
working class during the last years before World War I.
Lidtke also felt confirmed in his view of an alternative culture by the fact
that associational life in Germany became increasingly stratified and thus
must be related to the “segmentation” of society more generally. And, indeed, it is important to appreciate that the Social Democratic cultural movement represented but a fraction of a rich associational life that comprised
literally thousands of organizations. Yet, it would have been quite unthinkable for a factory worker to join the same club as his boss, just as they would
not have celebrated the Munich October Fest sitting next to each other in one
of the large beer tents, exceptions always granted.
This stratification of cultural life explains why, for example, there existed
no fewer than five singing clubs in the small town of Weinheim, north of Heidelberg. One of these attracted the local workers; another, the town’s civil
servants. Artisans dominated the third one, and the shopkeepers and traders
the fourth. Finally, there was the Singverein (singing club), the oldest organization in town, whose membership was made up predominantly of the local
elite. A similar segmentation of associational life appears to have occurred in
