other towns. Thus in 1896 no less than 74.4 percent of the membership of
Hamburg’s ninety-seven singing clubs were card-carrying Social Democrats.
Some 52.1 percent were trade unionists, and a mere 10 percent belonged to
none of these organizations. In 1910, the equivalent shares in Leipzig even
amounted to 85 to 90 percent. Some of the associations made membership in
the SPD a condition of acceptance. Initially, the share of nonworkers or nonSocial Democrats appears to have been higher in some of the cultural clubs;
151

Culture

but soon so many Social Democrats applied for membership that the sociology as well as the ideological orientation of the organization underwent a
marked shift. Conversely, complaints could be heard occasionally at the level
of the national organization that some local branches were becoming too
bourgeois.
While the attitudes of the authorities and of other social groups, as well as
the sociology of the cultural associations, seem to confirm Lidtke’s concept
of an “alternative culture,” organizational forms and the substance of associational life must also be considered. Certain forms, such as constitutions and
written rules of procedure, were required by law and thus cannot be used
against Lidtke, even if the authors of these procedures took the “bourgeois”
equivalents as their model. On the other hand, there are indications that some
of the routines and petty squabbles of the older middle-class associations,
normally criticized as Vereinsmeierei, began to rub off on the style of the proletarian movement. Sports clubs were especially prone to developing quite
rigid hierarchies. Sociability frequently also imitated the customs of bourgeois associations, and if group photos are any guide, there was a more general trend toward the propriety of mainstream associational life.
The criticism of such adaptive behavior, which was voiced at various levels, pinpointed the dilemmas of a Social Democratic cultural movement that
operated in the trendsetting milieu of a bourgeois society. The dilemma was
even more acute with regard not to the styles but to the content of associational life. Thus the sports clubs came under fire because they were accused
of having fallen for the competitive ethos of the bourgeoisie. By 1911 this
criticism was taken seriously enough for the national organization of the Social Democratic gymnasts movement to pass a resolution that, while competition between individuals was acceptable, there should be no competitive
events between clubs. Internal critics were also unhappy with a tendency to
adopt the traditions of Friedrich Ludwig Jahn, the revered founder of the
bourgeois gymnasts movement. On the other hand, there were those who defended these practices, feeling that physical fitness was useful at the workbench or in the daily political struggle against the existing monarchical order.
While it would be wrong to dismiss these phenomena, Lidtke is right in
pointing to the many indications that extraneous elements were but selectively
incorporated and their meaning was recast. Thus, the focus of the Jahn movement on nationalism became displaced by internationalist concepts of freedom and liberty. The names that the Social Democratic associations gave
themselves also indicate that their self-image was one of separateness. Some
choirs called themselves “Among Us,” “Freedom,” or “Forward.” An analysis of their song collections shows that choirs chose songs with the aim of
generating a Social Democratic sense of solidarity and political consciousness. Religious and patriotic texts were excluded. The focus was on workers’
152

High Culture and Popular Culture

songs; popular tunes were given new lyrics. On social occasions, following,
for example, a May Day parade, when members moved to the gemütliche
part, one would intone the “Workers’ Reveille” and the “Workers’ Marseillaise.” Since the singing was frequently accompanied by the consumption of
plenty of alcohol, these events regularly incurred the disapproval of Social
Democratic teetotalers. Overall, these activities and the language used in them
appear to have been designed to create internal cohesion and distance from
nonsocialist associations.
An examination of theater and literature shows, however, that the relationship between bourgeois and proletarian culture was nevertheless not as
clearly one of juxtaposition as Lidtke made out. There emerged, as has been
mentioned, various theater groups that were close to the working-class movement; but their performances remained largely naive and amateurish. A number of committed socialists, among them Willi Münzenberg, Manfred Wittich,
and Ernst Däumig, also produced plays. But these works tended to suffer
from an unresolved (and probably insoluble) tension between art and agitprop. This was also the problem with a five-volume collection of poetry that
appeared under the title of Deutsche Arbeiterdichtung in 1893 and to which
Karl Frohme, Adolf Lepp, Max Kregel, and others contributed.
The debate that ensued among Social Democrats became quite sharply
polarized. Some, like the dramatist Otto Krille, took the position that “tendential art” was valuable not merely from a political-ideological point of view,
but also from the standpoint of aesthetics. It was Franz Mehring, above all,
who objected to this notion, postulating that politics and great art were irreconcilable. He accorded a universality and timelessness to the aesthetic principles of the classical period and its literary giants. In his view, Goethe and
Schiller were the models to be emulated. However much they represented the
tradition of bourgeois theater, their works were to be read and staged for the
cultural refinement of the rank-and-file. At the same time, with the support
of August Bebel and Wilhelm Liebknecht, Mehring rejected Naturalism because he found it too pessimistic. Having shunned tendential art, opting instead for the classics, the SPD leadership tried to curb an openly ideological
theater. Political enlightenment and education remained confined to the arena
of politics rather than that of the stage. Not surprisingly, therefore, the party
promoted the Volksbühne movement, which offered plays that lived up to
Mehring’s standards.
This should not lead us to assume as a matter of course that working-class
Volksbühne audiences stepped outside the sphere of Lidtke’s “alternative culture,” overwhelmed by the magnetic force of a hegemonic bourgeois culture
whenever they saw a play by Goethe or Schiller. One must ask which plays
were in fact selected for subscription. Even more crucial is the question of
what working-class audiences took away from any given evening at the
153

Culture

Volksbühne. Although we shall probably never know for certain, as exit polls
did not yet exist, we should not assume that these audiences came away with
the same impressions as bourgeois theatergoers in the more expensive seats.
This assumption would seem to be justified when considering reader responses to literature. Here we move on much firmer ground because some
documentation on the borrowing habits of members of workers’ libraries has
survived.39 We also have information on lecture offerings and attendance.
As to the latter, the Party School, not surprisingly, concentrated on politics
and ideology, and Rosa Luxemburg was among the most popular lecturers in
1909/10. Other lectures and seminars had a more practical content or were
devoted to general topics of a more historical-political character. In the last
years before World War I, poetry readings showed a preference for Goethe,
Ferdinand Freiligrath, and Heinrich Heine. Programs also included Reuter,
Wilhelm Busch, and the great Russian poets. At party or trade union libraries,
most librarians tried to keep a good selection of the classics of Marxism on
the shelves. They bemoaned the poor taste of their readers, who forced them
to make “trivial literature” available. Consequently, Marx’s Das Kapital rarely
appears on the borrowing lists. Bebel’s book Die Frau und der Sozialismus
was more popular and also sold well in shops. All in all, the belles lettres
were most in demand. At the top of the 1908 borrowing list for Leipzig was
the adventure story writer Friedrich Gerstäcker, whose books were checked
out 2,844 times. Goethe and Charles Dickens appeared in the twelfth and
thirteenth places. According to the annual report of the Berlin Transport
Workers’ Union Library, Alexandre Dumas’s books were borrowed some 800
times, with his Count of Monte Cristo being particularly popular. Emile
Zola’s books came in second place. Other popular authors at Social Democratic workers’ libraries between 1908 and 1914 were Ludwig Ganghofer,
Clara Viebig, Maxim Gorki, and Jules Verne.
These lists can be fruitfully compared with those of Leipzig’s public libraries. One list, covering the fall of 1903 to the fall of 1904, shows Clara
Viebig at the top, followed by Edward Stillgebauer, Elisabeth von Heyking,
Franz Adam Beyerlein, Gustav Frenssen, and Thomas Mann. Apart from the
ranking differences, the preferences of Social Democratic borrowers seem to
indicate that works, whatever their literary merit, were read not merely because of their gripping plots, but also because they presented a social-critical
message. This may be particularly true of Zola and Dickens, but probably
also of Dumas’s Count of Monte Cristo, at the end of which justice and human greatness win out.
In general it may therefore be assumed that the patterns of stratification in
German society discussed above in Part II were reflected in the cultural
sphere.40 Indications of this can be found not only in the separatism that
marked the behavior of Social Democratic associations, but also in the hos154

High Culture and Popular Culture

tility with which other groups and the police viewed the workers’ cultural
movement (not to mention the SPD and trade unions). It also seems that artworks that were clearly products of bourgeois culture were absorbed through
the filter of the class experiences of industrial workers. They were taken in
selectively and partly reinterpreted. However, Lidtke’s notion of a tangible
“alternative culture” should perhaps not be understood in the sense of a
“ghetto culture” that existed in isolation and ostracism on the margins of the
majority culture. The workers’ cultural movement was sufficiently deeply
immersed in its national environment to be influenced not only by its aesthetic but also its ideological norms. This is strongly reflected in the increase
of reformist moods and tendencies within the labor movement at large, as
well as in the desire to gain recognition from the rest of society and in the
growing stress on respectability. The fact that this recognition was persistently denied by the majority has already been dealt with in our analysis of
social stratification and will be taken up again when we consider the political realm in Part IV.41
In this connection it is also relevant that, though anxious to preserve their
organizational autonomy, working-class cultural associations always insisted
on equal treatment, not least by the authorities and the police. If these demands could be fulfilled without revolution, a growing number of members
were, it appears, prepared to integrate themselves into the mainstream of
Wilhelmine culture, or at least into those currents that neither looked backward nor proclaimed a cataclysmic “transvaluation of all values.” The currents with which the workers’ cultural movement felt an affinity were those
that rejected cultural pessimism and took a positive view of industrialism and
its urban culture. The labor movement as a whole welcomed in principle industrial and technological change, also in its cultural implications.
What they were critical of and wanted to reform were the ways in which
economic, social, and political power were distributed in society. In this latter respect, the labor movement of course differed fundamentally from those
conservative and bourgeois groups who viewed the processes of industrialization, urbanization, and secularization with deep skepticism. If the cultural
distance of the labor movement was narrowing, it was toward those liberal
forces that were themselves wedded to a fuller exploitation of the potentials
of industrial society through gradual transformation. As these forces perceived industrialization as a cultural as well as a socioeconomic phenomenon, they, too, were searching for norms and values deemed appropriate to
the machine age and a laboring industrial society. In other words, there were
affinities that made the workers’ cultural movement something less than a
strictly separate phenomenon that developed an osmotic relationship with
bourgeois culture. We must also bear in mind the considerable pride in Social Democracy’s organizational achievements. This pride was not always
155

Culture

sharply set apart from a more generalized patriotism that the Reich government cunningly exploited in July 1914. At that point defensive responses to
the allegedly imminent threat posed by Russian autocracy were mobilized to
bring the working class and its movements into the war.
The movement that represented the optimistic position within the dominant culture rallied in a number of organizations, among them the Werkbund.
Within a year of its founding in 1907, this association had 492 members; by
1914, the membership had grown to around 1,870. Its founders hoped that
the Werkbund would fulfill a number of missions. They started from the basic
premise that in the twentieth century a bourgeois culture that was not urbanindustrial would be unthinkable. Accordingly, the Werkbund saw itself as a
mediator between industry and the arts. In particular it promoted the applied
arts by interesting entrepreneurs in modern design and industrial architecture. Two of the key figures in the movement, Hermann Muthesius and Friedrich Naumann, believed, in marked contrast to the cultural pessimism of
other intellectual circles, that the dawn of the machine age would usher in a
higher stage in man’s cultural development from which all individuals, not
just the producers, would benefit. This is why they hoped to bring about a
synthesis between high culture and popular culture that would ultimately create and foster a democratically organized society.
This latter idea was taken from British and American models that the
founding fathers of the Werkbund had in front of them. On the British side
was the Arts and Crafts movement, inspired by William Morris. Through it
the Germans incorporated an artisanal tradition, though without Morris’s anticapitalism. However, they did adopt his criticism of the production of inferior goods that merely undermined the producer’s joy of crafting them. The
emphasis was therefore on high quality, also as a way of motivating workers
and raising their self-esteem. In the United States, the architect Frank Lloyd
Wright had been trying since the 1890s to unite artists and entrepreneurs
within the framework of a democratic industrial culture. Similar professions
of democracy notwithstanding, the Werkbund continued to display elitist
traits. The average consumer, it is true, was to be educated to develop a new
sense for style and quality; yet the undoubtedly beautifully designed products that the movement began to offer were hardly for mass consumption.
Only the wealthy could afford them.
One reason for this apparent contradiction was that many members saw an
unbridgeable gap between the unique creativity of the individual artist and
the standardization of industrial products. Thus, when Muthesius raised the
question of standardization on the occasion of the opening of the Werkbund
exhibition at Cologne in July of 1914, he unleashed major conflicts and
barely avoided a secession. His critics were not opposed to the creation of a
coherent modern style; but they objected to his demand that this idea be pur156

High Culture and Popular Culture

posefully implemented by the collectivity of artists. Standardization was to
be the result of the stylistic decisions of the individual artist. As Henry van
der Velde, one of Muthesius’s critics, put it, his aim was the reproduction of
a “singular creation” on thousands of copies under the strict personal control
of the artist.42 The stress, he added, was on “singular creation” and uncompromising quality. In these circumstances it is not surprising that the Werkbund’s efforts were directed less toward educating the consumer than toward
effecting a close cooperation with industry as a first step toward generating
a new sense of quality and art. The main task was the introduction and development of a modern product design.
These ideas met with a positive echo among some entrepreneurs (even
though most of them came from the new branches of the second Industrial
Revolution, such as electrical engineering or chemical manufacturing) who
were more used to thinking in the social and political categories of the modern movement. Thus, Peter Bruckmann, a silverware manufacturer from Heilbronn, had made himself the spokesman of a number of modern entrepreneurs
at the time of the Werkbund’s founding. During the same year, Walther Rathenau’s Allgemeine Elekrizitäts-Gesellschaft (AEG) appointed Peter Behrens
to become the company’s chief product designer. Two of Behrens’s most
famous students were Walter Gropius and Mies van der Rohe. A large corporation like AEG, of course, could be more open to experimentation with unusual designs than many of the smaller firms. It was also in the forefront of
developing completely new products in the field of electrical household
goods, which facilitated the introduction of new styles. It was more difficult
with established goods to change the catholic tastes of the consumer and to
combine art with engineering science.
Nevertheless, there are many examples of Werkbund artists successfully
realizing their ideas for industrial production before 1914. Behrens designed
electric tea pots and street lights for AEG. In 1910, he was responsible for
the styling of a sewing machine by Pfaff. Meanwhile van der Velde was designing modern chairs. August Endell and Gropius created interiors for railroad sleeping carriages. Other Werkbund members were anxious to leave
behind the playful ornaments of the decorative art of the Jugendstil. Their
aim was to create functional forms and clear lines. Accordingly, the Austrian
Josef Hoffmann built his “seating machine” in 1905.
Meanwhile the movement also exerted considerable influence on industrial architecture. In 1909 Behrens designed the building for an AEG turbine
factory. A building constructed in 1910/11 on Berlin’s Brunnenstrasse for the
manufacturer of small electric motors features a facade powerfully emphasizing the vertical and horizontal. Another noteworthy building from this period was Alfred Messel’s design for the Wertheim department store in Berlin.
New ideas were developed in interior design and landscape architecture, and
157

Culture

there was strong interest in the design of housing estates and suburban settlements for industrial workers. In short, even a cursory glance at these creations
makes one realize where the Neue Sachlichkeit, or New Sobriety, movement
and the Bauhaus of the Weimar period had their roots. Some of Werkbund’s
aims may have been close to the mainstream of the time, like its nationalism
and the missionary zeal with which they wanted to flood the world market
with modern German goods of high quality. At the same time, they were
unanimous in their criticism of the educational ideals of German universities,
not only with the progressive entrepreneurs and engineers with whom they
collaborated, but also with the representatives of the Technological Institutes
and the applied sciences.43

11. The Sciences and Humanities
A. Basic Issues
Whoever speaks of the development of culture during the Imperial period
cannot avoid dealing with the human and natural sciences and their organization. As in other countries, most research took place in institutions of higher
education. But there were also many independent institutes that either undertook research themselves or promoted it. Among these, the Kaiser Wilhelm
Society, founded in 1910/11 to stimulate basic research, assumed an important role.44
All these institutions were primarily devoted to expanding the frontiers of
science through theoretical discussion and empirical research. Colleges and
universities had the additional task of providing basic training in scholarship.
The ideas and practices underlying this system gained Germany high prestige abroad and were partly adopted by other countries in the late nineteenth
century. Even if many students preferred a superficial studium generale and
the social life of fraternities, for the serious young scholar there was ample
scope in the labs and lecture halls for learning about the rules of advanced research. Starting from the notion that research and teaching were inseparable,
institutions of higher learning transmitted these skills through a finely graduated system of large lectures at the one end of the spectrum and the very small
seminar at the other. Professors had themselves undergone arduous training.
Following their admission to the doctorate, they were expected to submit
a second (habilitation) thesis. Only after passing this and a “colloquium” before the respective full faculty assembly would they be allowed to give lectures. However long and exhausting the years of preparation for this second
qualification and the subsequent period as a Privatdozent might be, there was
no guarantee of a much-vaunted professorship. Such an appointment was not
only dependent upon the faculty, but also on the approval by the ministry for
158

The Sciences and Humanities

cultural affairs of the given federal state, and both were time and again guided
by profound methodological or ideological prejudices. Thus there existed only
a few professors of Jewish background, however highly qualified as scholars
aspirants might be. To be a Social Democratic professor was virtually a contradiction in terms. Werner Sombart was falsely suspected of being a closet
socialist and found his career adversely affected because of it. Gustav Mayer,
who openly professed his Social Democratic beliefs and who, after long hesitations, decided, with the support of the highly respected Friedrich Meinecke,
to submit to the habilitation ordeal, could not marshal the requisite number
of votes in the Berlin University faculty after his “colloquium.” His venia
legendi was refused.
The atmosphere in institutes of higher education was no less conservative
in social terms. Even men like Max Planck who pursued revolutionary ideas
in their research were not consistently liberal. Conscious of the prestige that
they enjoyed both in German society and abroad, they tended to be rather full
of themselves and displayed a marked elitism. With a good deal of justification, they have therefore been called “the German mandarins.”45 But all too
often this elitism was the facade, behind which there existed a human wreck
who had long passed the prime of his scholarship. Worn out by the long years
of initiation prior to gaining a professorship, they would often teach the
knowledge of the previous generation, while being intolerant of the ideas of
the next.
In the discipline of history, the 1860s and 1870s were a period of an arid
and modest empiricism that was highly specialized. The orthodoxies of the
Prussian School dominated the field, which adhered to an uncritical glorification of Bismarck’s work of unification. The literary sciences were barely
less traditional. For Albert Bielschowsky, a student of Wilhelm Scherer and
Erich Schmidt, “the phenomenon of Goethe amounted to a collection of
anecdotal-biographical facts which were lovingly, pedantically, and sentimentally reported” by him.46 Analysis was replaced by solemn exegesis. The
Prussian legend emerged between the lines even in Wilhelm Dilthey’s highly
acclaimed book Das Erlebnis und die Dichtung. Just as in the arts, the humanities in the 1870s did not courageously advance into uncharted waters,
and the prevailing conservatism was felt for a long time thereafter. However,
by the late 1880s new developments had gotten underway, leading the famous theologian Ernst Troeltsch to conclude that all aspects of life had begun to “sway.” 47
B. The Natural Sciences
Troeltsch’s dictum was certainly true of the natural sciences. First, great breakthroughs occurred in chemical and electronic research. A number of phenomena that had puzzled scholars before began to generate serious doubts about
159

Culture

the hitherto unshakable world of classical physics. Was it really tenable that
the universe was composed of a limited number of molecules and atoms whose
structure existed for all eternity? The metaphysical dimension was raised by
the assumption that there existed a God who had created this universe. The
viability of this scientific conception became undermined at the end of the
nineteenth century, partly because of new research and partly because of
fresh theoretical and philosophical considerations.
In 1889, Heinrich Hertz demonstrated the identity of light, heat, and electromagnetic waves. Wilhelm Röntgen and others discovered the existence of
ultraviolet rays and the phenomenon of radioactivity of certain elements at
the upper end of the periodic table. Together with the discoveries of Ernest
Rutherford and Niels Bohr, this research called into question the assumed
immutability and indivisibility of atoms. Further investigations showed that
during the disintegration of inherently unstable (radioactive) elements very
small amounts of energy were set free. Suddenly matter and energy appeared
as the two sides of the same coin.
Around the turn of the century, on the basis of his research in thermodynamics, Planck developed the hypothesis that transformations of energy occurred in bursts. Finally, in 1905, Albert Einstein postulated that time and
space, just like energy and mass, were interrelated. Meanwhile the laws of
Euclidean geometry had also begun to crumble. According to Einstein, these
laws were invalidated in the proximity of large masses of matter, where space
was curved. However difficult it may have been for the average person to
grasp such notions, it was clear that a revolution had been set off that ultimately became condensed in Einstein’s famous mathematical equation of
E = mc2. 48
The four-dimensional space-time continuum of modern science beyond
Euclid had been born. With it the received image of the universe also began
to disintegrate. The former fixed points of a supposedly static universe, whose
particles and movements were governed by the laws of mechanics, began to
fade. Particles were ephemeral and could in principle also appear in other
guises. In the end it even became doubtful if there were laws of Nature in the
traditional sense. The assumption of relativity seemed more a promising
approach.
Physical chemistry made important contributions to the revolution in science. In 1906, Walter Nernst developed his heat theorem that subsequently
became the Third Principle of Thermodynamics. Developments in organic
chemistry may not have been quite so dramatic, but thanks to the research of
Emil Fischer and others major breakthroughs were also achieved in this field.
Germany gained a leading position in the world in dyestuffs. While Fischer’s
work made the link with biochemistry, biology made rapid advances of its
own. No more than brief reference can be made here to developments in
160

The Sciences and Humanities

medicine, particularly in the fields of serology and bacteriology. In 1882,
Robert Koch discovered the tuberculosis bacillus and two years later the carrier of cholera. In 1890, Emil Behring developed a serum against diphtheria,
while Paul Ehrlich became the founder of modern chemotherapy.
Although dismissed as being insufficiently scientific by some, psychology
also emerged in this period, at first on a strictly experimental and quantifying basis. Though mostly practiced by fully trained physicians, it subsequently moved to the margins of the natural sciences, the more it turned to
the possible societal causes of pathological human behavior. Sigmund Freud’s
hypotheses concerning the interpretation of dreams and female hysteria were
controversial enough even in their day. Last, but not least, there was Otto
Weininger, whose 1903 book Geschlecht und Charakter went through six
editions during the following three years. In the book he asserted that the female psyche was determined by women’s biological functions.
While contributions by scientists in other countries can hardly be overestimated in the field of physics, major impulses were provided by scholars from
Central Europe. This was also true when it came to considering the philosophical implications of the new vision of the universe. Among the first to do
so was Ernst Mach in Vienna who, in light of recent developments, proposed
a total separation of metaphysics from the sciences. In his book Die Mechanik
in ihrer Entwicklung (1883) he even went so far as to portray time and space
as metaphysical concepts that should be thrown overboard. Nature, he wrote,
did not know such confines. The body’s temporal and spatial position was
determined only in relation to other objects. Influenced by Mach, Einstein
took the final step on this journey into uncertainty when he replaced the idea of
particles by the notion of “events” that unraveled within the atom. Matter was
thus no longer something tangible, but a process that had physical properties.
Not surprisingly, all these discoveries and hypotheses unleashed heated
debates among the community of scientists. Mach’s position on metaphysics
ran into trouble when he failed to put forward an alternative unifying principle that held the universe together. Yet many of his colleagues did not wish
to abandon the search for such a principle. Thenceforth, the question of a
prima causa that would have led them back to metaphysics remained in the
background. What now propelled physicists was the prospect of finding a
“world formula” of the kind that Werner Heisenberg would work on so hard
a generation later. If it was correct that the processes of Nature evolved independently of humankind, Mach appeared to be heading in the wrong direction when he argued that reality merely consisted of perceptions and that
modern physics could be constructed exclusively as a sensual experience. If
Nature—as he postulated—was indeed no more than the most rational adaptation of the human mind to the world of human experience, all research was
bound to end up emphasizing what was individual and limited.
161

Culture

For many of Mach’s colleagues this degradation of the physical and mechanical world went too far. They did not expect anything good to come from
the attempt to link imagination to experience alone and thus to lapse into a
pure positivism. The image of the universe that they were developing instead
might never match reality completely; but at least there was a chance of approaching it asymptotically in the course of an incessant refinement of ongoing research.
In short, they asserted the continued legitimacy of asking questions about
the world’s structure and evolution beyond what was purely human. The
imaginativeness of the researcher was to be given free rein, so long as there
was a guarantee that the results of his experiments correlated with those of
other scholars who had independently undertaken their work in another part
of the globe. In this sense, the quest was also for the creation of a common
platform on which, pace Ernst Mach and irrespective of their sensibilities, all
physicists would be able to operate and interact rationally, promoting the internationalization of modern science. In the process, the “hard sciences” of
physics, chemistry, and mathematics might grow together, just as the various
branches of physics were being unified. The ultimate dream was that one day
all scientists would be united under one roof.
Whatever the future may have held in store, before 1914 space, time, and
energy had ceased to be viewed as immutable categories. Einstein’s relativity theory became the core and the symbol of a new theoretical understanding of the universe. Scientists had not yet officially declared God to be dead;
but explanations of what held the world together distanced themselves from
transcendental explanations and concentrated on the discovery of causal connections based on the human capacity to reason. It is no less significant that
all researchers in the laboratories and the debates that were carried on in the
academies were instilled with an optimism that it would be possible, one day,
to know the universe’s hitherto veiled structures in all their dimensions. Relativism, it is true, had complicated the process of scientific cognition; but it had
also opened up new opportunities that generated great hopes for the future.
This scientific optimism was reinforced in Germany by a sense that researchers were able to work in the most favorable milieu imaginable. Tertiary
education attracted the most talented individuals and was assumed to offer
them optimal room for intellectual development. State funding of scientific
projects, augmented by donations from industry, was thought to be generous.
This small scientific elite, several of whose members became candidates for
Nobel Prizes, was well looked after in terms of its economic status. In order
to attract him to Berlin in 1913, Einstein, for example, was offered a professorship without teaching obligations, the directorship of the yet to be established Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Physics, and a lucrative membership in
the Academy of Sciences. Small wonder that most professors—however rev162

The Sciences and Humanities

olutionary their research—were politically conservative and monarchist. It
was not inconceivable that there existed a connection between the fluid and
complex cosmic order that they were investigating and the notion of a pluralistically organized and colorful human society on planet Earth. However, a
few exceptions always granted, most scientists did not make this connection
with its implications for social and political change. They did not see a tension between their own revolutionary work, on the one hand, and their lives
in a strictly divided, hierarchical society, on the other. They believed that the
monarchical order would lead the country toward a golden age, both in science and in politics and economics.49
C. The Humanities
The scientists’ optimism and self-confidence was not as widely shared by
their colleagues in the humanities, even if it would probably be misleading
to assume that the cultural pessimists—who, as we have seen, were so influential in the arts—also dominated the universities.50 For that matter the influence of Kant, Hegel, and Ranke remained too strong in Germany even at the
end of the nineteenth century. What, despite this dichotomy, continued to
unite those in the humanities was their somewhat arrogant view that the insights to be gained from their disciplines were more profound than those developed in the sciences. It was not just that they saw the world in terms of
C.P. Snow’s “Two Cultures” but also that they insisted on the primacy of the
humanities. The historian Max Lenz, in a condescending wisecrack, called
his Naturforscher (natural science researcher) colleagues “Naturförster”
(nature foresters).51 In arguing their case, those in the humanities asserted, as
they had done before, that the difference was due to the divergent methodologies and vantage points with regard to the object of research.
Apart from their confrontation with the sciences, what united scholars in
the humanities was that they operated with much less fixed categories. Certainly by the end of the nineteenth century many scholars were no longer as
confident as before that there existed a reality behind the phenomena and that
the world was held together by a well-ordered system. This shift toward relativism was particularly marked among the idealists. Hegel had seen in history the expression of a universal reason that assumed concrete form in
institutions and through which the dialectical march toward the Absolute
Idea proceeded. However, when the late nineteenth century saw a Hegel Renaissance, the view that the world’s historical process moved rationally according to laws found few supporters.
Similarly, the determinism of the Marxists, whose materialist interpretation of history was supposed to have put Hegel’s idealism on its feet, lost
much of its orthodox rigidity. Many continued to adhere to the idea that history ran through different stages. Yet after the death of Marx in 1883 the belief
163

Culture

began to fade in parts of the working-class movement that the evolution of
capitalism would inevitably end in a revolution from which a new and ultimately communist social order would be born. Instead political forces gained
ground that stressed democratic action on the part of the masses and a reformist transformation of capitalism from the inside.
Among the cultural philosophers and historians, Karl Lamprecht was almost
alone in his particular search for laws of historical development. His determinism, too, met with skepticism and rejection. His work was directed against
those among his colleagues who equated scholarship with the straight-laced
presentation of “facts.” The natural sciences, he wrote, had “long overcome
the age of a descriptive method of the phenomena that merely differentiates
by striking individual characteristics.”52 He also turned against the dominance of political history and demanded that the cultural, economic, legal,
and intellectual aspects of human history be included in the analysis. In this
sense he may be called a relativist.
A rejection of the earlier certainties also marked the neo-Kantianism of
the late nineteenth century. It pervaded the work of the philosopher Heinrich
Rickert at Freiburg University, who, together with Georg Simmel, Max Weber,
and Georg Jellinek, has been counted among the “fathers of scientific value
relativism.”53 Immanuel Kant once started from the firm assumption that logical and ethical judgments possessed a universal and timeless validity and
that humans were participants in a transcendental reason. Rickert, writing a
century later, saw the pluralism of values during different epochs and of values that often contradicted each other. However, he did not go so far as to
abandon the belief that they were nevertheless all an expression of an eternal
morality. In this sense, his theory of knowledge did not take the final step into
a nirvana. This step was taken by other philosophers who will be discussed
in a moment.
First, mention must be made of the metamorphosis that Rankeanism underwent when, toward the end of the nineteenth century, it once again began to
outpace the so-called Prussian School.54 Ranke’s religiously founded historicism had seen nations and states as “divine thoughts.” Writing from a universalhistorical perspective, he was also convinced that world history was moving
toward a higher, divinely sanctioned, and ultimately harmonious order. His
epigones in the philosophical faculties of the German empire were more inclined to operate with a secularized notion of power. They started from the
assumption of a colorful quilt of nation-states. Over time this conception of
history became infiltrated by Social Darwinist and imperialist ideas that once
again undermined the relativist starting-point. For Ranke the peak of historical development was a superior order that was in harmony with God. For
Rankeans of the Wilhelmine period it was the victory of the most viable nation in the international struggle for survival. No doubt this interpretation of
164

The Sciences and Humanities

the fate of nations was also informed by the nationalist expectation that, given
Germany’s cultural and other achievements, she would win this victory. As
Hans Delbrück hoped, this was where the marriage of “power and culture”
would ultimately take place.
Thus the humanities moved away from the certainties of Hegel and Marx,
of Kant and Ranke, toward a more relativistic view of the world that, it should
be noted, was in principle still optimistic. This shift had implications for the
theory of knowledge, whose practitioners slowly became aware of the difficulties facing them. How, for example, was one to explain rationally man’s
irrationality, which had meanwhile been discovered and could no longer be
denied? The debates unleashed by such questions within the humanities also
reveal a shift into subjectivism. It was a mood that corresponded strikingly
with the proliferating relativism. There was a growing suspicion that cognition
was dependent on the viewer’s vantage point and that humans would never
have access to absolute truths. As Wilhelm Dilthey put it, it might be possible to describe and develop taxonomies. But whatever the explanations advanced, they would all rest on subjective life experiences.
This shift was remarkable because the humanities, in typical overestimation of themselves, had long adhered to the view that man’s capacity for cognition was limited only with regard to the physical world. Here, so it was
assumed, one observed no more than external connections that would never
be able to open a door to deeper insights. The humanities, by contrast, were
thought to be in a superior position to the natural sciences. The former facilitated objective cognition because the researcher was able to acquire firsthand knowledge of humans and society. The main difficulty was seen in the
scholar’s capacity to transmit his/her insights to others. Thus Dilthey was initially convinced that man was in principle capable of “recogniz[ing] himself
and the society and history created by him.”55 However, since he also believed
in the subjective sources of cognition, he had obviously begun to argue himself into a corner when he simultaneously postulated that knowledge was objectively possible. He tried to resolve this contradiction by hypothesizing a
common denominator for object and subject, which he called life, though this
was to be understood not in the sense of organic nature as viewed by Henri
Bergson, but that of historical existence. While this solution was hardly satisfactory, it is nevertheless characteristic of the age. Now the “objective
spirit” could no longer reside in Reason, but in the somewhat more nebulous
“structural links between the vital units” to be found in “communities.”56 With
this an irrational element had been taken into the theory of cognition. In this
respect, Max Weber was certainly more logical when he took the final step
in this debate. He denied the possibility of an objective search for universal
values and retreated into examining value systems within a particular cultural
epoch.
165

Culture

Meanwhile the Marxists did not allow themselves to be dragged into the
theory-of-knowledge problems that liberal and conservative scholars agonized
about. For them non-Marxist ideologies and value systems were at heart reflections of tangible material interests and as such easily accessible to analysis. The neo-Rankeans continued to believe for a long time that they could
escape the dilemmas of a scholarly subjectivism with the help of their peculiar notion of Verstehen, or understanding. They assumed with Ranke that humans were endowed with a unique capacity to detach themselves from their
own time and to immerse themselves in an earlier epoch that would be reconstructed and brought to life through their empathetic interpretation of the primary sources.
However, there were others already waiting in the wings for whom history
was not a purposeful process, as both the Marxists and Rankeans thought.57
With veritable fascination they had seized upon the irrationalities of that
process and of the human agency within it. Having spied the dark impulses
in the human soul, they had lost all hope for a better future and lapsed into a
deep cultural pessimism. Progress in a rationalist sense appeared to them to
be a totally questionable concept. And so they proclaimed the crisis of all existing value systems and retreated into a misanthropic relativism. They were
no longer interested in investigating the relationship between societal reality
and human norms. Instead what they aimed at ultimately was the radical
transvaluation of both. As for the possibility of cognition, they nurtured a
pure subjectivism and abandoned the idea that humans could make a scientifically founded choice between basic values.
Arthur Schopenhauer, who died in 1860, was among the most important
thinkers at the beginning of this seismic shift. He thought that, thanks to
spontaneous intuition, he had broken through the world of superficial phenomena, whose laws the natural sciences were trying to discover. For it was
beyond the barrier of these phenomena that the will could be found as embodying actual reality. This will comprised not only conscious aims and desires,
but all un- and subconscious impulses as well. According to Schopenhauer,
all human thought and action consisted of restless acts of will. What determined the development of humankind was not the logic of history, but creative ingenuity. By the end of the nineteenth century, then, the idea had made
great strides in the humanities that reason was controlled by “life” and that
great achievements were not the result of a determined intellectual inquiry,
but of a heroic deployment of the will. The most compelling advocate of this
position was Friedrich Nietzsche (1844–1900), poet, musician, essayist, and
classical philologist, who had to give up his professorship at Basle University in 1879 for reasons of poor health. Above all, he influenced a younger
generation of intellectuals and artists who supported the “transvaluation of
all values” that Nietzsche had proclaimed.58
166

The Sciences and Humanities

If Schopenhauer had continued to insist on the connection between voluntaristic irrationality and humanity, Nietzsche now broke them apart. He proclaimed the collapse of the great metaphysical systems of the eighteenth and
nineteenth centuries that science had brought about. What was more, since
Nature and Life were at heart irrational, the task was in his view to affirm the
concomitant irrationality of mind and morality. As far as morality was concerned, Nietzsche would merely recognize the existence of relative yardsticks. What was right for one person at a particular point in time could be
wrong for another at a later date. Since humans were blindly driven by their
impulses, the real value of life did not lie in an ascetic retreat from the world,
but in the affirmation of the will through struggle. Other values did not exist.
The central figure, Nietzsche maintained, was not the person who strove
to find universally applicable norms, but the hero who—following only his
self-set standards—would transcend himself. God was said to be dead, but
superman lived and asserted himself in this world, because there was no
other world beyond, just as there were no value systems. The domination of
the “herd” was replaced by an aristocracy of the strongest and most brutal.
The place of Christian-humanist principles was filled by pitilessness and
pride. Pain was given a positive connotation, because it offered the chance to
overcome it. Happiness was replaced by heroic creativity.
At first sight, Nietzsche appears to base his ideas on an image of humankind and the world whose structures and movements were geared exclusively to conflict and that was impervious to change. Even the hero could do
no more than to engage in a constant struggle. As there was no hope of salvation, heroic struggle was the only way to realize himself. And yet Nietzsche’s profound pessimism and disdain for humanity still had an optimistic,
though much less strikingly obvious, reverse side. At least in his later works,
Nietzsche saw an alternative to what he believed was the wrong path taken
by European civilization during the preceding two thousand years. Change
was therefore not completely out of the question, even if his alternative vision displayed some traits of antiquity when the old patriarchal morality was
still intact. In other words, his utopia contained backward-looking elements,
extolling the virtues of a time when the “evils” of the present had not yet
gained the upper hand.
If we try to understand why Nietzsche was so popular among a younger
generation, the fact that his books did not lend themselves in style and content to quiet, contemplative reading is certainly important. His books and essays agitated; they politicized philosophical discourse that had hitherto been
viewed as a scholarly discipline. Nietzsche took aim not only at Christianity
and utilitarianism, but also at socialism and democracy. Ultimately, there
were very few aspects of contemporary politics and culture that did not, in
one way or another, become the object of his vitriolic attacks. Often writing
167

Culture

in mere aphorisms and entangling himself in contradictions, he railed at industrialization and capitalism, enlightenment and Jewry, romanticism and
sentimentality, historicism and the militaristic Prussian state. And time and
again he spoke in favor of creating an elite that was not tied down by existing moral norms, while attacking the morality of the “herd” and, of course,
Marxism.
Other intellectuals also recognized the magnetic power of Marxism, viewing it either as a danger or a ray of hope. After all, Marxism had never been
satisfied with the formulation of abstract ideas, and its adherents always postulated the inseparability of theory and practice. They thought to have not
only an explanation of existing conditions, founded in history and rationality, but also a guide to changing them, though not through an act of will by
a heroic individual, but through collective action. However far removed the
Marxists were from Nietzsche’s followers, the latter, along with other antiMarxists, were no doubt correct in drawing attention to Marxism’s advocacy
of radical political change.
Accordingly, many concepts developed in the humanities at this time were
intended as an antidote to this movement and its utopia. As the examples of
Gustav Mayer and Franz Mehring showed, the academy may have been successful in barricading its doors to individual leftists; but the penetration of
Marxist ideas could not be stopped and hence was believed to require an intellectual response.
Some professors, such as Weber, Simmel, or Ferdinand Tönnies, took this
debate very seriously, just as the rise of sociology as a new academic discipline cannot be understood without the challenge that Marxism posed theoretically and methodologically. It was only against the background of this
challenge that Weber could develop his thoughts on value relativism, his concepts of “calling” and “status,” and more generally his articles and books on
the influence of ideas on society and on mentality and culture. Having analyzed capitalism’s rise and the “demystification of the world” under the impact of modern rationalism, he became greatly worried about an impending
age of highly organized bureaucracies and of the Fachmensch, the expert, in
which humankind would be forced into an “iron cage of serfdom.” In his
1900 book Philosophie des Geldes (Philosophy of Money), Simmel wrestled
with city culture in the age of capitalist mass production and mass consumption. He also examined the impact of the changing character of labor upon
the psychology of the worker. Meanwhile, Tönnies turned to the tension between Gesellschaft und Gemeinschaft, society and community. In economics
it was above all the “Kathedersozialisten” around Gustav Schmoller, Lujo
Brentano, and Adolph Wagner who were searching for a third way between
Marxism and classic economic liberalism. Their Verein für Sozialpolitik became an interdisciplinary forum where they met with historians and lawyers.
168

The Sciences and Humanities

While these men were preoccupied with the intellectual challenge of Marxism, most of their colleagues in the humanities barely cast an eye over the
relevant literature. Instead they allowed themselves to be guided, on the basis
of a scanty knowledge, by their prejudices and anxieties when they witnessed
workers’ demonstrations and strikes. With the exception of Ernst Troeltsch,
who engaged with Karl Kautsky’s interpretation of early Christianity, this
was also true of Protestant theologians. Meanwhile the Catholic position—
officially defined since 1891 in the papal encyclical against Liberalism and
Marxism—also became increasingly affective. Though theoretically wedded
to a notion of Verstehen that deliberately tried to distance itself from the present and to devote itself to a strict reconstruction of the past, the discipline of
history offers a good example of the progressive politicization of the humanities in the decades before 1914.
It has even been argued that historical scholarship became in essence a
veiled attack on the Marxist interpretation of the past. At least many academic historians believed that their work contributed to countering the influence of the political Left, when they highlighted the primacy of foreign
policy and of international over domestic power politics, or celebrated Bismarck as the towering figure of his age who had reconciled power and culture. As Max Lenz put it, historical scholarship revolved around the hope “to
discover the firm ground upon which a national consciousness can form that
is moved by the common idea of eternity.”59 However, there were also a number of professors who proposed to complement a social imperialist perspective that stressed nationalist solidarity and foreign expansion by policies of
domestic reform. Their aim was to integrate the working class into the existing
social order and to wean it from Marxism. Yet, ultimately even these socialreformist concepts remained subordinated to the primacy of foreign policy.
Geopolitical arguments and the demands for greater efficiency abroad served
as a cover behind which domestic ideological and political objectives could
be pursued. In this atmosphere of fear and suspicion it was not surprising that
academics like Sombart and Lamprecht, who advocated an expansion of historical methodology beyond the orthodoxies of diplomatic and political history, came to be suspected of being closet Marxists.
The most influential historian of his time was Heinrich von Treitschke,
who did not even go through the motions of draping his politicized view of
the past in a scholarly mantle. A professor at Berlin University and a member of the Reichstag, Treitschke was, before his death in 1896, a prolific writer,
taking a stand on the major political questions of his time. Unlike that of the
neo-Rankeans, his language was strident when he appeared in the invariably
overcrowded lecture halls. Few academics in the humanities achieved Treitschke’s political prominence. Most of them devoted themselves to teaching
and research in their increasingly specialized fields. Only occasionally would
169

Culture

they make political statements that reflected in most cases their conservativemonarchist attitudes. From time to time, the better-known among them would
write an essay in one of the many nonscholarly journals, taking positions on
topical political questions, few of which in retrospect make scintillating reading. Moreover, a sizeable group of intellectuals operating on the fringes of
the academic world were more regular contributors to these journals and
often used their writings to vent their cultural pessimism.60
At the other end of the spectrum, however, was another type of journal
that praised the blessings of the machine age and was read by engineers and
technicians. Some of the ideas presented in these journals were influenced by
Frederick Taylor, the American engineer who wanted to revolutionize industrial production and attitudes toward the factory among employers and employees alike. The Taylor Movement, which came to Germany soon after the
turn of the century, proposed the scientific study of factory organization with
the aim of achieving more than a mere rationalization of production; rather,
the followers of this movement wished to create a technological-industrial
culture that appealed to the material interests of all involved and harmonized
the daily routine of industrial labor. Although they harbored a few doubts
about Taylorism, it is not surprising that engineers and those in the engineering sciences inside and outside the academy were generally fascinated by
Taylor’s message. After all, it turned the engineer, rather than the worker, into
the key figure of modern industrial society and reassured them that the Marxist menace, which engineers were no less worried about than the rest of the
middle class, would be contained by the system of Scientific Management.
The sciences thus presented themselves in two guises under the Kaiserreich.
On the one hand, there was the theoretical and empirical research that was
conducted in studies and laboratories. Its results put Germany’s institutions
of higher learning into the top ranks internationally. Of course, the many scientific discoveries of the time rarely reached a wider public, and Einstein was
everything but a popularly known personality before 1914. One is tempted to
correlate the relativization of the classic scientific “truths” that the natural sciences promoted with the relativism that began to spread among the humanities
at about the same time. But this link, if it existed, was at most indirect. The
“two cultures” do not appear to have had much knowledge of what was happening on the other side of the fence. Certainly the humanities, in their desire
to uphold the notion of the “otherness” of the sciences, perpetuated a very
simplistic appreciation of Naturförsterei. The new images of the universe that
physicists were developing eluded them almost completely. More generally,
no more than a small number of contemporaries outside the academy appreciated the significance of this particular revolution. Nietzsche’s hypotheses
were no doubt more widely known than Einstein’s theories, not least because
they were more easily reconcilable with the ideology of the Right.
170

The Press, Its Readership, and Intellectuals

However, not all scientists remained in the ivory tower. Many saw their work
not as a contribution to the international community of scholars but as part of
a national project. Meanwhile the humanities, wedded to the same principle,
pursued themes and hypotheses whose ideological bias they were frequently
unaware of. The Germanist Rudolf Unger, for example, in his book Hamann
und die Aufklärung, presented the theoreticians of the “Storm and Stress” period in the early nineteenth century as opponents of the eighteenth-century
Enlightenment. But he failed to mention that he presented his own opposition to the eighteenth century and anti-rationalism in the same breath. Others
were either less naive or less worried about compromising their reputations
as scholars. In articles and speeches they dutifully participated in the debates
on the great questions of the time. Their tone was often pessimistic, and they
thus reinforced notions of a great cataclysm. On the Left of the ideological
spectrum, there was much talk of the impending collapse of capitalism.
Meanwhile the more radical Right predicted the demise of the decadent
bourgeois world. True, there were also optimists, and not just among the engineers and scientists. Yet, if cultural pessimism gained a wider audience toward 1914, it may also have been due to the anxieties that proliferated with
regard to the future viability of the Hohenzollern Monarchy. Additionally, academic and intellectual elites now had at their disposal a mass press with
which to articulate their pessimism and peddle their solutions to the crisis to
the general public. The colorful debate about Germany’s future, which became increasingly polarized toward 1914, was reflected in the wide variety
of papers whose orientation, on closer inspection, similarly fell into two large
camps. Pluralization and polarization developed in tandem.

12. The Press, Its Readership, and the Role of Intellectuals
In an age of radio, television, and electronic mass consumption, it is not easy
to imagine the extent to which the German Empire’s culture was based on the
written and spoken word. Cinema attendance, it is true, began to rise markedly just before 1914; but the press remained the most important medium
through which people informed themselves about their locality or the wider
environment and through which ideas and opinions were spread. However
highly developed the art of public speaking in parliaments, in associational
life, or at political rallies may have been, the spoken word had a larger impact
only when it was recirculated in newspapers, journals, books, and pamphlets.
It is important to emphasize this because it demonstrates that the Kaiserreich did have a functioning public sphere. Here—as we also saw with respect to censorship of the arts—the authoritarian state was time and again
reminded that the age of absolutism was over. However, this experience did
not diminish the authorities’ determination to let the emergent civil society
171

Culture

know who held ultimate power, both under the written constitution and in
constitutional reality. In other words, however significant the existence of a
“liberal” public sphere is for an understanding of Imperial Germany’s history, we should not forget to examine the reverse side of the coin. If one took
too much license in expressing opinions, the state’s repressive instruments
were still available and could be mobilized for illiberal purposes.
That contemporaries were conscious of these realities is evidenced by the
behavior of the Social Democratic Reichstag caucus during the period of the
antisocialist laws. The deputies’ immunity and freedom of speech had not
been touched by the proscription of the party’s organizations. However, the
privilege of free speech in Parliament proved an asset only if the statements
were extensively reprinted in the bourgeois press. Not least for this reason,
Social Democrat deputies were careful not to make speeches that were too
radical and might provide the authorities with a pretext to try to suspend their
parliamentary immunity.
Against the background of these developments, two further factors were
important for the rise of the printed word as a means of mass communication
in the nineteenth century. To begin with, there was a decline in the illiteracy
rate, measured by recruits in the armed forces, to below 10 percent between
1875/76 and 1894/95. The literacy rate as a percentage of the total population was even higher. This was particularly true in urban areas, where it was
easier to obtain printed materials. Second, technological breakthroughs, together with the proliferation of the telegraph and railroads, helped to open up
a mass market. Technical progress facilitated cheaper production of newsprint and, with the advent of rotation presses in 1872, a staggering acceleration of printing. The twin rotation machines that first appeared in 1895 were
capable of printing 12,000 copies per hour. Typesetting machines were introduced in 1884. This meant that the daily newspapers—linked as they were to
one of the telegraphic news services—could receive dispatches from the farthest corners of the globe and release them on the mass market within hours.
The statistics give a rough picture of the consequences of these developments.60 Thus in 1912 there existed over 4,000 journals and newspapers (some
of which appeared in several editions per day), an increase of 1,000 since
1895. The estimated total of copies per annum was 5 to 6 billion. In 1903 the
Deutscher Journal-Katalog listed some 300 titles under the section of critical
and literary journals alone. The best-known among them were Hans Delbrück’s
Preussische Jahrbücher and Maximilian Harden’s Die Zukunft. Satirical journals also flourished, among them Simplicissimus, Kladderadatsch, and the
Social Democratic Wahre Jacob.
Book production also shot up. In 1875, around 12,000 titles had been published. By 1910 this figure had almost trebled, reaching 30,317. Soon journals offered something for every taste—from light entertainment to serious
172

The Press, Its Readership, and Intellectuals

literature and intellectual debate. Picture and fashion journalism had emerged
in the middle of the nineteenth century in the form of the Leipziger Illustrierte (1843) and Bazar, published in Berlin since 1855. Humor and satire were
spearheaded at the same time by journals such as Die Fliegenden Blätter and
Die Lustigen Blätter. With the improvements in photography and reproduction, these publications soon gained competitors. The advertising sections of
all these papers are no less interesting to cultural historians than the news and
opinion pages. Here the reader could find advice on health and fashions,
beauty, and higher education. The adverts were addressed to a bourgeois consumer society that had come into prosperity and disposed of sufficient leisure
time to occupy itself with its outward and inner conditions.
As far as the readership is concerned, it is significant that the large dailies
established themselves relatively late. Until then the weeklies and monthlies
predominated, which could not provide up-to-date information and therefore
specialized in the publication of essays, literary opinion columns, and serialized novels. The German press, including dailies, was typically regional in
character, even beyond the newsletters of the innumerable local associations
and clubs. The Generalanzeiger press, which was financed through advertising and could hence be distributed free of charge, played an important role.
The Gartenlaube gained a supraregional readership that was wealthy enough
to afford a subscription. Many of its readers were women. Its editor, who pioneered the serialized novel in Germany, succeeded in pushing the circulation to 400,000 as early as 1876. The journal presented a mix of “poems by
our best poets, always well illustrated,” short-stories, letters, and reports on
nature, health, and cultural news. The educated bourgeoisie found this mix
particularly appealing, and its success allowed the journal to attract wellknown authors, including popular women writers such as Courts-Mahler,
Hillern, and Marlitt. The new mass media were no less lucrative for contributors than they were for publishers. Thus Sudermann received the princely
sum of 10,000 marks for the first serialization rights of his novel Es War.
Among the mass-produced literature was also the colportage novel that
could not be obtained through subscription or in bookstores, but were offered
by traveling salesmen or at newspaper stands. They were devoted to the representation of the trivial: stories about the American Wild West, about love,
or about private investigators and crime. The methods of distribution tended
to awaken the suspicions of censors, who thought that this type of literature
was prone to contain immoral or politically subversive ideas. Clearly, Reclam’s
classics series, of which by 1914 some 14 million of the slim volumes had
been sold, was much more acceptable to censors.
Finally, magazines designed to popularize science constituted a genre that
offers insights into contemporary mentalities. Richly illustrated and reaching
a circulation of some 100,000 copies, these magazines tried to prove that the
173

Culture

sciences were a cultural force in their own right. They mirrored the optimistic
vision of the role of science and technology that was described above and
that contrasted strikingly with the cultural pessimism expressed in the arts
and humanities. Another contrast is found in the thrust of the sciences in the
years before 1914. While Einstein developed his theory of relativity, popular
science magazines gave the impression of unity and promoted a “remystification of the world.” 61
The rise of the daily newspaper did not undermine the regional roots of
the mass circulation press. Only a few papers—especially those published in
Berlin—attained national importance. As early as 1876 no fewer than 83 newspapers appeared in Berlin alone, among them the Berliner Tageblatt and Vossische Zeitung. Important regional papers whose opinions were taken note of
in the capital were the Münchener Neueste Nachrichten, Frankfurter Zeitung,
Kölnische Zeitung, Norddeutsche Allgemeine, Hamburger Fremdenblatt, and
Magdeburger Zeitung. The growth of a daily press also reflected the increasing social differentiation and politicization of German society. For, although
there existed 1,900 publications in 1912 that called themselves “supra-party,”
none of the many papers were ideologically neutral. Another 870 openly appealed to right-wing and conservative readers. Some 580 papers were classified as national-liberal or left-liberal. Around 480 publications were close to
the Catholic church or the Center Party. Finally, the Social Democratic press—
forever having to operate under the vigilant eye of the police censor—experienced an impressive expansion. Among the 60 dailies that were published
after the lapse of the antisocialist laws in 1890, no more than 19 initially appeared on all days of the week. By 1912 this latter figure had risen to 90.
Still, by comparing these figures with the number of “supra-party” papers
that must in effect be counted among the conservative and middle-class press,
much can be gauged concerning the structure of the readership and opinion
formation. Certainly no prosperous bourgeois or East Prussian landowner
would have dreamed of subscribing to or buying the Social Democratic Vorwärts. Conversely, it would have been unthinkable for a Social Democratic
worker to open the agrarian-conservative Neue Preussische Kreuzzeitung. A
Catholic worker from the Ruhr area or Silesia would most likely read local
papers close to the Catholic Center Party. All in all, an analysis of the press
culture of the Kaiserreich provides indirect pointers to the ideological stratification of German society that will be examined in Part IV. 62
The rapid growth and pluralization of the book and newspaper market
opened up careers in journalism for thousands of people. Many of them were
permanently employed as reporters and correspondents, as editors and typesetters. But opportunities also existed for freelancers of all descriptions. Frequently academically trained, they may be described as intellectuals. Many
of them defined themselves as apolitical producers of culture. Others rejected
174

The Press, Its Readership, and Intellectuals

the notion of “art for art’s sake.” However, what united many of those who
worked in journalism with those who favored “art for art’s sake” was a widespread elitism and disdain for the “masses.” Given the development of German politics and society before 1914, none of the members of either camp
succeeded in escaping from a politicization of their literary activities.63 And
those who saw themselves as members of the revolutionary avant-garde were
even quicker to recognize that their “revolution” was inseparably connected
with the political and societal environment in which they lived.
Beyond this basic attitude began the differences in position. Two of these
began to take shape from the 1890s onward, if not before. There were those
who understood their writing as an affirmation and conservation of the status
quo. These conservative intellectuals were confronted at the other end of the
spectrum by those who ascribed to themselves a critical role in politics and
society. In the terminology of the period, most of them had their ideological
home on the Left. Whether they identified with Left Liberals or Social Democrats, what was decisive was their shared desire to change the status quo,
whether through revolution or reform. Given their relations with the established powers, their writings were closely watched by the police; at the same
time, the government and the bureaucracy had no inhibitions in supporting
publications with a conservative and monarchist bias. In this respect, the political Left fared no better, and probably worse, than the advocates of modernism and an aesthetic revolution in the arts.
However, leftist intellectuals eventually gained a competitor on the Right.
Here arose another group of writers who in speeches, books, and articles also
advocated a transformation of the existing order and of the Prusso-German
political system in particular. It may be difficult to find a common denominator of the concepts of societal change that they advanced. Some of these
rightist intellectuals have been described as forerunners of the fascist movements of the interwar period.54 Even if this view has met with objections, it
is indisputable that the German Empire was increasingly besieged, in the last
years before World War I, by its intellectuals on the Right and Left. Their
publishers saw to it that their products were widely available in the “department store of ideologies.”64

175

Part IV: The Realm of Politics

13. The Constitutional Framework
A. Basic Issues
The first three parts of this volume attempted to lay out the economic, social,
and cultural framework on the basis of which the political system and the
politics of the German Empire evolved after 1870/71. While analyzing this
framework, we made repeated references to Part IV and promised that we
would connect the issues that had arisen in the spheres of the economy, society, and culture to the realm of politics. Indeed, we argued that some of
these issues can be properly understood only if complemented by an analysis of the realm of politics.
Thus, when dealing with labor conflicts in Part I, it became clear that not
only their incidence but also their outcomes were related to the state of politics at particular points in time. When discussing the development of society
and problems of stratification, attention was drawn to the fact that the experience of social inequalities would find expression and could best be shown
to be tangible in a political system that, while monarchical and authoritarian
in its constitutional structure, nevertheless had given all male adults the vote
and had hence offered them an opportunity to express their opinions at the
polls. In other words, if those opinions remained more subterranean in daily
social interactions between landlord and land laborer, between the middleclass “mistress of the house” and her domestic servant(s), between factory
owner and his blue-collar workers and white-collar employees, they became
publicly articulated in politics, be it at the end of the workday in the local pub
or at the dinner table, by raising one’s voice at a party’s political rally, or by
going to the polling station on election day. When examining the manifold
aspects of German culture in this period in Part III, it again became clear
when dealing, for example, with cabaret and the question of censorship or
with official suspicions of working-class cultural associations that cultural
production and ostensible leisure activities could not be studied in a vacuum
but were similarly linked to the realm of politics.

The Constitutional Framework

Above all, the larger question that ran through all previous sections concerned whether economic, social, and cultural conflicts increased over time
and thus confirmed the suspicions of the pessimists, who felt that, however
prosperous and dynamic German industry, commerce, and finance may have
been, the Kaiserreich’s position abroad and at home was not improving. On
the contrary, it seemed to them that the Reich was running into a serious crisis; that, as 1913/14 approached, it was reaching an impasse. As mentioned
in the Introduction, an earlier generation of postwar historians had confirmed
this deterioration of the country’s situation with the benefit of hindsight and
on the basis of what was thought to be powerful evidence. To them, the inability of a monarchical constitutional system to open up and take account of
the massive economic, sociocultural, and political changes that had taken
place since 1871 were now undermining its future viability. The unwillingness of those who had the power to introduce political reforms was believed
by historians to have led to growing conflict and a radicalization of the disaffected and disappointed masses of voters. In the end, this process would
either lead to paralysis and civil war or the imposition of a regime that abolished the constitution and ruled with the help of the army to defend the status quo.
Subsequently, another generation of historians came along to disagree with
this position and to highlight the many features of Wilhelmine history that
pointed in the opposite direction. Germany, the protagonists of this view asserted, was on the path toward constitutional reform and would have developed into a British-style constitutional monarchy if it had not been for a
disastrous war that broke out in 1914.1 It has been one of the central lines of
argument of this book that the German Empire found itself on a trajectory of
growing pluralization as well as polarization. This means that between its
founding and World War I it became a more diverse and highly complex society, many features of which have been examined in previous chapters. But,
with the approach of 1914, it also experienced a coagulation of its various
parts and fragments into larger blocs. There are two ways of testing these arguments. The first is to see how far the often latent tensions that have been traced
in the realms of economy, society, and culture are reflected in the politics of the
time. The second test relates the question of the reformability of the PrussoGerman monarchy in the face of an increasingly total war. As this war, which
was not going well for Germany, imposed enormous stresses on the population, was the government finally prepared to make political-constitutional concessions that had been demanded insistently before 1914 and were demanded
again in 1917/18? If it was not prepared to make these concessions even at
the height of a wartime emergency, it becomes more plausible why the Kaiser
and his advisers did not make them in peacetime when the pressure to intro-

177

Politics

duce reforms was comparatively less great. This second test will be conducted in Part V.
At this point we first turn to politics between 1871 and 1914, continuing
our thematic approach by dealing with the structure of the Bismarckian constitution, the evolution of the parliamentary system and its political parties,
and with the many extraparliamentary associations that emerged as part of
the trend toward pluralization as well as bloc formation. The chapter will
conclude with a history of domestic and foreign policies that will be more
narrative, setting the stage for the unfolding of the July crisis of 1914 and the
outbreak of World War I, taken up at the beginning of Part V.
B. The Evolution of the Constitution
The Reich Constitution of 16 April 1871, whose basic structure remained unchanged until the end of World War I, was not a completely new document.
Rather it incorporated elements of the Prussian Constitution of 1850 and the
North German Confederation of 1867. Bismarck held firm ideas about the
