shape of the Reich Constitution; but other political forces were also involved
in its creation. What emerged in the end was a framework that was sui generis,
that is, not known in other Western European countries. Generally referred to
as “Prusso-German constitutionalism,” this framework brought together four
features—absolute monarchy, representative parliament, democratic plebiscite,
and federalism.
However, it would be wrong to assume that these basic features were finely
balanced. Rather the balance of power was tipped decisively in favor of the
monarchical element. The preamble provides a first indication that, unlike
the United States, Germany had not been unified through a “revolution from
below,” but by a contract “from above.” At its core, the unification of Germany was based on an alliance of German princes and was proclaimed by
Wilhelm I, “by the Grace of God German Kaiser and King of Prussia, in the
name of the German Reich [and] after the consent of the Federal Council and
the Reichstag” had been granted.2 Presented with the document in the spring
of 1871, the political parties in the Reichstag, the new national parliament,
made no more than a few minor changes to it. Clearly, the compromise was
in the end an uneven one. The reason for this was not only that parliamentary
forces were relatively weak, but also that major debates over the shaping of
the German political system had taken place in 1867 in the context of the
North German Confederation when the faith of many Liberals in being able
to affect serious reforms had been weakened.3
What is particularly striking about the Reich Constitution are the farreaching powers of the Kaiser. He alone had the right to conduct the country’s foreign policy and to make decisions on whether to go to war or to stay
at peace. He was also the supreme commander of the armed forces. He nom178

The Constitutional Framework

inated and dismissed the Reich chancellor, the state secretaries of the Reich
Offices (ministries), and the higher civil service. Apart from executive privileges, the monarch also had legislative rights. They were limited by the Federal Council, representing the German princes, and by the Reichstag. Both
had to approve the bills that the Reich government had drafted with the
Kaiser’s approval. If they refused, the Constitution directed all three organs
to seek compromise, and this in turn gave both the other princes and the parliamentary deputies influence and leverage.
On the other hand, the monarch and his chancellor had at their disposal
powerful means of exerting pressure on deputies to pass a bill in question:
there was the constant possibility that the Kaiser might exercise his right to
dissolve the Reichstag prematurely in the hope that elections would produce
a more compliant representative assembly. If this proved impossible, he could
also threaten to send deputies home for indefinite periods and to stage a socalled Staatsstreich, which in this context amounted to a coup, backed by the
army, in which the constitution was dissolved altogether. This was no empty
threat. Bismarck, in trying to stem all gains in parliamentary influence and
power, repeatedly considered such a coup. Under his successors during the Wilhelmine period rumors of an impending Staatsstreich circulated frequently.
The workings of the Reich Constitution therefore can only be fully understood if we take into account that, in principle, the Kaiser had at his disposal
the use of military force and could set in motion a violent solution to any domestic political conflict. Even if this instrument was never used, the threat of
its use was a powerful political tool to wield. However, this power began to
wane toward 1914. At that time members of the Reich government, Reich
Chancellor Theobald von Bethmann Hollweg in particular, harbored the fear
that, given the size of the working-class movement, a coup would merely
lead to civil war. He articulated this dilemma during the internal debate on
the infamous memorandum that a retired general, Ludwig von Gebsattel, had
sent to the Crown Prince in 1913; but his objections to implementing Gebsattel’s radical proposals were also symptomatic of the impasse that the
monarchy had reached in domestic politics.4
The Federal Council, as a permanent forum of the German princes or their
delegates, could not be bullied, like the Reichstag, into approving a bill whenever the Kaiser waved a dissolution order. However, the threat of a Staatsstreich
tended to put the non-Prussian princes’ nerves on edge and to induce them to
act as mediators and work harder for legislative compromise. There was a flip
side to this. The kingdom of Prussia, linked to the Kaiser through a personal
union, had a mere seventeen out of fifty-eight votes in the Federal Council.
This was sufficient to block changes that Prussia opposed. But it also meant
that the Reich chancellor, in order to move forward a bill that he wanted to
see ratified, depended on the votes of the other, mostly larger federal states,
179

Politics

such as Bavaria or Saxony, which—unless the bill was withdrawn altogether—
frequently forced him into long negotiations and modifications even before a
bill was sent to the parliamentary assembly. And when, after all this, the compromise that had been agreed upon in the Federal Council reached the Reichstag floor, further changes could and would be proposed by deputies. Clearly,
there were limits to the effectiveness of the threat to dissolve the Reichstag
or stage a Staatsstreich when it came to daily legislative business.
The relationship between the Crown and the Reichstag was further complicated by another peculiarity of Prusso-German constitutionalism: because
the Reich government was appointed by the Kaiser (and could be dismissed
by him alone), the chancellor, who was not responsible to parliament, could
not automatically count on the kind of reliable majority without which a particular bill could not pass into law—unlike in England where the government
emerged from the parliamentary majority and hence could reasonably rely on
its support. All the Reich chancellor could do was to campaign for parties
during election time likely to stand by him. He constantly needed to keep these
parties on his side during the legislative session. If he failed, he might have
to contemplate a Staatsstreich, or risk seeing all state activity grind to a halt.
In short, he was forced into an unending and delicate juggling act that became more and more difficult to maintain, as economic and political interest
groups proliferated, society became enormously more complex, and the country’s international situation deteriorated toward 1914.
It is not difficult to visualize the problems created for the political process
by the triangle between Reich executive, Bundesstaaten, and the parliament.
During election campaigns, the constitutional structure furthered demagogic
sloganeering by parties. As they were not responsible for the formation of a
government, they would try to win over voters by presenting irresponsible
platforms. Meanwhile, members of the Reich government were under pressure to help those parties and candidates whom they knew were favorably
disposed toward the government’s agenda. And once the elections had yielded
such a majority, any pro-government alliance was bound to remain precarious
and had to be propped up with ad hoc concessions, which the deputies—
excluded from responsibility for the Kaiser’s unrepresentative government—
had recklessly come to expect. If concessions led to more irresponsible demands, the system was ultimately threatened by paralysis and by becoming
ungovernable. The advocates of a Staatsstreich saw the way out of this
dilemma by undoing the constitution. Others hoped to escape it through constitutional reforms that would give the Reichstag a greater say, but with it also
greater responsibility. However, since the Kaiser and his advisers stubbornly
resisted such reforms, demanding them amounted in practice to advocating
revolution, the more so since the Social Democrats, by 1912 the largest party
in the national parliament, were thought to be agitating for one.
180

The Constitutional Framework

Although the Constitution concentrated a great deal of power in the Reich
monarch, Prusso-German constitutionalism obviously amounted to a very
cumbersome system, the smooth operation of which required great skill on
the part of the monarch and his advisors. If tensions rose within society and
if domestic and foreign policy options began to shrink, the entire system, unless modified to permit greater participation and support, was threatened by
political paralysis. Because the top leadership was predisposed to resist reform, Bismarck’s creation, engulfed after 1890, if not before, by rapid socioeconomic change, was in a precarious state.
Bismarck always saw and feared this constitutional dilemma and tried to
avoid it by resorting to a number of wide-ranging political maneuvers. One
of them was to pinpoint “Reich enemies” and use them as scapegoats. He also
adopted an active colonial policy and introduced social insurance schemes in
the hope of appeasing the masses. While we will return to these techniques
later,5 the task at this point is to examine how the first Reich chancellor tried
to coordinate the executive and legislative machinery and to streamline it
without having to resort to comprehensive constitutional reform. One of his
approaches was to facilitate the search for legislative compromise in the Federal Council by linking Reich policy more closely with that of Prussia, by far
the largest federal state. Initially he tried to engineer this through personal
unions, later by merging entire ministerial offices. If these plans ran aground,
it was not just because the other federal states feared a “Prussianization” of
the Reich; over time the Prussian Ministry of State, the kingdom’s actual cabinet, also developed an aversion to this form of centralism and possible absorption by the Reich. At the heart of these fears lay the electoral laws, which
were reassuringly restrictive in Prussia and other federal states, but menacingly
democratic at the Reich level. In other words, Prusso-German constitutionalism, for all its monarchist elements, was marked by yet another peculiarity:
the universal male suffrage to elect the national assembly.
When Bismarck introduced this suffrage system in the Reich, he expected
that the conservative rural population would elect conservative deputies to
the Reichstag who would contain the group he feared the most at the time:
middle-class Liberals.6 But his hopes were soon disappointed. The massive
migrations had depleted the agrarian eastern provinces. With the growth of
industry came an increase in the number of industrial workers whose socioeconomic situation soon drove them toward political parties that advocated
political change and constitutional reform. After the chancellor had ignored
the earlier warnings that universal suffrage might have dire consequences
that would destroy his calculations of the 1860s, he admitted in 1879 that, if
faced with the choice between strengthening the powers of the federal states
or of the Reichstag, he would opt for the former.7 Indeed, long before the chancellor’s fall, the Reichstag electoral law, as the historian Hermann Baum181

Politics

garten put it in April 1890, had begun to threaten “not only the state, but our
entire civilization,” because it “brought to the fore in all matters the coarse
instincts of the masses.”8 After his fall and the lapse of the antisocialist laws,
more and more people voted for the Social Democrats and hence for a political force that the Kaiser and his ministers flatly refused even to consider for
inclusion in their constant search for stable legislative majorities. Only in the
1907 national elections did the SPD suffer a setback, but only in terms of
seats; the number of their voters rose from 3 million in 1903 to 3.3 million
four years later.
This development had another, frequently underestimated consequence:
the more the Prussian government, protected as it was by a restricted suffrage,
saw a unitary state looming on the horizon that was parliamentary-democratic,
the more its archconservative members were inclined to distance themselves
from the policies of the Reich, whose government could not avoid dealing
with the Reichstag and Federal Council. Thus began the retreat of Prussia,
the largest and most influential monarchical state, behind the walls of a reactionary particularism, buttressed by a three-class voting system that greatly
favored the Prussian agrarian conservatives. It is from behind these walls that
they worked harder and harder “to put a brake on the democratization of the
Reich and to impede its parliamentarization.”9 Worsening the situation, “the
struggle for leadership” between the Reich and Prussia after the turn of the
century exacerbated the country’s political and constitutional woes;10 for
without Prussian cooperation, the Reich could not really be governed.
Whatever those later troubles, the nightmare of a democratic-parliamentary
unitarism was frightening enough to Bismarck, as early as the 1880s, that he
was tempted to consider solutions to the constitutional dilemma that went beyond his attempts to simplify the Federal Council’s work. Once or twice he
thought of revoking the universal suffrage in the Reich with the help of the
army; he also tried to create economic councils, constituted on the basis of
professions. These bodies were to act as a corporatist counterweight to a
Reichstag elected on the basis of parliamentary constituencies. He also considered establishing a Reich Economic Council, a plan that similarly failed.
Consequently, the first chancellor and his successors had no choice but to
govern with volatile party majorities since the alternative of a Staatsstreich
had become too risky. Meanwhile, decision making in the Federal Council
also became more difficult, thanks to the above-mentioned obstinacy of Prussia and the reluctance of other federal states to play along, especially after the
turn of the century when problems began to mount.
Only within the Reich executive branch was Bismarck relatively successful in promoting centralization under his leadership. The Reich Constitution,
it is true, did make him dependent on the monarch, who could dismiss him
at will. But in actuality the relationship between Wilhelm I and his chancel182

The Constitutional Framework

lor had slowly become reversed. Unlike his son and his grandson, this Kaiser
was not particularly interested in ruling personally; therefore in most cases
he was only too happy to follow Bismarck’s advice and lead. Thus, the Reich
chancellor’s office became the most important power center in Berlin. Until
1890 it was directed by Bismarck, who did not shy away from using modern
means of charismatic leadership and mass propaganda. Even if historians
have become more cautious in characterizing his rule as a Bonapartist dictatorship, the Reich chancellor had certainly learned something from Napoleon
III during his years in Paris as a Prussian diplomat.
It is also clear that the trend toward charismatic centralization that accompanied the growth of the Reich bureaucracy continued long after Bismarck’s
fall.11 However, there was a marked change in the relationship between his
successors and the new Kaiser who ascended to the throne in 1888, after the
death that year of both his grandfather and his father, Frederick III, the Kaiser
of one hundred days. As was his privilege under the Reich Constitution, young
Wilhelm II wanted to use his powers fully himself. It is only against the background of these ambitions that we can understand Bismarck’s abrupt dismissal by the monarch in 1890 and the latter’s persistent attempts in the years
thereafter to recast the executive branch of government in such a way that all
lines of decision making ran to him rather than to the Reich chancellor.
The results of this reorganization, which dragged on until about 1898,
have been the subject of divergent assessments by historians. John Röhl has
argued that the Kaiser and his advisors succeeded by then in creating a centralized government that was based on Wilhelm’s “personal rule” as well as
a further centralization that was based on a “royal mechanism.”12 HansUlrich Wehler and others have denied that the Reich’s “real constitution” was
successfully reshaped in this way. They have underscored instead the emergence of a largely leaderless polycracy that—propelled by impersonal forces—
consisted of several competing power centers.13 The weak and erratic Wilhelm
II was in this view no more than a “shadow emperor,” and other institutions
and forces are said to have filled the vacuum left by Bismarck. A resolution
of this conflict of views might be achieved by sharply dividing the Wilhelmine period into two phases. Up to the turn of the century, it seems, the Kaiser
did succeed in tailoring the governmental machinery to his specifications. However, when it came to deploying this machinery in the fields of foreign and
domestic policy after 1900, and when, on top of it all, political difficulties
began to accumulate both at home and abroad, the monarch lacked the imagination, strength, and steadiness to control both the executive and the increasingly well-organized and vocal movements in the political arena. It was from
this point onward that the civilian and military bureaucracy, together with
parliamentary as well as extraparliamentary forces, began to jockey for strategic positions from which to fill the void that the monarch had left.
183

Politics

While Röhl has continued to defend his position, differences of opinion
have erupted among the representatives of the polycracy perspective. The
question is to what extent larger centers of power and influence can be discerned in the constitutional development of the Wilhelmine period. While no
one denies that such centers came into existence, the disagreement pertains
to their actual identity and how important they were. Manfred Rauh has advanced the hypothesis that toward 1914 the Reichstag emerged as a major
center of gravity, powerful enough to propel a “parliamentarization” of
Prusso-German constitutionalism.14 Geoff Eley and a number of British scholars of German history have argued that the extraparliamentary sphere became the arena in which the major developments of the period were being
prepared after the successful mobilization of new political forces “from below.”15 Margaret Anderson’s recent study probably also falls in this category,
even if she is not so much concerned with the question of parliamentarization as with the gradual assertion and exercise of democratic practices at the
grassroots’ level of German society through universal male suffrage.16 But
she also shows how arduous it was to weaken the counterforces that threw
themselves into the path of those attempting to democratize. We will return
to these conflicts below in the context of a more detailed examination of the
question of pluralization and polarization in the political realm.
A third group of historians has identified as crucial the executive’s growing power in a wider sense that they relate to the rise of modern bureaucracies and the interventionist state.17 While these arguments about Germany’s
political development will also be scrutinized in subsequent chapters, the
ordering of the economic and financial structures of the Reich must be discussed first.
C. Civil, Economic, and Financial Codes
For an understanding of how the country came to be organized in terms of
civil law and its ordering function in the society and economy, the introduction of the Bürgerliche Gesetzbuch (BGB, Civil Code) in 1900 is of fundamental importance. In hundreds of paragraphs the BGB standardized norms
of family and inheritance law that had been covered until then by the federal
states and frequently even by customary law at the local level. The Civil
Code, drafted by liberal-conservative jurists and professors, was celebrated
at the time of its ratification as a great advance in the creation of a modern
bourgeois society. But, on the negative side, the code abolished overnight numerous local rules and common-law customs that had been in use in the federal states until 1900. This was particularly true of the legal position of
women, which had been much stronger in various parts of the country. Overall, the BGB strengthened the position of men and husbands inside and outside the family.
184

The Constitutional Framework

Other legal norms relating to industry, commerce, and finance had been
established step by step in the decades before 1871. The Commercial Code
of 1861 defined the rules by which businessmen were expected to abide. The
Reich Constitution of 1871 therefore contained no more than a few articles
that regulated, in rather global terms, questions of tariffs, as well as of railroads, postal and telegraphic services, and shipping. The Reich was given
legislative responsibility for refining the law with respect to these specific areas. This means that the Reich’s economic constitution cannot be found in a
single document like the Constitution of 1871. It was made up of a multitude
of successively ratified laws and, increasingly, court decisions. The 1897 ruling of the Reich Court concerning cartels is a good case in point. In it cartels
and syndicates—that is, horizontal cooperative agreements between independent companies to fix prices and production quotas—were declared to be
binding contracts in private law.18 Firms in breach of cartel agreements, which
various branches of industry had meanwhile concluded in larger numbers,
could be taken to court. It was a crucial ruling that moved German industry
and commerce away from the principle of market competition in the direction of a protectionist capitalism. This capitalism differed from that of the
United States, where the Sherman Act of 1890, notwithstanding various subsequently ratified exceptions, explicitly defended the principle of competition against restrictive economic practices, such as cartels.
If the state as a regulatory agency advanced but slowly into the economic
field, governmental interest in the financial constitution had long been strong,
and Bismarck made sure to incorporate earlier clauses in the 1871 document.
In this respect he knew the population and its representatives to be on his
side; they were no less anxious to establish firm rules under which taxes were
raised and state expenditures allocated. After all, “freed from all ideological
sloganeering and empty phrase-making, the sober figures of the state budget”
more than any other official material told the “bare facts of the political and
social condition” of the Kaiserreich.19 Article 69 of the Constitution stipulated that the Reich’s income and expenditures were to be estimated in advance on an annual basis, and that a law approving the budget was to be
ratified by the Federal Council and the Reichstag before the beginning of each
fiscal year. The army budget alone was fixed on a more long-term basis. It
was put before the legislature every seven (and later every five) years, and
even then only proposed additional expenditures were open to parliamentary
scrutiny. Similar rules for the annual submission and debate of the nonmilitary budget existed in the federal states and local communities.
In the federal states the restrictive suffrage systems, often based on an income tax qualification, guaranteed the dominance of the wealthier classes
through their elected representatives and hence the passage of conservative
budgets that had been drawn up by conservative state governments.20 Univer185

Politics

sal suffrage at the Reich level and the different social composition of the national parliament, however, made it much more likely that finance bills might
run into trouble. There was even the possibility that a more radical majority
might change appropriations or cut expenditures beyond what the Reich government found acceptable. If compromise proved impossible to achieve and
the government was not prepared to withdraw its bill, Germany faced the
same deadlock that Prussia did during the constitutional conflict of the 1860s:
the executive would be forced to carry on with an emergency budget in the
hope that a compromise could be struck at a later date, leading to the budget’s retroactive approval by a more progovernment Reichstag. The other alternative was to bypass the constitutional structure altogether by staging a
Staatsstreich. Although it never came to this crisis point, the Reich budget did
become a major annual battleground between an unrepresentative government, on the one hand, and an “irresponsible” parliament, on the other, ultimately culminating in an intensely bitter struggle over the 1913 budget. And
since the budget was “the realization of a program of political action” that
deeply affected society’s future as a whole, looking at the huge conflicts over
successive Reich finance bills proves especially instructive for studying the
above-mentioned constitutional dilemma and the threat of ungovernability.21
First, however, we must inquire into how the power to raise different types
of taxes was divided up between the Reich, the federal states, and the local
communities. The Reich Constitution gave the central government the ultimate power over all tax legislation. Yet Article 70 also specified that the sources
of Reich income were restricted to tariffs, postal and telegraphic services,
and to whatever indirect taxes on consumption the legislature agreed to levy.
Loans could only be taken out to cover “extraordinary expenditure.” The
powers to raise potentially very lucrative direct taxes, by contrast, were given
to the federal states. Local communities and cities were left with taxes on land
and buildings, local duties, and profits generated by commercially run public utilities, such as gas works. They could also expect some funds from the
federal states, for example, for education. In Prussia, a law ratified in July
1893 provided guidance to the local communities on how to deal with their
finances. Even more important was the question of fiscal equalization in the
case of deficits or surpluses at one of these three levels. The solution found
to this particular question contained further potential for major conflicts, due
to the above-mentioned division of direct and indirect tax rights between the
Reich and federal states. Some 80 to 90 percent of Reich expenditures went
to the armed forces and were distributed among the four independent military contingents of Prussia, Saxony, Bavaria, and Württemberg (Table 73).
These budgets proved particularly vulnerable to sharp increases once the pre1914 international arms race began. If Reich income from tariffs and other
indirect taxes could not cover armament expenditures, the federal states were
186

The Constitutional Framework

expected to chip in with so-called matricular contributions to balance the
Reich budget.
The reasons for this system are not difficult to fathom: the Reich had to
be prevented from using its supreme authority for a transfer, by legislation,
of direct tax rights from the federal states to the center. If this happened, the
propertied classes would be exposed to the threat of a democratically elected
parliament voting for progressively higher taxes on income and wealth. It
was difficult enough to get the well-to-do to pay direct taxes in the federal
states, where, thanks to their restrictive suffrage systems, they were protected
by reassuringly conservative majorities in the regional legislatures. The
Prussian minister of finance, Johannes von Miquel, experienced these difficulties firsthand when he introduced a bill that imposed a progressive rate of
0.6 percent rising to 4 percent on incomes of over 900 marks per annum.22
The conservative deputies in the diet found this plan outrageous and resisted
it. The prospect of the Reichstag trying to tap a lucrative source of income
with even steeper direct tax rates greatly alarmed the country’s wealthy, including those—and there were quite a few of them—who had become artful
tax dodgers.
Against the background of these realities concerning the distribution of
wealth and power in Germany, we can begin to see one reason why Bismarck
abandoned free trade in 1879 and resorted to successive tariff increases during the 1880s. His aim was not only to help industry and agriculture as they
clamored for economic protection in this period of retarded growth, but also
to augment Reich income at a time when the increasing activities of a more
centralized Reich government inevitably triggered additional expenditures.
Apart from indirect taxes on tobacco and alcohol, tariffs presented a good
source of income. Indeed, in 1879 tariffs appeared so lucrative that some feared
the Reich would become wasteful and profligate. In order to block this development, parliament ratified the so-called Franckenstein Clause that required
the Reich to transfer to the federal states all annual income from tariffs and
indirect taxes over 130 million marks.23 It also meant that the “matricular contributions” that hitherto had been provisional became a permanent feature of
the fiscal code. Thenceforth a peculiar system of moving tax revenue back
and forth between the Reich and the federal states fell into place, making them
mutually dependent upon each other. The dangers of this system of financial
equalization came into full view only when the Reich stopped paying the federal states excess revenue from tariffs under the Franckenstein Clause the
moment its own expenditures had begun to surpass its income from tariffs
and indirect taxes. Thus, the federal states suddenly found themselves in the
role of paymaster, obliged to transfer money to Berlin in the shape of regular and rapidly rising “matricular contributions.” Unhappy at this turn of events,
they began to push the Reich to increase indirect taxes and tariffs and take
187

Politics

out loans for “extraordinary expenditures,” even if the latter were in fact used
to pay for ordinary budget items.
The consequences of this development were dramatic for the economy
and politics. The Reich debt rose to 5 billion marks by 1914, placing, together
with the debts of the federal states (16.3 billion) and local communities (7.5
billion), a heavy burden on the capital market and adversely affecting private
investment.24 Loans became more expensive. Meanwhile the leftward drift in
the Reichstag’s political composition had made it more and more difficult to
increase tariffs and indirect taxes. After all, these taxes hit the weekly budget
of low-income groups particularly hard. The penny added to the price of a
loaf of bread because of higher grain tariffs was a socially explosive issue
and grist to the mills of the Social Democrats, who highlighted the tax system as a typical expression of an unjust Wilhelmine class state. They also
pointed to the Reich’s supreme fiscal authority and demanded that the government transfer direct tax privileges from the federal states to the center.
The propertied classes were terrified at this prospect. They feared heavily
progressive income taxes imposed by a leftist Reichstag that had been elected
by a majority of men with meager incomes who were incensed by the seemingly endless raising of taxes on items of daily consumption.
Of course, there was the alternative of increasing “matricular contributions” to plug the Reich deficit. But this also became a dangerous device,
especially in the less populous smaller states, where the contributions were
raised as a per capita tax. Moreover, the annual variations in the size of the
required contributions threatened to throw state budgets into disarray, as reliable projections became impossible. Finally, the financial crisis at the top
also undermined the financial health of local communities, especially in the
country’s economically weaker regions. What all this added up to was that,
as early as 1904, the entire financial constitution was in serious disorder.
Federal states felt besieged from both sides and, led by conservative Prussia,
were less and less prepared to make any payments, whether to Berlin or local administrations. Although it had become increasingly clear that the financial constitution was in dire need of a fundamental overhaul, attempts at
reform repeatedly bogged down. The Reich finance bills of 1906 and 1908/9,
designed to plug the deficits, quickly turned out to be totally inadequate.
Above all, these bills sparked major domestic conflicts that, as we shall see,
greatly exacerbated the growing crisis of the Prusso-German constitutional
order as a whole during the final years before World War I (Table 72).25
However significant the story of taxes may be for the development of the
Kaiserreich, the ways in which revenue was spent and redistributed in society deserve no less intensive study (Table 73). However, we are dealing here
with an issue on which the Reich Constitution did not contain any instructions beyond the requirement that both the Federal Council and Reichstag
188

Parties and Elections

ratify an annual plan. In order to understand where the money went, we must
investigate how socioeconomic and political power were actually distributed
and wielded in Imperial Germany.26

14. Parties and Elections in a Period of Dynamic Change
A. Problems of Parliamentarization, Party Structures,
and the Sociology of Parties
During the past thirty years, the question of whether the Kaiserreich was on
the road to parliamentarism has generated a good deal of heat among scholars, not least because this question is closely bound up with the problem of
the reformability of Prusso-German constitutionalism and of the extent of the
pre-1914 crisis. Writing in the 1960s and 1970s, Fritz Fischer and HansUlrich Wehler took rather pessimistic views of the situation, asking whether
the Kaiser’s decision to go to war in 1914 was an attempt to cut the Gordian
knot of a domestic and foreign policy deadlock.27 Subsequently, other historians, Thomas Nipperdey and a group of British and American historians
among them, doubted that Germany had purposefully maneuvered itself into
a cul-de-sac.28
Alfred Milatz and Ernst Deuerlein pointed out long ago that the possibilities of reforming the Bismarckian Constitution were “limited.”29 That was
putting it rather mildly. According to Article 78, any bill proposing to change
the Constitution would fail if fourteen of the delegates of the federal princes
in the Federal Council voted against it. Since Prussia commanded seventeen
votes, a single federal state had an absolute veto, and this state increasingly
saw itself in the years before 1914 as the last bastion of monarchism and of
the social and political status quo against the democratizing pressures of the
prewar decades. In view of the Reich’s deteriorating domestic and diplomatic
position after the turn of the century, chances of effecting peaceful constitutional change through legislation were therefore pretty much nil. Although
reform was vital for the monarchy’s survival and, for this very reason, was
urged by many far-sighted contemporaries, the balance of actual power was
tilted too heavily against such reform.
However, a constitutional system can, at least in principle, undergo tacit
reform due to subterranean shifts in power relations between the individual
organs of the Constitution. In two studies, Manfred Rauh has tried to advance
“a complete theory of the reichsdeutsche constitutionalism,”30 arguing that a
“silent parliamentarization” was in fact well underway in pre-1914 Germany.
In his first book he traced this alleged development up to 1909. He later extended his analysis of this parliamentarizing process in a second monograph
up to “its (provisional) end in 1917/18.” In particular he interpreted parlia189

Politics

mentarization as a long-term process that started off with a power shift away
from the federal states toward the Reich, and thereafter from the monarchical Reich executive branch toward the Reichstag. Parliament had effectively
penetrated the executive’s exclusive sphere of decision making, he maintained, including in the field of foreign policy. According to Rauh, another
indication of major shifts is found in the changing behavior of Reichstag
deputies, who, he believed, began to interact in ways typically found in fully
fledged parliamentary systems.
More recent studies concerning the power structure of the late Kaiserreich have taken more ambivalent positions. The voices of the deputies, it is
true, became louder in matters of foreign policy as Germany’s international
isolation increased toward 1914. There were votes of no-confidence, even if,
given the structure of the Bismarckian Constitution, they did not lead to ministerial resignations. On the contrary, criticism merely confirmed the Imperial
court and military in their view that preserving the monarch’s constitutional
right to conduct the country’s foreign policy and to decide on whether to go
to war had become more vital than ever. While the parties did display modes
of behavior that were “adequate to a parliamentary system,” at the same time
there were “considerable tendencies to adapt to existing constitutional conditions and to accept the game rules of political influence-wielding that had
been shaped by the constitutional system of government.”31 Ultimately it was
thought impossible “to decide with certainty” which of the two currents
“would in the final analysis prove more powerful.”
One way of reaching firmer ground in this debate is to examine—as we
shall in Part V—the enormous resistance that the government and conservative military and civilian elites put up toward the end of World War I when
defeat appeared on the horizon and it would have been wise to make constitutional concessions to an increasingly restive and radicalized population and
its representatives. What must be remembered at this point is that Bismarck
gave the Constitution its peculiar antidemocratic, federal structure precisely
in order to make the parliamentarization of the political system more difficult. It also seems wise to differentiate between contemporary perceptions
and developments that have become visible only with the benefit of hindsight. There were, after all, those who were prepared to defend the status quo
to the hilt, if necessary with the force of arms. To them a gradual slide into
Western-European parliamentarism was tantamount to revolution. However,
there were others who advocated a transformation of the existing power
structure and who hoped to make the Reichstag the key decision-making center. If the debate on parliamentarization periodically reached a crescendo, it
may be that the prospects for a silent constitutional change were more propitious at such junctures than they were in the years of crisis before 1914.

190

Parties and Elections

One of these periods coincided with the founding of the German Empire,
when the Liberals dominated the Reichstag and Bismarck could not get any
legislation passed without their support. But this sharing of responsibility did
not directly challenge the uneven distribution of powers that the Constitution
had just established. The Liberals were satisfied with participating in the formulation of the many new laws that had to be ratified after 1871, realizing
that they needed the monarchical state to guarantee stability at home and
abroad during this initial period. However, this did not mean that they had
abandoned for good all plans to move the Reich toward genuine parliamentary government. On the contrary, believing themselves to be indispensable
to Bismarck, many of them, among whom their leader Rudolf von Bennigsen
was most prominent, came to feel that time was on their side in promoting a
slow transformation of the Constitution. All they had to do was to wait for
the tide of history, which had created parliamentary systems in Western Europe, to sweep into Germany. The drawback of this position was that it impeded the formulation of concrete claims to power as the deputies were busy
passing legislation on all sorts of more specialized issues.
Even more importantly, Bennigsen underestimated Bismarck’s determination not to let time work for the Liberals, but to use the 1870s to promote the
consolidation of the conservative-monarchical order. This is why the chancellor, whose personal position had been further strengthened by the state-building
effort after 1871, did his best to keep his state secretaries subordinated to him
directly and to prevent them from becoming ministers answerable to parliament.
Above all, Bismarck worked tirelessly to resolve in his and the monarchy’s
favor the basic tension within the constitutional structure between representative and autocratic-monarchical government.32 An opportunity to effect
such a further shift came with the onset of the “Great Depression.” In those
early years of retarded economic growth, Bismarck skillfully succeeded in
dashing the Liberals’ earlier hopes for the future. Backed by political forces
that had meanwhile organized themselves into powerful pressure groups outside the Reichstag, his model of autocratic rule slowly gained the upper hand.
Divided among themselves, frustrated by the success of the “second founding of the Reich” in 1878/79 (i.e., the chancellor’s turn against the Social
Democrats and away from free trade), and now led by a generation of more
conservative-nationalist deputies, the Liberal parties thenceforth became the
mouthpiece of groups that were less interested in major constitutional reforms and more concerned with economic success and political stability. The
higher and more comprehensive goal of parliamentarization moved to the
margins of the political goals of the National Liberals, represented primarily
by the numerically weak Left Liberals. Yet even then, when he could have
been more relaxed about the Liberal threat, the chancellor and many conser-

191

Politics

vatives never lost sight of it and did their level best to remove, if possible forever, the danger of parliamentarization.
An appreciation of the victory of the Bismarckian system over the liberalconstitutional optimism of the Gründerzeit of the early 1870s is vital for an
understanding of developments during the Wilhelmine period. The inability
of the Kaiser to give teeth to his “personal rule” after the turn of the century,
and the polycentrism that subsequently resulted, no doubt increased the opportunities of the Reichstag and the major parties to influence political decision making.33 This was particularly true in the wake of the Daily Telegraph
affair of 1908, when the British paper published tactless remarks by Wilhelm
II that further weakened the prestige of the Kaiser. It has been argued that the
state secretaries, unlike in Bismarck’s time, now seemingly behaved like ministers in a parliamentary system: they lobbied and consulted with deputies.
Naval Secretary Alfred von Tirpitz tried to make members of parliament
more amenable to approving higher naval estimates by inviting them on carefully staged tours of Imperial shipyards to admire the building of Germany’s
awesome battleships. However, these tactical maneuvers in no way changed
the monarchist loyalties of the ministers. These considerations would also
seem to apply to the pressure from Social Democratic and Catholic voters to
fill the universal suffrage with a more democratic spirit. “Practicing democracy,” as Margaret Anderson has shown, had many advocates at the grassroots
level, while the authorities and conservative groups resisted the demands for
fair elections.34
Furthermore, we should not mistake the growing criticism of “personal
rule” by Reichstag deputies as a demand for the parliamentarization of the
Hohenzollern monarchy. Factors that must always be added to the equation
include the country’s increasing difficulties both at home and abroad, the rise
of the “unpatriotic” Social Democrats, and the impact of universal suffrage
for men, all of which promoted political polarization among the parties and
made it even more difficult to reach a broad and lasting consensus on basic
issues and to draw up proposals for constitutional reform. Nor did the manifold extraparliamentary pressure groups contribute to this process. Indeed,
the deepening of ideological differences made it difficult and ultimately wellnigh impossible to forge majorities for even the most ordinary bills. Basically, the party system had to be reformed before there could be an effective
movement among the parties for parliamentary government, and such a reform was not in sight in the last years before World War I. Apart from the Social Democrats and the small band of Left Liberals, the parties showed little
inclination, even as the crisis of “personal rule” deepened, to work together
to reform the Reich Constitution or to promote parliamentarism as a mediumterm objective. These realities lead us into a more detailed analysis of party
structures and sociology.
192

Parties and Elections

The parties had not been given an explicit role in the Reich Constitution.
Individuals and local notables elected as deputies were assumed to be subject
only to their consciences when they voted on a particular issue. Nevertheless,
even before 1871 political parties had come into existence almost everywhere
in Central Europe. It was tacitly assumed that they would participate in the
process of opinion-formation. At the same time, the early party organizations
did not have the same stable features as those of the late Wihelmine period.
They had started as electoral associations run by local elites, and this is what
they continued to be for many years after the Reich’s founding in 1871. It
took the Conservatives, who were moreover badly split in their attitude toward Bismarck, several years to develop consolidated party organizations.
During the early 1870s the Free Conservatives, who had supported Bismarck
in his unification policy and who, as a reflection of their attitude, after 1871
operated under the name of “Deutsche Reichspartei,” barely consisted of more
than a few informal electoral committees and even fewer electoral associations. The Central Committee included no more than a fraction of the thirtyseven Free Conservative deputies who had been elected in 1871, and the
remaining vacancies were filled by cooptation.
The Old Conservatives, who were convinced that Bismarck’s policy of
unification had been fundamentally wrong, split again in 1872 after much
wrangling in connection with the debate over a new District Code (Kreisordnung). When the remaining Old Conservatives lost no fewer than thirty-five
of their fifty-seven seats in the 1874 Reichstag elections, many of them concluded that the time had come to reconcentrate their forces and to make
peace with the Reich chancellor (Table 79). The German Conservative Party
was born two years later, and during the 1877 Reichstag elections the new
party almost doubled the number of its seats to forty. After the 1878 elections
it even had fifty-nine deputies in parliament. Still, the party continued to rely
less on a well-oiled organization than on its informal contacts in the higher
bureaucracy and at the various courts. Its spokesmen, most of whom were socially connected with the agrarians, had many such contacts. It was only due
to pressure increasingly exerted on them by the example of the—in terms of
voter mobilization—more successful Social Democrats and the Catholic Center, and also in reaction to their economic decline, that the agrarian Conservatives built up a more effective party machine.
Meanwhile the National Liberals had won no fewer than 125 seats in the
1871 elections, followed by the Progressives (46 seats) and the Liberal Reich
Party (30 seats) (Table 79). For the moment these groups remained tied to
each other in rather peculiar ways. In parliament they formed three independent caucuses, while running a common network of electoral associations and
committees throughout the country.35 In 1874 the National Liberals gained
as many as 155 seats. The Liberal Reich Party, by contrast, suffered heavy
193

Politics

losses and remained a splinter group until its merger with the Liberal Association and the Progressives. The subsequent history of German liberalism is
a story of increased organization, but also of painful divisions, disappointments, and decline. This decline occurred first at the Reich level and later in
the regions and local communities, although the Liberals tended to retain
strongholds in some major cities.
As the parties changed, so did the ways and means by which laws were
prepared. As long as the politics of notables predominated and the Liberals
were at the peak of their success, it was rare for formal negotiations to be
held between the Reich government and the majority parties. Bismarck focused his attention on influential deputies, whom he invited to his famous
evening receptions. If a vote had to be prepared at all, the preliminary work
took place in so-called Free Commissions, which informally and confidentially brought the leading deputies together. At first there were only a few
permanent expert committees, which were occasionally complemented by ad
hoc special committees. But on repeated occasions, compromises that had
been struck informally in advance were torn up in the plenary session. The
frustration felt by party elders over such setbacks hastened the introduction
of greater party discipline, which in turn promoted the emergence of more
stable party structures and clearer procedures.
One of the advantages to Bismarck of his informal gatherings and consultations was that he could exclude parties and politicians he found undesirable. In the first years after the German Empire’s founding, members of the
Catholic Center Party were treated as the pariahs of parliamentary life. This
particular party had its roots in southern Germany in the 1860s. In the summer of 1870, the decisive impulse came from the Rhineland to create a supraregional Catholic movement. The Center captured 63 seats in the first Reichstag
elections and, three years later, commanded no fewer than 91 (Table 79).
During the 1880s, the number of Center Party deputies hovered between 98
and 100, displaying an impressive stability of electoral support thereafter
right up to 1912. The Center, which did not have a particularly strict organization at first, could count on the support of an active associational life and
of the church hierarchy. Not surprisingly, the latter favored Catholic notables
and the local clergy. However, it is unlikely that they could have operated so
smoothly and succeeded in making tangible inroads into the traditional electoral strongholds of the Liberals if they had not come under external pressure
resulting from the Kulturkampf. More than anything else, Bismarck’s and the
Liberals’ struggle against them welded the Catholics together. When this period of ostracism came to an end, the common bonds began to weaken. Toward 1914 a number of Catholic industrial workers decided to vote for the
Social Democrats, as memories of the Kulturkampf faded and no longer provided a particularly strong ideological glue. Meanwhile, in Protestant Prus194

Parties and Elections

sia and at the Imperial court, animosities against the Catholic church and the
Center Party remained too strong to herald the complete end of their stigmatization as “Reich enemies.” Faith-based politics may have become less important than the politics of class in the final years before World War I, but it
remained a factor to be reckoned with.
The experience of being stigmatized as a dangerous “Reich enemy” also
united the political arm of the working-class movement during the 1870s. In
1875 the Allgemeinen Deutschen Arbeitervereine (General German Workers’ Associations) combined with the Social Democrats under the leadership
of August Bebel and Wilhelm Liebknecht. The first electoral successes were
very encouraging. In 1871 there were merely two Social Democratic deputies
(Table 79). Three years later, this figure had risen to nine and by 1877 to
twelve, with almost 10 percent of the voters casting ballots for the new leftist party. By August this party counted over 38,000 members in 291 local
groups. The antisocialist laws put a severe damper on the growth of the Left.
After their lapse in 1890, the growth of SPD representation in the Reichstag
was arrested only once, that is, during the 1907 elections. By 1912 the workers’ party conquered no fewer than 110 seats and became the largest party in
the national parliament, with consequences for domestic politics that will be
examined later in this part.
Social Democracy’s status as a new type of party, very different from the
loose organizations of notables, first emerged during elections throughout the
1870s. Many years ago, Sigmund Neumann tried to develop a taxonomy for
this new type of organization by differentiating between representation parties, on the one hand, and integration parties, on the other.36 In comparison to
the parties of notables (Honoratiorenparteien), integration parties were more
firmly set with regard to both ideology and organization. From the start, they
tried to attract voters and their families, young and old, on a permanent basis. It was a successful recipe that, according to Neumann, soon began to
have an impact on the older liberal representation parties. In order to survive
in elections, they too had to transform themselves into integration parties.
From the 1870s onward, the Honoratiorenparteien thus began their slow
decline. Parties now built more durable structures that survived beyond election campaigns. Political work inside and outside parliament increasingly occurred in formally constituted committees that had their own bylaws and
procedures. The work of the diets in the federal states developed along similar lines.
To be sure, informal channels of influence and power did not disappear, and
even in the Social Democratic Party, which in so many ways was the pacemaker
of organizational modernization, an ostensibly democratic-representative
constitution often became a facade behind which powerful politicians made
their deals. This tendency to form oligarchies, which Robert Michels wrote
195

Politics

about in connection with the pre-1914 SPD,37 was even more marked among
parties of the Right. Although, following a broader trend toward participation, they began to put on “democratic gloves,”38 authoritarian rule by a few
continued to be regarded as a virtue.
All in all, the organization of the country’s political parties in 1913 was
therefore quite different from that of 1871. Only the basic pattern of four
large blocs (Social Democrats, Liberals, Conservatives, and the Center), supplemented by divergent minority parties (Poles, Danes, Alsace-Lorraineans,
and Guelphs), remained unchanged (Table 79). The internal structures and the
modes of operation had meanwhile undergone a striking metamorphosis.
A look at the type of politician who could be seen wheeling and dealing
in the Kaiserreich’s assemblies shows that it would be erroneous to equate
changes in party organization with a silent parliamentarization. The basic
trend, which sooner or later affected all parties, was for the amateur to be
slowly replaced by the professional. If nothing else, the growth and complexity of parliamentary business made this shift virtually inevitable. In the early
days of the Bismarckian period, it was perhaps still possible to take the train
to the capital to be present for a crucial vote, but otherwise to continue with
one’s main profession in business or agriculture back at home. Nor were the
costs of serving in parliament so high that they could not be met by a deputy’s
ordinary income. With the passage of time, however, political work became
more expensive and time-consuming. The shift from representation party to
integration party, as observed by Neumann, can also be gleaned from a growing debate on whether parliamentarians should be paid expenses and salaries.
That this demand should be promoted more and more insistently indicated,
furthermore, that the social composition of the assemblies was changing.
Conservative opponents of expense accounts rightly argued that, in the age
of universal suffrage for men, any such payments would act as an “incentive
for wider circles to put themselves forward as candidates.”39 Of course, conservatives had nothing but disdain for the “mercenaries of parliament” who,
on top of it all, did not even have the “proper” social background.40 Such attitudes contributed to delaying the introduction of payments to Reichstag
deputies until 1906. But in the long run not even the delaying tactics of the
conservatives and the Reich government were able to prevent the rise of the
professional politician who, beyond the routine of attending the plenary sessions, had made himself an expert in certain fields and served on specialized
committees.41
Heinrich Best has collected more detailed information on the social profile
of deputies. His material signals that a major sociological change occurred,
adding that it remained incomplete and unfolded in a segmented fashion.
Thus, the trend toward professionalization was much more prevalent in the
SPD than elsewhere. The percentage of farmers and men from small towns
196

Parties and Elections

among the deputies remained higher than might have been expected from the
share of the total population living in urban centers. Among Social Democratic deputies, 60 to 65 percent were city-dwellers, while a mere 7 to 10 percent came from rural areas. None of the other parties had so many urban
members. The Social Democratic Party also had a larger share of deputies
who were party functionaries or lobbyists and hence professionals in a double sense. The greater “modernity” of the Social Democrats is also evident
in their religious affiliations, or lack thereof. Compared to their colleagues in
other parties, more of them had been seized by the wave of secularization and
hence did not list a formal denomination in their resumés.42
Other calculations indicate a less segmented process of secularization.
Thus the “transition from an ascriptive to a competitive mode of recruitment
of political elites” is reflected in the successive drop in the number of aristocratic deputies up to 1912.43 The share of university-trained deputies remained
above 50 percent throughout, but it also began to decline. A similar drop
affected members who had received legal educations. Meanwhile the share
of deputies who held positions in modern pressure groups increased. With respect to other sociological criteria, our knowledge of the Reich’s changing
parliamentary elites still needs to be refined. As regards Social Democratic
candidates for Reichstag elections, a few data point to an underrepresentation
of unskilled workers even in this party. Tobacco workers formed an exception here, but their share declined from 7.1 percent in 1898 to 3.8 percent in
1912. Meanwhile the share of skilled workers in the Social Democratic Reichstag caucus grew from 53.6 percent in 1898 to 66.4 percent in 1912. During
this time the percentage of candidates who failed to gain a seat remained relatively constant at around 75 percent. Next to the tobacco workers, workers
in the lumber industry, printers, and editors of party newspapers also saw their
share of seats decline. Metal and construction workers, by contrast, made
gains, as did party and trade union functionaries.
The gradual displacement of the parties of notables by integration parties
and of the amateur politician by the professional might be thought to have facilitated communication among the deputies. However, professional homogenization did not mean that social background became any less significant.
Early on, Bismarck had expressed his dismay at “the suffocating increase in
party bickering and hatred among the caucuses.”44 In the years before 1914,
as political and ideological conflicts deepened, a continued consciousness of
social differences tended to exacerbate the situation, making cooperation more
difficult. The coordination of campaign styles at the national level worked in
the direction of bloc formation. Both the party system and the social composition of parties therefore moved in a direction that impeded parliamentarization. The attempts under the Hohenzollern monarchy to effect constitutional
change were impeded by the emergence of a number of tightly organized polit197

Politics

ical blocs, led by politicians with uncompromising ideological commitments
and interests.
B. Electoral Systems and Electoral Behavior
The analysis of electoral systems offers further evidence of the problems raised
by Rauh’s hypothesis on parliamentarization. As was the case in many other
European countries, political systems at the local and regional levels restricted
suffrage that contributed to the progressive hardening of party politics. The
most frequently cited example is Prussia’s indirect three-class voting system,
which was important if for no other reason because two-thirds of Germany’s
adult male population resided in Prussia. As indicated by the name, there
were three types of voters, categorized according to their tax bracket. Voters
in the highest taxation class (about 2.0 percent of the population, depending
on the year) selected one-third of the electors, who in turn elected a corresponding number of candidates to the Prussian Diet. Another third were
chosen by voters in the middle tax bracket, constituting 4 to 14 percent of
taxpayers. The majority of those eligible to vote—some 80 to 85 percent—
belonged to the third category and cast their ballots for the last third of the
electors. This meant that a vote in the first category tended to carry sixteen
to twenty-six times more weight than one in the third category. A good 10
percent of eligible voters (i.e., men over twenty-four years of age) fell below
the tax threshold and were hence barred from voting altogether. Given these
realities, it is not surprising that, for example, during the diet elections of
1908 the mainly agrarian Conservatives gained 47.9 percent of the seats,
although no more than 16.7 percent of the voters cast ballots for them. Authorities made matters worse by refusing to adjust the borders of electoral
districts to take account of the huge migration movements from the countryside to the cities. They did so for blatantly political reasons.
But official stubbornness met with increasingly persistent protests, to which
the Prussian government finally responded in 1910 by producing an electoral
reform bill. This bill called for the replacement of the indirect system of electors with a direct one and proposed to merge constituencies whose populations had become very small. It also realigned the tax levels and introduced
a partial plural ballot that favored the educated bourgeoisie. It says much about
the state of domestic politics and the balance of power that the conservative
opposition to this very modest bill eventually succeeded in toppling it. The
Prussian three-class voting system remained in force until it was abolished in
the revolution of 1918. Voters who thought these and many other injustices,
big and small, objectionable continued to protest, both before 1914 and during
World War I. Yet, it was difficult to bring about even the most gradual political change. Those who held the reins of power simply refused to acknowledge the momentous social and economic transformations that the Reich had
198

The Constitutional Framework

meanwhile experienced and to introduce a greater measure of fairness at the
ballot box.
There are other telling examples from outside Prussia. Since 1868, the
Kingdom of Saxony had used an electoral system that bestowed voting rights
only to those who possessed a residential building lot and made annual payments of a certain minimum in direct taxes.44 As a result of these restrictions,
no more than half of the male population of this federal state was able to go
to the polls. After the turn of the century, pressures mounted to initiate reforms; but with fears of Social Democracy in the “Red Kingdom of Saxony”
rising, government and parties maneuvered to achieve not only advantages
for themselves, but above all to block a further advance of the Left. In 1909
a system was finally introduced that lifted some of the existing restrictions,
but the idea of universality was quickly undermined by a new set of conditions. Under the new requirements, voters had to have been Saxon citizens
for at least two years prior to the elections and to have paid their taxes. Furthermore, wealthy Saxons now obtained up to three additional votes. Anyone
who was over fifty-nine years of age or occupied an elevated position received one additional vote. Another restriction was that the chamber was
elected every six years and candidates had to gain an absolute majority, enabling other parties to form temporary local alliances in order to keep Social
Democratic contenders out.
The Bavarian system was similarly based on an income qualification and
other restrictions so that about one-third of the men of minimum age were
excluded altogether. As in Prussia, the polls merely identified electors, and
until 1881 ballots were not filled in behind the curtain of a polling booth, but
written out in public. By 1914 a certain degree of democratization had occurred in Baden and Württemberg, where the principle of direct elections was
introduced in 1905/6. Meanwhile Hamburg, Lübeck, and Brunswick actually
tightened their systems. Thus, over half of the 192 seats in the Hamburg Chamber were elected by specially protected groups of patrician notables, while
the remaining taxpayers elected a mere 84 deputies. By the turn of the century a number of other changes were made. In view of the unstoppable advance
of the Social Democrats, the tax qualification was sharply increased in 1906,
triggering massive popular demonstrations against this “robbery of the voting right.” These outbursts were ruthlessly suppressed by the police.45 Many
other urban communities with tax categories similar to those in Prussia raised
their tax qualification levels at the very moment when the existing bourgeois
majorities came to be threatened by the gains by the Social Democrats in local elections. Only in a few cases, such as in Barmen or Düsseldorf, were the
suffrage restrictions actually eased.
Voting inequalities were also perpetuated by the stonewalling tactics of
authorities who were responsible for determining constituency boundaries.
199

Politics

In Bavaria they engaged in active gerrymandering, repeatedly changing boundaries in such a way that parties loyal to the government were favored. The
Prussian State Ministry, and later the Reich government, perpetuated inequality by inaction. The extensive migrations from the eastern provinces to new
industrial centers further west ought to have resulted in regular reviews of
voting districts, but this never happened. Accordingly by 1914 a mere onetenth, in some cases one-thirtieth, of eligible males in the east’s depopulated
rural regions elected the same number of deputies as voters in densely populated industrial zones. This explains why the Conservatives, with the exception of the 1881 Reichstag elections, always gained a higher percentage of
the seats than was justified on the basis of votes obtained (Table 80). Being
handicapped or privileged as a voter was therefore not just a matter of one’s
tax bracket, but also of where one lived, and was ultimately dependent upon
socioeconomic status.
In comparison with the restricted suffrage systems of the federal states and
the local communities, the direct, universal, and secret ballot for the Reichstag that Bismarck had taken over from the Constitution of the North German
Confederation was a revolutionary innovation. Judging from the initial turnout
in the early 1870s, it may have taken some time for eligible men to become
accustomed to going to the polls. But with turnout at 80 percent and higher,
which indicates that those eligible began to take voting very seriously, participation was not a problem, once ordinary voters had a sense that each ballot
counted (Table 79). Where this sense was lacking, as it was in many federal
states with restrictive systems, turnout figures were much lower, though even
here participation increased over time. Without discussing in detail the first
chancellor’s cunning political calculations, it is important to remember that
he did not take the step into universal suffrage because he had been won over
to the idea of democracy. Rather he was hoping to weaken the forces of urban liberalism by counting on the innate conservatism of the rural populations. His calculations turned out to be badly flawed, later causing Bismarck
and, even more so, his successors many agonies. That the strategy behind the
introduction of universal male suffrage had backfired is reflected not only in
the fact that, as we have seen, the Reich government repeatedly toyed with
the idea of a Staatsstreich, a forcible revision of the Reich Constitution that
would have abolished universal suffrage, but also in the official inaction when
it came to adjusting constituency boundaries to demographic shifts.
The system of a second ballot (Stichwahl) opened up further possibilities
for undermining the principle of equality at the polls. As the rise of the Social Democrats since the 1890s challenged the strongholds of other parties in
many regions, second ballots to determine the winners of races that had been
inconclusive on the first ballot were held with increasing frequency. This provided local nonsocialist parties with the opportunity to form alliances and to
200

Parties and Elections

agree on a single candidate whenever the first ballot had shown that the Social Democratic contender might win. The combined effect of all these rules
and practices was that in the 1890s the share of the Social Democratic vote
was twice as high as that of the seats gained by the party (Tables 79–80). In
the 1907 Reichstag elections it was even three times higher. Only in 1912 the
proportion once again became more balanced (34.8 percent of the votes compared with 27.7 percent of the seats). By that time, it even happened in southwestern Germany that the Left Liberals would link up with the SPD to defeat
more right-wing opponents in the second ballot. It is not difficult to see that
such alliances made the other parties even more frantic and hostile.
Beyond the question of how universal and equal male suffrage was actually practiced in selecting Reichstag members, there were also violations of
the principle of secrecy, especially in the rural constituencies of East Elbia.
Thus, it was by no means an unusual sight that, on election day, land laborers
would be marched straight from the fields to the polling station. There they
were given the “correct” ballot paper, which the local “estate owner, in his
role as poll supervisor,” would then “graciously” accept, occasionally using
as ballot box “an empty cigar case or a soup bowl without a lid.”46 Margaret
Anderson has recently analyzed this system with respect to the rural parts of
the country as well as some industrial districts.47 Later the Social Democrats
turned the tables on their opponents and learned to apply gentle pressure in
their industrial strongholds to insure that local shopkeepers or publicans voted
for them. Catholic and Protestant priests also developed techniques of exerting moral pressure to get their flock to vote for a “Christian” party.
Overall, however, the outcome of elections was not determined by various
corrupt practices, but by the ideological commitments and interests of the
voter. Nothing demonstrated this more clearly than the fact that the political
stratification of German society increasingly coincided with socioeconomic
class lines. Exceptions always granted, this applied above all to Protestant industrial workers, for whom it became less and less thinkable to vote for a
nonsocialist party. In the 1912 Reichstag elections, the Social Democrats obtained over 4.2 million votes (Table 79). Most of these came from the reservoir of approximately 5.5 million male industrial laborers who had reached
the age of twenty-five. The SPD’s share of the voting public was very high
in a number of large industrial cities. This is also where most of the 1.0 million members came from whom the party had meanwhile recruited. By 1912
a larger number of voters belonged to the “new Mittelstand” who by moving
toward the Left wanted to show their dissatisfaction with the overall drift of
Wilhelmine politics and the role of the other parties.
Another partial exception to the rule that class determined party affiliation
or support was the high number of Catholic workers for whom denomination
remained the more decisive factor. Politically they inclined toward the Cath201

Politics

olic Center Party and the Catholic trade union movement. Socially, political
Catholicism remained a heterogeneous phenomenon, and the successful integration of so many diverse elements into one party over a long period of
time remains a considerable achievement. Unlike their Protestant counterparts, Catholic workers turned toward Social Democracy in larger numbers
only in the last years before 1914.48 In the southwest, the Center Party proved
an effective political force when, after the end of the Kulturkampf, it succeeded
in challenging the strongholds of liberalism in that region. Supported by the
800,000 members of the Volksverein für das katholische Deutschland, the
party attracted Catholic estate owners from Silesia, Catholic bankers and industrialists from the Rhineland, Catholic peasants and artisans from Bavaria,
and Catholic miners from the Ruhr area. For a long time, the electoral support from these groups remained remarkably stable at 22 to 23 percent (Table
79). With the rise of the Social Democrats after 1890, it declined to about 19
percent, where it remained fairly steady until 1911. The 1912 Reichstag elections resulted in a further drop of 3 percent, as Catholic workers began to
move to the Left in larger numbers. Votes were also lost in Upper Silesia,
where the Polish minority movement drew the most support. The simultaneous decline of political Catholicism in Alsace-Lorraine, by contrast, was
probably due to a change in the method of vote counting in comparison with
the 1907 elections. Its total number of seats in the Reichstag shrank from 105
in 1907 to 91 in 1912.
On the Right, the denominational factor remained of significance insofar
as no Protestant estate owner would have voted for the Center. Most likely,
such an individual would have voted for the German Conservative Party. Nor
was it thinkable for a Junker to support the Social Democrats or, with a few
exceptions, the National Liberals. The Free Conservatives found their dwindling
electoral support among industrialists and those agrarians who—favoring
Bismarck’s unification of Germany—had, as in Silesia, links with industry.
The numerous secessions and regroupings among the Liberals reflect not only
the political-ideological crisis into which Bismarck’s policies had thrown them
after 1878/79, but also the diversity of the middle classes. Unlike the other large
parties or, for that matter, the minority movements, they did not operate in a
social or ethnic milieu that was clearly delineated. Meanwhile the Danish minority party usually attracted between 14,000 and 16,000 votes; only in 1912
did this figure rise to 17,000. During the 1870s and 1880s, Alsace-Lorraine
regularly dispatched some fifteen deputies to Berlin; these gained the support
of 150,000 to 235,000 voters. This figure declined to just over 100,000 after the
turn of the century, before returning to 162,000 in 1912. It is quite likely that
this latter surge was connected with popular disappointment over the Reich
government’s failure to effect tangible constitutional reforms in this region.
The move toward minority parties is most marked among the Poles. During the
202

Parties and Elections

1870s and 1880s, minority candidates usually obtained no more than 200,000
votes. There was a slight rise over the next decade, although it remained under the 250,000 mark. It then shot up in the 1903 elections to 348,000, later
reaching 454,000 in 1907 and 442,000 in 1912. All these results reflect the
negative consequences of governmental policies that discriminated against
minorities.49
The figures presented above confirm a picture of growing political mobilization among the population, just as they show the emergence of powerful
blocs. Meanwhile the rise of minority parties, which had no fewer than thirtythree Reichstag deputies by 1912, must be taken as an indicator that Wilhelmine society was losing its capacity to integrate divergent forces in support
of the status quo. The Jewish minority, which for various reasons never formed
a party of its own, mostly voted for Left Liberal candidates. In the eyes of
many German Jews, these were the only politicians who openly dissociated
themselves from a rising anti-Semitism.
An analysis of electoral behavior during Reichstag elections explains much
about the changing material and psychic condition of German society under
the Kaiserreich. There were, it is true, many distortions, among which the exclusion of the female half of the population was the most glaring. Nevertheless, thanks to suffrage for men of all classes, national elections represent a
much better barometer of the mood of the male population than the restrictive systems in the federal states. The Prussian and Saxon elections, which
guaranteed in advance the preponderance of the wealthy, are therefore less
interesting in themselves than they are in their repercussions at the Reich
level. They not only complicated relations between the Reich government
and the federal states, for example, in connection with taxation and the equalization of financial burdens,50 but also enhanced the leftward drift of ordinary
voters. These voters noted with bitterness that their vote in Saxony, Hamburg,
or Prussia was not worth very much. But this was different at the Reich level;
thus, the Left’s political rise in the years before 1914 was partly fueled by a
protest movement against blatant inequalities at the regional and local levels,
as well as the direction of domestic and foreign policy. This may also explain
the continuing high voter turnout.
C. Ideological Main Currents
The history of the German Empire provides many examples of how the majority parties in the Reichstag, in the diets of the federal states, and in the local assemblies ruthlessly exploited the advantages of the electoral laws and
their victories at the polls to promote and uphold their voters’ interests. Nevertheless, it would be wrong to assume that the programs and ideological
positions with which they justified their policies were no more than smokescreens covering up hard-nosed social and economic calculations. The ideol203

Politics

ogies that they embraced did have a solid core that leaders and supporters
genuinely believed in. Their programs were not just empty propaganda ploys.
Rather they served to integrate and mobilize members and helped to distinguish “their” party from those of their opponents.
Although Bismarck was, socially speaking, one of them, the Prussian Conservatives found it very difficult at first to reconcile themselves to his work
