There was no such massive resistance to the construction of railroads. The
bankruptcy of many private companies in the “Great Depression” and their
fragmentation into a multitude of separate entities had strengthened the hand
of the advocates of centralization. Bismarck, it is true, could not realize his
goal of a unified Reichsbahn, but from the late 1870s onward the state began
to take over the railroad system on a regional basis. By 1903 most railroads
were under state control. Thenceforth, authorities could directly intervene in
the economic development of individual regions by building new lines. Although he had to consider the military-strategic interests of the army, Bismarck was motivated by political and economic calculations when he
decided to link his tariff policy to the government’s takeover of the railroads.
Only by gaining control of freight tariffs was it possible to reverse the discounting practices of private companies and to impose higher rates on imported goods than on exports. State authorities also found it easier than
private companies to disregard questions of profitability and to extend lines
into economically weaker regions.
Up until World War I, both objectives were pursued by the federal states,
albeit with varying degrees of energy. The Bavarian bureaucracy, for example, found it more difficult than the Prussian one to abandon its economic liberalism in designing its infrastructural policies. Nevertheless, it had certainly
become easier to open up remote areas by building connecting railway lines
and introducing special rates. Some authorities even believed that they could
control, with the help of their railroad policies, the regional concentration of
industry if they came to the conclusion that it attracted too many potentially
restive industrial workers. In this way, weaker enterprises might find themselves favored by the state’s infrastructural policy, while booming industries
had their applications for special tariffs turned down.

230

The Executive Branch

Although the primary targets of such policies were medium-sized enterprises, agriculture also benefited from them. The federal governments also
supported “ailing landowners” by providing direct subsidies and tax breaks.
Finally, as the Reich Treasury Office discovered in 1907, the regional administrators (Landräte) in East Elbia became accessories to extensive tax fraud
by Junkers in their districts.91 As in urban areas, the basic principle continued to hold in agriculture: the politically most powerful groups were also the
first and biggest beneficiaries of governmental policy making in the area of
infrastructural development.
The mirror image of this principle is found in the treatment of the poor,
who had no political power. Traditionally, the execution of laws regarding the
poor was in the hands of the federal states and communities. They defined
the extent of support and the conditions under which it was given. The founding of the Reich in 1871 had brought no major changes to this system, except
that it became more bureaucratized. The bureaucratic trend was accompanied
by the rise of the social policy expert, who, as time went by, interpreted his
role less and less as purely charitable, and increasingly from a eugenic viewpoint.92 Doctors as a professional group moved in the same direction. With
the development of genetics, biologistic ideas about human society began to
take root that classified ethnic minorities as either inferior or superior. But
these ideas also appeared in a eugenic variant that categorized the indigenous
population by socioeconomic status. The demographic explosion, and the
concomitant increase in the number of poor people, triggered fears of a degeneration of the nation’s health and of popular morals and also confronted
authorities with the additional question of who was to pay for welfare provisions.93 By a long-standing rule, the poor could expect support only at their
place of domicile.
The introduction of unrestricted movement in 1867 promoted mass migrations. A Reich law tried to deal with the implications of this a few years later.
According to this law, the welfare applicant qualified only if he or she had
lived in the locality without interruption during the previous two years. In
this case the local or regional agency had to offer sufficient welfare, including accommodation and medical services, even if the person concerned had
meanwhile left. In other words, in addition to the obligation of supporting the
poor in the community, above all widows and orphans, the authorities were
also expected to pay for migrants at their new place of domicile. The agrarians were the first to rebel against this system by proposing to restrict the free
movement of people once again. For them this was, of course, also a way of
trying to solve the problem of a diminishing supply of rural labor that the
mass migrations had caused. When this move failed, rural communities were
offered relief by a new rule under which their obligation to support impover-

231

Politics

ished former residents elsewhere terminated after two years. In the 1880s,
Bismarck made another attempt to impose an immediate welfare obligation
on the new place of domicile. But cities were vigorously opposed to this
change, and they also refused to budge when it was pointed out to them that
the new social insurance system would reduce the burdens on the local communities. As before the poor found themselves between a rock and a hard
place, without the political muscle that landowners could deploy when it
came to obtaining public subsidies for themselves.
The reference to social insurance leads us to an aspect of state interventionism that many have seen as the beginning of the modern welfare state in
Germany.94 From its modest beginnings, the system expanded considerably
up to World War I, employing some 13,000 civil servants in 1913. The first
beginnings were taken in three steps: the health insurance law of 1883, followed a year later by the accident insurance law, and finally in 1889 by legislation relating to old-age pensions and invalidity (Tables 75–77). The
coverage was initially rudimentary, benefiting only industrial workers and lowranking employees. The 1889 law also included land and forestry laborers.
Family members were excluded, and so they, as well as the non-working poor,
continued to depend on public or private charity. This system’s beginning and
subsequent expansion point to the modern elements of German industrial society. But this should not lead us to overlook that it also preserved existing
hierarchies and provided a measure of social control.
All three insurance laws had precursors that served as models or were
drafted on the basis of older laws that had proved unsatisfactory. The latter was
true of the accident insurance law, whose ratification must be seen against the
background of the Reich Liability Insurance Law of 1871. The weaknesses
of this earlier law, which tried to regulate the growing number of industrial
accidents, had resulted in numerous conflicts between employers and workers. After this, industry and commerce came to prefer a national insurance
scheme that covered all employees, even if it meant that employers had to
pay the premiums themselves. By contrast, workers were expected to cover
two-thirds of their health insurance premiums. But, considering that before
1883 a mere 5 percent of the population had health care coverage, it certainly
brought tangible protection to some working-class people in case of illness.
The concept of health insurance, which from 1892 also included the family members of insured workers, had been inspired by an earlier system that
had been established in the mining industry and that, apart from providing
coverage against accidents, included medical aid and a pension in case of invalidity.95 Similar plans had also emerged in other branches of industry and
were subsequently incorporated in the law of 1889. Taking as their model the
security in old age that civil servants enjoyed, employees began to push for
their own pension scheme from the mid-1880s. If insurance coverage became
232

The Executive Branch

successively extended from the 1890s, it was also to relieve the provision of
welfare to the poor. And there was also the wheeling and dealing with the
parties in the Reichstag. Thus the introduction of insurance for surviving
family members became possible because the Catholic Center linked it to its
support of the renewed increase in agricultural tariffs in 1902. In the years
leading up to 1914, the Reich’s escalating financial crisis put the brakes on
the rapid growth of the system. Nevertheless, the number of health insurance
members rose from 4.2 million in 1895 to 13.4 million in 1911. The costs of
medical services increased from 47 million marks at the start to 358 million
in 1911. By 1914, more than half of the working population had been included
in health care plans, and 51.4 percent of those between the ages of fifty-five
and sixty-nine received modest pensions. A separate pension plan was promulgated for employees in 1911. Public service workers also saw their benefits improve, with the telling justification that the choice was “between a
strengthening of Social Democracy and an extension of the civil service status” to these workers.96 Of course, the former was to be avoided at all costs.
Although Bismarck’s role in the promulgation of these insurance laws has
been played down by some scholars who have seen them as products of various earlier welfare programs, Gerhard A. Ritter subsequently provided convincing evidence of the Reich chancellor’s decisive contribution.97 In light of
powerful resistance from industry, the laws would not have come about without him. There has been less debate on Bismarck’s motives. It was not the
widespread poverty and the clamor of social reformers that moved him to
consider a social insurance system, but political calculations, above all his
growing worries about the working-class movement. Ultimately, the Reich
chancellor aimed at the destruction of Social Democracy and the trade unions
with the help of social policy. This plan was designed to complement his policy of violent repression with the aid of his antisocialist laws. In the end he
convinced even employers that the idea of undermining the SPD by making
social concessions to all workers might work. Volker Hentschel is therefore
correct when he argued that the country’s social policy, as proclaimed by the
Kaiser in November 1881, had another important “birth certificate”—the socalled Law to Combat the Criminal Aims of Social Democracy of 1878.98
There can be little doubt that Bismarck’s policies of government subsidies
and social insurance had an integrating effect. But one must also consider the
repressive apparatus of the Prusso-German constitutional state. It is true that
all European nations modernized and expanded the institutions charged with
the maintenance of law and order. Faced after 1871 with the additional task of
building a nation, Bismarck, as we have seen, had unleashed a struggle against
alleged “enemies of the Reich.” At first it was the Catholics who found themselves persecuted by the authorities. Later it was the Social Democrats. If the
police organs and the judiciary expanded on Bismarck’s watch, it was not
233

Politics

merely because of the more general trend toward centralization and bureaucratization, but also because of the growing tasks of surveillance and prosecution of activities that became part of the criminal justice system.
Well before 1871, the federal states and communities had established considerable policing powers. The extent of criminality in Imperial Germany is
not easily estimated, because of variations and uncertainties in the rates of
detection and prosecution. In any case, the crime rate rose by a little over 14
percent between 1885 and 1900, to 1,143 crimes per 100,000 inhabitants, and
it subsequently hovered around this mark up to World War I. There was a
steep increase in reported homicide deaths in Prussia from a yearly average
of 356 in the period 1886–1990 to 847 in 1911–1913. But there were great
regional variations, and cities were not necessarily at the top of the league
table. It must also be remembered that the line between genuine criminal behavior and breaches of the law for reasons of economic desperation was often fluid.99 After the introduction of the antisocialist laws, authorities were
fully occupied with, and probably also more interested in, using their powers
widely against suspected Social Democrats and leftist intellectuals. In the
context of the 1878 antisocialist laws, censorship codes were formulated for
the whole of Germany. These allowed authorities to deal with alleged breaches
of cultural and political norms. A press law required publishers to submit a
copy of their publications to the local police, who would then check whether
they contained blasphemous, indecent, or otherwise incriminating passages.
Munich, with its reputation for greater liberalism, offers a good example
of how the intellectual and artistic avant-garde was treated by law enforcement agencies. Bavaria may have been liberal in comparison with Prussia,
but this did not prevent the Bavarian authorities from harassing representatives of modernism. They prosecuted the modernists for alleged blasphemy,
lèse-majesté, and depiction of obscenities. Often under pressure from Catholic politicians and the local clergy, the authorities frequently used their powers, even though only the theater was subject to pre-censorship requirements.
As mentioned earlier, in 1903 they shut down the “Eleven Executioners,” the
city’s successful political cabaret.
In 1899, Wilhelm II insisted that the “Lex Heinze” be sent to the Reichstag. It made punishable depictions or writings that “crudely offended the
sense of decency.” Similarly, a censorship advisory council, which was instituted in Munich in 1908, should probably be seen in connection with increased
police surveillance of the local artistic community. Initially Max Halbe and
Thomas Mann agreed to be members of this council; but they soon found that
they were surrounded by conservative teachers and academics and withdrew.
With the help of Mann and Halbe, Wedekind’s Frühlingserwachen was deemed
acceptable by the council, albeit only after considerable cuts. His play Lulu,
like the plays of other authors, encountered sharp opposition. It was banned
234

The Executive Branch

in 1913, while some of his poetry got him a seven-month prison term, which
he served in the Saxon fortress of Königstein. Censorship became increasingly
politicized. Demands for a stricter prosecution of violations came from the
Catholic Center Party and from an organization, founded in 1906, that—significantly—called itself the Munich Men’s Association for Combating Public Indecency. Together with the clergy, who were increasingly alarmed by the
erosion of the Catholic faith and the church’s authority, they fought to intensify the prosecution of the avant-garde in the suburb of Schwabing and of the
proliferating business of low-cost entertainment in the Bavarian capital. At
the other end of the spectrum, we find the moderate Social Democrat Georg
von Vollmar defending artistic freedom and mocking the “Nuditätenjagd.”100
Such differences of opinion indicate that the whole matter involved questions not merely of taste and morality, but also of divergent ideologies and
political positions. Similar considerations apply to film censorship, which
also increased before 1914, and the search for erotic under-the-counter literature.101 The changing ideological climate is also reflected in the authorities’
adoption of police and judicial practices that openly violated the principles
of justice and Rechtsstaatlichkeit (rule of law). In short, Munich was not a
haven of cultural liberalism, and reading about the never-ending prosecutions
in the Bavarian capital is not a pleasant assignment.
However, these policies paled when we consider the treatment of the “criminal” Social Democrats. Following the promulgation of the antisocialist laws,
over 600 newspapers and some 318 associations were banned. Hundreds of
members of working-class organizations and other suspects were arrested,
sentenced, and put in prison. A “minor state of siege” was imposed in cities
with strong Social Democratic organizations, such as Frankfurt, Berlin, Leipzig, Altona, and Stettin. This empowered the local police authorities to send
known local activists into exile. In Berlin, some 300 men suffered this fate,
and their families had to rely on the support of their neighbors. The city-state
of Hamburg provides an example that pressure from the higher authorities
could be very strong. Urged by the Prussian police president of neighboring
Altona, the Berlin government pushed the city fathers to impose a “minor
state of siege” and to exile some 75 local Hamburgian Social Democrats.
However, there was also resistance and support. In Hamburg a number of
well-known merchants expressed their displeasure by lining the streets as exiles were escorted to the city gates and handing them small presents. In the
cities of Wiesbaden, Erfurt, and Breslau, police noted as early as 1878 the
organizing of collections that frequently led to the founding of a local aid association. Around 1885 some 30 of these had come into existence with close
to 264,000 members. Another 1,020 Fachvereine, with approximately 58,000
members, attempted to represent workers’ economic interests while trade
unions were proscribed. Such activities made authorities suspicious, and with
235

Politics

the renewal of the antisocialist laws in 1886 a fresh wave of repression set in.
In April of that year, the Prussian minister of the interior published an antistrike decree. This was followed one month later by another decree stipulating that all assemblies in the Berlin region required an advance notification
of forty-eight hours. In the meantime, the arrests and trials of prominent Social Democrats continued.
The lapse of the antisocialist laws in 1890 reduced the legal grounds upon
which the police could persecute Social Democrats, but it did not put a damper
on the dogged enthusiasm for searching for “subversive elements.” The case
of Hamburg demonstrates that this enthusiasm was not confined to Prussia.
Dominated by an oligarchy of patrician families, the city was deemed cosmopolitan and urbanely liberal. But, on orders from the local government, the
police continued their surveillance of the indigenous workers. As the chief
of the Political Police Department reported, between January and April 1892
alone, twice as many meetings were attended by undercover agents and informers than in the same period during 1891.102 The number of dutifully
collected newspaper clippings rose from 3,948 to 12,722. Dressed up as ordinary workers, policemen sat in the pubs of the harbor quarters, eavesdropping on the conversations of dockers and other workers. By 1914 they had
produced some 20,000 reports. However, none of these measures prevented
major scandals. When in the middle of January 1906 Hamburg’s workers
staged massive demonstrations against a planned further restriction of the local class-based right to vote, the police were poorly prepared and humiliated
in the chaos that ensued. Trying to make good, they staged a bloody counterattack on the harbor quarters on the following day. Searching for and arresting the alleged ringleaders of the earlier demonstrations, they inflicted many
injuries on innocent people. After this, fears of “revolution” never subsided
among parts of the Hamburgian bourgeoisie. Slowly the legal barriers against
a persecution of the working class were also lowered in other parts of the
country.
The repercussions of such scandals and of the presence of policemen at
rallies upon the country’s political culture is not difficult to gauge. Historians, who have emphasized the lack of political uniformity and the rule of law
in the Kaiserreich, are no doubt correct in calling the powers of the federal
states and the communities vis-à-vis the Reich capital “enormous.”103 However, the salient point is that, in the years before 1914, these powers were deployed everywhere in ways that brought about an even greater polarization
of politics. The rate at which the political climate deteriorated may have been
slower in the southwest than in the north and in Prussia; but one is hard put
to detect major currents in any of the federal states that effectively counteracted this general trend. However multifaceted German society had become,
it is wise to differentiate between the situation in the 1890s and that of circa
236

The Executive Branch

1913/14, when the polarization in the fields of culture and politics could no
longer be overlooked.
Given this atmosphere and the widespread perception of a growing socialist threat, it is not surprising that the renewed introduction of special legislation was repeatedly considered. In December 1894 the Reichstag debated an
amendment to the Criminal Code that extended the criteria for a number of
political offenses and also increased the available penalties. Two months earlier, the Kaiser had made a typically tactless statement regarding the bill, after which it became nicknamed the Umsturzvorlage (Sedition Bill). No doubt
this helped to defeat the measure. Four years later, the Reich government
made another attempt with a piece of legislation that—following another
swashbuckling speech by Wilhelm II—came to be known as the Penitentiary
Bill. At the core of this bill, which likewise failed, was a clause banning picketing and imposing severe penalties on strikers who prevented fellow workers from crossing picket lines. After the success of the Social Democrats in
the 1903 Reichstag elections, industry and agriculture pressured the government once more to reintroduce antisocialist laws. However, prospects of a
bill getting through parliament were now bleaker than in the 1890s. Recognizing this, the Reich leadership concentrated on a revision of the Criminal
Code of 1871, into which it promised to incorporate stricter sanctions that
could be used against the Left. Although completion of the comprehensive
review of this code was not expected until 1917, the government was able to
refute the rightist charge that it was passive in the face of the “Red threat,”
while declaring at the same time that there was no realistic hope of getting
special legislation through the Reichstag. It was an early version of government by procrastination that soon became the hallmark of the Reich executive in the face of the monarchy’s growing political paralysis in the last years
before 1914.
At the same time, the depth of antisocialist fears and hatred in government
circles and among those social groups that strongly supported the existing
order may be gauged from the revival of the Staatsstreich idea and support
for a radical revision of the Constitution. In January 1897, General Alfred von
Waldersee, the commander of the Ninth Army Corps, submitted a written proposal to the Kaiser to smash the Social Democrats without delay, before it
was too late. After a further rise in the SPD vote in the 1903 elections, unilateral changes of the Constitution and the abolition of universal suffrage
were once again being considered. At one point, Wilhelm II talked himself
into a frenzy about “the coming revolution and its repression” before exclaiming: “I have to take revenge for [18]48—revenge!”104 Three years later he
bragged again about an impending “bloodbath” among the Social Democrats, to be followed by a successful foreign war. Finally, in 1913 the monarch
forwarded a memorandum by a retired general and prominent Pan-Germanist,
237

Politics

Konstantin von Gebsattel, to the Reich chancellor. The document called for
a violent coup against the working-class movement and the Jewish minority.105
Since the Reich chancellor regarded such solutions to the constitutional and
growing political dilemma of the Prusso-German monarchy too risky from both
a domestic and foreign policy standpoint (and given the Reichstag majority’s
opposition to renewing antisocialist laws), the executive had to rely on existing decrees and statutes. These continued to provide the police and courts with
extensive powers, particularly if they were prepared to interpret “creatively”
not only the relevant paragraphs of the Criminal Code, but also those relating
to association, press, and trading laws. Finally, it was always possible to resort to bureaucratic chicanery. In this climate of hostility, many a worker who
had made a joke or critical remark about the Kaiser at the local alehouse found
himself denounced to the police for lèse-majesté by some informant. Legal
scholars even raised the question of whether it constituted a violation of this
paragraph in the Criminal Code if someone did not join in the royal cheer
during celebrations. The courts frequently sentenced workers to prison terms
that bore no relation to their “crimes.” Between 1890 and 1914 the number
of convictions rose from 508 to 622 per annum. The authorities also liked to
invoke the code’s blasphemy section. Paragraphs 130 (incitement to sedition)
and 360 (causing a serious nuisance) of the Criminal Code were deployed no
less extensively, and the latter was also used to curb the socialist press.
The treatment of strikers and strikebreakers became a major preoccupation for the police and the judiciary. The starting point was Paragraph 152 of
the Trade Code (Gewerbeordnung), which guaranteed the right of coalition.
Much of this was undermined, however, by the following paragraph, which
stipulated that it was illegal to oblige “others through the use of force, through
threats, through violations of their honor, or by damaging their reputation” to
participate in a coalition (or a strike) or to deny them the right to leave that
coalition. Attempts to participate in these acts were punishable under the
Trade Code, if it did not prove possible to invoke the Criminal Code, with its
higher penalties. Frequently used clauses of this latter code were Paragraphs
185 (violation of honor), 240 (blackmail), and 241 (announcing a crime). Thus
striking workers might be prosecuted because they had shouted the word
“strikebreaker” or had spat at the feet of fellow workers whom the police had
been escorting through the picket line. When employers threatened a lockout
in advance of a labor dispute, the authorities regularly conceded that they were
merely trying to uphold their justifiable interests and hence desisted from
prosecuting them. When announcing a strike, the unions, in contrast, had to
word their statements very carefully to avoid charges of blackmail. Like the
employers, policemen and strikebreakers found much sympathy in court,
even if they had actually violated existing codes. Justice was blindfolded on
just one eye.
238

The Executive Branch

With the passage of time the police network became denser, and local authorities received ever more insistent instructions “from above” to use their
powers and, if necessary, a strong arm. In this atmosphere the police were
less and less prepared to look away or to withdraw a prosecution. The state
prosecutors, who were likewise bound to follow higher orders, tended to respond with alacrity, knowing that the courts would give more credence to a
vague statement by a police witness than to the politically suspect defendant.
Verdicts that the prosecution deemed unsatisfactory were appealed without
delay. The Court Constitution Law formally protected judges from outside
interference. But just as the Kaiser surprised other civil servants, including
the director of the Prussian Art Gallery, he occasionally also surprised the
courts. In 1898 he removed a judge who had acquitted the well-known journalist Maximilian Harden of lèse-majesté. No doubt this acted as a reminder
for other judges, most of whom were ideologically conservative in the first
place and had been socialized into a profession whose outlook was monarchist. They also sensed, or even knew, that their superiors expected certain
verdicts, and so opinions were handed down that were often based on very
questionable evidence, legal constructions, and lines of reasoning. Furthermore, many judges held the view that defendants from the lower classes were
accustomed to minor penalties and had been hardened by them. Harsher sentences were thus thought to be justified in order for the punishment to have
an effect.
And yet policemen, prosecutors, and their superiors could never be certain
that trials would have the outcome they believed to be desirable from the
point of view of a tight judicial policy. A less experienced or younger judge
might issue a mild sentence that grossly diverged from the general norm. In
Prussia it was fairly certain that juries would be packed with notables who
took a hard line without much prodding. In the south this was not always the
case, however, so that the prosecution had to brace itself for the occasional
surprise. Such experiences with juries resulted in cases being heard, if at all
possible, before a bench of professional judges. Another way of influencing
jury selection was to refuse to pay daily allowances. This immediately restricted the circle of potential jurors. It was only in the summer of 1913 that
the Reichstag ratified a bill that provided for a payment of five marks per day
of jury service. But before we celebrate this as a major improvement of the
justice system, we should not forget that judges continued to pass down verdicts designed to please the authorities.
In the meantime, the police had developed a variety of alternatives to public prosecution where their experiences with the courts seemed to make this
necessary. A number of authorities successfully used local traffic regulations
against peaceful picketing. Picketing was declared a traffic obstruction—an
interpretation that the courts were prepared to support. When the unions
239

Politics

objected that this violated the freedom of coalition provided under Paragraph
152 of the Trade Code, the police retorted that this freedom was in no way
being touched. What was at stake was the free flow of traffic. Consequently
it continued to be up to the discretion of the local policeman whether or not
a picket line was an obstruction, and in many cases he ruled that it was, even
if the traffic was not at all impeded. Time and again there were clashes between the police and the population, which Thomas Lindenberger has analyzed as an aspect of a proliferating “street politics.”106 He counted no fewer
than 400 such clashes in Berlin alone between 1904 and 1914; thus, the street
became a “place for class action.” If we view the problem from the workers’
perspective, one cannot but admire their courage. But in view of their experiences with the authorities, this was but one reaction to the realities of Wilhelmine Germany. Otherwise there was bitterness and even greater poverty
for those who got caught up in this machinery.
Yet, however much policemen were urged by their superiors to contain
and intimidate the working-class movement without the broad powers of antisocialist laws, and however unashamedly the courts practiced “class justice,”
ultimately there was always the army to back up the police saber or arbitrary
judges. The army was not merely an instrument against Germany’s external
enemies, but the ultima ratio regum in a civil war against the working class
that many officers believed imminent. It was no accident that shortly after the
lapse of the antisocialist laws in the spring of 1890 the Prussian war minister
reminded the commanding generals of the powers they had under the State
of Siege Law of 1851. The Reich Constitution stipulated that this ancient law
be replaced after 1871 by a Reich Defense Law. But for all too transparent
reasons the Reich government never introduced such a bill. With the 1851
law therefore still in place, the commanding generals were free to proclaim
a provisional state of siege if they judged such a measure necessary for the
maintenance of order. Outside Prussia, it is true, the Kaiser’s consent was
also required; but neither the friends nor critics of the officer corps were in
any doubt about the military’s far-reaching powers, including the right to suspend basic liberties. And to make certain that there were no misunderstandings about who was seen as the main enemy of the monarchical state, all
officers down to the commanders of local garrisons received a further directive in 1890 to keep themselves “constantly” informed about the “organization, the leaders, and the agitators” on the Left.107
Further ministerial instructions that followed in subsequent years were designed to keep the army in a state of readiness for civil war. After the turn of
the century, the General Staff began work on a study whose final version was
submitted in 1907 under the title of “Fighting in Insurgent Cities.” In April
1907 this study triggered an order by the Seventh Army Corps at Münster,
northeast of the Ruhr area, that provided, inter alia, for the arrest of Reichs240

The Executive Branch

tag deputies. It was withdrawn in a storm of protest after it had been leaked
to the press. The civil war measures that General Paul von Hindenburg drew
up in February 1908 for his Fourth Army Corps at Magdeburg met with so
much approval in Berlin that they were held up as a model to the other military districts. A decree by the Prussian war minister on 8 December 1912 reminded the commanding generals once more that they should be prepared for
an immediate response. Reactions to a number of strikes showed that the officers had no qualms about calling out the troops. As of late December 1896,
even the hardliner Waldersee had taken the view on the occasion of the Hamburg dockers’ strike that he would be happy if the police proved sufficient to
deal with it. “To use armed force against hungry workers,” he added, “is certainly no pleasure.”108 But by 1914 the military’s willingness to take a hard
line during domestic crises had become noticeably greater. In 1910 a decree,
apparently issued by the civilian administrator of the Düsseldorf district, had
urged subordinate authorities to rely on troops only “in the most extreme
emergency.”109 No such restraint was shown in Halle during the same year,
with bloody results. When Ruhr miners went on strike in the spring of 1912,
police were used on a massive scale, and the authorities drew on additional
units from as far as Berlin, Frankfurt, Wiesbaden, Hanover, Kassel, and
Cologne. These forces were complemented by some 5,000 soldiers, including two machine gun detachments. Finally, in the July Crisis of 1914, the
generals thought of moving against the domestic opposition and arresting the
Social Democratic leadership before declaring the start of a foreign war.110
The army’s growing importance in the political struggle at home had, during the 1890s, raised the question of whether recruits would be reliable enough
to fight in a civil war. Industrialization and urbanization had inevitably increased the percentage of young factory workers in the army. There were growing suspicions that Social Democratic “agitators” might be among them. The
military authorities tried to counter the influence that these men were believed
to exert on gullible recruits from the country’s rural areas. Consequently, they
resorted to searches of soldiers’ lockers, spying, and bans on frequenting certain pubs in the vicinity of the garrison; they also introduced lessons to foster patriotism. Even reserve officers, most of whom were of middle-class
background, came under a cloud of suspicion when “reliable” and absolutely
loyal cadets of noble background were no longer available in sufficient numbers. Faced with this recruitment dilemma, the Prussian war minister abandoned the further expansion of the army. As late as 1910, he wrote to the
Reich chancellor that he had “at the present time no intention” of enlarging
the army’s size beyond the twenty-three corps that had been fixed as far back
as March 1899.111 He added that, apart from military considerations, the reasons for this restraint were to be found in “the political arena” and were too
obvious to require repetition: at stake was the army’s reliability in the event
241

Politics

of civil unrest. It was only from 1911 onward that the earlier domestic calculations that had been made in the face of the presumed Social Democratic
threat became secondary. As international tensions rose, Germany resumed
her rearmament on land. The naval buildup, which until then had enjoyed priority status, came to a virtual standstill. The system of patriotic instruction
that had been designed to produce “reliable” recruits was substituted by older
methods of harsh discipline and drill.
While the Army as the ultima ratio regum thus prepared itself for civil as
well as foreign war, the civilian government attempted to expand and sharpen
its instruments of propaganda. Once the financial crisis made the expansion
of the social insurance system more difficult, the leadership worked hard to
stimulate monarchist loyalties in the population through emotional appeals.
Bismarck had used the press to influence public opinion in matters of foreign
policy and, in pursuing this objective, had skillfully drawn on his slush fund.
Bülow’s press chief, Otto Hammann, later worked hard to systematize the
flow of official information. Meanwhile the Social Democrats remained the
principal domestic enemy against whom Hammann’s office campaigned relentlessly. Reich Chancellor Caprivi had proclaimed as early as 1890 that all
legislative projects and government actions were to be constantly scrutinized
in terms of their impact on the “Social Democratic question.” For the same
reason, the authorities extended their youth work after the turn of the century.
The legal requirement that this work be nonpolitical was conveniently overlooked in the case of right-wing associations but applied to leftist youth
groups. Within the educational system it was above all the primary school
teachers who came under increasing pressure when the Left Liberals among
them were suspected of being closet socialists. In 1898 the so-called Lex
Arons made certain that holding a teaching position anywhere in the educational system was treated as incompatible with membership in the SPD.
While some teachers’ associations courageously resisted political interference with what they saw as their professional task as educators, from 1906
onward Prussia tried to push back what little influence parents had gained in
schools by establishing school commissions subject to official supervision.
The veterans’ associations and works’ committees (Werkvereine), founded by
employers to combat Social Democratic trade unions, enjoyed the special favor of the authorities. When the financial crisis forced the government to reduce its subsidies to these organizations, the authorities stepped up the
dispatch of prominent politicians to address their annual rallies. Private benefactors who gave money to “patriotic” associations were recommended for
the award of decorations or the coveted title of “councilor.” In this way private donations also became increasingly politicized, as all measures came to
be justified in the fight against the perceived leftist threat.

242

The Executive Branch

In retrospect, it may be said that, paradoxically perhaps, the system of
subsidies and state insurance had a polarizing effect. It favored the producers and was so reluctant to offer tangible welfare and participatory benefits
that might have appeased the workers that many of them felt held back in
their social aspirations by a class system that discriminated against them in
thousands of small ways. The question of fairness became a major bone of
contention. This is even more true of workers’ frequent encounters with state
authorities. Police chicanery, the injustices of the court system, and the policies of the army greatly embittered workers. Even after the lapse of the antisocialist laws, unfair and unequal treatment by the authorities was part of the
daily experience in working-class quarters. Faced with outrageous verdicts
on the right to form coalitions and go on strike, even the Christian and HirschDuncker unions found themselves pushed to the side of the “free” unions. To
be sure, some reformers among the liberal bourgeoisie sought the middle
road and hoped to build bridges between the entrenched camps on the Right
and Left. Reich Chancellor Bethmann Hollweg, even more than his predecessor, labored to forge a “policy of the diagonal.” However, it was unthinkable for a monarchist chancellor to seek cooperation with the allegedly
revolutionary SPD. At the same time, the conservative forces lapsed more
and more into a fortress mentality. Given this situation, and the peculiarities
of the Prusso-German constitutional system, the executive was left with little choice but to postpone the resolution of serious and conflict-laden political problems.
The trouble was that no complex society and economy can be governed
by an executive branch that sits on its hands and refuses to address fundamental problems. Paralysis threatened, made worse by the fact that powerful
organizations in the political sphere had begun to checkmate each other.
However far the expansion of the executive may have progressed by 1914,
and however much it had changed its functions, by the outbreak of World
War I the most striking feature of Prusso-German constitutionalism was its
failure to produce at least some tangible results. There was little parliamentarization to speak of, and even in the Center Party polarization had now set
in “between the majority dominated by the bourgeoisie and the workers’
movement.”112 The Reich government did not dare to place vital questions of
financial reform on the agenda. The capacity of political forces to forge compromises had become severely limited, as divergent ideologies and interests
struggled ever more vigorously for an outright victory of their side. How this
impasse was reached by the eve of World War I will be discussed in the next
two sections. They will provide a more strictly chronological account of the
most important events between 1871 and 1914, before we finally move to
Part V, World War I itself.

243

Politics

17. The Evolution of Domestic Politics, 1871–1914
A. The Early Years Up to Bismarck’s Fall
After the swift victory over the French in 1870 and the official founding of
the German Empire in the following spring, Wilhelm I, his government, and
the political forces that had unified Germany were faced with a major task of
nation-building and of consolidating a highly dynamic process that had begun ten years earlier and that was by no means completed in 1871. Historians once debated whether the country was united by “blood and iron” or by
“coal and steel.” In the end, it was both Bismarck’s wars and rapid industrial
and demographic change during the 1860s that had produced this success.
We shall examine in a moment how the Empire’s stabilization was connected with the country’s foreign policy. The first task here is to focus on the
policies employed by the Reich chancellor, as the key person in the new government, to try to rally divergent forces and to keep them on the side of a conservative monarchy that was not prepared to make any major concessions to
parliamentarism or a more general democratization of the Prusso-German
constitutional system. The chancellor’s struggle against the Catholic church,
the Kulturkampf, provides the first piece of evidence that his strategy of nationbuilding and consolidation was not merely based on the principle of cooperation with the Liberals and Conservatives, as discussed earlier. Rather he used
methods of discrimination and ostracism against groups that were deemed to
be and turned into “Reich enemies.” Fighting these enemies was designed to
provide the glue that brought other political forces together on the basis of
what had been created in 1871.
Accordingly, the Reich government and the Reichstag, dominated as it
was then by the Liberals, introduced a number of measures to impede the
work of the Catholic church and its political arm, the Center Party. The campaign began in the summer of 1871 with the dissolution of the Catholic department in the Prussian Ministry of Culture, which, according to Bismarck’s
later verdict, had become a group that “represented Roman[-Catholic] and
Polish interests in the midst of the Prussian bureaucracy.”113 December saw
the introduction of the “pulpit paragraph,” which was added to the Criminal
Code and directed against clergy members who tried to influence the flock at
election time. Violators faced incarceration. In the spring of 1872 a law was
introduced that secured ministerial supervision over all schools, public and
private, including Catholic institutions. The Jesuits were banned in July 1872.
Another set of laws, ratified in May 1873, gave authorities the right to supervise the training of priests and the disciplinary policies of the church hierarchy. This was followed in May 1874 by the Expatriation Law, under whose
terms priests could be expelled from the country and their citizenship revoked.

244

The Evolution of Domestic Policies, 1871–1914

The Monastery Law, adopted a year later, ousted, with a few exceptions, the
remaining religious orders from Prussia.114
The effect of these measures on the Catholic clergy and population was
predictable. The hierarchy resisted discrimination wherever possible, while
the faithful stood by them. They became more conscious of the minority position into which they had been cast in the new Reich. The loyalty to their
church also showed in their voting behavior. As we have seen, the Center
Party could henceforth count on a solid bloc of voters for whom religious affiliation rather than social class was the crucial determinant at the polls.
Thanks to Bismarck and the Liberals, the number of Reichstag seats won by
Catholics hovered around the 100 mark, and it took a long time for the memories of the Kulturkampf to fade. If for Bismarck the struggle and the “ultramontane question” was primarily an instrument for promoting the consolidation
of the founding of the Reich on a conservative basis, for the Liberals the repression of Catholicism was more than a nation-building device. It also reflected their more deep-rooted ideological commitment to the advancement
of a modern and secular industrial society. For several decades the Catholic
church had been a large boulder blocking the path toward this type of society. By embodying everything that the Liberals loathed, Catholicism became
the negative foil against which the Liberals could define more clearly what
they themselves stood for. For this vision they were prepared to accept the
ouster of a sizeable section of the population from the national consensus.
In the long-run, Bismarck proved to be the more pragmatic party in this
conflict. He had not merely to consider the overall stability of the PrussoGerman monarchy but also to secure parliamentary majorities that would
pass the legislation he and his ministries never tired of drafting. From the first
national elections of 1871 to those of 1874, the Catholics had increased their
number of seats from 63 to 91. While the Liberals slightly increased their
representation, the Conservatives dropped from 57 seats to 22. To the chancellor, it was therefore not inconceivable that someday he might have to rely
on the Center Party for support. Since the church was not weakened by the
Kulturkampf but, on the contrary, emerged from it strengthened, it became
clear that the conflict had to be abandoned sooner or later. However, this did
not mean that Bismarck was thenceforth exclusively focused on the question
of how to integrate all Germans into the new Reich. Being able to pinpoint
an internal enemy had the advantage of providing a rallying point for the majority of voters, and it was therefore no doubt fortuitous that a new “Reich
enemy,” the still embryonic working-class movement with its radical critique
of the existing order and of capitalism, was readily available. From the mid1870s onward the appearance of this “threat” to the consolidation of the Reich
enabled Bismarck to wind down the struggle against Catholicism.

245

Politics

The ratification of the antisocialist laws in 1878 was the first step in the
formal instrumentalization of this new “danger.” It is also telling of the chancellor’s by then changing relationship with the Liberals (and of the mistrust
with which the latter had begun to eye his policies) that he failed to find sufficient support in the Reichstag for special legislation against the SPD after
a first attempt on the Kaiser’s life on 1 May 1878. However, a week later Wilhelm I was seriously injured in another assassination attempt, and this time
Bismarck succeeded, with the help of a vigorous press campaign, in getting
the public to accept that the “subversive” Social Democrats were responsible
for this outrage, even if there was no real evidence for this. Yet even then, the
Liberals refused to give the chancellor all the repressive powers that he
wanted and insisted that some rights, such as the right to run for legislative
office, remain untouched. Nor was the parliamentary immunity of the twelve
Social Democratic Reichstag deputies who had been returned in the 1877
elections lifted. Finally, the Liberal majority imposed a time-limit on the antisocialist laws so that they had to come up for renewal at regular intervals.115
The turmoil in domestic politics during 1878 was followed a year later by
a major debate on the introduction of higher external tariffs that would abandon the policies of free trade of the previous decades. Industry and agriculture,
to be sure, had been clamoring for protection against foreign competition for
some time, after the boom of the early 1870s had turned into a period of retarded growth (which was perceived by contemporaries as the “Great Depression”). If industry and agriculture now got their way, the new tariff laws
would benefit Bismarck politically. After the antisocialist laws had given him
powers to repress the fledgling working-class movement, the tariffs gave him
the opportunity to put an end to the period of Liberal dominance in the Reichstag (Table 79). Thanks not least to the better protection against agricultural
imports from North America and Russia, the agrarian Conservatives were
now prepared to forgive the “sins” Bismarck had committed at the time of
Germany’s unification. They came out of their oppositional corners to cooperate with him. Domestic politics was now set on a new and more right-wing
course. The Reich, as has been argued, was at this point founded for the second time and on a different coalitional basis.116
However, subsequent elections in the 1880s and the “irresponsibility” of
the political parties in their dealings with the Reich government repeatedly
threatened the durability of Bismarck’s new and more conservative parliamentary majority. In these circumstances Bismarck in both 1884 and 1887
tried to overcome his domestic difficulties of getting legislation passed with
the help of foreign policy initiatives. In particular, it explains his willingness
to embark upon the acquisition of colonies for which he had never shown
much interest before. He knew, as he once put it in connection with the 1884
election campaign, that the colonial business was “a hoax” that he needed for
246

The Evolution of Domestic Policies, 1871–1914

election purposes. But there was a flipside to his quest for the renewed stabilization of internal affairs: he found that the genie of imperialism that he
had released could not be put back into the bottle. As we shall see, it began
to affect his foreign policy design and his relations with Britain in particular.117
Three years later, in 1887, Bismarck again exploited the Reich’s deteriorating international position to counter the Reichstag’s demand for a greater
voice in budgetary matters. At this point, many deputies were prepared to vote
for higher military expenditures, but only if the septennial cycle of appropriations was replaced by a triennial review. The Reich chancellor responded to
this attempt to intrude into the sphere of the monarchical prerogative over the
armed forces by dissolving the national parliament, hoping that fresh elections would result in a strengthening of the Right. In this situation it proved
useful to highlight mounting international tensions and in particular the “Russian menace.” As a result, the Free Conservatives, as the Bismarckian party
par excellence, were able to increase the number of their seats from 28 to 41.
The National Liberals rose from 51 to 99 seats, while the Left Liberals dropped
back from 74 seats to 32. The chancellor now had the support of a so-called
cartel majority, which helped him to weather the storms of 1888, the year
when both Wilhelm I and his son Friedrich III died in quick succession, ultimately bringing Wilhelm II to the throne. With this “generational leap,” an
immature 29-year-old assumed the powerful reins of German Kaiser and
King of Prussia.118
Although the “cartel majority” of 1887 did ratify a number of bills that
Bismarck put before it, fresh conflicts arose in the fall of 1889 when the antisocialist laws came up for renewal. This time Bismarck aimed at an indefinite extension, and when resistance to this plan did not subside, he once
again resorted to a dissolution of parliament and national elections. This time
his calculation of obtaining another right-wing shift badly misfired. Instead
the Left Liberals augmented their seats from 32 in 1887 to 76. No less alarming, the Social Democrats (whom the antisocialist laws had not banned from
participating in elections and whose deputies had used the Reichstag freely,
though cautiously, as a platform to advance their programs) tripled their
seats, from 11 to 35. This meant that the “cartel majority” was finished. Finding himself at the end of the road, Bismarck apparently considered resorting
to a Staatsstreich, a violent coup against the obstinate deputies. There has
been some debate on whether the plan ever assumed more concrete shape or
merely remained a vague possibility. However, what is more decisive for the
subsequent course of events is that the Kaiser and his advisors seem to have
taken rumors about a coup seriously. Since Wilhelm II not only intended to
rule by himself but also hoped to introduce himself to the nation as a Kaiser
of all Germans and of peace, he decided to dismiss the powerful chancellor,
as was his privilege under the Constitution. Not wanting to start his reign
247

Politics

with a dangerous domestic conflict, he appointed Leo von Caprivi, who was
quite agreeable not only to take the position but also to help Wilhelm II dismantle the executive powers that his predecessor had built up since 1871.119
No less important, there was no escalation of the conflict with the Reichstag,
and the antisocialist laws were allowed to lapse altogether.
B. Stabilization and Crisis, 1890–1914
After the upheavals surrounding Bismarck’s dismissal, Wilhelm II had been
hoping to steer a “new course” and to center the Reich government around
the powers he enjoyed under the Constitution. At first this strategy seemed to
work. In 1891, the Reichstag accepted a number of improvements to existing
labor laws, raising the monarch’s hopes that after the Konfliktkanzler he might
become a Kaiser of peace and of Germany’s workers, beloved by all. However, the debate on another army bill in 1892 caused so many difficulties that
Caprivi felt compelled to resort to the well-worn Bismarckian ploy of calling
early elections and of using foreign policy issues to move voters in a more
conservative, progovernment direction. The election became another boomerang in that it strengthened both the extreme Right and Left (Table 79). Worsening the situation, at about the same time, the Reich’s commercial treaties
with a number of foreign countries came up for renewal, kindling a bitter argument about whether Bismarck’s high tariff policies should be continued.
The agrarians were all in favor of a continuation and in 1893 created the
mighty Agrarian League to put this point across to Caprivi and the public.
Meanwhile larger sections of industry, keen to exploit the upswing in the
world economy and no less well-organized than the agrarians, called for an
across-the-board reduction of protective tariffs. With the end of the period of
retarded growth, many entrepreneurs had regained enough self-confidence to
want to plunge into the international market to sell their goods. The demand
for colonies and for an empire “commensurate” to the Reich’s size and economic importance now grew even stronger than it had been in the 1880s. The
conflict between agriculture and industry thus shifted to the fundamental
question of Germany’s future development. The commercial and industrial
bourgeoisie extolled the advantages and virtues of modern capitalism for the
country’s standing at home and abroad. At the other end of the spectrum, Otto
von Völderndorff aptly voiced the uneasiness that many conservatives felt
about industrial and urban society when he wrote: “We must leave dabbling
in world politics to others; we must limit ourselves to securing the country
against the two neighbors [France and Russia]. We must pursue utmost parsimony in all matters (except for the army) and a refounding of the Reich
upon the only stand that provides a firm base, [i.e.,] the rural population. Our
industry is not worth much anyway. It is in the hands of Jews; it produces
‘cheaply and poorly;’ it is the seedbed of socialism.”120 Small wonder that
248

The Evolution of Domestic Policies, 1871–1914

agrarians developed a visceral hatred of Caprivi, the modernizer and advocate of a reversal in commercial and tariff policies. When, on top of it all, he
refused to give his consent to renewed plans for a violent strike against the
Social Democrats and the Reichstag, the Kaiser was persuaded that he was
intolerable and dismissed him.
However, his successor, the aging Prince Clodwig zu Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst, had no appetite, either, for an era of conflict that court circles rumored
to be imminent. The future direction of domestic politics was also fueled by
a program of naval expansion that Naval Secretary Friedrich Hollmann had
drawn up at the Kaiser’s prompting. Tailored to give naval cover to Germany’s future overseas expansion through the construction of battle cruisers,
the Reichstag majority was quick to criticize the “limitlessness” of these plans,
adding that they lacked a systematic approach. Wilhelm II, who became very
agitated by the deputies’ refusal to support his program, was finally won over
by a group of advisors around Hohenlohe against a faction of hard-liners who
were calling for a Staatsstreich. This group succeeded in reassuring a concerned public that no unconstitutional moves were in the offing. Instead, Hohenlohe and his supporters promised to rally the middle-classes and agrarians
on a basis of conservative moderation. The inauguration of Weltpolitik, the
building of a huge fleet of battleships to be deployed in the North Sea, and
the idea of a grandiose economic and political future for the Kaiserreich were
key elements in their grand design.121
If the policy of violence against the Left had, at least for the moment, receded into the background, the political battles that Hohenlohe and his successor Bernhard von Bülow had to wage were tough enough. By the same
token, the outcome of these battles demonstrated that key political forces inside and outside the Reichstag still had the capacity to forge compromises
rather than unilaterally resorting to force. Without this capacity, which was
lost by 1914, it would be difficult to explain the passage of the navy laws of
1898 and 1900, on the one hand, and the majority agreement on agricultural
tariffs in 1902, on the other. What greatly helped the ratification of Tirpitz’s
navy bills was that they appeared to offer the systematic program that Hollmann had failed to develop and that, at least on paper, they looked modest
and fiscally responsible. A temporary calm in the international situation and
optimism about the Reich’s finances helped to ratify these two major pieces
of legislation. The increase in agricultural (though not industrial) tariffs was
passed two years later and similarly raised hopes for a stable domestic future.
The more radical economic demands of the Agrarian League were defeated,
and Bülow negotiated a middle way on the tariff issue that was ultimately
quite acceptable to industry and the middle-class parties on whose votes he
depended. But it was equally clear, as the experience of very effective agrarian opposition to the building the Mittellandkanal had indicated a few years
249

Politics

earlier, that industry and commerce could not have the prosperity all to themselves. Given the power structure, concessions to agriculture were unavoidable. This also applied to the Catholics and the Center Party, whose loyal
voters regularly secured a solid number of around 100 deputies. Since the end
of the Kulturkampf, the party had slowly been drawn into coalitions needed
by the government to form legislative majorities. In return the discriminatory
legislation of the 1870s was gradually dismantled.122
The navy laws and the tariffs were of fundamental importance to the future development of the country and provided the grounds for further political conflict and compromise. Certainly, the ratification of the three pieces of
legislation mentioned above must be regarded as a remarkable political feat.
The question of whether the compromises that were struck went beyond the
actual accords has caused some controversy among historians. Eckart Kehr
was the first to establish a direct link between the two navy laws and the 1902
tariff legislation. To him it enshrined a historic compromise that rallied the
middle-classes and agriculture against the working class and its movement.123
Others have concurred.124 Geoff Eley, on the other hand, has challenged this
hypothesis, asserting that concrete documentary evidence is lacking to sustain it.125 Indeed, beyond some circumstantial evidence, there is, for the time
being, only the statement that Reich Treasury Secretary Max von Thielmann
made on 1 May 1900 during the Reichstag debate on the second navy bill.
Pressured by the Center Party and the Conservatives, he assured them that the
Federal Council—formally the government of the Reich—supported an increase in agricultural tariffs that would soon be submitted. The Reich executive therefore did see the larger context, even if that context often disappeared
behind vague slogans about the need to rally in support of Weltpolitik and
against the Social Democrats—slogans that Bülow was a master at inventing
when he spoke on these subjects and yet did not want to reveal too much.126
There was another link between the navy laws of 1898 and 1900 and the
tariffs of 1902: in 1900 Thielmann predicted that the naval armaments—so
heartily welcomed by commerce and industry—could be paid without difficulty from the additional income that would accrue to the Reich from raised
agricultural tariffs and the anticipated further growth of the national economy, which would automatically yield higher tax revenues (Tables 72–73).
After 1902 this prediction turned out to be badly wrong and soon triggered
another major domestic conflict over the escalating crisis of the Reich’s finances. It was above all the navy’s expansion that proved more costly after it
triggered an unanticipated quantitative as well as qualitative arms race with
Britain. This arms race undercut all of Thielmann’s and Tirpitz’s elaborate
fiscal calculations and threw into disarray the Reich budget and the system
of federal “matricular contributions” (examined above).127 Meanwhile the federal states and local communities also accumulated uncontrollable deficits. It
250

The Evolution of Domestic Policies, 1871–1914

soon became clear that the holes in the Reich budget could only be plugged by
new taxes. Yet the mere mention of this topic alerted a welter of well-organized
interest groups and parties, all of which tried to protect their constituencies
from the tax reform proposal that Bülow, recognizing the looming fiscal crisis, had been working on since 1904.
When the tax bill was finally introduced in 1906, the Reichstag chopped
and changed it so much that it became no more than a temporary band-aid.
Only one innovation survived the legislative tax battles that was to rattle the
National Liberals and the Conservatives and to have lasting consequences:
the Catholics insisted on the adoption of a direct tax on legacies. While most
funds were raised, as before, by increases in indirect taxes, thus hitting the
mass of the population hardest, to the propertied classes the inheritance tax
was the thin end of the wedge and a harbinger of the “confiscatory” taxes that
the Reichstag, elected on the basis of universal suffrage for men, might well
introduce in the future.
However, for the moment a shift in the balance of political forces in the
national parliament that would have made further expansion of direct taxes
possible was prevented by the outcome of the 1907 elections. Campaigning
against Social Democrats and in part on a colonialist platform (which is why
they became known as “Hottentot elections”), the Liberals and Conservatives
succeeded in gaining enough additional seats to form the “Bülow Bloc.” The
SPD, which, together with the Catholics, had been highly critical of the government’s brutal policies in southwestern Africa, had its number of seats
slashed from 81 to 43 as a result of a number of second-ballot agreements
among Liberals and Conservatives. While the Catholics were able to increase
their seats slightly from 100 to 105, the other nonsocialist parties had enough
seats to oust the Center Party from the legislative position it had held in the
coalition of the previous years. Despite his triumph, Bülow knew that he
could not sit back and gloat over the defeat of the Social Democrats. Following the meager finance reform of 1906, another bill had to be put before the
Reichstag to deal with the growing deficit. Worsening things, in the meantime the hole in the Reich budget widened after the Royal Navy had begun
to build the Dreadnought class of battleships, which were much bigger and
faster than what Tirpitz had launched and planned under his program. His decision to follow the British lead steeply increased the costs of the German
naval buildup, and the money for this could only be generated through higher
taxes.128
Fully aware of these problems, Bülow initiated a major publicity campaign
to put pressure on the Bülow Bloc parties to vote for his finance bill. He presented it as absolutely vital for the entire domestic and international future of
the Kaiserreich. His bill had one flaw: along with the usual increases in indirect taxes, it contained a further modest direct tax proposal. Ultimately it
251

Politics

was because of this proposal that he failed. The Conservatives presented an
alternative proposal that put the new tax burdens primarily on the shoulders
of the mass of the population and of commerce and then found just about
enough votes in the Reichstag to pass it. The defeat of Bülow’s bill and the
agitation for and against its Conservative substitute demonstrated how polarized the situation had become by 1908/9. Bülow had to go, and the capacity
to forge compromises on central issues such as taxation that would not lead
to a backlash had begun to evaporate to a point that deeply worried Bülow’s
successor, Theobald von Bethmann Hollweg. Sooner or later elections would
have to be held, giving voters an opportunity to take revenge for the escalating injustices of the tax system. This opportunity came in 1912, and in the
meantime the SPD made certain in its propaganda that the “little man” would
not forget how he had been hit in the pocket by the 1909 finance bill.
Embittered by the injustices of the tax system, the mounting costs of armaments, the restrictive franchises in the federal states, and the illogicalities
of Prusso-German constitutionalism in general, over 4.2 million voters gave
their vote to the Social Democrats in January 1912 (Table 79). The SPD became the largest party in the Reichstag, holding 34.8 percent of the total vote
and 110 seats (27.7 percent). The Conservatives and the Reich Party (Free
Conservatives) gained a little over 12 percent, with the Center Party (16.4
percent) and the National Liberals (13.6 percent) garnering less support than
in 1907. The Progressives increased their vote to 12.3 percent. When the
April 1913 elections were held for the Prussian Diet, the Conservatives suffered further losses despite the special protection that they enjoyed under the
three-class voting system in this federal state. The massive demonstrations
that had taken place in 1910 against the inequalities of the Prussian suffrage
system had been harbingers of these developments. After 1912, then, it was
not only the finances that were coming apart at the seams, but the political
system more generally.129 The difficulties facing the Reich government were
thrown into sharp relief during the Zabern Affair and the debates surrounding the 1913 army bill and its astronomical costs.
In November 1913, the local military provoked a confrontation between
the army and the population in the small Alsatian town of Zabern, which resulted in the maltreatment of civilians by officers and the proclamation of a
state of siege by the local commander. The incident revealed that behind the
façade of civilian government, the Prussian military state still stood ready to
assert its power. Indeed, the events in Zabern represented more than a regrettable local incident that could be blamed on the inflexibility and stupidity of
a few officers on the ground. The affair grew into a national scandal when it
became clear that the Kaiser, as commander-in-chief, was not prepared to accept the slightest criticism of “his” military. It was as if a flashlight had lit up
for a moment to reveal the deep and ever deepening divisions within German
252

The Evolution of Domestic Policies, 1871–1914

politics. The incident separated those Germans who were inflexibly hostile
to any change in the status quo from those who called ever more insistently
for fundamental reforms of existing political conditions. As Marie Countess
Radziwill observed at the time, there existed a “latent antagonism between
two very different Germanies.”130
Although the military had committed clear breaches of the law, Wilhelm
II, under the influence of his maison militaire, refused to admit that any mistakes had been made. As the monarch’s loyal servant, the Reich chancellor
was forced, against his better judgment, to defend before the Reichstag the
bad decisions that the Kaiser’s generals had made. Amid the deputies’ noisy
protests, he tried his best to stop the erosion of the crown’s constitutional
privileges. The Reichstag majority in turn expressed its displeasure by passing a vote of no-confidence in the chancellor. To be sure, this vote could not
directly touch his position, as the monarch alone had the constitutional right
to dismiss him. Accordingly, the Kaiser remarked with glee that he could
simply ignore the vote of no-confidence. In the face of so much myopia it is
not surprising that many quite moderate people were deeply depressed by
these political developments in a country that, as they saw it, had many impressive cultural and economic achievements to its credit, but was shaken by
scandals that could only polarize society.
These growing tensions and the gradual disappearance of the capacity to
make compromises also surfaced in the debates on the army and finance bills
of 1913. The enlargement of the army was—as we have seen—131 reluctantly
adopted by the War Ministry after years of stagnation related to the desire to
preserve the homogeneity and reliability of the armed forces should, with the
rise of Social Democracy, civil unrest break out. All this changed when, with
Tirpitz’s virtual defeat in the Anglo-German naval arms race and rising international tensions between the great powers, the military began to worry
about the Reich’s relative strength in comparison to Russia and France, Germany’s main antagonists on the European continent. Suddenly, these two
countries were deemed to pose a lethal threat to the monarchy’s future. The
nationalist associations and rightist press made an important contribution to
securing the passage of a smaller bill in 1912, which was to be followed by
a bigger one in 1913.
The trouble was that the parliamentary majority that had ratified the army
bills quickly evaporated when, in a separate finance bill, the taxes had to be
found to pay for it all. It was clear from the start that the enormous costs
could not be covered by additional indirect taxes that would affect the mass
of the population. Nor were matricular contributions from the federal states
available to plug the deficit. Direct taxes imposed by the Reich seemed the
only way out. Bethmann hoped that, in the face of the perceived threat from
Russia and France, even the Conservatives would swallow the bitter tax pill
253

Politics

if he offered them a compromise: the money was to be levied via a one-shot
“military contribution” that could be presented as a patriotic deed. The Wehrbeitrag would not be a permanent direct tax.
As the Reich chancellor soon learned, the Conservatives were not prepared to make this kind of relatively minor sacrifice. No matter whether the
financial crisis and the deficits slowly paralyzed all orderly government activity, direct taxes were in their view out of the question. Such taxes, they argued, would open the door to the progressive expropriation of the wealthy by
a Reichstag that was, after all, elected on the basis of universal suffrage for
men and in which the “dangerous” Social Democrats were now the largest
party. In the end, the “military contribution” was accepted by a large majority
against the votes of the Conservatives. Among those voting for the bill were
some seventy Center Party deputies and, for the first time ever, many Social
Democrats, who on this occasion gave up their long-standing opposition to
support the financing of an army that might be used against them and into
which the party’s rank-and-file might be drafted in the case of a foreign war.
However, no Reich chancellor appointed by the monarch could afford to
rely on such a left-wing coalition for a second time if he wanted to keep his
job. Accordingly, Bethmann thenceforth confined himself to administering
the country. No major bill was introduced before the outbreak of war in August 1914. Overall, the 1913 debates on Zabern and financing the army law
threw a cold light on the desperate predicament into which the monarchy had
maneuvered itself at home and abroad.

18. Foreign Policy
A. Bismarck’s Diplomatic Balancing Acts, 1871–1890
As the discussion of domestic politics has shown, the first task after 1871
was to consolidate the founding of the German constitutional system and to
complete the nation-building process. In the face of this task, the responsible
politicians had a vital interest in avoiding major foreign crises, and this is
what Bismarck’s diplomacy was initially geared to.
The first major international challenge with which the new German Empire and Bismarck as its prime political strategist were confronted in 1871
was the question of peacemaking with a defeated France and of integrating
the new power in the heart of Europe into the existing community of nations.
Germany’s neighbors watched with interest, but also with suspicion, to see
which “path out of war”132 the Reich chancellor would take. His reputation
from the 1860s was, after all, that of a politician of military force who had
worked to overthrow the international status quo. Britain and Russia, it is
true, had tolerated his work of national unification, but in London decision
254

Foreign Policy

makers realized very well that the European state system had undergone something akin to a revolutionary change. Nor did it go unnoticed that the generals and some members of the general public had been prepared to escalate
the conflict in order to win a total victory over France. Given these problems,
it was remarkable that Bismarck achieved a moderate peace. If any serious
misjudgments occurred, it was in the failure to resist widespread calls to annex Alsace-Lorraine. This decision, which some historians have argued may
have been unavoidable, created an irreparable rift with France and in later
years contributed to the deterioration of the German position within the international system.
After 1871 German diplomacy was faced with two tasks: to keep the French
“archenemy” as isolated as it had been at the outbreak of war in 1870 and,
second, to fit the Kaiserreich into the group of the major powers of the day
in such a way as to make it impossible for other countries to exert political
pressure upon it or to pose a direct military threat. With these objectives in
mind, Bismarck tried to convince neighboring countries that Germany had no
further territorial ambitions in Europe. To this end, he attempted to reach an
understanding with Russia, Austria-Hungary, and Britain. The first successes
of this policy came in October 1873, when Wilhelm I acceded to a treaty that
Russia and Austria-Hungary had signed in June of that year. However, as became quickly evident, the three emperors had concluded a precarious alliance. Meanwhile Britain was not interested in any such arrangements. She
was preoccupied with her overseas empire and merely saw herself as a “balancer” outside the continental European state system. London appeared on the
scene only when, in 1875, the threat of another Franco-German war loomed
on the horizon. This ephemeral crisis was rooted in the rapid military and
economic recovery that France had been making in the early 1870s. German
military leaders were greatly alarmed by this and began to consider a preventive war. This situation and the ratification of a French military bill in March
1875 triggered the so-called War in Sight crisis. Russia and Britain immediately launched a diplomatic counteroffensive that made Bismarck realize the
limits of Germany’s ability to conduct power politics. It was a major diplomatic setback for the new empire.133
Determined not to find himself ever again in an isolated position like the
one he faced in 1875, the Reich chancellor henceforth tried to strengthen the
Three Emperors’ League. Perhaps this maneuver would have been more successful if the decline of the Ottoman Empire had not produced fresh tensions
between the Tsarist Empire and Austria-Hungary. The immediate trigger was
a Russian victory over the Sultan’s armies and the forced Peace of San Stephano in March 1878, which, among other things, created a pro-Russian Greater
Bulgarian state in the Balkans. In Vienna, and also London, these shifts in the
balance of power unleashed anxieties about the future. As late as January
255

Politics

1877, Russia and Austria-Hungary were in agreement with regard to their interests in southeastern Europe. On this occasion the Tsar had promised the
