was allegedly undermining popular morale and the war effort with defeatist
and subversive slogans. As will be seen below, among the alleged enemies
were, not surprisingly, the Social Democrats, stigmatized as “unpatriotic fellows” and “traitors of the fatherland” long before 1914. But with the search
for scapegoats in full swing by 1916, there was another minority group on
which the blame for the growing crisis could be conveniently pinned: the
Jews. Although anti-Semitism had been on the rise before 1914, the lies that
were spread about this group and its role in Germany during the war (and especially toward the end of it) had never been more vicious.54
The search for “Reich enemies” cannot be separated from another debate
in which intellectual elites, but increasingly also politicians and the military,
engaged: war aims, the territorial fruits to be gained from the war that would
justify it all. This debate must be seen against the background of the Burgfrieden, the sacred peace that all classes, including the industrial working
class and its leaders, had entered into in August 1914. As the Kaiser put it to
the crowds outside the Berlin Schloss on the day that mobilization was proclaimed, from now on there would be only Germans.
Reich chancellor Bethmann, who had made an important contribution to
the forging of this truce when he persuaded the SPD leadership to support
what was said to be a defensive war against the aggressive and autocratic Tsarist empire,55 appreciated from the start that the truce would only hold if the
question of war aims could be kept under wraps until war’s end. The Social
Democrats would never accept a program of annexations and territorial expansion. To prevent a public debate on war aims seemed all the more important since Bethmann was under pressure from influential nationalist and
business circles to subscribe to a program of vast annexations that was summarized in his famous-infamous memorandum of 9 September 1914. In other
words, just one month after the outbreak of war, the German government had
put together a list of territorial claims to be pursued after victory had been won.
The discovery of Bethmann’s September Memorandum led Fritz Fischer
to argue that its basic demands had existed before 1914 and had in fact been
282

The War “From Above”

a major reason for unleashing the war in the first place.56 Although there is
no direct evidence for this hypothesis, a case can certainly be made that prewar hopes and expectations had shifted away from Weltpolitik and overseas
possessions. With Tirpitz’s failure to build a battle-fleet that posed a serious
challenge to the Royal Navy and the British Empire, the army had once more
become the main focus of Germany’s military power, and this return to a reliance on land forces also moved the European and Eurasian continent back
onto the radar screen of those elite groups who strategized about the country’s geographical position in Europe. At this point it was not yet a question
of a direct military and administrative presence in eastern and southeastern
Europe. Rather those regions were seen as part of an informal German Empire that would tie the predominantly agricultural economies to the Central
European industrial hegemon. While these were the Mitteleuropa conceptions of businessmen and academics, Friedrich Naumann prominently among
them, some military and Prussian conservatives had begun to think of the creation of a formal German Empire in the east.57
Their calculations were summarized later by General Wilhelm Groener,
who had been in charge of the General Staff’s Railroad Department prior to
1914, before becoming director of the War Office. A man who was no doubt
in the know, he remarked in 1919: “We have inadvertently striven for world
domination before we had secured our position on the Continent—this I can
of course say only in the most intimate circle, but who views matters more
or less clearly and historically, cannot have any doubts about this.”58 In 1915,
Tirpitz had heard that similar opinions circulated in “numerous circles in the
army and in other rightist forces.”59 According to them, what the Germans
should have done was “to conduct power politics, but continental [power]
politics. First defeat the enemies on the continent; everything to be invested
in the army for this purpose.… [Our] world and naval policy has been ‘premature’. We have ‘overstretched’ ourselves with [the creation of] the navy.”
It was against the background of such criticisms of Wilhelmine Weltpolitik,
first before 1914 and again after the war commenced, that the relatively rapid
collation of continental-European annexationist war aims in the September
Memorandum must be seen that were sent to Bethmann by a welter of agrarian and business groups during August.60 According to the document, Luxemburg and the eastern parts of Belgium were to be incorporated into the Reich.
The rest of Belgium would be reorganized as a kind of vassal state. France
was to lose the heavy-industrial region of Longwy-Briey. Moreover, all Western European states were to become part of a customs union under German
leadership that would eventually also comprise Scandinavia and Poland. Initially Berlin had been planning to leave Poland to the Habsburg empire. But
from 1916 Bethmann began to conceive of the region as another vassal state
complemented in the east by a “frontier strip” and cordon against Russia.
283

World War I

However, it appears that the September Memorandum was not just a digest of numerous submissions that Bethmann kept receiving from economic
pressure groups. On 28 August, the Pan-German League published a declaration on war aims that envisioned huge territorial acquisitions from Russia.
Concerned with keeping the Social Democrats in the fold, the Reich chancellor did not want the ultranationalist Pan-Germans to spearhead a large public discussion of German war aims. Clearly, it was better to let various elite
groups have their say and continue an internal debate on the subject.
The subsequent evolution of this issue offers a good illustration of how
domestic and international affairs became inextricably linked as the war unfolded and became ever more total. At the beginning of the conflict it was no
doubt also wise not to formulate one’s war aims too clearly in order not to tie
one’s hands for the day when peace would be negotiated. Nor is it difficult to
see that the official proclamation of exorbitant territorial annexations would
stir up the internal opposition. After all, such aims could only be achieved after final and total victory. However such a “hard peace” logically precluded
the conclusion of an earlier compromise peace without annexations. As we
shall see in a later section, the long-term effect of the war aims issue was tremendously polarizing in that it divided those Germans who wanted to fight
on in the hope of reaping the rewards of ultimate victory from those who
wanted to stop the slaughter in the trenches and advocated a return to the status quo ante.
There was yet another reason why some people promoted war aims. The
rising costs and sacrifices of the world conflict were bound to reinforce demands for greater social justice that the working-class movement had made
before 1914. Women had also been seeking more equality and suffrage. Once
the war had started, businessmen and other elite groups were quick to recognize that the conflict had a strongly democratizing impact on society. Men
who had made major sacrifices in the trenches in the nation’s defense would
not be happy to return to a political system that upheld restricted suffrage, such
as Prussia’s three-class voting system. After Social Democratic demands for
equality at the polls and the removal of many other forms of discrimination
had been firmly rejected before the war, the fear of increased pressure for reform in the wake of total war was widespread. It was articulated as early as
October 1914 by Alfred Hugenberg, a director of the Krupp trust.61 He argued
that one would have to reckon with an increased sense of power on the part
of soldiers returning from the front. They would insist on improvements in
their positions in the workplace and changes in the law.
There were two ways in which businessmen and politicians could respond
to this pressure: they could enter into negotiations to reach reformist compromises while rejecting more radical demands. Alternatively, they could, apart
from repressing the “increased sense of power” of returning front soldiers,
284

The War “From Below”

adopt what Hugenberg recommended as a remedy. According to him, “it
would therefore be well advised, in order to avoid internal difficulties, to distract the attention of the people and to give fantasies concerning the extension
of German territory room to play.”62 It is worth taking Hugenberg’s words seriously: the proclamation of grandiose war aims was indeed suited to turn the
eyes of the gullible away from the country’s internal problems and the need
for change toward visions of a continental European empire, from which all
Germans were to benefit. Those who fanned the war aims debate did so in the
justified expectation that the annexationist program would mobilize the nationalists and others. The drawback that was consciously accepted was that it
accelerated the division of society into two hostile camps. After all, the more
the Right, increasingly supported by the military leadership after Bethmann’s
ouster from the chancellorship, agitated for the war’s continuation until final
victory and a hard peace, the more those who were working for a peace without annexations and other reformists in the Left would rally against a boundless German nationalism and imperialism.

21. The World War As Experienced “From Below”
A. The Outbreak of War and the German People
While diplomats negotiated with neutrals and allies, bureaucrats, businessmen, and agrarians struggled to organize a total war economy. Professors and
journalists sat in their studies to scribble patriotic pamphlets and poems. And
while generals prepared the next all-out attack on the enemy lines, millions
of ordinary soldiers and civilians experienced the world war in a different
way.
Most of them had attended the massive rallies and demonstrations that had
taken place in towns and villages when the mobilization orders were published. To reconstruct their thoughts and feelings, two factors will have to be
taken into account. To begin with, they all thought that the nation had been
attacked by the Russians. Of course, we know today that they were hoodwinked and that their leaders in Berlin and Vienna were primarily responsible for the escalation of the Sarajevo Crisis into a world war. Still, the fact
remains that most ordinary Germans believed that they rallied in defense of
the fatherland against Tsarist autocracy. The pinpointing of this particular enemy also made the war justifiable for the Social Democrats. However much
they despised the Kaiser and the existing Prusso-German political system,
Tsarism must never be allowed to come to Central Europe.
Second, those who went to the demonstrations and assembly points to
sign up and to listen to the war proclamations had no idea what kind of war
was about to start. There were, as we have seen, a number of voices that had
285

World War I

warned of industrialized warfare between great powers in the twentieth century. But their arguments had not sunken into the public’s perspective in any
general way. Even rank-and-file Social Democrats, imbued with a simplified
version of Marxism, did not think of catastrophe, but rather contemplated the
wonderfully progressive changes that conflicts between colonial powers and
the impending crisis of capitalism would bring to the proletarian masses. Ideas
on how the war at the front and home front would unfold were extremely
vague. On top of it all, those who had read too many of the science fiction
novels popular at the time tended to be more mesmerized by the utopian descriptions of technological gadgets than deterred by the lethality of modern
weapons and mysterious robots.63
The kind of war many Germans therefore saw coming looked more like
the Franco-Prussian War of 1870/71. They expected a clash of two armies
from which the one side would quickly emerge victorious, and there was little doubt that their country had the superior forces. The fact that, at the end
of the war of 1870/71, the conflict had seen the beginnings of a “people’s war”
had been conveniently forgotten, and the elder Moltke’s qualms about a future people’s war were not even heeded by the professionals. Instead, there
was a widespread rumor in August that the soldiers would all be home again
by Christmas 1914.
However, recent research has also shown that the enthusiasm for war among
the masses was not as great as it had traditionally been depicted in the history books of later generations.64 Whoever went to the rallies and listened to
patriotic speeches by more or less prominent politicians was probably pulled
along when the crowds burst into cheers. But quite a few may well have
joined in only because silence and passivity would have provoked frowns and
hostility from those around them. It was only on the way home that one became more pensive again. It appears therefore that a member of the Social
Democratic Youth League in Hamburg gave an accurate description of his experience in those heavy August days of 1914 when he recorded in his diary:
“The excitement of the population, which had already led to a panicky onslaught on savings banks and grocery stores, increased. Most people were depressed as if they were to be beheaded the next day.”65 And an older Social
Democrat from Hamburg remarked in those days: “Day after day many comrades came to the trade union house at Besenbinderhof. We observed the
commotion with incomprehension. Many asked themselves: ‘Am I mad or is
it the others?’”66
Soon the experiences of those who had marched off to the front and those
who stayed at home began to diverge even more radically. To be sure, the soldiers were in frequent touch with their families, and a deliberate effort was
made to keep the military mail flowing. Many soldiers were also given brief
leaves of absence. And yet, increasingly there arose something like a psycho286

The War “From Below”

logical wall between the young fighters at the front and their parents and siblings at home. The world of the trenches and dugouts that they had experienced in the age of industrialized warfare was just too different. How was it
possible to describe to a worried and terrified mother what one had gone
through at Ypres, Verdun, or during the Battle of the Somme? There were just
no words for it. It was only towards war’s end that there was a rapprochement
between front and home front, as the longing for peace rose everywhere.
B. The Totalization of the War at the Front
As we have seen, the war was initially a war of movement in both east and
west. Casualties at this early stage were already staggeringly high, among not
only the troops but also the civilian population. After Moltke’s retreat from
the Battle of the Marne in September 1914, a new type of warfare began in
the west. Both sides built an elaborate system of trenches and dugouts that
ultimately stretched from Ypres in Belgium in a huge arch all the way to Verdun in Lorraine. Behind a frontline stretching some 450 miles long, there existed an extensive maze of trenches and supply-trenches that added up for
both sides to an estimated 25,000 miles.67 Following the Battle of the Marne,
there were repeated attempts to roll back the enemy, but compared to what
was to come the fighting was still relatively moderate. The Christmas period
also revealed that feelings of hatred were not yet as visceral as they would
become in later years. In various sections of the front the fighting stopped on
Christmas Eve. The two sides exchanged best wishes across the no-man’s
land, and there was even fraternization, which was, however, quickly stopped
by the officers. A similar atmosphere existed on the eastern front, where hatred
was also restrained and where both sides tried to observe international law,
even in the POW camps of Siberia. Tens of thousands of Habsburg soldiers
were interned in faraway places following the huge encirclement battles in
the war of movement in the east.68
Still, by the middle of 1915, it was no longer possible to deny that this had
become a long, brutal, and increasingly total war. Here is one example: the
name of the town of Verdun is to this day remembered in both France and Germany as one of the most catastrophic battles in modern history. The battle
was based on a plan hatched by Erich von Falkenhayn, the successor to Moltke,
who had resigned after his failure on the Marne. He calculated, probably correctly, that Verdun would be of such great symbolic value to the French that
they would never abandon the fortifications along that sector of the front. They
would bring in massive reinforcements, and this would give the Germans a
chance to bleed the French army white.69
In preparation for the attack on Verdun, the Germans assembled some 1,300
howitzers, which on 22 February 1916 unleashed an inferno along a small
stretch of the frontline. Poison gas was added to secure success. On 25 Feb287

World War I

ruary the Germans were able to conquer the Fortress Douaumont, whose surroundings had meanwhile been turned into a moon landscape by the artillery
bombardment. On the following day General Philippe Pétain took over as
commander of the Verdun frontline. Fresh French reinforcements were brought
in who—as Falkenhayn had expected—defended their position to the last bullet and sustained huge casualties. By April, the French had lost about 89,000
men when Falkenhayn discovered that German losses were almost as large.
The struggle continued. On 29 May the Germans took another strategic
position that had the telling name “Mort Homme.” The Fortress of Vaux fell
a week later. But the French did not give up, and on 2 July Falkenhayn was
forced to halt the offensive. The breakthrough that the Kaiser had prematurely
announced on 1 April had not been achieved. France did not capitulate, and
the war continued. Indeed, in subsequent months the French reconquered the
Fortresses Vaux and Douaumont. Total human losses on both sides amounted
to 500,000 each. They had fired some 40 million shells. The main reason for
Falkenhayn’s retreat at Verdun was the beginning of the Battle of the Somme,
which the British began on 24 June 1916 as a relief operation. This battle and
its horrendous number of casualties have already been mentioned.
For many years now historians have been trying to explain why soldiers
on both sides, as had happened again in the Battle of the Somme, would be
prepared to rush across no-man’s land into the enemy’s machine-gun fire and
hence into certain death. They have also asked themselves how, during the
long breaks between major battles, men held out in the trenches and dugouts
surrounded by corpses, rats, mud, and lice. The American historian Jay Winter may be right when he put the buddy system, a sense of honor and duty,
and patriotism high on his list. There were also the harsh rules of military discipline. But in comparison to other countries, the number of German soldiers
court-martialed and sentenced to die remained quite small: a mere 150, of
whom some 48 were in fact executed.70
Yet, neither Winter’s list of psychological factors nor the sanctions of martial law were able to prevent discussions among the rank-and-file about the
meaning of the terrible bloodletting. After the costly battles of 1916, disillusionment rose, and soldiers began to long for peace. Similar processes set in
on the eastern front. The outcome of the Battle of the Marne and the beginning of trench warfare in the west meant that the projected massive transfer
of troops after the successful completion of the Schlieffen-Moltke Plan was
never possible. Worse, the Russian armies had mobilized more quickly than
expected. As early as the middle of August 1914 they began to threaten East
Prussia and advanced westward to the north and south of the Masurian Lakes.
General Paul von Hindenburg, brought back from retirement, then succeeded
through a number of bold countermoves to defeat the Russians, who were badly
led and trained, near Tannenberg. A week later the German counteroffensive
288

The War “From Below”

along the Masurian Lakes set in, and the end of the Tsarist armies were again
beaten. Until December, and again in the spring and summer of 1915, the Germans thus made considerable territorial gains up to a line that ran south from
Riga in Latvia eastward of Vilnius, Grodno, and Brest-Litovsk. Further south,
where the Habsburg armies had clashed bloodily with the Russians and where
the frontline had moved back and forth several times in 1915 and 1916, the
losses of military personnel were higher. If the 2 million POWs who had
been captured by both sides along the eastern front posed enormous logistical problems, the fate of the civilian population was possibly even more dire.
Some regions experienced foreign occupation and subsequent “liberation”
several times. Whatever provisions they had were confiscated by troops who
were never properly supplied. People were constantly on the road trying the
escape from the fighting. In the German zone of occupation in the north of
the eastern front, some 4 million people were forced to leave their homes.
Villages were razed to the ground; scorched-earth tactics were widespread.
We still do not have any reliable figures on how many civilians perished during those years of total warfare before the collapse of the Russian front in the
revolutionary upheavals of 1917.71
C. The Totalization of the War at the Home Front
While the German troops experienced the beginnings of total war with its
massive casualties, the civilian population back home did not have to fear losing their lives in battle. And yet the stresses and strains of the conflict reached
the German home front more quickly than in Britain or France. As elsewhere,
notifications of the deaths of fathers, brothers, uncles, or sons that arrived in
the towns and villages with increasing frequency were devastating enough.
But the mourning of a loved one was exacerbated in Germany by a very rapid
deterioration of the material position of the population. In this respect, the
British naval blockade had immediate and catastrophic consequences. As
Germany’s international trade collapsed, causing millions of marks in losses
to finance and commerce, early bread shortages that were never overcome affected the average family most severely. Until 1917, grain production fell by
some 43 percent. Several factors caused this crisis. To begin with, supplying
the armed forces had absolute priority over the civilian population, and the
army alone had a voracious appetite. Just one army corps consumed 660,000
loaves of bread and 500,000 kilos of meat per month. If domestic grain production had been insufficient before 1914 to feed the population, it was difficult to raise it when milk and other agricultural produce also remained in high
demand, even if the feeding of animals withdrew grain from human consumption. Potato production offered an alternative, but this market suffered badly
from the early and harsh winter of 1914/15, which was followed by further bad
harvests in 1916 and 1917.72
289

World War I

These shortages, which in times of peace could have been made up by grain
imports, confronted the authorities with the impossible task of organizing the
fair distribution of very scarce basic foodstuffs. Even if they had been paragons of efficiency, the authorities would have found the grain shortages too
severe to manage equitably, all the more so since shortages in meat and milk
products set in sooner than expected. In these circumstances, it was to be expected that the authorities would become the prime target of complaints and
protests. In the second half of the war this was indeed more and more the
case. But for a longer period, the officials in towns and cities managed to portray themselves as the concerned and caring party that tried ever so hard to look
after their citizens’ wellbeing.73 Consequently, at the beginning of the war,
the population tended to blame other groups for the shortages. In the fall of
1914, there were the so-called Kriegerfrauen, whose husbands had been called
up and who received financial support from the state. It seems that quite a few
of these women came from the better-off middle classes and spent their money
having their afternoon Kaffee und Kuchen in local cafés. Other women who
had to work and did not have the time and money for such treats felt aggrieved
and demanded that flour be used for bread-baking rather than cake-making.
By the fall of 1914 these complaints had become so strong that demonstrations occurred against the Kriegerfrauen.
However, since an increasing number of these women soon appeared in
the streets dressed in black and hence constituted an awkward target for protests, producers and retailers began to appear in the visor of the protesters.
They were accused of hoarding and price gouging. Over time it became increasingly clear that it was general inflation, not price gouging, that devoured
a growing percentage of weekly household budgets. The authorities now developed another redress: soup kitchens, where those who had reached the
starvation line could obtain at least one fairly nutritious meal. Tensions also
arose over the question of whether workers in heavy industry (Schwerarbeiter),
and the vital armaments industries in particular, should be given special rations and hence preference over the needy who were starving. When in the end
rationing was introduced, first for flour as early as February 1915, and soon
thereafter for other food items, fresh conflicts arose over the existence of a
thriving black market, in which those with savings and higher incomes could,
at inflated prices, get whatever they needed, while the population’s poorer segments had to live on turnips and water.
For a long time, the authorities succeeded in appearing on the side of the
popular majority and thus avoided being blamed for the crisis. But given the
worsening food situation, it was perhaps inevitable that sooner or later the
government would end up on the firing line of civilian protest. This meant that
a confrontation that had begun over economic issues increasingly became
politicized into a struggle between the monarchy, which did not seem able to
290

Military Defeat

win or end the war, and the masses in the cities, who were starving. Women
who had stood in the ever-lengthening bread lines at the beginning of the war
were the first to grumble and then explode in frustration and anger. Soon they
would be joined by working women whose families were also starving. Their
male colleagues began to join them. Almost inevitably protests that were triggered by the deteriorating economic conditions slowly turned into demands
to end the war and to introduce fundamental political reforms.74

22. Military Defeat and the Collapse of
the Hohenzollern Monarchy
By early 1917 the predicament of the Kaiserreich was truly desolate. The war
was going badly. The stalemate and the war of attrition on the western front
continued, while casualty figures mounted and doubt about the meaning of
the conflict spread in the trenches. The decision to resume unrestricted submarine warfare in the Atlantic had brought the United States into the war on
the side of the Allies. But once again the calculations that had been made concerning the benefits of sinking merchant ships without warning had proven
wrong, as had so many other calculations made by the German military since
August 1914. Although the number of shipments destroyed in the Atlantic
briefly surpassed the figures that were supposed to be needed to force Britain
to sue for peace, “Perfidious Albion’s” collapse was nowhere in sight. Thanks
to the invention of the convoy system, more ships were still getting through,
and the country had also adopted other means, such as the ploughing of grassland for grain production, that prevented the kind of food shortages under which
Germany was now reeling. Meanwhile, the Americans had put their war machine into high gear, and the arrival of fresh troops in Europe was expected
by the spring of 1918. On the domestic front, economic protests became more
and more politicized and thus reinforced the division of society into a camp
that agitated for a harsh Siegfrieden with exorbitant territorial annexations in
Eastern and Western Europe and the political status quo at home, juxtaposed
by a camp that called for an immediate cessation of hostilities without annexations and the reform of the Hohenzollern monarchy.
However, the developments of 1917 and 1918 that culminated in the defeat of the German army and the abdication of Wilhelm II can only be fully
understood against the background of events in Russia in 1917.
It has already been mentioned that the Russian army suffered terrible losses
during the great battles of 1915/16. Time and again the troops’ inexperience and
the incompetence of the Tsarist officer corps extracted a heavy price. Morale
was declining fast, accelerated by the strict discipline that the military leadership imposed on the rank-and-file in an attempt to cover up its own failures.
Additionally, things could have been better at the home front. Unlike the situ291

World War I

ation in Germany, Russia’s agricultural production capacity was adequate to
feed the population. But again it was bureaucratic muddle that prevented sufficient foodstuffs from reaching the urban centers. The civilian population in
towns and cities therefore had ample reason to be critical. But there was also
ferment in the countryside, driven by the losses of an army that was made up
predominantly of soldiers of peasant background. With increased mourning
in the villages came dissatisfaction with the regime’s handling of the war.75
Meanwhile the Tsar and his advisors were largely isolated from the rest of
society. They had little inkling of the actual mood of the population and came
under the influence of sinister forces, above all that of Rasputin, a monk who
until his assassination in 1916 had the ear of the Tsarina. Inexorably, the prestige of the monarchy headed toward its nadir in the winter of 1916/17. There
were, it is true, forces who wanted to reform the political system and open it
up to greater popular participation. Among them was Prince Georgi Lvov,
who proposed giving more powers to the local semstvo authorities and the
Duma, the national assembly. Mikhail Rodzianko, the president of the Duma,
pursued similar aims. But both men were summarily rebuked by the archconservative court circles and the military at the Tsarist headquarters. Isolated and
unwilling to make any concessions, Tsar Nicholas II had no defenders when,
after the number of smaller strikes had grown to 2,300, involving some 1.8
million participants, massive demonstrations broke out in St. Petersburg and
other cities in February 1917 demanding his abdication.76
Worried that the country might lapse into chaos, moderate politicians inside and outside the Duma forced the monarch to step down. They staged what
might be called a “revolution from above” in order to stave off a threatening
“revolution from below.” The new Provisional Government, first headed by
Prince Lvov and later by Alexander Kerensky, tried its best to stabilize the
situation and to steer a middle course between the reactionary officer corps,
which was considering a coup to establish a military dictatorship, and the
workers’ and soldiers’ councils, which had sprung up spontaneously from the
February demonstrations. The latter came increasingly under the influence of
more radical forces, among them the Bolsheviks, led by Vladimir Lenin and
Leon Trotsky. The attempt to establish a military regime under the leadership
of General Lavr Kornilov quickly collapsed, thanks to the resistance of the
naval units stationed in St. Petersburg and of the railway unions, whose members diverted the trains with Kornilov’s contingents away from the capital.
Kerensky’s Provisional Government had been saved, but it had also become
clear that it lacked the military forces to defend itself against any challenge.
Taking advantage of this weakness, Lenin and Trotsky turned their supporters against Kerensky. In November they succeeded in wresting power from
him in a leftist coup.77

292

Military Defeat

Thenceforth the Bolsheviks had a vital interest in safeguarding their new
regime and in fulfilling some of the promises with which they had garnered
support among the masses for their program of “bread, land, and peace.” It
was the latter promise of an immediate peace that presented the German government with a unique opportunity in November 1917. It seemed possible to
end the war in the east, enabling Hindenburg and Ludendorff to throw larger
numbers of troops from the Russian front into France and thus turning the
tide in the west in Germany’s favor. In December 1917 Berlin entered into
peace negotiations with Trotsky. But the latter procrastinated, and by the end
of February 1918 the signing of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk was still not in
sight.78 The Germans then issued an ultimatum, and when this was not immediately accepted, troops began to march eastward. On 1 March they occupied Kiev. Two days later, the Bolsheviks signed the peace agreement under
which the Kaiserreich annexed huge territories up to the Caucasus, comprising all of the Ukraine and the Crimea. Ultimately the frontier ran from Narva
on the Baltic Sea, via Mogilev and Kursk along the River Don, to Rostov and
Taganrog. It is no exaggeration to say that the German High Command implemented, through the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk, the eastern half of an annexationist program that was reminiscent of the demands put forward by the
Pan-Germans in their memorandum of 28 August 1914. There can also be little doubt that the Germans would have been no less ruthless in the reordering
of Western Europe, had they been able to end the war victoriously in the west.
In March 1918 the prospects for such a victory looked good. The troops
moved into France, including contingents from Serbia and Italy, now numbering forty divisions with 600,000 men. Hindenburg and Ludendorff launched
their spring offensive without delay. But after making early territorial gains, the
attack soon ground to a halt, not least because in the meantime some 300,000
Americans had arrived on the western front who subsequently helped to turn
the tide. By the middle of July the Allies began their counterattack. Four weeks
later the German defenses that had been hastily erected began to crumble. On
29 September the High Command informed the Kaiser that the war was lost.79
What followed was in some ways reminiscent of events in Russia in February 1917. It was to be expected that the public admission of defeat would
come as a terrible blow to millions of Germans who had been told in the
spring that victory was around the corner. The High Command and the Reich
government rightly feared unrest and the beginnings of a “revolution from
below,” spearheaded by the disillusioned workers and soldiers. At this point
it was Paul von Hintze, the state secretary of the German Foreign Office, who
came up with a cunning plan. He proposed to introduce a major constitutional reform. The government would henceforth no longer be formed by the
monarch alone but would emerge from the majority parties in the Reichstag.

293

World War I

In other words, Hintze put forward the idea of parliamentarizing the PrussoGerman political system. The center of decision-making power was to be
moved from the Kaiser to the popular assembly.
Wilhelm II and the High Command approved the plan. Negotiations with
the Reichstag parties began that included the Social Democrats, and the party
leaders responded positively. They felt that, however unfavorable the circumstances under which they were asked to assume governmental responsibility,
they could not stand aside in the country’s hour of extreme crisis. Accordingly, Georg von Hertling, who had been appointed chancellor by the Kaiser
under the old system, stepped down. Prince Max von Baden, who had a reputation as a liberal and enjoyed the confidence of the Reichstag majority, succeeded him as Reich chancellor. The other members who entered his cabinet
did so with the approval of the center-left coalition that had been formed. In
short, something very remarkable and indeed “revolutionary” had happened:
without removing the Kaiser, Germany had become a constitutional monarchy along the lines of the British system.
However, before we praise Hintze’s initiative as a wise and statesmanlike
act, it should be remembered that the constitutional change was made only in
the hour of total military defeat. There were hence ulterior motives that Ludendorff put as follows: “I have asked His Majesty to bring those people [i.e.,
the majority parties] into the government who are largely responsible for things
having turned out as they have. We shall therefore see these gentlemen enter
the ministries, and they must now make the peace that has to be made. They
must now eat the soup that they have served us!”80 By cold-bloodedly placing responsibility for the war and its disastrous result on the shoulders of the
Reichstag deputies, he tried to absolve himself and the army from any blame
for the defeat. The party leaders, with Friedrich Ebert among them, will not
have missed the cynicism that motivated the constitutional change. But by
joining the government they not only hoped to help the German people but
also to stave off a possible “revolution from below.” Russia after all offered
an ominous example of how a volatile situation could end up in a Bolshevik
seizure of power, which they all wanted to avoid in Germany.
The government of Prince Max tried its best to maintain law and order and
to enter into negotiations with the Allies to sign an armistice and eventually
a peace treaty. Initially, their chances of success did not look bad. But the
civilian government’s efforts were undermined by the criminal behavior not,
in this case, of the army but of the admiralty. At the beginning of November,
Admiral Reinhard Scheer secretly ordered the German battle-fleet in Wilhelmshaven to undertake a final sortie against the Royal Navy in the North Sea.81
Given the strategic inferiority of the Germans, this was nothing less than a
suicide mission. It was also clear to the admiralty that the sortie would undermine Prince Max’s armistice negotiations. However, Scheer thought himself
294

Military Defeat

guided by “higher goals.” The army, it could be argued, had fought a heroic
battle and would therefore maintain its prestige in the nation’s eyes after the
war. The fleet, on the other hand, had spent most of the war bottled up in Wilhelmshaven and Kiel. The submarines had valiantly fought the war at sea instead. It was expected that the country would never, after the war, wish to
rebuild a navy that, despite the enormous resources that Tirpitz had put into
it, had proved so useless. A spectacular battle in the North Sea was supposed
to rectify this. When ordering that thousands of sailors be sent to their deaths
in a final do-or-die battle, the admiralty had its own future in mind.
Scheer could not prevent rumors from spreading about his plan in Wilhelmshaven. The sailors wanted to go home rather than die as heroes in the
North Sea. They flatly refused to sail the ships, whereupon the commanding
admiral stopped the operation and sent the fleet through the Kiel Canal to
Kiel on the Baltic Sea, where the sailors immediately fraternized with their
comrades and shipyard workers. Strikes and demonstrations now spread from
Kiel throughout the rest of Germany like wildfire. The “revolution from below” had broken out. Ignorant of the realities on the ground, the Kaiser, who
had retreated to his military headquarters in Spa on the Belgian border, surrounded by his generals, expressed his indignation at the revolutionary upheavals. He announced that he had decided to march back home at the head
of his troops to quell the uprisings. His military advisors thereupon informed
him that there were no more troops that would follow their supreme commander. Rather, the soldiers were all on their way home on their own initiative, and the monarch had become a liability for the army leaders, who, like
Scheer, were also thinking about their postwar future. And so Wilhelm II was
bundled into a car and driven across the border in the middle of the night into
his Dutch exile, where he stayed until his death in 1941. In the capital Prince
Max announced the monarch’s abdication even before it had been agreed. On
9 November 1918 a prominent Social Democrat proclaimed a republic before
a jubilant Berlin crowd.82

295

Conclusion

I will now make a few concluding remarks at the end of what was conceived
as a general textbook history of the German Empire from its founding in 1871
to its demise in 1918. No attempt is being made here to summarize individual chapters.
Rather than providing the chronological narrative found in most other studies of this kind, my approach has been systematic, starting with economic developments, moving on to the structure and evolution of German society and
culture, and ending with an analysis of the political system and the country’s
foreign and domestic policies. Within those major parts, the account has been
organized further around key themes. Again, it would seem unnecessary to
recapitulate those sections here.
However, this would appear to be a good moment to come back to two
major, related issues that have driven my own interest (and the interest of
most other scholars of the period) in the Kaiserreich. The first issue relates
to explaining why the country ended up in a catastrophic world war that, most
historians now agree, was triggered primarily by the decision makers in Berlin and—not to be underestimated—Vienna. Earlier interpretations had related
this decision to the authoritarian character of the Hohenzollern monarchy, arguing that Germany was dominated by powerful conservative elites, led by
an autocratic monarch and his ministers, who were concerned with preserving the socioeconomic and political status quo in the face of a rapidly changing, industrializing and urbanizing society. The criticism of this position in
the 1970s, probably most forcefully articulated by Hans-Ulrich Wehler in his
book The German Empire, 1871–1918, was not long in coming.83 With the
rise of social and cultural history “from below,” scholars pointed to what they
felt the others had failed to deal with: the astonishing extent to which Bismarck’s Germany, and even more so Wilhelmine Germany in general, had
been a multifaceted, rich, and diverse country.84 This book tried to take on
board the rich harvest of research on aspects of life in Germany that simply
could not be found in the early work of the post-Fischer years. Furthermore,
it tried to capture this scholarship through the notion of pluralization. Clearly,
over the decades after 1871, the Kaiserreich became a more pluralistic society in all spheres. Looking at life before 1914, it was more differentiated,

Conclusion

dynamic, and colorful than at the beginning. This book contains plenty of evidence of this.
However—and this became a second analytical category—Germany in
my view also became more polarized. While few people would dispute the
pluralization argument, the question of polarization has remained more controversial because it is also linked to another controversy, that is, whether or
not Wilhelmine Germany was in a state of deepening crisis in the years before World War I. I have tried to demonstrate this crisis in all four parts that
make up the account of the pre-1914 period: (1) the economy, which was no
longer in good shape, not least because of its overburdening with armament
expenditures that augmented already large deficits and resulted in major conflicts over taxation; (2) the society, which not only had increasing difficulties
integrating its ethnic minorities but also above all its largest social class, industrial workers; (3) the culture, which mirrored some of the larger societal
tensions and was propelled by the increasing cultural pessimism of its intellectuals and artists, some of whom predicted, and even welcomed, some kind
of cataclysm to overcome the materialism and stuffiness of a bourgeois world;
(4) the political realm, which began to lose its capacity for compromise between
divergent forces, became hopelessly bifurcated, and lapsed into a state of
stagnation and paralysis.
In the Introduction, and also later in Part IV, I referred to those who do not
share this “pessimistic” view of those years.85 Rauh was, possibly, the scholar
who advanced the most “optimistic” counterargument, postulating that Germany was well on its way toward abandoning its autocratic-monarchical political structures and developing a modern representative system. It was only
the world war that disrupted this evolution. More recently, Margaret Anderson
has added her voice by examining how German men, enjoying the universal
suffrage in national elections, were increasingly “practicing democracy.” What,
she asked, “would have happened had there been no war—the war that Germany’s governors, although not solely responsible, did so much to bring
about?”86 She admits that “some kind of ‘jump’ would surely have been necessary to have moved Germany from dualism to a parliamentary regime.” She
then resorts to a counterfactual: “Perhaps the death of the kaiser at age eightythree would have sped a regime change—in 1941—analogous to Spain’s at the
death of Franco at the same age in 1975.”
Although it is true that the war’s outbreak prevents us from knowing for
certain whether the pessimistic or optimistic view of the Wilhelmine period is
the more plausible one, two considerations make me veer to the side of pessimism. First, there is the very tangible mood of pessimism that seized hold
of the Reich government, the still-powerful Conservatives, and the military,
above all Helmuth von Moltke. Although these circles pushed for war in 1914
primarily in order to break the dangerous international situation of the Kaiser297

Conclusion

reich and to act militarily before it was “too late” and the French and Russian rearmament programs would have shifted the balance by 1915/16, hence
nullifying the chances of a German victory at that point. But, even if direct
documentation is lacking, there also seems to have been the realization in
Berlin that a lightning campaign and a swift German victory over the Allies
would tremendously stabilize a troubled monarchy. This would have been the
situation of 1866 when Bismarck, after his defeat of the Austrians, was able
to settle the constitutional crisis of the previous years and to effect a rightwing shift in the Prussian Diet that defeated the Progressives agitating for the
monarchy’s parliamentarization. No doubt, an external success of the German armed forces in 1914 would have enabled the chancellor to reverse the
electoral trend of the previous years. The leftward drift in the elections would
have been stopped, and the power and prestige of the Kaiser greatly boosted.
But we do not have to rely on this particular hypothesis alone to cast doubt
on the “optimistic” view of the German Empire’s development before 1914.
If the crown and the political establishment fought tooth and nail before the
war to block any constitutional reform, and if change could have been brought
about only through a revolutionary upheaval, what is the indirect evidence
that no one in the government or, even more crucially, in the army would have
tolerated attempts to effect a gradual, silent political transformation that, in
their different ways, Rauh and Anderson identify as gradually moving forward? This evidence emerges from the behavior of those same elites during
World War I when they confronted this same question.
The difference was that the pressure of total war and the mobilization of
millions of ordinary men, many of them workers who were giving their lives
for the fatherland, had greatly increased the pressure for reform. Hugenberg
had seen this connection between democratic war mobilization and the demand for an end to political and other discrimination by the mass of the population as early as October 1914.87 He believed then that the pressure could
be deflected by giving “fantasies concerning the extension of German territory room to play,” that is, by promoting war aims and annexationism. But with
no end to the war in sight, the population growing more and more restive, and
imperialism being a divisive issue, some less cynical and less dogmatic politicians began to consider making constitutional concessions and political
promises that would lead to a more parliamentary system and a broader sense
of participation in decision making than had existed under Wilhelm II’s centralized rule as a way of gaining fresh popular support. One of the possible
concessions was to change the unpopular three-class voting system in Prussia and with it the restrictive suffrage laws in the other federal states. Given the
deterioration of both the front and the home front after the battles and deprivations of 1916, Bethmann and other more farsighted people began to think of
such a concession. Reform of the three-class vote, announced in April 1917,
298

Conclusion

was not to be immediately effective, but would follow the victorious end of
the war.88 But so strong was the opposition to this plan that it had to be withdrawn. It also cost Bethmann his job. He was replaced by Georg Michaelis,
a creature of the High Command, who promised not to tolerate such dangerous concessions.
Worse, the conservatives and the military thenceforth escalated their policy of rallying the hard-line nationalists and annexationists and of denouncing
as “Reich enemies” and traitors those pleading for a compromise peace and domestic reforms. To be sure, it was not altogether easy to make large numbers
of demonstrating women and factory workers responsible for the predicament of the Reich. The anti-peace and anti-reformist propaganda could be expected to succeed only if a smaller and identifiable minority could be blamed
for stirring up the opposition to annexations and the monarchy. Although the
agitation of the Pan-Germans, supported from 1917 by the protofascist Fatherland Party,89 also focused on other minorities and the traditional scapegoat,
the Social Democrats, the Jews of Germany now became a major target. Among
the measures taken to fan anti-Semitic resentments was a so-called Judenzählung (survey of Jews).90 Initiated by the army, it was to prove that Jewish men
were proportionally underrepresented in the army in comparison to their Christian comrades and had therefore shirked their duty to serve the fatherland. The
statistics showed the opposite. But instead of publishing the results, the survey was held back, which allowed anti-Semites to spread their lies with even
greater zeal and impunity. By war’s end the most incredible stories were circulating in Germany about the Jews as war profiteers and international wirepullers, as racially inferior parasites and congenital cowards, who were working
hard to engineer a German defeat.91
Now, the portrait that emerges here is one of a country in which those endowed with the constitutional and political powers to initiate reforms adopted
such polarizing strategies to prevent change even though it would have been
wise to grant concessions in this extreme emergency. Thus, is it really plausible to assert that those same forces would have been willing to introduce
political reforms in a prewar situation that looked much less serious to them
and in which they confidently held absolute command of the army as the ultima ratio regum, should constitutional change by attempted by demonstrations escalating into violent upheaval? Given also the wartime experience, it
is therefore more likely that, had war not broken out in 1914, Wilhelmine
Germany would have seen a Staatsstreich, not a peaceful and gradual slide
toward parliamentarism? Parliamentary government was introduced only after
the military knew that the war had been lost. They would never have granted
it without that defeat. Offering it in the summer of 1918 was a cynical move,
for which Ludendorff in his statement gave a revealing reason. Not surprisingly,
he became one of the many protagonists of the “legend of the stab in the back,”
299

Conclusion

which blamed not the Kaiser and his advisors but the German Left, including Ebert, for the war and its unhappy outcome.92 It was a lie that came to be
widely believed after 1918 and imposed a heavy burden on the parliamentarydemocratic Weimar Republic that emerged from the catastrophe of World
War I and the disappearance of the Kaiserreich that Bismarck had so proudly
founded in 1871.
